title: Army Intercepts Missile In ABM Test Over Pacific
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31  The Army has successfully staged an interception of one of its own intercontinental ballistic missiles. The interception, which took place above the atmosphere, tested key elements of the controversia Safeguard antiballistic mis sile system.

title: Oilers Linebacker Sidelined
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) Loyd Wainscott, a linebacker, will miss at least two months while recovering from surgery on his right knee, the Houston Oilers reported today.

title: Tour of Dirty City Planned by Ribicoff With Mayor as Host
description: Mayor Lindsay will give Sen ator Abraham A. Ribicoff of Connecticut a guided tour of the city's sanitation services on Sept. 21.

title: DRUG PLEDGE GETS A MIXED REACTION
description: Reaction ranging from hope ful eagerness to skepticism and even despair was voiced in Harlem yesterday in response to Arthur J. Goldberg's pledge that if elected he would, with in six months after taking of fice, provide treatment for every drug addict seeking it.

title: Wreckage Spotted in India
description: CALCUTTA, India, Aug. 31 (AP)The wreckage of an In dian Airlines Fokker Friend ship aircraft missing since Sat urday with 39 persons aboard was sighted today in northeast Assam State, officials said.

title: Ghana Parliament Elects Former Justice President
description: ACCRA, Ghana, Aug. 31 (Reuters)  Edward Akufo Addo, a 64yearold former Chief Justice, was elected President of Ghana today.

title: Miss Dinah Day Future Bride
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Aug. 31.The engagement of Miss Dinah Hawkins Day to John Weatherbee Tarbell Jr. has been announced by Miss Day's mother, Mrs. Baldus Day of Locust Valley. Mr. Tarbell is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Tarbell of Brockton, Mass. Miss Day is the daugh ter also of John Fisher Day of Syosset. An October wed ding is planned.

title: Vermont College Head Quits
description: LYNDON, Vt., Aug. 31 (AP) Dr. Robert E. Long, president of Lyndon State College, has resigned to become academic vice president of Elmira College in Elmira, N. Y. Dr. Long, who is 54 years old, has been presi dent of Lyndon since 1959.

title: WEBSTER ADMITS TEAM LOOKS BAD
description: BROOICVILLE, L. I., Aug. 31 Coach Alex Webster and his staff have learned a lot from the films of the New York Giants 216 loss to Pittsburgh last Friday night.

title: LINCOLN DOCTORS ASKED TO RETURN
description: Negotiations continued yes terday between the city and the physicians who had walked off their posts in Lincoln Hos pital as pleas were made to them to resume their duties on promises that their security would not be threatened and that medical services in gen eral would improve.

title: Unusual Combination of Dances Closes Philadelphia Folk Fete
description: UPPER SALFORD TOWN SHIP, Pa., Aug. 31An un usual mixture of dancesa Nigerian harvest dance, a Morris dance, jigs, reels and a stool danae from Ghana provided the high points of the final day of the Philadel phia Folk Festival, which drew 27,000 people to Old Pool Farm here over the weekend.

title: Birrell First in Car Race
description: BRANDS HATCH, England, Aug. 31 (AP)Gerry Birrell, a 26yearold Scot, won the in ternational Formula Three auto race today after leading for all but four of the 30 laps. In his Brabham he covered the 79.5 miles in 49 minutes 6 sec onds for an average speed of 97.15 miles an hour.

title: PANTHERS RAIDED IN PHILADELPHIA
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 Heavily armed Philadelphia po lice contingents swooped down on three Black Panther party centers at dawn today.

title: COX TURNS DOWN BROADCAST POST
description: Kenneth A. Cox, whose serv ice as a member of the Federal Communications Commission expires today, has declined an, offer to become president of the National Citizens Committee for Broadcasting. Be will become senior vice president of Micro wave Communications, Inc., and join the Washington law firm of Haley. Bader & Potts.

title: Hanoi Movie of P.O.W.'s Is Shown in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31A North Vietnamese film of Amer ican prisoners of war attending a Christmas church service was shown here today.

title: Clay Dons Gloves Again Tomorrow
description: Cassius Clay will be in the boxing spotlight for the first time in more than three years tomorrow when he steps into the ring for two fourround exhibition bouts.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: Milwaukee Gets Softball
description: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 31 (UPI) The United States Softball Association said today that Milwaukee would be host to the world industrial tournament Sept. 11 to 13.

title: Brooklyn Policeman Wounded By Shot While Answering Call
description: A policeman was shot in the arm by an unknown assailant last night while investigating a report that a man with a shot gun had been seen near Brooklyn yacht club.

title: U.S. Envoy Leaves
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 31 (UPI)  Ambassador Walworth Barbour of the United States flew home today for a vacation and con ferences with Secretary of State William P. Rogers.

title: 2 Tristar Jets on Order By Pacific Southwest Air
description: Pacific Southeast Airlines, the largest intrastate (California) air carrier fin the country, an nounced yesterday it had signed a letter of intent with the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation to purchase two L1011 tristar jetliners, with an option for an additional three planes.

title: Police Accused
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) The National MexicanArnerican can AntiDefamation Commit tee said today that a demon stration in East Los Angeles that resulted in the death of Mr. Salazar was the result of violence precipitated by police abuse of authority.

title: British Boxing Team on Way
description: LONDON, Aug. 31 (UPI) Britain's 11man amateur box ing squad left today for a threematch tour in the United States beginning Friday at Columbus, Ohio.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: To the Editor: It seems to me that the McGovernHatfield approach to getting the United States out of Vietnam is doomed to fail ure due to President Nixon's success in convincing the ma jority of the American pepole that he is ending the war in the only manner consistent with American standards of honor. [Editorial Aug. 31.]

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Nixon Administration made the first public acknowledgment yesterday that the United States was shipping arms to Israel during the current truce in the Mideast. Sec retary of Defense Melvin R. Laird, in a letter to the chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, warned against Con gressional delays on funds for the weapons shipments. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: DART HANOVER JOINS RICH YONKERS TROTS
description: YONKERS, Aug. 31A Swe dish standardbred was named today to the $50,000 Gotham Trot on Sept. 11 and the $50, 000 United Nations Trot Sept. 18 at Yonkers Raceway, as the invitation extended to Dart Hanover was accepted by his owner, Ulf Moberg of Stock holm. With Une de Mai of France already in the field, six berths remain to be filled.

title: 3 SEIZED IN SHOOTING OF A HARLEM PUSHER
description: Three men, who, the police said, shot a pusher of poor quality narcotics on a Harlem street last night were captured, shortly afterward in an ex change of gunfire with police men.

title: 2Man PoliceFoot Patrol Has Little Effect in City
description: The Police Department's new buddy system for evening and night patrols had its first full tryout yesterday and appeared to have only minimal effects.

title: House Panel to Investigate Magazine Sales Efforts
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP)A special House inves tigation was ordered today into alleged deceptive practices by some magazine subscription salesmen.

title: Miners Strike in Chile
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 31 (AP)About 10,000 coal miners walked off the job in a wage dispute today, paralyzing Chile's principal source of domestic fuel. The strike halted opera tions of the Lota Schwager Coal Company in the Province of Concepcidn, 560 miles south of Santiago.

title: Miss Stevenson To Be Married To Navy Officer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Walker W. Stevenson Jr. of Princeton, N. J., and Nantucket, Mass., have announced here the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Sharon Stevenson, to Lieut. (jg.) Charles T. Griffith Jr., U.S.N. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Griffith of Brad ford, Pa.

title: F.A.A. Orders Xray Of Engines of 747's As Result of Blast
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI)A recent explosion and fire in the engine of a Boeing 747 jetliner has prompted a Government order to Xray the engines of the 400passenger jetliners.

title: RCA Consolidates Divisions
description: The RCA Corporation yester day announced a consolidation of its defense and commercial electronics groups, a move aimed at enhancing the com pany's competitive position in the Government and commercial systems markets.

title: Chautauaua Head Resigns
description: JAMESTOWN, N. J., Aug. 31 (AP)Dr. Curtis Haugh an nounced today that he was re signing as president of the Chautauqua Institution, effec tive Oct. 25. Mr. Haugh, head of the cultural center since 1963, will become executive director of the Van Wezel Cen ter for the Performing Arts in Sarasota. Fla.

title: Funds Bill Gains in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP)  The Senate Appropriations Committee approved today a $9.5billion bill to provide funds for the Treasury and Post Office Departments in the current fiscal year, $44.7mil lion more than the House voted. The total in the com mittee's version was 28.6 million less than President Nixon asked for the depart ments.

title: JULIUS GOLDSTEIN, LAWYER, 66, DEAD
description: SILVER SPRING, Md., Aug. 31  Julius L. Goldstein, a prominent New York civil rights lawyer associated with the late Samuel Untermyer in antiNazi activities, died yes terday while visiting members of his family here. He was 66 years old and had lived in New York until his retirement two years ago, when he moved to Miami.

title: Treasury Statement
description: Treasury Statement

title: S. E. C. WILL KEEP SURCHARGE PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31  The Securities and Exchange Commission authorized to day an indefinite continuation of the special brokerage com mission surcharge first im posed in April of this year.

title: Facts on Food Stamps
description: ELIGIBLES: All of the nearly 1.1 million welfare recipi ents who have cooking facilities are automatically eligible. Persons not receiving welfare aid may apply through special food stamp certification offices if family size and net income meet certain limitsfor example, not more than $370 monthly income for a family of four.

title: GUERRILLAS WARN JORDAN'S REGIME
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 31 The main newspaper of the Palestine commandos voiced defiance of King Hussein's Gov ernment today after one of the noisiest nights of skirmishing between commandos and Gov ernment troops that this city has heard.

title: STEEL PRODUCTION ADVANCES IN WEEK
description: Steel production rose 0.2 per cent last week froth the week earlier output, the AmeriCan Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday in Washington.

title: You're RightAugust Was Hotter Than Usual
description: The month that ended yes terday was the hottest Au gust in 15 years in New York City, the Weather Bureau said in its preliminary month ly weather summary, with an average temperature 2.6 de grees above normal, and eight days on which temper atures hit 90 degrees or over.

title: HERMAN KNAUST, BUILT ASHELTER
description: CATSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 31 Herman Knaust, a founder of Knaust Brothers, Inc., and the KB Products Corporation, at one time one of the world's largest growers and canners of mushrooms, died in a hos pital here yesterday after a long illness. He was 75 years old and lived in nearby Cli max and in Safety Harbor, Fla.

title: Danger on the Job
description: Every day men and women go to work and lose their lives or suffer crippling injuries. Every year nearly a halfmillion workers come down with job related illnesses of varying duration and severity. Approximately two million persons suffer from chronic diseases picked up from their work.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: RapidSpilling
description: CHURCHILL LAKE, Me. Girls in bikinis and young men in bathing trunks were negotiating Chase Rapids on the Allagash River with vary ing degrees of success when we launched our two canoes in the pool below Churchill Lake Dam.

title: DR. SAMUEL R. POWERS
description: WEST LAFAYETTE, Ind, Aug. 31Dr. Samuel Ralph Powers, an authority on the teaching of science, died last Wednesday at his home here. He was 83 years old.

title: Trenton Mayor Imposes Curfew After Clash Outside Courtroom
description: TRENTON, Aug. 31Mayor Arthur J. Holland imposed a nighttime curfew here this evening in the wake of a brief courtroom clash this morning between the police and blacks who were identified with the Black Panther party.

title: English Pop Fete Ends in. Bitterness
description: NEWPORT, England, Aug. 31 In a chilly dawn drizzle, the Isle of Wight festival ended somberly today with Richie Havens chanting Hare Krish na and mobs of motorcyclists and other angry youths ripping down iron fences and smashing lights.

title: CORNFELD REGAINS I.O.S. BOARD SEAT
description: PARIS, Aug. 31  Bernard Cornfeld fought his way back today to a place in the man agement of Investors Overseas Services and the mutualfund empire he had built.

title: Executive Changes
description: John W. O'Connor has been named vice presi dent and manager, Metropolitan New York City Department of the Continental Insurance Companies.

title: 10 Poles Defect to Denmark
description: RONNE, Denmark, Aug. 31 (AP)Ten Poles, including two children, fled to this Baltic is land of Bornholm on a trawler today after six of them hid for four hours in an empty oil tank to escape detection at departure from Poland.

title: Impasse on Coffee Export Ends; Quota Is Set at 54 Million Bags
description: LONDON, Aug. 31 (AP) The International Coffee Or ganization agreed early today to a 197071 export quota, end ing a twoday deadlock be tween representatives from consumer and producer nations.

title: Agnew Is Flying Back To See Nixon Day Early
description: HONOLULU, Aug. 31 Vice President Agnew cut short his planned rest stop here today to fly to the West ern White House in San Clemente, Calif.

title: Increasing Demand for Fancy Foods Is Forecast
description: Despite the recession, re tailers and importers appear to be betting that sales of fancy goods, most of which sell for higher prices than staples, will continue to rise.

title: AMEX RISE IS CUT BY PROFIT TAKING
description: The American Stock Ex change just barely managed to post its seventh consecutive gain yesterday as advances out numbered declines by a slight margin in moderate trading.

title: Nixon, in TV Interview, Is Cool to Talk of Mideast Peace Force
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 31President Nixon sought to dissociate himself today from a suggestion put forth by one of his senior officials that the United States is prepared to join the Soyiet Union in a peacekeeping force in the Mid dle East if the crisis there is settled.

title: EUROPEAN STOCKS EDGE DOWN A BIT
description: Prices on most foreign stock exchanges moved downward yesterday In lighttomoderate trading.

title: HOSPITAL SIEGE IN NHATRANG ENDS
description: NHATRANG, South Vietnam Aug. 31 (AP)  A fourday armed siege of a South Viet namese military hospital by a Vietnam Army doctor accused of killing a hospital adminis trator ended today when four armored vehicles blasted their way into the hospital com pound.

title: Market Place:
description: Remember the chaotic sec ond quarter on Wall Street, when the market averages were falling off the charts and visions of financial Arma geddon were carving new lines in financiers faces?

title: SOUTH PEACEFUL AS MANY SCHOOLS ARE INTEGRATED
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 31Most of the children of the South quiet ly returned to school today, many to newly integrated class rooms, in what the Nixon Ad ministration has characterized as a last, sweeping assault in a battle joined 16 years ago.

title: Princeton Gets Fusion Grant
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 31 Public Service Electric and Gas Company of Newark announced today a $50,000 grant to Prince ton University to support re search of hydrogen fusion as a potential source for electric power. Fusion is the principle used in exploding the hydrogen bomb. Atomic power plants now in operation use the fission principle that produces the atomic bomb.

title: NEUTRALITY URGED IN GOVERNOR RACE
description: Victor Gotbaum, one of the union leaders supporting Ar thur J. Goldberg for Governor, said yesterday that he would urge delegates to the state A.F.L.C.I.O. convention, open ing tomorrow at Kiamesha Lake, to refrain from making an endorsement do the guber natorial race.

title: U.S. COURT DENIES EXTRADITION CURB
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 31 (UPI)The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit turned down today a request to stop the extradition of Charles D. (Tex) Watson of the hippie family of Charles M. Manson, accused of killing Sharon Tate, the actress, and six others.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: Mr. Agnew Shows the Flag
description: In recent decades Vice Presidential travel abroad has often been the diplomatic equivalent of showing the flag. It has served to reassert American interest in a threatened area or to reassure client states at a nervous moment. But sometimes its purposes have been much more political than diplomatic.

title: CLUB IS EXPECTED TO SETTLE DOWN
description: When the New York Jets re sume their exhibition schedule against the Saints in New Or leans on Saturday night, Joe Namath will be their starting quarterback.

title: Police Say Wealthy Roman Killed Wife, Lover, Himself
description: ROME, Aug. 31 (AP)  A wealthy Roman marquis shot and killed his wife, her young lover and himself, the police said today.

title: MINE INSPECTORS RESTRICTED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 The Bureau of Mines acknowl edged today that it had been requiring its safety inspectors to obtain telephoned authority from Washington before exer cising a key enforcement pro vision of the new Federal coal mine safety law, which has come under attack by the min ing industry.

title: Red Sox Ace Snaps Tie
description: BOSTON, Aug. 31 (AP)Ray Culp drove in the tiebreaking run with a sixthinning single and posted his 14th victory to night as the Boston Red Sox defeated the Detroit Tigers, 42.

title: Cotton Market
description: Cotton Market

title: High Court to Speed Ruling on Busing
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 The Supreme Court announced today that it would make a broad test of school desegre gation measures the first order of business when the new Court term begins.

title: Credit Markets: Reaction Is Awaited to 8.65%. Yields Set on Debentures
description: The corporate bond market will discover today how much investment appeal there is in a yield of 8.65 per cent.The $175million issue of Aaarated New England Tele phone and Telegraph Company 39year debentures scheduled for sale this morning will yield 8.65 per cent.

title: Goldberg Flies to Chicago Today To Ask Campaign Contributions
description: Still having difficulty raising campaign funds in his adopted home town, Arthur J. Goldberg is flying to Chicago, his former home town, today, to seek out ofstate contributions to his campaign for Governor.

title: VOTE ON WAR CURB IS PLANNED TODAY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 The Senate lumbered through five hours of debate today on its amendment to end the war, preparing to vote on it tomorrow and then go home for a week.

title: Cholera Warning to Travelers
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) The Government today ad vised americans going to South east or Southern Asia, the Middle East and Northeast Africa to get a second anti cholera shot in view of the disease's growing threat in those areas.

title: Advertising: New Chief at Business Press
description: Charles S. Mill, who headed the selection committee that selected him president of American Business Press, starts his new job today.

title: City Will Distribute 3,000 Wire Baskets In All 5 Boroughs
description: The distribution of 3,000 new wiremesh litter baskets throughout the city's five bor oughs will begin tomorrow morning, the Sanitation De partment announced yesterday.

title: In Memoriam
description: BLYNNathan. In memory of my beloved husband, September 1, 1922. AMY.

title: RapidAmerican Seeks to Acquire The Dunes Hotel
description: The RapidAmerican Corpo ration, one of the largest con glomerates, is negotiating to acquire the Dunes Hotel, one of Las Vegas's oldest and larg est hotel casinos, it was report ed here yesterday.

title: PRICE RIGGING LAID TO JAPANESE FIRMS
description: TOKYO, Aug. 31 (AP)  The Tokyo Stock Exchange today said it was investigating a complaint that the country's four largest securities firms manipulated the share price of the Matsushita Electric Indus trial Company.

title: Buddhist Slate Appears to Win 10 Seats in Saigon Senate Race
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 31  AntiGovernment Buddhists appeared today to have won 10 of the 30 Senate seats contested in yesterday's election.

title: Phillies Get Pitcher
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 31 (AP) Bob Browning, a pitcher will go to the Philadelphia Phillies to complete a deal involving Curt Flood, the St. Louis Cardinals said today. The 18yearold righthander has been on the disabled list with a broken col larbone since July 15.

title: Trial Delayed Again
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 31 Marison's murder trial was in terrupted again today when one of his three young women co defendants continued to com plain of illness.

title: Books of The Times
description: From the leftover records of an aban doned boat, from careful pursuit of other clues, two British newspapermen, Nicholas Tomalin and Ron Hall, have come up with a weird but completely convincing sea tale that (as the title indicates) will surely stand as one of the strangest chronicles of the sea. It is a tale of a great defeat that is a kind of tri umph, of a great fraud that is trans muted into truth, of a dangerous ocean cruise that is really a voyage through the shoals and hazards of ex istence. To dream away one's fancies in regret or resent ment can be a waste of life, but to be able to act on those fancies can be even worse, as this moving chronicle makes clear. Donald Crow hurst's imagina

title: DR. FRANCIS J. CRONIN
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., Aug. 31 Dr. Francis J. Cronin, a former member of the Elizabeth City Council, died yesterday, appar ently of a heart attack, visiting a son in Stamford, Conn. He was 62 years old and lived at 737 Westminster Avenue.

title: Drop in State Traffic Deaths
description: ALBANY, Aug. 31 (UPI) Traffic fatalities for the first six months of this year ran well below those for the corre sponding period last year, the State Department of Motor Ve hicles reported today. High way deaths totaled 1,363, com pared with 1,478 a year ear lier.

title: Diane Gillman of Duke Faculty Is Married to James Charney
description: TUXEDO, N.Y., Aug. 31 Miss Diane Joy Gillman and James Charney were married here this evening in the Rose Garden of the Sterling Forest Gardens. The ceremony was performed before 300 guests by Rabbi Robert Port of Mid dletown. He was assisted by Rabbi Moshe Goldblum.

title: Business Records
description: HENRY A. D'ARENZIO, cargo agent, 14415 107th Ave., Richmond Hill, Queens. Liabili ties, $8,975; assets, $200.

title: War Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) The Defense Department to clay listed the names of the fol lowing servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Southeast Asia:

title: Football Transactions
description: Football Transactions

title: Bishop Walsh Greeted on Return to U.S,
description: Gaunt and shaky after 12 years in jail in China, the Most Rev. James E. Walsh returned to the United States last night and said that his heart is still in China.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Article 3  No Title

title: Women's Lib Invades Boxing For Place in Fighter's Corner
description: The women's liberation movement, which has put Pat Palinkas into football, jockeys in thoroughbred racing and grooms in harness racing, came to boxing yesterday.

title: Carol Mann Poised For Tee Time Today
description: GROSSINGER, N. Y., Aug. 31  Carol Mann, a 6foot 3inch athlete will stroke a golf ball for women's liber ation when she meets Doug Sanders for a purse of $2,500 over the Grossinger Country Club course tomorrow.

title: Insurance Companies Elect
description: Nationwide Insurance Com panies said yesterday that J. Christy Beall, senior, vice presi dent in charge of investments, had retired after 33 years, ef fective Sept. 1. He will be suc ceeded by Robert Rennie, re search vice president, who be comes vice president in charge of investments.

title: Spanish Theater Seeking a Foothold
description: The other day, Frank Ro bles locked the door of the furniture store he manages and hurried to the subway. He was on his way to the theaterto rehearse for three strenuous hours.

title: Roosevelt Aides Dispute Lindbergh's View on War
description: James MacGregor Burns, a leading scholar of the Adminis tration of Franklin D. Roosevel disagreed yesterday with Charles A. Lindbergh's contentions that the United States had lost World War II and had been led, into the war by the Adminis tration, proBritish elements and the Jews.

title: Uniroyal Line Moving To Minneapolis Agency
description: Can a monster created in New York find true happiness in Minneapolis?

title: Job Bank Is Planned to Aid Long Island.
description: MINEOLA, L. L, Aug. 31 Senator Charles E. Goodell an nounced at a hearing here today on unemployment on Long Island that preliminary steps were being taken to establish a computerized job bank for Nassau and Suffolk Counties, similar to ones in operation in Syracuse and Buffalo.

title: Allies Report a Drop in Activity By the Enemy in South Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 31 (Reuters)War activity in South Vietnam fell off today after a surge yesterday coin ciding with the voting for 30 senators.

title: ALTERNATE CASTS IMPRESS IN AGON
description: A bright or witty thought tersely expressed or a short poem treating concisely and pointedly of a single thought or event. Those descriptions have been borrowed from the well known dance critic, Noah Web ster. While they are definitions of the word epigram they could apply to the individual sections in Agon.

title: MURTAGH REJECTS PANTHER MOTIONS
description: A ruling yesterday will per mit the prosecution to intro duce alleged confessions in the trial of 13 Black Panthers charged here with conspiracy, arson and attempted murder.

title: Bucs Moving to Memphis Under a New Ownership
description: MEMPHIS, Tenn., Aug. 31 The New Orleans Buccaneers, who changed their name to the Louisiana Bucs during the off season, will be sold to P. L. Blake, a wealthy real estate dealer from Greenwood. Miss.

title: TV Ban Eased by. Mitchell For Deportation Hearings
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) Attorney General John N. Mitchell has ruled that televi sion newsmen cannot be barred from condors surounding de portation hearings, although they cannot televise the hear ings.

title: L.I.R. Gets Court Order Barring Union's SickIn
description: The Long Island Railroad late yesterday afternoon obtained a temporary restraining order in Federal District Court in Brooklyn, barring a sickin by the majority of its switchmen.

title: ExCrime Leader Sentenced
description: PROVIDENCE R. I., Aug. 31 (AP)  Raymond L. S. Patri arca was sentenced today to the maximum of 10 years in prison for conspiracy to mur der Rudolph Marfeo in a small grocery store here two years ago. Judge James C. Bulman of Superior Court said the sentence given Patriarca, identified by the authorities as once head of organized crime in southern New England, would run con currently with the fiveyear term he is serving in the Fed eral prison for conspiring to murder Willie Marfeo, Ru dolph's brother in 1966.

title: White House Reported Aware Of Retreat by Rogers on Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 A State Department decision to yield to Senator Barry Gold water and cancel the appoint ment of a press officer was reported today to have been made with the knowledge and apparently the approval of the White House.

title: MATTEAWAN MAN GIVEN TRANSFER
description: A Federal judge, describing Matteawan State Hospital for the criminally insane in Beacon, N.Y., as a place more likely to drive men mad than to cure the insane, has ordered the transfer of an 86yearold man who has been there since 1951.Judge Marvin E. Frankel granted the request of Alfred Curt von Wolfersdorf, who was judged insane and unable to stand trial on a 1951 murder kidnapping indictment. He has been confined at the hospital since then.

title: Now, Food Stamps
description: To begin the distribution of food stamps to the poor and nearpoor, as New York City did yesterday, is to enter the Model A stage of assuring national nutritional adequacy. It is an improvement over the Model T, but there is still a long way to go to get a really effective program on the road.

title: CITY ABORTION TOTAL IS 11,200 SINCE JULY
description: New York City hospitals per formed more than 11,200 abor tions between July 1, when the state's liberalized abortion law went into effect, and Aug. 22, the Health and Hospitals Corpo ration said yesterday.

title: 50FootLong Banner Just a Birthday Card
description: The 50footlong red ban ner hanging from the 86th floor of the Empire State Building yesterday afternoon, the one that said Jack in large letters, was just a sort of oversized birthday card.

title: Bridge
description: A team of four Los An geles players headed by Lew Mathe became candidates to represent North America in the 1971 world championship by winning a qualifying match in Phoenix, Ariz., yesterday.

title: MRS. GEORGE E. INGHAM
description: NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 31 Mrs. Eva B. Ingham, first woman probation officer of the Juvenile Court of Fairfield County, died yesterday in Bloomfield Convalescent Home. She was 84 years, old, and had lived in this city for many years.

title: LFC Financial Holds Talks on Merger
description: The LFC Financial Corpora tion has been holding ex ploratory merger negotiationi for several months with quite a few other companies, according to George A. Ed wards, president of the trou bled Los Angelesbased savings and loan holding company.

title: PROFIT TAKERS HIT FUTURES TRADING
description: After advancing sharply early in the session, soybeans and corn futures dipped markedly on profit taking yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: 650 More British Soldiers To Leave Northern Ireland
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 31 (UPI)The British Army announced today that it would withdraw 650 more soldiers from Northern Ireland.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Entertainment Events

title: CHANGES LISTED BY PHILHARMONIC
description: Gregor Piatigorsky, the cell ist, and four conductorsAldo Ceccato, Dean Dixon, Milton Katims and Robert Shaw have been added to the roster of artists who will appear with the New York Philharmonic this season.

title: RATIONING URGED FOR OIL AND COAL
description: Citing a critical national shortage of fuels and rapidly escalating prices, the Ameri can Public Power Association urged President Nixon yester day to impose rationing and price controls on fuel oil and coal.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Shipping/Mails

title: Guerrillas and Guard Units Exchange Fire in Uruguay
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 31 (UPI)Men believed to be members of the Tupamaro guerrilla movement opened fire from a speeding car on an army training school in down town Montevideo today and security guards returned the fire. No one was reported wounded.

title: BENSON STORFER
description: BOSTON, Aug. 31Benson Storfer, former president of Parfums Corday, Inc., and Stor fer Imports, Inc., importers of perfume, died yesterday in New England Baptist Hospital here. He was 81 years old and lived at 9 Rock Hill Lane in Scarsdale, N. Y., and in Sara sota, Fla.

title: The Proceedings in the U.N. Today
description: Special Committee on Co lonialism10:30 A.M.; sub committee on Pacific terri toriesImmediately after.

title: BELL DEVELOPING A POCKET LASER
description: Scientists at the Bell Tele phone Laboratories have de veloped what they expect will be a lowcost, pocketsize, re liable and versatile infraed layer the first such device that may be practical for use in com munications systems.

title: Malaysians Celebrate
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Aug. 31 (Reuters)Malaysians turned out today for rallies and parades to celebrate the 13th anniversary of their independ ence. Prime Minister Abdul Rah man said last night that a ban on political activity would be lifted and parliament recon vened. He also announced he would step down Sept. 21.

title: Dr. Everett D. Hawkins, 64, Professor at Wisconsin
description: SOUTHBRIDGE, Mass., Aug 31  Dr. Everett D. Hawkins, Professor of Economics at the University of Wisconsin, Madi son, died in Southbridge Hos pital today after a brief illness. He was 64 years old.

title: U.S.INQUIRY URGED FOR A RIOT VICTIM
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 31  Angry leaders of the Mexican American community called for a Federal investigation today into the death Saturday of Ruben Salazar, a columnist for The Los Angeles Times and news director for a Spanish language television station.

title: Overseas Weekly's Editor Forced Out
description: BONN, Aug. 31The long time annoyance of senior offi cers of the United States Army with one of its major gadflies, The Overseas Weekly, has led to the forced resignation of its editor. Curtis Daniell.

title: Now I Know for Sure We Are Going to Eat
description: Mrs. Phyllis Delaney usually spends about $60 a month to feed herself, her two sons, her niece and her niece's baby. When she spends more, it means she has to cut back on something important.

title: Sears Earnings Up 6.6% In 2d Quarter
description: Sears, Roebuck & Co., the country's largest merchadis ing company, reported profit gains yesterday for the second fiscal quarter and first half, in sharp contrast to an earn ings downtrend reported last week by four other major re tail chains.

title: Signs of Impatience on U.S. Response Grow in Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM. Aug. 31Is rael told the United Nations Truce Supervisory Organization today that her reconnaissance had detected evidence of fur ther deployment of missiles and construction of new launching sites along the entire length of the Egyptianheld bank of the Suez Canal.

title: MRS. HARRY B. EPSTEIN
description: UNION, N. J., Aug, 31Mrs. Rose Negbaur Epstein, widow of Dr. Harry B. Epstein, a physician, died in a nursing home here yesterday. She had lived until recently in East Or ange.

title: L.I. PARTIES TRADE CHARGES OF FRAUD
description: SMITHTOWN, L. I., Aug. 31 The chairman of this town's Republican and Democratic committees exchanged charges today of fraud and forgery in connection with nominating petitions filed by candidates for the Fourth State Assem bly District seat.

title: EXTREMISTS ROLE DENIED BY O'BRIEN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 Lawrence O'Brien, Democratic party chairman, said today that extremists who called themselves Democrats were a tiny but vocal minority who did not speak for the party.

title: ROLE OF KENNEDY IN 1961 ASSESSED
description: WALTHAM, Mass. Aug. 31 President John F. Kennedy's conduct at his 1961 summit meeting with Nikitas Khrush chev has been depicted by George F. Kerman as that of a tonguetied young man, not forceful, with no ideas of his own.

title: Ta Wee Triumphs by a Neck as Racing Returns to Belmont

title: 68 Columbia Candidates Report to Football Camp
description: LAKESIDE Conn. Aug. 31 Columbia's football coach, Frank Navarro, and his staff greeted 68 candidates, includ ing 20 letter men, at the open ing of Columbia's preseason training camp today.

title: LANDRY STANDOUT AS LIONS TRIUMPH
description: DETROIT, Aug. 31 (AP) Greg Landry threw two long touchdown passes and scored on a 33yard run as the De troit Lions. crushed the Phila delphia Eagles, 317, in a Na tional Football League presea son game tonight.

title: Sociologist Assails Use of Colleges as Battleground
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 The president of the American Sociological Association, Dr. Reinhard Bendix of the Univer sity of California, criticized politicians and protesters alike today for turning the nation's universities into convenient battlegrounds.

title: Police Say Man Chopped 18 Holes in Jet
description: MIAMI, Aug. 31 (AP)  A man who the police say blamed Eastern Airlines for the death of his champion Irish wolf hound walked up to an East ern jet today and chopped 18 holes in its underbelly with an ax, airport officers said.

title: Lily Darvas Gets Part
description: Lily Darvas has been signed for a feature role in Les Blancs, the late Lorraine Hansberry's new drama, which opens Oct. 20 at the Longacre Theater. The play, which stars James Earl Jones, will be di rected by Sidney Walters.

title: 5 UNEARNED RUNS SCORE ON MISCUES
description: Winning makes for fun, which means the Baltimore Orioles have a lot of fun be cause they win a lot. And no one among the Orioles has more fun than Earl Weaver, their impish manager, especial ly when he's creating playful ideas such as game plans.

title: NEWARK POLICE GET ANTIITALIAN MAIL
description: NEWARK, Aug 31Police Director John L Redden or dered an intensive investiga tion today into obscene letters and hate mail that has been sent to the homes of policemen of Italian descent.

title: U.S. FIVE TRIUMPHS OVER BRAZIL, 8575
description: TURIN, Italy, Aug. 31 (AP) The United States won its sec ond straight game in the final round of the basketball tourna ment at the World University Games today and strengthened its chances for a gold medal.

title: 4 Yonkers Buildings Burn
description: YONKERS, Aug. 31A fire swept through four small apart ment houses on Van Cortlandt Avenue near Spruce Street here tonight. No one was injured, although two residents with a history of heart trouble were taken to hospitals for observa tion. Fire equipment from Mount Vernon and New York was called in to assist Yonkers firemen battling the blaze.

title: RIGGS 3SET VICTOR IN SENIOR GRASS NET

title: Paul Horgan, at 64, Displays Literary Versatility
description: Paul Horgan, the Pulitzer Prize man of letters whose September novel, White water has already made him a man of $250,000, is mark ing the start of his 64th year with a display of literary versatility.

title: South Jersey Judge Orders Prompt Arraignment of Migrants
description: BRIDGETON, N. J., Aug. 31 Local courts in many south ern New Jersey farming com munities have been directed to arraign every jailed migrant farm worker before a judge or a magistrate within 24 hours of arrest, even if it means con ducting extraordinary court sessions.

title: EARNINGS LIFTED BY NORTHWEST AIR
description: Northwest Airlines, Inc., which is seeking to acquire Northeast Airlines, Inc., yester day reported increased earn ings and revenues for the sec ond quarter and first half of this year.

Dr. Henry A. Schroeder, di rector of the Trace Element Laboratory of Dartmouth Med ical School, told a Senate sub committee and said in an inter view in his laboratory here that, in pollution and food proc essing, science and the public had hit on the major killers.

Mulvey being in troduced recently to two Pan ther leaders. Huey P. Newtonand David Hil Man Hard. The ta 11, in the courtly judge smiled affably, as News if he were on a reception line of the Knights of Columbus the most militant organiza tion to which he has ever belonged. I believe I know Mr. Hilliard, he said, shaking hands.

Now Bill Blass, who designs both men's and women's clothes as well as watches, furs and stockings, is about to start his own men's toiletry Brie. The Grooming Gear (the industry cringes at the word cosmetics for men) being manufactured by Revlon. The company said that the Hoosierborn de signer plotted most of the line himself, from the blue and silver packaging to the type of products and their Scent.

Olsen to a post as director of the department's office of press relations.

description: BUFFALO, Aug. 31 (AP)A City Court judge dismissed a criminal anarchy charge against the vender of a Black Panther newspaper today on the ground of insufficient evidence.

description: NEWARK, Del., Aug. 31 Jim Colbert of Levittown, Pa., wanted to be a Penn State quarterback following an im pressive career in high school. He went to the Nittany Lions den three years ago, where there were enough former high school quarterbacks to stock several teams.

title: DEFENSE SPENDING EASED IN QUARTER
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) The impact of military spending on the nation's economy de clined to the lowest point since 1966 in the second quarter of this year, the Commerce De partment reported today.

description: ORENSThe family of Or. Sidney R. Orens wish to thank their relatives and many friends for their kind expressions of sym pathy.

title: Film: 'The Things of Life':Sautet Presents a Man Many Would Envy
description: It sounds so much more special in French, but "Les Choses de la Vie" translates accurately enough into "The Things of Life," which is the title given to Claude Sautet's movie for its American opening, yesterday, at the Fine Arts Theater.The life belongs to a Parisian architect (Michel Piccoli), and as the movie begins, it has been placed in precarious balance by a fairly spectacular automobile accident on the road to Rennes. The things include a lovely wife (Lea Massari, whom most will remember as the girl who disappears in "L'Avventura"), a charming mistress (Romy Schneider), an intelligent and sympathetic son (Gerard Lartigau), an excellent apartment, a country house, a delightful little cruising sloop, and a speedy sports carwhich does not last.Of course, nothing lasts. The architect has left his wife, sort of, and she now has a lover of her own. He is not really committed to his mistress, and she has a serious suitor. The son is in business for himself (a curious cottage industry, which he runs from his own room, manufacturing complex but useless electronic gadgets). The country place needs new shutters. The boat may not be launched this year. And all this filters through the mind of the architect, who himself lies dying in the midst of a life that is rich in associations and heavy with the music (piano and orchestramostly strings) of bitter-sweet memories.The memories and the associations are the real reason for "The Things of Life." Although the accident generates some excitement and, in various slow-motion cuts and snippets, provides a lot of footage (making the film look in places like a sentimental "Weekend"), nevertheless its tensions and its ironies both give way before the pressures of profession, wife, mistress, boat, etc., in which we can only feel it would be a privilege to share.For in its own moderately sophisticated way, "The Things of Life," like the type of women's magazine fiction to which it essentially belongs, depends upon a kind of envious recognition value for audience approval.Thus, in spite of his employer's the architect insists on "gardens, not garages" to surround his apartment development  and we know he's a right kind of guy at the same time that we wish, we had such a simple and courageous decision to make. And how nice it would be if we were burdened with the question of the shutters on the country place, or whether to make bed with Romy Schneider (plus distinguished parties, excellent lunches, etc.) a really permanent affair.I should mind this syrup less if Sautet showed more of a conscience in serving itif the relationships seemed to have been felt rather than merely displayed; if the sailboat (a most important image) were not always under power with sails flapping: if you couldn't see the crash helmet on the stuntman in the automobile accident; if Poccoli actually took a mansized bite of those superior restaurant meals.However, Piccoli is the only reasonable point of interest in "The Things of Life." Like everyone else in the cast, he is distinguished and a bit moody, and like everyone else in the cast, he makes a major stage business of perpetually smoking cigaretes as if there were no lung cancer. But although he is not especially well directed here, he brings to many individual scenes a sufficiently detailed sense of himself and of his situation almost to cover the succession of clichs out of which he must construct a characterization. He is better than his movie, and he remains one of the real lights of current French cimema.

title: A.T. & T. PLANNING DIGITAL NETWORK
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company plans to have a privateline digital data network operating in late 1973 or early 1974, W. M. Elling haus, executive vice president, said here yesterday.Speaking before about 200 participants in a threeday con ference on The Revolution in Transmission of Business Infor mation, Mr. Ellinghaus, whc will become president of the New York Telephone Compa ny today, predicted that by 1980 data communications would account for roughly $2 billion of our revenues. He said that the total at present is about $450million.

title: COMPROMISE SET IN SEABED TREATY
description: GENEVA, Aug. 31  The United States and the Soviet Union, which have been work ing on a draft treaty to pro hibit the emplacement of nu clear weapons on the ocean floor, have agreed that coun tries that sign should be al lowed to ask United Nations help in checking for violations.

title: Southampton's Polish Families: The Heritage Remains Strong
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I.The delicatessen with the herring and the pickle barrels has disappeared, Pulaski Hall has become almost a village meeting place, the family unit isn't as tightly knit as it once was, and few of the younger generation speak their ancestral tongue. But the Polish community here has not assimilated with the group they still call Yankees; it has merely blended.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The fate of the New York Mets remains far from settled, and the football season (exhibition games aside) has not even begun, but a new basketball season is sneaking up on us already. Within 10 day s, the world champion New York Knickerbockers will be in training camp; in three weeks, exhibition games will be under way, and the regular National Bas ketball Association season will start on Oct. 13, while the baseball World Series is still on.

title: JOHN C. CRAWLEY, 78, OF LAW FIRM HERE
description: MANHASSET, L. I., Aug. 31 John C. Crawley, a former partner in the New York law firm of Thacher, Proffitt, Pri zer, Crawley & Wood, died at North Shore Hospital today. He was 78 years old and lived in Port Washington.

title: MRS. GENE FOWLER
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., Aug. 31 (AP)Mrs. Agnes Fowler, widow of Gene Fowler, the author, died Friday at her home in Encino from injuries suffered in an automobile accident six months ago. She was 80 years old.

title: Central Park Festival Presents Louis and Black Dance Troupes
description: The Black Dance Union and the Murray Louis Dance Com pany appeared at the New York Dance Festival for the first time Sunday evening in Central Park's Delacorte Theater. The rain held off long enough for the Black Dance Union to close the program with Where To Go? a jazz dance by Morton Winston. Mr. Winston also chor eographed The Bell Dance, the company's opener. In both pieces he showed an awareness of dance designs and a feeling for percussive movement within their simple confines. The company, made up of one girl and four men, is dynamically alive and generates a high visual energy level. Eli nor McCoy, who appeared only in Where To Go? has a won derfully supple style of move ment, which she played off skillfully against the driving energy of the men, Winston Hemsly, Ronald Dunham, Mi chael Peters and Mr. Winston.

title: Sad Smiles of Alaskan Eskimos Speak of the Joy and Harshness of Their Land
description: GOLOVIN, AlaskaNoth ing much happens in Golovin. But then, nothing much ever did.

title: White Rouse Comment
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 31 (AP) At the Western White House the Presidential press secretary, Ronald L. Ziegler, said Mr. Nix on regarded Mr. Salazar's death as a very tragic thing.

title: Observer: Like Days of Old
description: LONDON, Aug. 31Can any one remember what August used to be like in America be fore the Thirty Years War? Be fore the era of the Long Hot Summer? Before revolution be came chic and rage became all the rage? No? Perhaps this summary of the news that ab sorbed Britain during the August now ending may help revive memories of those pas toral days and remind us that life among the Englishspeaking peoples need not necessarily be waged constantly at the brink of desperation.

title: Nuptials for Joan Brewster Garver
description: Miss Joan Brewster Garver, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chauncey B. Garver of Oyster Bay, L. I., was married in Juarez, Mexico, last Thurs day to John Daniel Downey, a chemical engineer she met on vacation in Aruba. He was with the Parsons Construc tion Company there. The cou ple are honeymooning in Ber muda.
