description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 31 (AP) Arthur Ashe, hobbled by an old heel injury, fought back from match point in the fourth set today and beat Christian Kuhnke, 68, 1012, 97, 1311, 64, to complete a 50 sweep of West Germany in the Davis Cup tennis challenge round to day.

title: Byers A. Burlingame Dies at 70; Former Studebaker President
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Aug. 31 (AP)Byers A. Burlingame, former president of the Stude baker Corporation, died yester day while vacationing at the family cottage at Rondeau Park, Ontario. He was 70 years old.

title: Utility Maps 197074 Outlay
description: BOSTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) The Public Service Company of New Hampshire said today it plans capital expenditures of $172,266,000 for the 197074 period, with $36,009,000 to be spent this year. An estimated $117,525,000 will be raised for longterm debt, sales of pre ferred and common stock, and shortterm loans. The rest will be generated internally, the company said.

title: McLucas Guilty of Plotting In Panther Murder Case
description: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 31A jury of 10 whites and two blacks convicted Lonnie Mc Lucas today of conspiracy to murder for his role in the Alex Rackley slaying, but they ac quitted him on three other charges that carried heavier penalties.

title: BLACK EDUCATOR GETS TOP D.C. POST
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31A young, black Detroit educator was chosen tonight Superin tendent of Schools by the Dis trict of Columbia Board of Edu cation. He would become the first Negro school superintend ent of a major city.

title: Jarring and Egyptian Mee
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 31Dr. Gunnar V. Jar ring conferred today with Dr. Mohammed H. elZayyat of the United Arab Republic though other leaders in the peace talks are absent.

title: Court Lifts Garden City Bar to DayCare Center
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 31 A State Supreme Court justice here today swept aside the ob jections of the village of Gar den City to the establishment of a daycare center for wel fare children in a Unitarian Universalist church.

title: Graham Getting Checkup
description: ROCHESTER, Minn., Aug. 31 (AP)The Rev. Billy Graham, the evangelist, entered Mayo Clinic today for a periodic medical examination.

title: GEORGE STEGERWALD
description: NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 31 George Stegerwald, retired vice president of the Hat Corpora tion of America, died yesterday in Norwalk Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 6 Harbor View Avenue.

title: Howard Clouts No. 38
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) Frank Howard belted a home run with a man on in the fifth inning tonight to tie Harmon Killebrew for the American League lead with 38 as the Washington Senators defeated the Cleveland Indians, 54.

title: Newsprint Consumption Off 1.1% in July, 1.6% in 1970
description: Newsprint consumption in the nation this July was 721, 267 tons, down 1.1 per cent from 729,149 tons in July, 1969, the American Newspaper Publishers Association reported yesterday.

title: A Versatile Ingredient for Casseroles
description: Locally grown zucchini, or courgettes as they are called in France and Britain, are one of the most versatile and delectable of summer vege tables. Here are three cas serole dishes based on zuc chini that can be put together hours ahead and baked at the last minute.

title: Storm Strikes Toronto
description: TORONTO, Aug. 31 (UPI) A thunderstorm struck Toronto with winds up to 50 miles an hpur last night, causing thou sands of dollars in property damage. There were no reports, of deaths or serious injuries.

title: Bill Rates Register an Advance At Treasury's Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31  treasury bill rates advanced at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.

title: Cab Drivers Are Promised Greater Police Protection
description: Taxi fleet owners said yes terday that they had been as sured by city officials that the activities of the police taxi sur veillance unit would be in creased in an effort to cut crimes against taxi drivers.

title: LATONIA SEEKING 72 HAMBLETONIAN
description: DU QUOIN, Ill., Aug. 31 This friendly, though arid area of corn, wheat, soybeans, strip coal mines and harness horses was hit briefly but hard by thunder, lightning and a fright ening rain storm early this morning.

title: SelfDescribed Defector Back in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31A young marine from West Baby lon, who declared in Stock holm last week that he was a defector, was returned to New York today, the Defense Department announced.

title: Largest Drop Since 48
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI)  Declining prices for hogs, cattle, potatoes and eggs the month ended Aug. 15 sent national average farm Agriculture down 3 per cent, the Agriculture Department re ported today.

title: LEFKOWITZ URGES SCHOOL BUS SAFETY
description: The reinspection of all school buses and installation of seat belts before classes start next week was advocated yes terday by Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz.

title: Caution: School Bus
description: Whatever the disagreement on some aspects of school busing, there can be no disagreement at all on one aspect: The bus itself must be mechanically per fect. So it comes as another safety shock to learn that dangerous buses will be carrying millions of children to school this year.

title: U.S SENDING ARMS TO ISRAEL TO KEEP MIDEAST BALANCE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 The Nixon Administration re ported today that the United States was shipping weapons to Israel during the current ceasefire so that the arms balance does not tip against Israel.

title: Indonesian Rebels Kill Dutch Policeman in Storming Embassy in The Hague
description: THE HAGUE, Aug. 31 (AP) A band of Indonesian rebels took over Indonesia's Embassy today after killing a Dutch po liceman and threatening a group of hostages, but they sur rendered hours later and were taken to jail.

title: EXPERT DEFENDS INTEGRATION FOES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1An urban expert noted for his integrationist views defended today white middle class Amer ica's economic reasons for re sisting housing integration.MeMDerS or minority groups have every right to enter de sirable neighborhoods, and discriminating against them for racial reasons is immoral and illegal, the expert, Anthony Downs, told the Senate Com mittee on Equal Educational Opportunity. But integration cannot be achieved, he said, until the nation recognizes that white resistance is often highly rational and not merely the result of foolish prejudices or immoral selfishness.

title: PHILIP MURPHY, 62, BUILDER OF BRIDGES
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 1 J. Philip Murphy, who directed the construction of many ma jor bridges in the West; died on Sunday while on a business trip in Columbia, S. C. He was 62 years old.

title: Moody's Is Blocked On FundSale Plan
description: Moody's Investors Service, the investment counseling and information subsidiary of Dun & Bradstreet, Inc., has en countered a significant road block to its plan to sell its right to manage the $30million Moody's Capital Fund to Vance, Sanders & Co., Inc., a big Bos tonbased mutual fund manage ment and distribution concern.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 2, 1970

title: G.M. Calls In 4,400 Trucks For Bolt Safety Inspection
description: DETROIT, Sept. 1 (UPI)  General Motors Corporation asked the owners of 4,400 light trucks today to return them to their dealers for inspection and possible replacement of bolts that could cause the driver to lose control if they broke.

title: Miss Victoria Schofield Plans Bridal
description: The engagement of Miss Victoria Smith Schofield to Thomas John Arkins, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Arkins of Garden City, L. I., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William H. Schofield of New York and Jaffrey Center, N H.

title: Plumbers Strike in Boston
description: BOSTON, Sept. 1 (AP)About 3,000 plumbers and pipefitters in the Greater Boston area went on strike today virtually halting all building construction in the area. Contracts for both unions expired at midnight on Mon day.

title: AGNEW TO ASSIST KENTUCKY LIBERAL
description: LOUISVILLERepresentative William O. Cowger, a Republi can who built a liberal political coalition here, is turning to an unlikely quarter for help in winning reelection to a third term in this predominantly Democratic city.

title: CORDIER IN FAREWELL AS COLUMBIA'S HEAD
description: On the eve of his replace ment by Dr. William J. McGill as president of Columbia Uni versity, Dr. Andrew W. Cordier issued a farewell message of gratitude this week to the uni versity's 30,000 faculty mem bers, students, administrators and employes.

title: 2 ON BRONX STREET WOUNDED BY SNIPER
description: Two persons were wounded by a sniper on a Bronx street last night.

title: 29 Seized in Disturbance At a City, in Arkansas
description: BLYTHEVILLE, Ark., Sept. (AP)This city of about 26,001 people in northeastern Arkan sas was placed under curfew tonight by Mayor Tom A. Little after several incidents las night that resulted in the arres of 29 persons.

title: Drama of Indians Past Plight Aids Carolina Cherokees Now
description: CHEROKEE, N. C., Sept 1 An outdoor drama depict ing the white man's expul sion of 19thcentury Chero kees from the North Carolina mountains has developed over the last two decades into a major source of funds for programs to enrich the lives of 20thcentury Chero kees.

title: Atlantic City Results
description: Atlantic City Results

title: NADEL & CO. CEASES BROKER OPERATIONS
description: Nadel & Co., a small broker age firm with memberships on the New York Stock Exchange and American Stock Exchange, said yesterday that it had ceased operations, preparatory to the sale of its business.

title: Labor and the Economy
description: What is at the heart of the bluecollar blues  the dis content, even anger, of blue collar workers over current trends in the American society and economy? This is a question of growing concern to politi cians in both ma jor parties, to trade union lead ers and to em ployers as well. It has a highly significant bearing on indus trial relations, the use by or ganized labor of the right to strike, race relationships in factories, the recruitment of whites and blacks for manual jobs and even the inflationary impact of collective bargain ing. The issue cannot be separated from politics.

title: JAPANESE COUNTER DUMPING CHARGE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 Japanese makers of television sets have charged that the Treasury's action last week al leging dumping in the United States market was based on stale price data going back as long as three years.

title: 3 EXPLOSIONS ROCK DOWNTOWN ST. PAUL
description: ST. PAUL, Sept. 1 (UPI) Three explosions within 38 minutes shook this city's Lower Loop today and injured three persons.

title: NEWSMEN PROTEST STATE DEPT. ACTION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UPI) Reporters covering the Sate Department protested today against the withdrawal of the appointment of a director of the State Department's Office of Press Relations after Sena tor Barry M. Goldwater had objected to it.

title: ROBERT ANDERSON OF FINANCE GROUP
Senate Rescinds Action
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) The Senate rescinded tonight its passage earlier in the day of a bill to increase the Gevern ment's share of the cost of high option health insurance coverage for Federal employes from 24 per cent to 40 per cent.

title: 6 of Foe Reported Slain in 8Hour Battlle
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 1South Vietnamese troops, reinforced by Ameri cans, reported having killed 56 Vietcong soldiers yesterday in a battle lasting nearly eight hours, 120 miles eastnortheast of Saigon.

title: RATES CONTINUE TO MOVE LOWER
description: The summer's strong swing toward lower interest rates and higher prices for fixedincome securities remained largely in tact yesterday in the face of a heavy supply of new notes and bonds for sale.

title: Physicist, 49, Becomes Head Of Los Alamos Laboratory
description: LOS ALAMOS, N. M., Sept. 1 (AP)  Harold M. Agnew, 49 yearold physicist, assumed command today of the Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory. He succeeds Dr. Norris E. Bradbury, Los Alamos director for 25 years, who is retiring.

title: Power Rationing Discussed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1The possibility of rationing fuel this winter to keep some small electric utilities running was raised today at a meeting of private power officials with the President's Council of Econom ic Advisers.

title: 60 Reported Dead In Guinea of Cholera
description: GENEVA, Sept. 1  The World Health. Organization saic today that cholera had spreac into Guinea, killing 60 persons in the first outbreak of the disease ever reported in Africa south of the Sahara.

title: TRIAL OF MANSON IS DELAYED AGAIN
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 1 Susan Denice Atkins, a co defendant in the murder trial of Charles M. Manson, underwent further medical tests today.

title: Charts of Races at Belmont
description: Tuesday, Sept.1. Second day. Weather clear. Track fast.

title: Quality and Diversity Mark the Edinburgh Festival
description: EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 31As a festival cen ler, Edinburgh has learned over the years how to make the least of its disadvantages. It has no opera house and the acoustics of its main concert hall are blurred. It lacks theaters and hotels.

title: JOHN H. BAKER, 60, SHIPBUILDER, DIES
description: John H. Baker, vice president in charge of sales and a direc tor of the Todd Shipyards Cor poration, died yesterday at his summer home in Southampton, L. I. He was 60 years old and lived at 135 East 83d Street.

title: Cash Prices
description: Cash Prices

title: Weaver to Be a Consultant
description: Sylvester L. (Pat) Weaver, former president of the Na tional Broadcasting Company, will be a consultant to the Cor poration for Public Broadcast ing in programs dealing with environmental matters.

title: Miss Davis's Pay Halted By U.C.L.A. Faculty Unit
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 1 (AP) A faculty committee has stopped paying Angela Davis, on the ground that it has re ceived no word from her that she intends to lecture in the fall at the University of Califor nia at Los Angeles.

title: Business Records
description: JOHN BALOUGH, locksmith, 13955 35th Ave., Flushing, Queens. Liabilities, $6,941; assets none.

title: Yale President Declines Comment on McLucas
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 1. Late last April, Kingman Brewster Jr., president of Yale University, said he was skeptical of the ability of black revolutionaries to achieve a fair trial anywhere in the United States.

title: Senate Warning on Vietnam
description: The Nixon Administration will make a colossal mistake if it interprets the Senate's rejection of the Hatfield McGovern amendment as an invitation to slow down American troop withdrawals from Vietnam or to stonewall the peace talks in Paris. The fact that 39 Senators were sufficiently concerned over the erratic course of Administration pronouncements on Vietnam to favor a legislated timetable for withdrawal should be evidence enough of the impatience felt by many Americans at the lag in progress toward a negotiated peace.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: How the Cities Rank
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1The following table shows the ranking by population of the 25 largest cities in preliminary I data for the 1970 census, as compared with the ranking the 1960 census:

title: HAROLD D. MAINE
description: PEEKSKILL, N. Y., Sept. 1 Harold D. Mabie, a former city official here and a retired rep retentative of the Bethlehem Steel Company, died today at Community Hospital. He was 78; years old.

title: 300 in Subway Help Tilt Car and Release Boy's Wedged Foot
description: A rescue team of subway passengers, hastily organized by three transit patrolmen, tipped back a 54ton subway car last night, to free an 11 yearold boy whose foot was wedged between the car and the platform at a downtown Brooklyn station.

title: War Protester Arrested
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 1 (AP)  Robert G. Muncaster, a Montgomery businessman who complains that United States funds are being used to finnce an illegal war, was arrested today on charges of willful failure to file Federal income tax returns. Mr. Mun caster has been convicted of aiding his son in refusing to register for the draft.

title: BRAVO ACQUIRES MARKS TRACTOR
description: The Dravo Corporation of Pittsburgh announced yester day that it had acquired the Marks Tractor and Equipment Company of Cleveland and several affiliated companies for an undisclosed number of pref erence shares and cash. The acquisi tion proposal was announced la st February. Marks, a major dis tributor of earthmoving and construction equipment, was founded in 1948. It has annual revenues of $14million and 200 employes.

title: Peddlers in Harlem Fear New Code Is a Death Blow
description: The president of the 125th Street Peddlers Association accused the city yesterday of imposing economic death on Harlem venders if it insisted on enforcing a new regula tion increasing fines forun licensed sidewalk venders up to $100. The new rule also carries with it a possible 10 day jail sentence.

title: Hostile Silence At the Signing
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 1 The scene aboard the battle ship Missouri 25 years ago seemed designed to emphasize the humiliation of a beaten Japan.

title: G.I.'s Find Marijuana Is Plentiful
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 1Five helicopters flut tered into a jungle clearing northwest of Saigon several months ago to pick up a pla toon of American infantrymen that had been staging ambushes for 10 days.

title: Bicycle Standards Set Up For U.S. Manufacturers
description: The Bicycle Institute of America announced yesterday the adoption of a set of in dustrywide bicycle safety and performances standards.

title: Giants Put Through Strenuous Drill
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., Sept. 1 Alex Webster didn't yell a lot and he didn't make a lot of threats. All he did was hold a friendly little scrimmage this afternoon.

title: Stae Schedules Hearings On 4 Independent Parties
description: Stae Schedules Hearings On 4 Independent Parties

title: Victor in Saigon Senate Race
description: SAIGON, Sept. 1Dr. Vu Van Mau, a Buddhist law pro fessor who headed a victori ous 10man antiwar slate in elections for the Senate, re calls having shared top scho lastic honors in his Hanoi lycee with another outstand ing studentVo Nguyen Giap now commander of the North Vietnamese forces. General Giap was two years behind Dr. Mau at the Lycee Albert Sarraut, where the brightest Vietnam ese boys formed an intellec tual elite in the twenties and thirties. He was a very bril liant student, Dr. Mau said of his schoolmate. Every three months the first student of each class was congratu lated. Giap and I were always meeting on such occasions. Man in the news

title: ARTHUR W. GREASON
description: MENDHAM, N. J., Sept. 1 Arthur W. Greason, former vice president of the First National State Bank of New Jersey, died yesterday at a nursing home in Succasunna. He was 92 years old and lived here at 20 East Main Street. He retired 25.years ago from the bank, which he joined as a messenger in 1893.

title: Vatican Increases Prices and Causes Employe Protests
description: ROME, Sept. 1 (AP)The Vatican increased prices for gasoline, liquor, meat and other commodities today with no ad vance notice.

title: Hussein Escapes Another Attempt At Assassination
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 1 King Hussein of Jordan escaped an attempt on his life today, the Amman radio reported. The Government station said that the assailants, whom it did not identify, opened fire on the 34 yearold monarch's motorcade as he was driving to the Am man airport to meet his daUgh ter Alia. The Princess was re turning on a flight from Cairo.

title: Treasury Statement
description: Treasury Statement

title: David Miller, Kate Dilworth Wed in Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 1David Miller, man ager of the Columbia Broad casting System bureau here, married Kate Dilworth of Washington in a civil cere mony today.

title: CLASSICS MINGLE WITH JAZZ DANCES
description: Three new groups were the features of the program last night at the freeadmission New York bane Festival, now in its second week at Central Park's Delacorte Theater under the auspices of the New York Shakespeare Festival.

title: School Openings Delayed In Districts Near St. Louis
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 1 (AP)  Tens of thousands of pupils and their teachers got an extended summer vacation today as teacher disputes and money problems delayed school open ings in some districts in the St. Louis metropolitan area.

title: JONES BATS IN RUN THAT STOPS GIBSON
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 1The New York Mets edged back into sec ond place tonight when they outlasted the St. Louis Car dinals, 43, in 12 innings and sent Bob Gibson to his first de feat in five weeks.

title: ATHENS DROPS LIST OF BANNED BOOKS
description: ATHENS, Sept. 1  The Greek Government has abolished its list of banned books and has told bookstores they are free to sell all volumes so long as they do not contain propa ganda against the established constitutional order.

title: Divestiture Is Goal Of U.S. Trust Suit Against Company
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) The Government sued Com bustion Engineering, Inc. today seeking divestiture of two sub sidiaries whose purchases in 1966 and 1968 allegedly have stifled competition in sales of industrial boilers and pulpmak ing equipment.

title: Buckley Calls His Two Rivals White Flag Candidates on War
description: James L. Buckley, Conserva tive party candidate for United States Senator, described his two opponents yesterday as white flag candidates for supporting a Congressional ef fort to require the withdrawal of all American troops from Indochina by the end of next year.

title: List of Activities For the Children
description: List of Activities For the Children

title: 4,000 JOIN MARCH IN PORTLAND, ORE
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 1 About 1,000 young people marched through Portland's streets tonight in the second licensed parade by the People's Army Jamboree in three days. The parade, which disrupted the flow of homebound traffic from 5:30 to 7:30 P.M., was held as a protest against racism.

title: AERIALS TO SPUR VILLANOVA DRIVE
description: VILLANOVA, Pa., Sept. 1  When taking over a new job there are always dozens of problems, but Lou Ferry has one less as the new head coach at Villanova. He doesn't have to adjust to the environment.

title: SENATE DEFEATS END WAR MOVE BY VOTE OF 5539
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1The Senate defeated today the Hat fieldMcGovern amendment to end the war.

title: Iraqi Threat Reported
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Sept. (Reuters)Iraq threatened to night to order her 12,000 troops in Jordan into action against the forces of King Hussein un less Jordanian troops immedi ately ceased fire against the Palestine commandos, the Bagjidad radio reported.

title: The Concorde Flies Over Populated Areas
description: LONDON, Sept. 1  Flying for the first time over popu lated areas, the supersonic Concorde soared today over an 800milelong corridor along the coast of West Scotland, Wales and England.

title: CITY HALTS A LOAN FOR $60MILLION
description: A $60million loan that the city had agreed to provide as the longterm financing for the 50story Burlington Building on the Avenue of the Americas be tween 54th and 55th Streets has been ordered held up in definitely.

title: OHIO STATIONS HELD UNFAIR TO NEGROES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1A federation of black community organizations in Columbus, Ohio, asked the. Federal Corn munications Commission yes terday to deny license renewals for three local broadcasters on the ground that they had given inadequate coverage to the needs and interests of black listeners.

title: WILLIAM GASTON
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Sept 1  William. GaSton, who ran unsuccessfully for Congress or the Democratic ticket from the FOurth District in November, 1948, died Sunday. He was 79 years old and lived at 463 Val ley Road.

title: ISRAEL POSTPONES ACTION ON PEACE IN MISSILE CRISIS
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 1The Isiaeli Government today post poned further moves to ad vance the peace talks with the Arab states until the removal of all Egyptian missiles she says have been newly placed at the Suez Canal.

title: Cultural Center Will Offer Two Film Retrospectives
description: Two retrospective film pro grams will be presented in con junction with forthcoming exhibitions at the New York Cultural Center, 2 Columbus Circle. Starting today, a series of features called Woman will illustrate the theme of the Second World Exhibition of Photography on the fourth and fifth floors. Among the movies scheduled are Applause, The Heiress, The Scarlet Empress, Belle of the Nine ties, Blonde Venus and Design for Living.

title: I.O.S. Board Schedules Meeting To Restore Cornield's Place
description: GENEVA, Sept. 1 The board of directors of Investors Overseas Services will meet here Thursday to restore the membership of Bernard Corn feld, the deposed head of I.O.S., and place him on its seven member executive committee.

title: PEACE CORPSMEN QUIT BOLIVIA AREA
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Sept. 1 Twelve Peace Corpsmen have been evacuated from two areas where Marxist guerrillas have been battling Government forces during the last month.

title: Contracts Are Down for Construction
description: Nationwide contracts for all kinds of construction work in July had a total value of $6,177,789,000, just a bit below the July, 1969, total of $6,180,435,000, the F. W. Dodge division of the McGraw Hill Information Systems Com pany reported yesterday.

title: Yonkers Entries
description: Yonkers Entries

title: Release Is Denied to 14 Seized in Philadelphia Raids
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1  Fourteen persons seized in po lice raids on Black Panther party headquarters were de nied release today.

title: British Halt Ulster Clash
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 1 (AP)Roman Catholics and Protestants tangled in a freeforall at Lurgan tonight and British troops moved in to break up the battle.

title: Census Lists 200 Million; 12 House Seats May Shift
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 The first national statistical picture of the population emerged from the 1970 census today, and it showed that the nineteensixties were a decade of outward movementout ward from cities to suburbs and outward to the coastland. Officials estimated today that the census would show a population of more than 204 million when servicemen, tran sients and others were added to the 200,261,723 now counted.

title: Money
description: Tuesday, Sept. 1, 1970

title: MRS. GEORGE MALLETT
description: BLUE HILL, Me., Sept. 1 Mrs. Renee D. Mallett, widow of Dr. George H. Mallett, died in the Blue Hill Hospital today after a short illness. She was 92 years old.

title: Football Transactions
description: BALTIMOREAsked waivers on Perry Lee Dunn, running back; Frank Amelung, Florida guard; Barney Harris, Texas A. and M. quarterback, Eugene Moore, Occidental running back.

title: University Computing Unit Closes for Lack of Orders
description: The University Computing Company said yesterday it has closed its data preparation cen ter at El Paso, Tex., due to cir cumstances beyond the com pany's control.

title: Westmoreland Visits Seoul
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 1 Gen. William C. Westmoreland, the United States Army thief of Staff, arrived here today for talks with South Korean offi cials and an inspection of American and South Korean troops.

title: CLAY SET TONIGHT FOR 2 EXHIBITIONS
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 1 (UPI) Cassius Clay promised today that he would produce a real fight in his two exhibition matches tomorrow night, but said he needed four more weeks to get in championship form.

title: United Plans New Seating
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 1 (AP) Beginning Sept. 14 United Air lines will introduce fivea cross seating in the coach sec tions of some its transcontinen tal flights. Robert E. Johnson, a vice president of United, said that the move from the present sixacross seating would pro vide for greater passenger comfort. He added that exist ing flight schedules would be adequate to handle passenger traffic.

title: Budget Director of City Is Sworn In by Mayor
description: Mayor Lindsay invited Ed ward K. Hamilton yesterday to step up for your execu tion and then swore him in as the city's Budget Director.

title: Market Place:
description: Almost every investor knows by now that the big gest clout in the stock mar ket is wielded by institutions  the mutual funds, bank trusts, pension funds and in surance companies with bil lions to invest.

title: OTHER COMPANY REPORTS
description: RRecord

title: The Key Panther Witness Is Still to Come
description: NEW HAVEN Sept. 1With the conclusion of the Lonnie McLucas trial here on a some what ambiguous notea guilty verdict on a charge of con spiracy to murder, withacquit tal on three others that carried heavier penalties  the state's effort to prove that the leader ship of the Black Pantherparty ordered the Alex Rackley slay ing is likely to focus on a party member who has yet to testify. His name is Landon Williams and for the last 15 months he has been in a Denver jail with another Panther, Rory Hithe, fighting extradition to Connec ticut on five different charges arising from the Rackley murder.

title: MRS, MYLES B. GAYNOR
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Sept. 1Mrs. Ida L. Gaynor, cofounder with her late hus band, Myles B. Gaynor of the Gaynor News Company and its affiliated companies, distribu tor of newspapers in this area, died yesterday in New Rochelle Hospital.

title: JAMES SWEENEY
description: MASSAPEQUA, L. I., Sept. 1James Sweeney, a cocoa broker, died today in Mercy Hospital, Rockville Centre, after a short illness. He was 67 years old and lived here at 82 Peconic drive.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, P.M.

title: Ample Power Expected in East
description: Despite what has been termed a critical national short age of fossil fuels used to gen erate electrical power, there is little chance of a power short age this winter in New York or in neighboring states, accord ing to utility officials.

title: Box Scores of Major League Games
description: Box Scores of Major League Games

title: ASARCO REDUCES LEAD PRICE AGAIN
description: The American Smelting and Refining Company reduced its price for lead yesterday for the third time in less than two months, but other major pro ducers immediately announced that they would not follow suit.

title: Railroads Seek Freight Rate Rise of 15%
description: The Eastern and Western railroads of the country asked the Interstate Commerce Com mission yesterday for authority to raise their freight rates across the board by 15 per cent. They proposed that the commission allow them to put an 8 per cent increase into ef fect on Sept. 15, and a 7 per cent increase on Nov. 1.

title: Follmer in Lime Rock Field
description: LIME ROCK, Conn., Sept. 1 (UPI)George Follmer of Ar cadia, Calif., said today he would make a midnight flight across the United States in order to drive a Lotus Ford Formula A car in the $35,000 Inver House Grand Prix at Lime Rock Park Sept. 7.

title: Ministry Is Restored in Soviet For Administration of Justice
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 1The So viet Union announced today the restoration of the once abolished Ministry of Justice as part of a stepped up drive against crime, particularly against graft and embezzle ment of state property.

title: STOCKS OFF A BIT ON LONDON BOARD
description: The London stock market closed slightly lower yesterday after a steady opening. Trading was extremely light following the extended bankholiday weekend.

title: BRONX MAN, 68, DIES AFTER HE IS MUGGED
description: A 68yearold man who liked to take lateevening strolls died early this morning after being mugged in the hallway of his Grand Concourse apartment building in the Bronx.

title: BELL SUPPLY UNIT LIFTS PRICES 2.8%
description: The Western Electric Com pany, the manufacturing and supply unit of the Bell System, yesterday announced price in creases in certain of its manu factured products that average 2.8 per cent.

title: Dividends Announced
description: Dividends Announced

title: PETITIONS FOR DODD PASS TOTAL NEEDED
description: HARTFORD, Sept 1United States Senator Thomas J. Dodd was unofficially certified today by the Secretary of State's of fice to run as an independent candidate for reelection.

title: FOODSTAMP LINES GET LONGER HERE
description: The Federal food stamp pro gram drew a larger turnout here yesterday than it did on Monday, the day the national program went into effect in the city, according to officials.

title: Agnew Briefs President, Sees Hope for Cambodia
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Sept. 1Vice President Agnew said here today that the Cam bodian Government has at least a fighting chance for sur vival as a result of the United States and South Vietnamese assault on Communist border sanctuaries.

title: SOYBEAN PRICES SHOW A DECLINE
description: The bottom appeared to drop, out of the rising grain and soybeanfutures market yester day, with all components show ing price decreases from the day before on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Large Find of Uranium Reported in Australia
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 1 An Australianowned company, Queensland Mines, Ltd., an nounced today what it said was the world's largest uranium discoveryat least 55,000 tons of uranium oxide worth $761 million at current world prices in the Northern Territory of Australia. The site is 170 miles east of Darwin.

title: Wharram Quits Hockey
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 1 (AP)  Kenny Wharram, 37yearold former National Hockey League AllStar who was stricken with a heart ailment a year ago, notified the Chicago Black Hawks of his retirement from pro hockey today.

title: Anthony Ryan Plans to Marry Rose D. Cutler
description: HAMILTON, Mass., Sept. 1 Miss Rose Dimond Cutler and Anthony Allan Ryan, a greatgrandson of the late Thomas Fortune Ryan, the fi nancier, will marry here Dec. 19.

title: CITY SCHOOL CHIEF STARTS WORKING
description: The new Chancellor of the New York City school system spent the first few minutes of his initial day on the job yes terday trying vainly to open the office door that carried his name in new gold lettering.

title: Shoemaker Gets Triple, Is 4 Short of Record
description: DEL MAR, Calif., Sept. 1 (UPI)Bill Shoemaker scored a riding triple at Del Mar today that left him four short of John Longden's career rec ord of 6,032 winners.

title: Proudest Roman Suffers Hairline Fracture in Drill
description: Mrs. John A. Morris's Protid est Roman, winner of the $130, 950 Hopeful at Saratoga last Saturday and a ton contender for 2yearold honors, fractured a sesamoid bone in his left foreleg during a gallop yester day morning at Belmont Park.

title: U.S IS CONVINCED U.A.R. BROKE TRUCE
description: WASHINGTON; Sept.1 High Administration officials said today that the United States was now satisfied on the basis of photographic and electronic evidence that the United Arab Republic had vio lated the standstill ceasefire in the Suez Canal region by moving antiaircraft missile bat teries into the truce zone.

title: V.A. to Keep Beds Open
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 1 (AP) The Veterans Administration has decided not to close 4,800 beds in veterans hospitals, the American Legion national con vention was told today by Donald E. Johnson, administra tor of Veterans Affairs.

title: GOVERNMENT ACTS ON CARPET SAFETY
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1The Social Security Administration moved today to establish stringent flammability stan dards for carpeting in nursing homes that are certified as ex tendedcare facilities under the Medicare program.

title: Earl S. Potter, Racing Steward, Once an Amateur Rider, Dead
description: Earl S. Potter, one of three stewards overseeing thorough bred racing at Belmont Park, Aqueduct and Saratoga, died Monday night at his racing season residence in Garden City, L.I. Mr. Potter, who made his home in Pottersville, was 63 years old.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: U.S. Acts to Deport Italian Alleged to Be Executioner
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., Sept. 1A Federal Government ef fort to renew deportation pro ceedings against an alleged Sicilian Mafia executioner, wanted by the Italian police since 1963, was approved today by a special hearing officer for the United States Immigration and Naturalization Commission. The hearing was held in the Bergen County Courthouse here.

title: Plans to Increase Forces
description: PNOMPENH, Sept. 1 (Reu ters)  Cambodia aims to in crease the size of her armed forces from 140,000 to 210,000 men, Foreign Minister Koun Wick said today. But we need arms for another 10,000 men, he said at a news conference.

title: LLOYDS BANK UNIT PLANNING TO MERGE
description: LONDON, Sept. 1 (Reuters)  Lloyds Bank said today that its wholly owned subsidiary, Lloyds Bank Europe, Ltd., would merge with the Bank of London and South America.

title: New York Weather in August
description: New York Weather in August

title: Advertising: D.D.B. Hails a New Executive
description: J. Ross MacLennan, who was apparently squeezed out of Ted Bates & Co. less than two months ago, has just turned up at Doyle Dane Bernbach as a senior vice president.

title: ATTWOOD NAMED TO HEAD NEWSDAY
description: William Attwood, the editor in chief of Cowles Communica tions, Inc., and former United States Ambassador to Guinea and Kenya, was named yester day as publisher and president of Newsday.

title: Roundup: Bombers Have A Busy Evening in Boston
description: The switchboard at Bos ton's Fenway Park received three telephone calls warning of a bomb in the park last night, but the police bomb squad looked in the wrong place.

title: Meany to the Democrats
description: Wounding other people's sensibilities never has given George Meany much pause so it is no surprise to find the 76yearold president of the A.F.L.C.I.O. celebrating the advent of Labor Day with a hatful of harsh words for practically everybody outside labor's own ranks.

title: Aitcheson Rides. Top Bid to International Chase Victory, Setting Track Mark
description: Who win it? a groom asked after the fourth race at Bel mont Park yesterday.

title: M'DANIEL RECORDS 22D SAVE IN NINTH
description: A winning performance by Fritz Peterson; perfect relief by Lindy McDaniel, home runs by Bobby Murcer and Roy White, four crisp double plays and the New York Yankees put victory No. 75 into their record at Yankee Stadium last night, 42, over the Baltimore Orioles.

title: Mrs. Agnes Meyer Dies at 83; Writer Active in Social Causes
description: MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., Sept 1Mrs. Agnes Ernst Meyer writer and leader in Social service and education, and widow of Eugene Meyer, board chairman of The Washington Post, died this morning at he home here. She was 83 years old and also maintained a resi dence in Washington.

title: ROCKEFELLER FACES UNION VOTE FIGHT
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., Sept. 1Union supporters of Governor Rockefeller face a strong challenge from backers a Arthur J. Goldberg at the State A.F.L.C.I.O. convention opening at the Concord Hotel here tomorrnw.

title: Jets Save a Move on Philbin's Status
description: At their training camp in Hempstead, L. I., the Jets will go to work today on their of fense, which has been so un even lately. In the fourth preseason game, against the Saints in New Orleans on Saturday night, Al Woodall will follow Joe Namath at quarterback and, Coach Weeb Ewbank said, Na math will play at least a half. None of the rival teams in the American Confer ence put in a claim for Gerry Philbin, the Jets star defen sive end, or for Jimmy Wil liams, a rookie cornerback. They were placed on waivers Monday. Philbin goes on in active status and the club thus did not have to use up one of its 10 allotted moves whereby a player goes from active to inactive status with out waivers having to be re ceived from the other teams. Philbin can be brought back when his shoulder heals and Williams will join the Jet taxi squad.

title: Market Averages
description: Tuesday, September 1, 1970

title: Riggs Wins, 75, 60
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1 Bobby Riggs of Plandome, L. I., the defender, advanced to the third round in the United States senior grass court tennis cham pionship today with a 75, 60 triumph over Herbert Benham of Bakersfield, Calif., at the Germantown Cricket Club.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Guns and Crossbow Found In Eviction of Bronx Tenant
description: Policemen called to assist in an eviction in the Morrisonia section of the Bronx last night said they found four unlicensed guns, one crossbow and two longbows.

title: $176,000 U.S. Open Tennis Starts Today With Tiebreaker Adding to Drama
description: Erick Van Dillen gave up an athletic grantinaid at the University of Southern Cali fornia last spring for a fling at the fame and fortune of the professional tennis tour.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Entertainment Events

title: CITY'S POPULATION PUT AT 7,771,730,
description: The Census Bureau made public yesterday its preliminary count for New York City, giv ing the 1970 population as 7, 771,730, only 10,254 below 1960, despite some earlier unofficia forecasts of a major drop.

title: BURGER IS CHIDED ON ORDER TO PRESS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 Chief Justice Warren E. Burger became embroiled in another controversy over freedom of the press today when a Wash ington publisher chided him for requiring permission before his State of the Judiciary speech may be reprinted.

title: Winds Curb Tuna Tourney
description: YARMOUTH, Nova Scotia, Sept. 1High winds and rough seas cut short the start of the 21st International Tuna Cup event at nearby Cape St. Mary today. Anglers from five coun tries were competing.

title: PACKERS ADDERLEY TRADED TO COWBOYS
description: DALLAS, Sept. 1 (AP)The Dallas Cowboys took a step to bolster their defensive second ary today by trading a center, Malcolm Walker, and a de fensive end, Clarence Williams, to the Green Bay Packers for Herb Adderley, cornerback.

title: 2 Charged in Omaha Blast
description: OMAHA, Sept. 1Two Neb raska leaders of an offshoot of the Black Panther party have been charged with murder in the Aug. 17 death of Patrolman Larry Minard.

title: U.S. Tops Italy by 9556 To Gain Basketball Final
description: TURIN, Italy, Sept. 1 (UPI) The United States beat Italy, 9556, tonight to join the Soviet Union in the basketball final of the sixth World University games.

title: Volpe Would Aid Buses To Cat Traffic Jams
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UPI)Transportation Secre tary John A. Volpe proposed today that city traffic con gestion be relieved by en couraging greater reliance on buses, with special lanes and even highways reserved for their exclusive use.

title: Two Faces of Justice
description: Like every extremist group, the Black Panthers pose a severe challenge to the orderly processes of justice. They make so many boasts of militancy and threats of violence that it is difficult to establish their re sponsibility for specific acts of violence. Organized on an authoritarian pattern and operating in a semi clandestine manner, the Panthers obscure the specific roles of individual members.

title: Cannon Wins Bid For Renomination in Nevada Primary
description: RENO, Nev., Sept. 1 (UPI) Senator Howard W. Cannon Won renomination today in Nevada's Democratic primary election. William Raggio, a Re publican district attorney, rolled up an apparently unbeatable lead against token opposition in the senatorial primary.Representative Waiter S. Bar ing, a Democrat seeking his 10th term as Nevada's only member of the House, pulled well ahead of Otto Ravenholt, who advocated a social welfare and ecology platform.

title: How Stable the Census?
description: The White Queen: What's one and one and one and one and one and one and one and one and one and one?

title: BRONX LANDLORDS WARN OF A STRIKE
description: Bronx landlords reported yes terday that an impasse had been reached in their negotia tions with apartmenthouse workers, whose contract ex pires Sept. 14.

title: Monday Night Fight
description: San Jose, Calif.Mickey Duarte, 131 pounds, Nicaragua, knocked out Bobby Sedillo, 131, San Jose, 2 rounds.

title: ISRAEL REPORTS RAID ON AREA IN LEBANON
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 1A spokesman here said today that Israeli ground forces demol ished buildings in a retaliatory raid across the Lebanese border during the night. The spokes man said that one Israeli sol dier had been killed and two injured.

title: BOOKER T. ERVIN, 39, JAZZ SAXOPHONIST
description: Booker T. Ervin Jr., a jazz musician and composer who played tenor saxophone with many leading contemporary groups, died Monday in Belle vue Hospital of a kidney ail ment. He was 39 years old and lived at 204 East 13th Street.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Man Is Accused of Enticing Girl Addicts
description: A Yonkers businessman who allegedly persuaded young wo men heroinaddicts to engage in sexual intercourse by posing as a lawyer for Odyssey House was arrested yesterday in Brooklyn.

title: Soviet Says a Survey Ship Rescued Drifting U.S. Yacht
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 1 (AP)  A Soviet survey ship, the Shok alsky, has rescued a storm tossed American schooner that had been adrift in the Indian Ocean for six days, Tass, the official press agency, reported today.

title: Blood Shortage in Boston
description: BOSTON Sept. 1 (AP)The Maddechusetts Red Cross says it is in need of blood for the labor Day weekend. A spokes man for the Red Cross said there were only 50 pints of blood at centers in Boston and Pea body. There is a total of 400 pints at the Worcester and Springfield centers. He said the state needed 1,000 pints of blood daily4to meet hospital needs.

title: REUBIO THOMAS
description: Reubio Thomas, a group en gineering manager at Loral Electronic Systems, a division of the Loral Corporation in the Bronx, died after a long illness Sunday at Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia Presbyterian Med ical Center. He was 49 years old and lived in Teaneck, N. J.

title: GRIFFIN TV SHOW EYING TO COAST
description: Mery Griffin confirmed yes terday that he is taking his latenight talk show to Cali fornia.

title: Coast to Get Cordone Play
description: Charles Cordone's 1970 Pulit zer Prizewinning play, No Place, to Be Somebody, will open a threeweek engagement at the Huntington Hartford in Los Angeles on Sept. 14. Key roles will be played by mem ber of the current New York cast, including Wally Taylor and Chuck Daniel.

title: Census Data Listed For 3State Region
description: Following are Census Bureau preliminary reports 1970 populations for counties and major cities in New York State with calculations of changes from 1960:

title: Score for Martinique
description: Score, a new play written and directed by Jerry Douglas, will open at the Martinique Theater on Wednesday, Oct. 28. The play, which deals with the new sexual freedom and its ef fect on two married. couples, is being presented by Michael Harvey, a Wall Street invest ment banker, who is making his debut as a producer. Previews begin Tuesday, Sept. 15.

title: MARKET RETREATS ON A BROAD FRONT
description: The stock market, keeping a wary eye on automobilecon tract negotiations in Detroit, beat an orderly retreat yester day. Both glamour issues and blue chips gave up ground.

title: Poland Tempers AntiGerman Mood on Anniversary of 39 Invasion
description: WARSAW, Sept. 1Poland today recalled the 31st anniver sary of the German invasion that started World War II, though the commemoration was less stark than in the past.

title: A Correction
description: Morris J. Laurie, a member of the city's Board of Correc tion, said yesterday that an article in The New York Times on Monday listing him as one of a group of critics of food being served to prisoners was in error. Mr. Laurie defended prison food on the WCBSTV Public Hearing program on Sunday.

title: Selling Surge Puts Pound At Lowest Point in a Year
description: LONDON, Sept. 1 (UPI)  A surge of selling today drove the British pound to its lowest point in about a year. It closed at $2.3825, against its closing of $2.38375 on Friday, before the threeday bank holiday.

title: Japanese Aide to Visit U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) Yasuhiro Nakasone, the di rector general of the Japanese Defense Agency, will visit the United States for a weeklong tour of military bases begin ning Sept. 9.

title: As Summer Advanced, Amendment Lobby Waned
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1  Early in May, aflame over the allied drive into Cambodia and the deaths at Kent State Univer sity, a group of young political activists banded together to lobby for the amendment to end the war.

title: Bridge
description: The world team champion ship title was won this year by the United States for the first time since 1954, and the full account of the victory of the Dallas Aces in Stockholm is now available from the American Contract Bridge League, 125 Greenwich Ave nue, Greenwich. Conn. 06830.

title: How States Populations Have Changed in Decade
description: How States Populations Have Changed in Decade

title: Cotton Market
description: NEW YORK COTTON

title: Vote in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) Following is the rollcall vote by which the Senate today de feated an amendment to the military authorization bill, of fered by Senators George S. McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, and Mark 0. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon, to set Dec. 31, 1971, as the deadline for the withdrawal of all United States military forces from In dochina:

title: TWO POLICEMEN INDICTED IN SOUTH
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., Sept. 1 Two white policemen were in dicted today by a Federal grand jury on a charge of violating the civil rights of two Negroes on May 11 when racial violence swept through this city, leaving six Negroes dead, 60 persons injured and $1million in prop erty damage. Those indicted were William Samuel Dennis, 33 years old, who is accused of the fatal shooting of John W. Stokes, and Louis C. Dinkins, 33, accused of wounding Louis Nel son Williams.

title: Carol Mann Finds Liberation on Links Is 12 Strokes Away
description: GROSSINGER, N. Y., Sept. 1Can a powerhitting woman golfer beat one of the top moneywinning men profession als? That was the question to be answered today when 6 foot3inch Carol Mann of the Ladies Professional Golf Asso ciation played an 18hole match against Doug Sanders at the Grossinger's Golf Club course.

title: Heinz Results in Quarter Reach Record Despite a 45Day Strike
description: The H. J. Heinz Company re ported yesterday that its net income and sales in the first quarter ended July 29 rose to record levels despite a costly 45day strike at the company's Canadian production facilities that ended early in July.

title: NIGERIA RECONCILED WITH FOUR NATIONS
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 1 (AP)Nigeria has be come reconciled with the four African countries that gave dip lomatic rcognition to Biafra.

title: MICHAEL I. BEGUN
description: Michael I. Begun, a lawyer, died yesterday at University Hospital of New York Univer sity Medical Center. He was 66 years old and lived at 400 Edst 56th Street.

title: Mayor Disputes Poverty Workers On Their View of Dead End Jobs
description: Mayor Lindsay disputed yes terday, the contention of some antipoverty workers that de partmentstore jobs are a dead end.

title: CanAm, Needing Competition, Looks to BigName Europeans
description: ELKHART LAKE, Wis., Sept. 1It was just as well that Sunday's Road America CanAm here, sixth of the 1970 series of 10 events, end ed in a protest over the 13 lap penalty against Denis Hulme for restarting his stalled engine with a push start. The controversy of 1 hour 40 min utes was only 14 minutes shorter than the race it self, but more in teresting. If the dispute had not occurred, it might have been necessary to play the National Anthem to wake the customers and send them home. This was the sixth consecutive victory of the season for McLaren Racing, and the 19th in a row since October, 1968. Since the beginning of the 1967 season, the McLaren team has won 26 of 29 CanAm races.

title: 14 Senators Urge Nixon Seek Truce At Vietnam Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 Fourteen Senators, including the Democratic and Repub lican leaders, urged President Nixon today to propose a comprehensive standstill ceasefire for South Vietnam at the stalemated peace talks in Paris.

title: Plants Used by Peruvian Indians Are Analyzed as Contraceptives
description: The sedge is an innocuous looking, grasslike plant of many varities that grows all over South America. Two vari eties, however, are potent con traceptives, thought to be used by Indian women for centuries as their pill.These are not the only bo tanical contraceptives known. More than a dozen different plants used to prevent concep tion or induce abortion or fer tility have been collected by Mrs. Nicole Maxwell, a re search associate of the Museum of the American Indian Heye Foundation, who has studied the health of the Peruvian and Ecuadorian Indians for the last 20 years.

title: Julianne Rash To Be a Bride
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 Miss Julianne Rash and Dr. Robert M. Weir, who is a captain in the United States Public Health Service, will be married here Nov. 1 at the home of the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Bryson B. Rash.

title: Sports Illustrated Magazine Announces Editorial Shifts
description: Several changes in the edi torial management of Sports Il lustrated were announced yes terday by Hedley Donovan, edi tor in chief of Time, Inc., which publishes the weekly magazine.

title: State Fair Opens
description: SYRACUSE, Sept. 1  The New York State Fair opened under sunny skies here today, with more than half a million people expected to attend be fore the fair closes Monday. The gateway to the fairgrounds is decorated in psychidelic colors to connote the theme: Empire HappeningPeople and Progress.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: To the Editor: Those Americans who point to the new RussoGerman ac cords and to the ostensible flexibility of the Soviet Union in the Middle East as the start of a new era of negotiation are deluding themselves.

title: Books of The Times
description: Since we're onto the subject of sex edu cation, where everyone has at least some qualifications to hold forth, I had better introduce my credentials immediately. At this time, I have none. Our daughter has not asked a single question; in fact when I solicitously handed her Mary Breasted's Oh! Sex Education! she tried to eat it

title: Labor Party Unit Shuns Pinning Onus Of Loss on Wilson
description: LONDON, Sept. 1The Labor party's National Executive Com mittee, in a report today on the defeat in the general election in June, avoided pinning the blame on Harold Wilson, the former Prime Minister, and criticized publicopinion polls.

title: Chess Computer Loses Game in a KingSize Blunder
description: The world's first major chess tournament played by computers proved yesterday that masters have little to fear from machines and that not even a milliondollar electronic marvel is blunder proof.

title: LTV Suspends Paying Dividends On Its Preferred
description: DALLAS, Sept. 1 (AP) LingTemcoVought, Inc., an nounced today that it was suspending payment of divi dends on its preferred stock to preserve working capital.

title: Negro Democrats Put Up a Slate Of 169 for Elections in Alabama
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 1 Hoping to take advantage of close local races between Re and Democrats, the, predominantly black National) Democratic Party of Alabama) formally qualified a slate of 1691 candidates today to run in the Nov. 3 general election. All but nine are Neeroes.

title: Francois Mauriac
description: Francois Maurtac was that rare combination, a mas ter storyteller and.a master moralist. He wrote about sinnersmen and women palpably of the flesh And about sin. Thinking of life in such terms may be old fashioned these days, and Mauriac may therefore put Off some readers. But that would be a pity, for he Utilized evil to illuminate virtue; and in so doing he Universalized and humanized his profound moral and religious concerns.

title: TODAY'S PROBABLE PITCHERS
description: Baltimore at New York (2 P.M.) McNally (217) vs. Keitich (43).

title: Belmont Entries
description: Belmont Entries

title: Hickel Visiting Finland
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 1 (UPI)Secretary of the Interior Waiter J. Nickel arrived in Fin land today to discuss environ mental problems. He also will visitSweden and Norway.

title: Stage: Oriental Fantasy
description: The Emerald Slippers, which opened last night at the Gramercy Arts Theater, is billed as a fantasy for children of all ages. Since it runs evenings at 7 in addi tion to weekend matinees, obviously the producer, Henry Testa, is interested in luring some adults into the house.

title: A. L. Sager Weds Carole Bayer
description: Miss Carole Jill Bayer, daughter of Mrs. Elias Bayer of New York and the late Mr. Bayer, and Andrew L. Sager, son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Sager of New York and Deal, N. J., were married here yes terday afternoon in the Re gency Hotel by Rabbi Judah Nadich.

title: New Hampshire Called Goal Of Hashish Seized on Crete
description: CONCORD, N. H., Sept. (UPI)A cache of 1,452 pounds of hashish, estimated to be worth $5million and captured on the island of Crete last weekend, apparently was headed for New Hampshire, it was disclosed today.

title: NEW HAVEN TO TRY ZONES IN EVENING
description: The Penn Central plans to introduce a new zonal schedule on its evening New Haven commuter service Sept. 21 that it said would mean more trains, faster service and fewer standees.

title: Marriages
description: SAGERBAYER. Mrs. Ellas Bayer announces the marrlage Sent. 1, 1970 of her daughter Carole 10 Andrew Sager, son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Sager, all of New York City

title: Vanquished Felt That Nobler Ideal Won World War II
description: TOKYO, Sept. 1  Mankind stands in the presence of his tory.

title: GOLDBERG IN CHICAGO ON FUNDRAISING TRIP
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 1Arthur J. Goldberg traveled to Chicago today to look up some old friends for financial assistance on his New York gubernatorial campaign.

title: Rutgers Offense Looks Potent, But Lack of Depth Is Problem
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. 1, Sept. 1When a football team that has little depth begins to suffer injuries, chances for an outstanding season become buried under bandages and trainers reports. That's what happened to Rutgers last year when the Scarlet Knights opened the centennial season with one of the best teams in its history.

title: R. H. Lapin & Co. Is Formed By Fanny May's ExChief
description: Ray H. Lapin, who was ousted last year by President Nixon from his job as president of the Federal National Mort gage Association, announced yesterday his reentry into the mortgage banking business with the formation of a new com pany, R. H. Lapin & Co., Inc., San Francisco.

title: Executive Changes
description: Leon B. Dorfman has been named vice presi dent, manager, corporate bond department of Loeb, Rhoades & Co.

title: City Opera Calmly Prepares to Open
description: It looked like anything but a major opera company get ting ready for an opening night. Julius Rudel, the New York City Opera's general director, chatted with John White, the managing director about the relative charms of Vienna, London and Paris.

title: CANADA TROUBLED BY JOBLESSNESS
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 1The re duction in the bank interest rate announced last night by the Bank of Canada reflects a shifting of political and eco nomic pressures on the Trudeau Government from a worry over inflation to unemployment that has now rached a peak of 6.7 per cent.

title: Osaka Finds Philharmonic Wonderful!
description: OSAKA, Japan, Aug. 30 The New York Philharmonic received a tumultuous wel come from a capacity audi ence at Osaka Festival Hall this weekend as it opened an 18day tour of Japan.

title: BICH CASTIGATED FOR COMPLAINTS
description: The Baron is a bad loser, as well as a bad sailor, Com modore Frederik Horn of the International Race Committee said yesterday in answer to the charges made against his croup by the head of the French America's Cup syndicate.

title: Those White House Flowers
description: The White House isn't saying why, and members of the staff are reluctant even, to discuss it, but starting this week some of those beautiful bouquets in the Executive Mansion will be artificial.

title: U.S. and Soviet Bid Parley Back Seabed Treaty
description: GENEVA, Sept. 1The Unit ed States and the Soviet Union urged the disarmament confer ence here today to give prompt approval to their much revised draft treaty to prohibit the in stallation of nuclear weapons on the seabed outside 12mile coastal limits.

title: British Soccer Results
description: First Division

title: POLICE ASSAULTS HELD UNRELATED
description: Mayor Lindsay and Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary said yesterday that recent armed assaults on policemen here were apparently uncon nected incidents without an overall plot.

title: Ronan Pledges Public Hearings On 2d Ave. Subway Station Sites
description: Dr. William J. Ronan, chair man of the Metropolitan Trans portation Authority, said yes terday that public hearings would be held before final plans were approved for the location of stations on the new Second Avenue subway.

title: Basketball Transactions
description: NATIONAL ASSOCIATION

title: Film About Eisenhower Bows in Kansas City
description: KANSAS CITY, Sept. 1 (AP)The film, A Place in the Sun, which presents highlights in the life of the late Dwight D. Eisenhower, made its debut here yester day.

title: New Books
description: The Bridges, by Tarjei Vesaas, translated from the Norwegian by Elizabeth Rokkan (Morrow, $5). Involvement and compassion bring three adolescents to ma turity.

title: Aspen, Colo.: The Philosophers at Bay
description: ASPEN, Colo., Sept. 1In the last few days, a group of distinguished scientists, econo mists, historians and philoso phers meeting here have reached the melancholy conclusion that modern technology, greedy men and complacent or inefficient governments are debasing hu man values, ruining the quality of our environment, and threat ening the future of a decent and civilized world.

title: AMEX IS LOWER AS TRADING EBBS
description: The recent upswing on the American Stock Exchange ended yesterday as profit taking weakened most issues in light trading.

title: Chamber of Commerce Criticizes Nixon's Welfare Reform Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 The United States Chamber of Commerce challenged today much of the basic line of rea soning behind the Nixon Ad ministration's welfare reform plan.

title: Sports of The Times
description: On billboards throughout the Twin Cities area, Joe Kapp smiles. Next to him is the slogan, Joe Kapp Can't Lose with Instant Interest, a message from a local bank.

title: MRS. GANDHI FIGHTS TO STOP RAJAS PAY
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 1Prime Minister Indira Gandhi staked her Government's future today on legislation to end allow ances and other privileges for India's former rulers.

title: Linda Goodwin To Be Married
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 1Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Goodwin have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Linda Ruth Goodwin, to Mi chael Alan Hordell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond L. Hordell of New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: $143,630 Hambletonian Today Draws Field of 15 Trotters
description: DU QUOIN, Ill., Sept. 1  The 45th edition of the $143,630 Hambletonian, the trotting clas sic for 3yearolds, will be staged tomorrow (weather permitting) over the onemile oval at the Du Quoin State Fairgrounds.

title: The Box Score
description: The Box Score

title: DR. SMITH IS BACK IN LINCOLN POST
description: Dr. Joseph J. Smith, whose ouster from Lincoln Hospital was demanded by South Bronx militants, returned to work yes terday after receiving assur ances that he would be protect ed from personal harm.

title: Careers Wrecked by Wisconsin Blast
description: MADISON, Wis., Aug. 29 Early on the morning of Aug. 24, David Schuster, a bearded, 28yearold graduate student in nuclear physics at the Univer sity of Wisconsin, was perform ing the last experiment he needed for his Ph.D. degree, which he hoped to win by this December after three years of painstaking research.

title: Washington Proceedings

title: Miss Verdy Injects Swan Queen Role With Lyric Quality

Last night, McGrawHill's loss was the New York City Ballet's gain as Violete Verdy moved from the translation land of Giselle to the resplendent world of the Swan Quen. Miss Verdy drew enchantment from the atmos phere and gave one of those special performances that faith ful audiences treasure as she lyrically inflected the tragic destiny of the princess en trapped in a swan's body.

description: Ralph Nader asserted yester day that the United States would become a nation of slaves unless safeguards and human values were integrated before it's too late into what he called the unregulated and uncontrolled use of computers.

The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. Nathan J. Harri son of Chicago and the late Mr. Harrison, who was a lawyer in Chicago.

title: Salesmanship for Safeguard
description: The Pentagon announcement, replete with photo graphs, of the first interception of an intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM) by the Spartan antimissile mis sile undoubtedly gave some newspaper readers this week the impression that an important forward step in nuclear defense had been taken. The feat appeared to constitute new evidence that the controversial Safe guard antiballistic missile (ABM) system would work. Unfortunately, there is no warrant for the impression that the development is either new or dependable proof of the Spartan's effectiveness.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Doug Sanders, a male professional golfer best known for the size and variety of his wardrobe, played 18 holes the other day against Carol Mann, the leading money winning female professional golfer. The object of the match was to determine, for all time, that male golfers, nay, male athletes, well, males in general, were superior to females. If Sanders won, it would be a clearcut victory. If Mann won, the entire project would be rethought: After all, there is something strange about a man who travels with 25 pairs of shoes, and, besides, at 6 feet 3 inches, Carol Mann can eat apples off poor Doug's head.

title: Soviet Discloses Cholera Caused Deaths in South
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 2  Soviet health officials said today that the cholera outbreak had caused several deaths but that the spead of the disease had been virtually stopped.

title: GOODELL SHIFTS CAMPAIGN CHIEF
description: Senator Charles E. Goodell, who has become increasingly dissatisfied with his own politi cal campaign, announced yes terday that he was replacing his campaign manager, former Deputy Mayor Robert W. Sweet.

title: Screen: Stranger With a Fast Draw:Van Cleef Heads Cast in 'Sabata' at De Mille Italian Western Also at Other Theaters
description: "Sabata," which opened yesterday at the DeMille and neighborhood theaters, is a very long, hugely eventful, moderately bloody, immoderately inventive, generally good-humored Italian Western that succeeds in a lot of the areas that better, or at least more serious, movies tend to ignore. As heroic fiction, it is stronger on colorful success than on noble character, but it is so energetic and at the same time so tactful about its achievements that I find it impossible not to credit most of its ideas at face valueand sometimes a little more.Sabata (Lee Van Cleef) is a black-cloaked mysterious stranger, with looks of Judex and the manner of Fearless Fosdick, who foils a clever $100,000 bank robbery by the simple expedient of single-handedly shooting to death all seven robbers, and then blackmails their employers into paying him a like amount in hush money.The employers ultimately pay the blackmailboth because they are ostensibly respectable men who in the first place only wanted the money so they could buy Texas with it, which they would then sell to the railroad; and because Sabata, against the usual overwhelming odds, eventually does them all in, and where they're going they won't need it.Sabata is one of those rarities (even among mysterious strangers) who absolutely never make mistakes, never is surprised, and always win, usually by superior fire power, even when their enemies number an army. He is as-sisted (not that he needs it) by a Mexican ne'er-do-well (Pedro Sanchez) and an acrobatic Indian (Nick Jordan) whose leaps and somersaults wonderfully extend the meticulous agility that is central to Sabata's enterprise and to the film's style.Style is really the substance of Sabata's chief adversary, Stengel (Franco Ressel, who has the appearance, but, alas, not the technique, of William Buckley.) Stengel lives, with countless henchmen, in an incredible ranch featuring a decor that ranges from late medieval to early rococo  all in one room. Since Stengel indulges in various effete cruelties and ornamental assassinations, experiencing him is rather as if you had scratched the dust of the desert and discovered, of the sins of the Borgias.And style must be very nearly an article of faith with Frank Kramer (his real name is Gianfranco Parolini) whose graceful camera performs elegant arabesques above the simplicities of a plot for which he is also partially responsible. "Sabata" keeps throwing out almost gratuitous pleasures in movement and designlike the lovely Mario Bava adventure filmsand for this enterprising prodigality Kramer deserves praise.So do the cast members I have mentioned, and also one Gianni Rizzo, as the villainous Judge O'Hara, and William Berger, as a treacherous pal of Sabata who shoots with his banjo. Finally, credit is due to the plucky populace of the film's Daugherty City, Tex. No sooner are they all shot dead (at least once a reel), than they spring back to life for more action in the best traditions of show biz and the spirit of the Old West.

description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 2  Superior Court Judge Charles H. Older ordered the murder trial of Charles M. Manson to proceed today despite the loud protests of a codefendant, Susan Denice Atkins, that she was still too ill to appear in court.

Happily, gone are the days when most of the public, in its naivete, would set tle for the numbered combination plat ters, the spareribs, egg roll, chow mein and so on.

description: VENICE, Italy, Sept. 2 (AP) The 31st Venice Film Fes tital ended last night, and the critics agreed it was a flop. Some are calling for replace ment of the festival's direc tor, Ernesto G. Laura. He is former film critic of the Vati can newspaper L'Osservatore Romano.

They voted 379113 for the deletion, then made the decision unani mous by voice vote. The amendment was sponsored by locals from Brooklyn, Manhat tan and Newark.

description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Sept. 2 (UPI)A Navy spokesman said yesterday that unidentified civilians had deliberately planted explosives near the municipal pier on 10square mile Culebra Island.

title: LATE RALLY LIFTS FUTURES PRICES
description: Corn and soybean futures prices rose yesterday in a late rally after decreasing in price early in the day following two sessions of declining prices. Wheat, which had been off as much as 1 cent a bushel early in the day, also rallied. Trading was fairly active from the opening bell but there were periodsup to 10 minutes at timesof inactivity. An ini tial upward move failed to gen erate sufficient enthusiasm and prices dropped back again. However, buying again turned strong in the closing half hour, particularly in soybeans, wheat and corn.

title: Philippines Declares Emergency as Floods Kill 24.
description: MANILA, Sept. 2A state of national emergency was de clared by President Ferdinand E. Marcos today as floods brought on by three days of heavy rain surged over many parts of Luzon Island, includ ing the Greater Manila area.

title: U.S. HUNTING WAYS TO SALVAGE TRUCE ALONG SUEZ CANAL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2The United States Government urg ently searched today for ways to preserve the tenuous cease fire in the Middle East and to bring about resumption of the ArabIsraeli peace talks. It acted as new American evi dence showed that the num ber of Egyptian missile posi tions in the truce zone had nearly tripled in the last month.

title: Bronx Crash Kills Driver
description: One driver was killed and two others wer slightly injured in a threecar collision yester day on the CrossBronx Ex pressway at White Plains Road in the Bronx, the police re ported. The driver killed was William Dee, 50 years old, of 146 15th Avenue, White stone, Queens.

The blast killed a graduate student and wounded four other persons.

description: Diana Sands, the actress, and her mother were sitting around Miss Sands's West Side apartment one night last June, chatting about their relatives. The talk eventually turned to the actress's nephew, Gary Thomas, who was about to become a father for the first time.
