description: ROSLYN, L. I.; Sept. 3  William H. Walters, who rose from printing apprentice to chief executive officer and chairman of the board of Dia mond International Corpora tion, with annual sales of $500 million, died today in St. Fran cis Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 548 Manhasset Woods Road. Manhasset.

title: Broadcast Music Offers Young Composers Prizes
description: Broadcast Music, Inc., the performing rights licensing organization, is offering prizes totaling $15,000 in its 1970 B.M.I. Awards to Student Corn posers Competition, which is open to entrants who will still be under 26 years old on Dec. 31, 1970. Prizes ranging from $250 to $2,000 each will be awarded. The permanent chair man of the judging panel is William Schuman.

title: Honor Pacts or Lose Jobs, Labor Chief Tells Unions
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) A labor leader warned today that union construction workers faced rising job losses if they did not give a full day's work for their pay, live up to their contracts and stop devastat ing jurisdictional strikes.

title: 4 PIERS PICKETED BY DOCK WORKERS
description: Chelsea longshoremen yester day won the opening skirmish in their fight to prevent the city from turning four idle Hudson River piers into cul tural centers.

title: Savings Bond Sales End Long Redemption Drain
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UPI)Savings bond sales ex ceeded redemptions by $7million last month, breaking string of 20 straight months in which withdrawals topped sales, the Treasury Depart ment reported today.

title: Charts of Races at Belmont
description: 1970, by Triangle Publications, Inc. (The Morning Telegraph)

title: U.S. BIDS SOVIET AND EGYPT AVOID NEW VIOLATIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3The United States appealed to the Soviet Union and the United Arab Republic today to refrain from further violations of the tenuous ceasefire in the Mid dle East and urged an imme diate resumption of the peace talks at the United Nations.

title: Books of The Times
description: I have hated you in every hour that has gone by, I hate you so that I would happily give my life for your death, and happily go to my own doom if only I could witness yours, take you with me into the depths. When I let this hate free, I am almost overcome by it, but cannot change this and do not really know it could be other wise. These words, addressed to Adolf Hitler, were entered in a diary, in August, 1939, by Friedrich Percyval Re c k Malleczewen, or Fritz Reck, as he seems to have been called. He was a Bavarian land owner who lived on his ancestral estate in southern Germany through out the war  an aristocrat, welloff and wellcon nected, the son of an East Prussian Junker family, and a popular novelist by trade. He had begun his diary in May, 1936, at the age of 52, with the portentous news that his friend Oswald Spengler had died. He was to con tinue making entries in it until October, 1944, when his hatred at last caught up with him and he was arrested by the Nazis for evading a draft call (at the age of 60!) and neglecting to say Heil Hitler! in his daily rounds. He died in the Dachau con centration camp the following February, of a bullet in the neck.

title: DOCTORS RETURN TO LINCOLN JOBS
description: Two dozen physicians who walked off their jobs at Lincoln Hospital on Aug. 25 returned to work yesterday, restoring normal service in the hospital's department of obstetrics and gynecology.

title: Marine Acquitted in Death Of a Vietnamese Woman
description: DANANG, South Vietnam, Sept. 3 (AP)A United States Marine lieutenant from Los Gatos, Calif., was acquitted today of a charge of having negligently killed a Vietnamese woman with a sniper rifle.

title: 2 Unions Give Auto Workers $35Million Credit
description: DETROIT, Sept. 3  Two major unions, the Teamsters, and the Steelworkers, pledged today a total of $35million in credits to help build up the strike fund of the United Auto mobile Workers.

title: Paterson Soldier Killed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UPI) The Defense Department an nounced today that Pfc. Robert W. Ortiz of the Army, from Paterson, N. J., had been killed in action in Vietnam.

title: Curb on Mine Inspectors Expected to Be Dropped
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) A Federal official who told mine inspectors to check with Washington before shutting down coal mines for uncorrect ed safety violations acknowl edged today that the policy might have encouraged opera tors to drag their feet on safety, if they had known about it.

title: Immunization Scorned by Many In Texas Diphtheria Epidemic
description: San Antonio, a city of stark contrasts between aircondi tioned affluence and tradition conditioned poverty, is in the grip of the worst diphtheria epidemic in the nation in more than a decade, but few people living there, on either side of the economic tracks, seem to be bothered very much by it all.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: An article in The Week in Review of Aug. 23 quotes former Judge Bernard Botein as advocating elimination from the court system of cases in volving drinking (presumably mere drunkenness not involving the commission of a crime), prostitution, narcotics addic tion, homosexuality and hous ing violations. All of these, it is suggested, should be handled by other agenciesor perhaps not at all, as suggested by some authorities with respect to prostitution and homosexual practices.

title: DR. JOSEPH S. LANDA, DENTAL SPECIALIST
description: Dr. Joseph Simeon Landa, who retired in 1959 as pro fessor in charge of prosthodon tics and cleftpalate rehabili tation at New York University College of Dentistry, died yes terday in Montefiore Hospital after an illness of five weeks. He was 78 years old and lived at 45 Sutton Place South. His office was at 140 East 54th Street.

title: Superb Swiss Restaurants
description: The restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored where indicated.

title: Murder Suspects Fingerprints Found at Tate Home, Jury Told
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 3A Los Angeles policeman testi fied today at the murder trial of Charles M. Manson that the fingerprints of two sus pects in the case were found at the home of Sharon Tate, the slain actress.

title: Mr. and Mrs. Palinkas At Home This Weekend
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Sept. 3 (AP)Pat Palinkas, profes sional football's first woman player, made the Orlando Panthers roster at the final cutdown today but was im mediately suspended for miss ing practice.

title: 5 Airlines Curtail Plans For Suburban Substations
description: Five major airlines, which joined forces six months ago in the experimental operation of three suburban airline ter minals, or satellite checkin stations, announced yesterday that they would discontinue two of them.

title: AMEX STOCKS GAIN IN RISING VOLUME
description: The American Stock Ex change turned in a strong per formance yesterday as the list advanced steadily throughout the session in active trading.

title: Swiss May Try Mall Plan
description: The Mayor of Zurich, Switz erland, said yesterday that he was so impressed with the Lindsay administration's pedes trian mall experiment that he might try it in his own city. The Swiss Mayor, Dr. Sigmund Widmer, made the observation of the experiment that bans traffic in some streets during a courtesy call on Mr. Lindsay at City Hall. The Mayors ex changed photo albums of their respective cities.

title: 7 Arrested in Atlantic City On Bomb Possession Count
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 3 (AP) Six men and a woman were arrested in a hotel here today and charged with possession of a bomb and other offenses.

title: Union Carbide Ends Some Discounting
description: The Union Carbide Corpora tion indicated yesterday that it would refuse after Oct. 1 to offer discounts from its pub lished prices on the ethanola mine group of industrial chemi cals.

title: Screen: Van Cleef Rides:Western 'Barquero' on View at Victoria
description: Lee, Van Cleef gets around. One of his Italian-made Westerns "Sabata," arrived here earlier this week. Add to it now a Colorado-made Western at the Victoria Theater, starringyou guessed it.The newer picture, titled "Barquero," has carefully held to the format of those popular horse operas from abroad: stark color, clanging music, perpetual gunfire, stacks of corpses and a plot heavily punctuated with murderous glares, growls and squints.Rather surprisingly, the second half of the film gets an interesting foothold on reality. There are, so help us, a few quiet stretches, along with a spate of good acting. And one or two characterizations take on persuasion and bite.The picture opens in utter confusion as a band of mercenaries swoops down on a little river-landing outpost. When the smoke clears, the village survivors are crouched on one side of the river, led by a tough barge operator, Mr. Van Cleef. Across the water the bad guys bide their time. For some reason they want the boat for a getaway instead of legging it back over the hills.The very modesty of the setting comes across picturesquely during the tense cat-and-mouse wait, under Gordon Douglas's direction. Four of the players are quite good, with the star leading in a burly, convincing role. Mariette Hartley has two interesting scenes as an earthbound wife. Good, too, are Warren Oates as the chief culprit who becomes unhinged and Kerwin Mathews as his level-eyed partner. And Forrest Tucker, as the Edgar Buchanan of the piece, does well by the few amusing lines.Considering the format, it could have been much, much worse.

title: Retreat From the Moon
description: It cannot have been easy for Dr. Thomas O. Paine to end his tenure as head of NASA by announcing what amounts to a retreat from the moon well before all hopedfor scientific objectives have been achieved.

title: Rabin's Tax Exemption To Get Federal Review
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP)The Internal Revenue Service said today that it would take a hard look at the taxexempt foundation set up by Jerry Rubin, the Yippie leader.

title: Exact Fare on Jersey Bus
description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 3 The Hudson Bus Transportation Company will switch to an exact fare system Monday. The company announced the changeover today, saying it will become effective on one of its four Jersey City routes, the Marion Line. A spokesman said that the drivers had complained about assaults and robberies and that the exactchange sstem was designed to reduce such occurrences.

title: Kentucky Expects U.S. Aid to Improve Strip Mining
description: FRANKFORT, Ky., Sept. 3  Kentucky said today that it expected to get more than S1.5million in Federal research grants for the first attempts to improve the landscapedamag ing methods of strip mining for coal.

title: Met Museum's Moves In Park Face Review
description: A full scale review of the proposed expansion of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in Central Park was an nounced yesterday by City Council President Sanford D. Garelik and Thomas 3, Cuite, the Council's majority leader.

title: Film Protest Almost Real
description: ANTWERP, Belgium (UPI) The script for a movie being shot in downtown Antwerp called for policemen to break up a demonstration, but the police did not get the word. They broke up the demonstra tion and were about to take Robbe de Hert, the movie maker, to jail when they discov ered their mistake.

title: Mayor Calls on Senate To Halt Funds for SST
description: Mayor Lindsay urged the Senate yesterday to halt Fed eral financial support of the supersonic transport (SST) pro gram, calling it a complete misplacement of national priorities and a disastrous misallocation of national re sources. He also said he might seek to forbid supersonic airliners from operating at New York airports.

title: Dr. Cordier's Farewell
description: Dr. Andrew Cordier, in a letter to Columbia Uni versity's 30,000 faculty members, students and em ployes, has expressed his deep gratitude for so much quiet, constructive work in the two years of his presidency. This is a reversal of the proper roles. It is Dr. Cordier who has earned the gratitude and respect of the academic community, beyond the boun daries of Morningside Heights, for charting a rational course out of conflict and chaos that threatened the life of a national institution.

title: France Seeking to Halt IncomeTax Cheating
description: PARIS. Sept. 3The Govern ment began today what prom ises to be a long and tough struggle to get Frenchmen to stop cheating on their income taxes.

title: Bearded Policeman Sues To Get His City Job Back
description: Luther P. Gales, who lost his job as a Housing Authority po liceman last April 18 because he wore a beard, filed suit yes terday for reinstatement and back pay.

title: Menus Suggested
description: In the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: M. K. ARGUS DIES; WRITERNEWSMAN
description: M. K. Argus, a Russianborn writer and journalist, died Mon day of lung cancer in his home at 309 East 87th Street. He was 70 years old.

title: ARMS TALKS CLOSE AS VOTE SUPPORTS TREATY ON SEABED
description: GENEVA, Sept. 3The dis armament conference ended its 1970 session today after achiev ing near unanimity on a draft treaty to prohibit the emplace ment of nuclear weapons or launching platforms on the sea bed outside the 12mile limit.

title: Home Savings and Loan Considers Going Public
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 3The Home Savings and Loan Asso ciation, the $3.3billion institu tion built by the late Howard Ahmanson, is actively consid ering becoming a publicly held corporation, according to a re port today in The Los Angeles Times. Officials of the company could not be reached for com ment.

title: Arms Survey Shows Aid by Soviet Has Rebuilt Arabs to Prewar Power
description: LONDON, Friday, Sept. 4 (AP)Soviet aid in the Middle East during the last year has raised the Arab military strength to its highest level since the eve of the war with Israel in June, 1967, the Insti tute for Strategic Studies said here today.

title: Old New Haven Society Clubhouse to Be Street People's Center
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 3For years, the prim, exclusive Union League was a mainstay of elite society in New Haven. It attracted men of wealth and prestige from the most proper New England stock.

title: Yankee Records
description: Yankee Records

title: Jonathan Cerf, Rosanne Novick Wed in Suburbs
description: Miss Rosanne Novick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Novick of Clifton, N. J., and Jonathan Cerf, the younger son of Bennett Cerf, the publisher and board chairman of Random House, and Mrs. Cerf, were married on Tuesday at The Columns, the home of the bridegroom's parents in Mount Kisco, N. Y.

title: Pentagon BudgetCutting
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3For six weeks, Senate critics of mili tary spending tried to hack away at the Pentagon budget. They got nowhere: their chal lenge to the Safeguard anti missile system, their proposal to restrict payments on the C5A cargo jet and their move to cut $5billion from defense outlays all lost. And yet, according to those on both sides of the debate, the liberal cause  a smaller and more closely controlled military budget won.

title: MATTEO'S DANCERS PERFORM IN PARK
description: Ma tteo's Indo  merican Dance Company is a troupe that is Indian in manner and Ameri can in its sense of theatrical time. It eschews the longueurs that are the recitative of much Indian dance and concentrates its energies on the more im mediately appealing dance passages. Last night, the com pany appeared for the first time this season at The American Dance Festival in Central Park's Delacorte Theater.

title: School Strike Curb Sought
description: NASHUA, N. H., Sept. 3 (UPI)School officials sought a court injunction today against a teachers strike that has dis rupted city schools for three days.

title: RCA Shows New Computer For TimeSharing Users
description: The RCA Corporation un veiled yesterday a new and larger timesharing system for users of computers.

title: Major League Baseball
description: TODAY'S PROBABLE PITCHERS

title: THOMAS J. MACCABE SR.
description: YONKERS, Sept. 3Thomas J. Maccabe Sr., who retired in 1946 after 35 years as an ac tuary with the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, died today in Yonkers Professional Hospital. He was 91 years old and lived at 127 Morsemere Avenue.

title: Plus and Minus on Seabed
description: A limited breakthrough and a major setback have emerged from coincidental negotiations in Geneva involving the oceans. The United Nations Disarmament Committee has endorsed, with only a minor reserva tion by Mexico, a revised SovietAmerican draft of a treaty to prohibit nuclear weapons in the international seabed. Each of the superpowers made concessions to meet objections smaller countries had raised to three earlier versions, so the treaty now has an ex cellent chance of acceptance by the U.N. General Assembly later this month.

title: 76ers Clark Paces Victors In St. John's Charity Game
description: The Reds, coached by Bernie (Red) Sarachek, defeated the Blues, coached by Lou Carne secca, 10389, last night at St. John's in a charity basketball game in which many pro stars competed.

title: Calm Prevails in Cairo
description: CAIRO, Sept. 3Amid furor in Israel about antiaircraft missiles in the Suez Canal zone and sudden anxiety in Wash ington about a possible break down of its peace initiative, an almost Olympian calm prevails in Cairo.

title: Retarded Youths Honored
description: Four mentally retarded youngsters who won medals in the Special Olympics for the mentally retarded, held in Chi cago Aug. 1215, were con gratulated by Mayor Lindsay at a brief City Hall ceremony yes terday. The winners are Jona than McKie, 12 years old, of 133 Waverly Avenue, Brooklyn; Elisa McNeil, 13, of 12816 161st Street, Jamaica, Queens; Harry Negroni, 15, of 1635 Popham Avenue, the Bronx, and Sharon Shaw, 13, of 2175 Lacombe Avenue, the Bronx.

description: OutofTown Exchanges

title: I.C.I.'S PROFIT OFF ON RECORD SALES
description: Imperial Chemical Indus tries, Ltd., one of Britain's largest industrial complexes, reported yesterday that earn ings in the first half of 1970 fell to $184.5million from $218.4million in the yearear lier period. The company blamed higher costs for the profit decline.

title: Apollo 14 Passes Test
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Sept. 3 (UPI)  The Apollo 14 com mand ship, scheduled to set out for the moon Jan. 31, passed its second and last manned test in the simulated outer space of a vacuum chamber today.

title: Store Sales Reported
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3The Commerce Department today estimated last week's depart ment store sales at $734mil lion, down 6 per cent from the yearearlier $782million. Last week's total retail store sales were about $7,036,000,000, lit tle changed from $7,053,000, 000.

title: 2 COAST CAR PLANTS DAMAGED BY BOMBS
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Sept. 3 (AP)  Bombs went off within an hour of each other last night and early today at the Ford plant at Milpitas near here and at the General Mo tors plant at Fremont six miles away.

title: Leo Frederick Burt
description: Leo Frederick Burt, 6 feet 4 inches tall and weighing 185 pounds, was No. 4 oar on the University of Wisconsin jun ior varsity crew. And when he wasn't rowing, he was writ ing about his favorite sport for The Daily Cardinal, the University of Wisconsin's stu dent newspaper.

title: Straub and Lohren Get 71's In Long Island Qualifying
description: GLEN COVE, L. I., Sept. 3 Austin Straub of the Huntington Country Club and Carl Lohren of North Shore posted par 71's to lead the Long Island qualify ing round for the Metropolitan Golf Association open cham pionship at the Glen Head Country Club today.

description: Morning

title: World Unity of Blacks Sought at Parley
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 3  An in ternational Congress of African People opened here today with hundreds of black delegates, mostly young, conterging on the five college campuses of Atlanta University.

description: REPECHAGE SUMMARIES

title: Mauch Suspended 3 Days
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 3 (AP) Manager Gene Mauch of the Montreal Expos was suspended for three days and fined $100 by the National League presi dent, Charles Feeney, today for bumping the home plate umpire, Paul Pryor, in last night's Pittsburgh PiratesExpos game at Jarry Park.

title: Court Backs Army Ban
description: RICHMOND, Sept. 3 (UPI) The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit said today that the Army could forbid antiwar meetings and publications on military posts to preserve discipline and morale. A threejudge panel up held a ruling that the command ing general at Fort Jackson, South Carolina, did not violate First Amendment rights.

title: NEW LEGION CHIEF PLANS P.O.W. DRIVE
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 3 Alfred T. Chamie, a Los An geles lawyer, was elected na tional commander of the Amer ican Legion today in the final session of a fourday conven tion.

title: Burma Reports Battle Toll
description: RANGOON, Burma, Sept. 3 (UPI)Twelve Communist reb els were killed and three wounded in five clashes with Government troops during the second half of August, the Gov ernmentoperated news agency, Burma, reported today. Four teen Government soldiers were reported killed and 24 were missing.

title: U.S. Banks Units Abroad Lifted Assets 79% in 1969
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3As sets of overseas branches of United States banks surged by 79 per cent to $41.1billion last year, with the biggest increase coming in London branches, the Federal Reserve Board re ported today.

title: WAGNER SUPPORTS GOLDBERG SLATE
description: Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner endorsed Arthur J. Goldberg for Governor and State Senator Basil A. Paterson for Lieutenant Governor yester day.

title: Gold Price Up in London; Japan Cool to Asian Plan
description: LONDON, Sept. 3 (Reuters) The London market price of gold today reached its highest level in nearly a year when speculators from the Middle East and the Far East showed renewed interest in buying the bullion.

title: 3 Banks and Savings Office Are Robbed of $13,800 Here
description: Robbers escaped with a total of $13,800 yesterday in four apparently unrelated bank and loan association holdups here two in Manhattan and one each in Brooklyn and Queens, ac cording to the police.

title: HUGH FERGUSON, 69, IN RESEARCH FIELD
description: HYANNIS, Mass., Sept. 3 Hugh S. Ferguson, who retired as president of the National Research Corporation pf Cam bridge in 1965, died here yes terday. He was 69 years old and lived on Main Street in Barn stable.

description: Senator Charles E. Goodell declared here yesterday that the machinery of criminal jus tice had broken down in the city and that the socalled Federal Safe Streets Act had not fulfilled its purpose.

title: Advertising: Plymouth Joins In Gin Race
description: Of the 13.93 million cases of gin sold in this country last year, 1.43 million were imported, mostly from Eng land.

description: Thursday, September 3, 1970

title: EAST GERMAN SETS 1711 VAULT MARK
description: TURIN, Italy, Sept. 3 (AP) Wolfgang Nordwig of East Germany cleared 17 feet 11 inches today for a world rec ord in the World University Games. It was the second world mark of the day.

title: Judith Elen Bob, R. H. Bronstein Married on L.I.
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., Sept. 3Miss Judith Elen Bob, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Murray M. Bob of St. Albans, Queens, was married here this evening at the Town Club to Robert M. Bronstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Bronstein of Merion, Pa. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Eliot Spar.

title: West Point Cadet Loses Fight In Court for Objector Discharge
description: A West Point senior who had been denied a discharge from the Army as a conscientious objector failed yesterday to get a court order directing the Army to release him, as he wished.

title: Australia Bars U.S. Cleric
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 3 The Government has refused a visa to a New York clergy man, the Rev. James R. Mc Graw, who was to have ac companied Dick Gregory, the comedian, to Australia to take part in antiVietnam rallies at colleges later this month. The Minister for Immigration, Phillip Lynch, said that Mr. Gregory had earlier been denied a visa on grounds that his in tended activities here were understood to be of a nature inimical to the object for which Australian troops are fighting in Vietnam.

title: Crime Bill Planned
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, announced today that he would introduce legislation to make the shooting of a policeman or fireman a Federal crime. Mr. Williams said he would intro duce a bill that would enable Federal agents to enter the in vestigation of the murder of a public safety officer within 24 hours of its occurrence.

description: Entertainment Events

title: Transport Notes: T.W.U. Seeks Role
description: The Transport Workers Union demanded yesterday that it be represented on a panel that has been appointed by the Metro politan Transportation Authori ity to study transit workers safety records.

title: They Liked the Way They Looked  Others Didn't
description: The fashions of the seventies are get ting some people into hot water.

title: Gen. Pierre Koenig, Hero of World War II, Dead
description: PARIS, Sept. 3General of the Army Pierre Koenig, one ' of France's most prestigious military leaders in World War II and a leading champion of FrenchIsraeli friendship, died last night at the American Hos pital of Paris in suburban Neuilly, following surgery. He was 71 years old.

title: Cards Return Weatherwax
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 3 (UPI) The St. Louis Cardinals said today that a defensive tackle, Jim Weatherwax, had failed his physical examination and had been returned to the Green Bay Packers, from whom he was obtained yesterday on waivers.

title: Cards Fine Absentee $250
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 3 (UPI) The St. Louis Cardinals fined a linebacker, Jamie Rivers, $250 today for missing one day of practice.

title: Humanistic Psychology Shows Its Force
description: MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Sept. 31 Miami Beach, which is used to bizarre scenes, had never seen anything quite like it. Eight hundred persons were sprawled out on the floor of the main ballroom of the ornate Deauville Hotel, silently touch ing each other with their eyes closed.

title: PHONE RATE RISE GRANTED BY P.S.C.
description: ALBANY, Sept. 3The Pub lic Service Commission gave the New York Telephone Company permission today to raise its rates enough to bring in $120.8 million in additional revenue a year  $16million more than the commission had said earlier that it would allow the utility.

title: Rockefeller Urges More U.S. Arms for Israel
description: Governor Rockefeller called on the Nixon Administration last night to restore the bal ance of power in the Middle East by supplying Israel imme diately with planes and other essential military equipment.

title: Chile Votes for a President Today Amid Uncertainty
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 3 Chile votes for a President to morrow in an election dramatic in uncertainty over who will win and in the danger of vio lence after the results are known.

title: Sports Today

title: Veterans Fight Security Forces in Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Sept. 4 (AP)Forty disabled South Vietnamese war veterans were barricaded in a Governmentowned apartment house today after exchanging gunfire with policemen and soldiers in their campaign for improved benefits from the Government.

title: A Royal Ham Replies To Jersey Man's Call
description: PARSIPPANY, N. J., Sept 3 (AP)The handle is Hus sein and the QTH location is Amman, Jordan, said a voice coming through the loud speaker of Irving Bersak's ham radio.

title: Riggs and Johansson Reach Semifinals in Senior Tennis
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3  Bobby Riggs, the defending titleholder from Plandome, L.I., and Torsten Johansson of Swe den reached the semifinal round of the 52d United States senior grass court tennis cham pionship today at the German town Cricket Club. They will meet Saturday.

title: Air Force Women to Drill

The Air Force said yesterday that 22 women had applied for acceptance in the 16member team at Lang ley Air Force Base, Va.

title: GROUND GAME KEY TO LEHIGH ATTACK
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Sept. 3 Jerry Berger can do about everything expected of a col lege quarterback, as long as the defensive rush does not consist of extremely tall line men. The problem is that Ber ger is only 5feet6inches tall.

title: Madison Blast Suspect Linked To Dynamite in Earlier Attempt
description: MADISON, Wis., Sept. 3  Karleton Lewis Armstrong, one of four young men being sought in connection with the fatal; bombing at the University of Wisconsin, was linked by the authorities today to an attempt ed bombing last Feburary of a power station near Baraboo, Wis.

title: Nixon Is Host to the President of Mexico in California
description: CORONADO, Calif., Sept. 3 President Nixon today wel comed the Mexican President, Gustavo Diaz Ordaz, to what was once a fertile part of Mex ico and is now fertile political country for California Republi cans.

title: Lawyer Teams to Observe Demonstrations Here
description: An experimental group of neutral observers has been or ganized by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York in an effort to reduce vio lence at mass demonstrations.

title: State Blames the Driver In Bus Crash Injuring 15
description: ALBANY, Sept. 3 (UPI) The State Public Service Com mission today blamed the driver, not mechanical failure, for the Aug. 3 bus crash that injured 15 persons in the West chester County village of Haw thorne.

title: RUM CUSTOMER 52 FOR TONIGHT'S PACE
description: YONKERS. Sept. 3Seven pacers will go postward tomor row night in a $25,000 invita tion, with Rum Customer the 52 favorite. Billy Haughton will drive the 5yearoid, owned by Louis and Connie Mancuso, and will leave from the No. 5 slot.

title: Radio
description: Radio

title: City Asks Stations For Time to Rebut TV Gasoline Ads
description: The city is requesting free time from three major tele vision stations here to rebut commercials asserting that new gasolines are helping to reduce air pollution.

title: Horton Is Hospitalized
description: GLENS FALLS, N. Y., Sept. 3 (AP)Edward Everett Horton, the film actor was admitted to Glens Falls Hospital in satis factory condition today for treatment of an undisclosed ail ment. The 83yearold charac ter actor was taken to the hos pital from his Adirondack sum mer home at nearby Lake George.

title: Extradition Move
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 3 (UPI)The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit set a Sept. 11 deadline today for the extradition of Charles D. Watson to Califor nia. The court ordered Watson to be extradited from Texas at that time unless the United States Supreme Court agreed in the meantime to intervene.

title: Australia Will Send Arms To Cambodia, If Necessary
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 3  The Australian Government announced today that it had changed its policy and would now provide arms for Cambo dia, if necessary.

title: Arthur Einstein Jr. Will Marry Miss Mimi Matsner, an Editor
description: Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Fried of New York and East Hampton, L. I., have an nounced here the engagement of Mrs. Fried's daughter, Miss Ingrid Digby Matsner, to Ar thur William Einstein Jr., a partner in the New York advertising firm of Lord, Gel ler, Federico and Partners.

title: BOND PRICES SLIP AS SUPPLY GROWS
description: Bond prices declined rather sharply yesterday as the credit markets paid more attention to this week's buildup in the supply of new issues for sale than to the Commerce Depart ment's report of another down ward revision in corporate cap ital spending plans.

title: Bombing and a Weatherman Myth
description: Marion Delgado  the name chosen by the collec tive that said it committed the bombing of the Army Mathematics Research Cen ter at the University of Wisconsinis a mythical 5 yearold revolutionary boy popularized by the Weather man faction of Students for a Democratic Society.

title: For Status, $100 Shawl Is Answer
description: Someday someone will lib erate us from the struggle for status but, in the mean time, those with the money and the desire are well looked after. Yves Sc Saint Laurent, a couturier of some status himself, inspired by shawls that grandmother used to drape over the grand piano, has come out with a small collection to be draped over pres entday shoulders. The shawls are, as one would expect, large. They are, in fact, 60 inches square, fashioned from silk crepe de Chine and nar rowly fringed. There are three patterns, all featuring roses in various sizes and shapes, and several color combinations. One of the prettiest is an ashes of roses shade blooming on a black background. Bonwit Teller has several designs in the shawls. They are $100 each.

title: U.S. Oarsmen Advance in Repechage
description: ST. CATHARINES, Ontario, Sept. 3The United States crews staged a sharp recovery today at the world rowing championships held on the Royal Canadian Henley course here. Five of the six American boats in competition today qualified for further action, four of them for semifinal races on Saturday and one for the finals on Sunday.

title: Fire at Brooklyn Base
description: Firemen fought a twoalarm blaze at the Brooklyn Army Terminal for more than two hours yesterday afternoon be fore bringing it under control. The fire started in a frame re pair shop near First Avenue and 57th Street. No injuries were reported.

title: Karleton Lewis Armstrong Dwight Alan Armstrong
description: To those who knew them at the University of Wiscon sin, Karleton Lewis Arm strong, 22 years old, and his brother, Dwight Alan Arm strong, 19, had little in com mon except a sense of rest lessness and a penchant for radical rhetoric.

title: Paul Crowell
description: No City Controller, Budget Director or Finance Administrator ever had a more detailed understand ing of New York City's fiscal problems than Paul Crowell. In the three decades he spent at City Hall as a correspondent for this newspaper, he anticipated the computerized miracles of data storage and retriev al by squirreling away in his own head limitless information about every aspect of municipal affairs.

title: Bituminous Coal Output Up
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UPI) The National Coal Associa tion estimated todaythat bitu minous coal production in the United States last week was 11,960,000 tons.

title: Eight Policemen Indicted Over 3 Beatings in Ohio
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) A Federal grand jury has re turned two indictments alleging that eight Cleveland area po licemen violated the civil rights of a television cameraman and two hospital orderlies in sepa rate incidents.

title: Students Decide to End Strike At College for Human Services
description: Students at the College for Human Services voted yester day to end their threeweekold strike and return to classes next Tuesday.

title: National Drop Reported In Losses From Traffic
description: The Insurance Information Institute reported yesterday that in June, for the first time in 1970, the nation's en tire traffic experience deaths, accidents, injuries and total economic loss had shown an improvement.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on the Peace ful Uses of Outer Space 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Ky to Address Rally in U.S.
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 3 (UPI)Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky will visit the United States soon to address a rally on behalf of President Nixon's policy in Vietnam. A spokesman said Mr. Ky had ac cepted an invitation to address a Parade for Victory rally in Washington. The date of his trip has not yet been set.

title: Avon Calling Is Heard At Ogilvy & Mather
description: The door chimes rang at Ogilvy & Mather yesterday and a pleasant voice was heard to say, Avon calling.

title: Kite's 136 Leads Amateur by 3 Shots
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 3 (AP)Tom Kite Jr., a 20year old University of Texas golfer, took the lead at the halfway point of the 70th United States Amatour golf championship to day with a threeunderpar 67 that put him three strokes ahead of Steve Melnyk and Gary Cowan.

title: MexicanAmerican Hostility Deepens in Tense East Los Angeles
description: EAST LOS ANGELES, Calif., Sept. 3Earlier this week, hun dreds of MexicanAmerican youths jammed into a swelter ing news conference where community leaders were com menting on the riot that rocked East Los Angeles last Satur day.

title: Cuba Leads in Aircraft
description: LONDON, Sept. 4 (Reuters) Cuba has more combat, planes than any other country in Latin America and herl armed forces are outnumbered only by those of Brazil and Argentina, the Institute of Strategic Studies said today.

title: Insurance Hearing Set
description: Richard E. Stewart, State Su perintendent of Insurance, said yesterday that he would hold a public hearing at 10 A.M. Sept. 25 at the New York County Lawyers Association, 14 Vesey Street, to discuss the tight market, for burglary and theft insurance. A new law rtstrict ing insurance  policy cancella tions has helped, he said, but further action is required.

title: Canadian Bill Rates Rise
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 3 (Canadian Press)The Government today auctioned $150million of new 91day Treasury bills at an average price of 98.645 and average yield of 5.56 per cent, compared with last week's 98.644 and 5.51 per cent. To day's $40million of 182day bills brought 97.251 and 5.67 per cent, against last week's 97.253 and 5.66 per cent.

title: How Verdy Retains Own Style With the City Ballet
description: As the New York City Bal let's first summer season at the State Theater draws to a close Sunday, it will have proved again that Violette Verdy is one of New York's most beloved ballerinas. The Frenchborn dancer has needed only to step onstage during the current twoweek engagement for the applause to roll in.

title: STOCK PRICES RISE IN A BROAD SWATH
description: Stock prices boomed yester day on sharply higher volume as the trendsetting glamour issues paced the broad ad vance.

title: U.S. Donates $10,000 to Aid Flood Victims in Philippines
description: MANILA. Sept. 3The Unit ed States Government donated $10,000 today to help resettle thousands of slum  dwellers driven from their homes by the threeday floods in Manila and surrounding areas.

title: London Metal Market
description: London Metal Market

title: U. S. JURY INDICTS EXJUDGE OF PERU
description: A former Supreme Court justice of Peru was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in Brookivn on charges of smuggling diamonds worth $750,000 into the United States from Israel.

title: SIEMENS TALKING WITH SOVIET UNION
description: BONN, Sept. 3  The view that West German industry is bracing for more lucrative business with the East har dened today as Siemens, the giant electrical company, an nounced budding prospects of a deal with the Soviet Union.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: INDONESIANS GREETED AT THE HAGUE: President and Mrs. Suharto are flanked by Queen Juliana and Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands. Because of an assault Mon day on the Indonesian Ambassador's residence, strong security measures were taken and Amboinese, who are campaigning for their own independent republic in South Moluccan group of islands, were barred from city. How ever, demonstrators got into courtyard as Mr. Suharto addressed Parliament. He is first Indonesian President to pay such a visit since Indonesia won its independence.

title: Special on Vince Lombardi Scheduled by A.B.C. Tonight
description: The American Broadcasting company will televise Vince Lombardi: What His Life Was MI About, a tribute to the fositball coach who died of can cer yesterday, at 7:30 P.M. to day. The program will pre empt The Flying Nun on Channel 7.

title: CITY FACING LOSS OF 2 HOUSE SEATS
description: Manhattan faces the loss of one of its four members of Congress as a result of the new census returns, and the likely solution may be a mer ger of districts now represented by William F. Ryan and Leon ard Farbstein, both Democrats.

title: Brooklyn Shopping Center to Open in Week
description: New York City's first large regional shopping center opens a week from today in the Mill Basin section of Brooklyn, with big new units of Macy's and Alexander's that look surprisingly similar in appearance.

title: Miss Jonna Gane Will Be Bride
description: JAMESTOWN, N. Y., Sept. 3Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Gane have made known the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Jonna Gane, to Fred Lazarus 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lazarus 3d of Cincin nati.

title: A Teacher With 10 Poems Wins the Welsh Bard Title
description: AMMANFORD, WalesUn der a vast; hot tin roof, 8,000 people acclaimed the winner of the National Eisteddfod of Wales crown competition. Bryan Davies, a 37yearold schoolteacher from Ruabon, Denighshire Wales woo the honor with 10 poems about people and places in the Amman valley.

title: CeaseFire for Vietnam
description: The standstill ceasefire proposal for Vietnam urged on President Nixon by fourteen Senatorsincluding prominent hawks and doves of both partiesis far more than a scheme for a military truce. Its im portance lies precisely in that it addresses the cen tral issue in the war and in the Paris negotiations, the political issue of who is to govern South Vietnam.

title: WORLD CHURCH FUND TO COMBAT RACISM
description: GENEVA, Sept. 3 (AP)The World Council of Churches an nounced today that it would allocate $200,000 to groups that fight racism, including African guerrillas.

title: Art Gallery Wants Works Owned by Deported Forger
description: A Madison Avenue gallery demanded yesterday that the Police department property clerk give up valuable works of art used as evidence in the prosecution of David Stein, art forger, more than four years ago.

title: Theater: Prospect Company Pays Visit to Edinburgh Festival
description: EDINBURGH, Scotland, Sept. 1Britain is fortunate in having many subsidized drama companies, some well knowc, some almost un known, but all of them have a home of their own, a base theater. All of them, that is, except one, for there is the Prospect Theater Company, which is a touring group moving from town to town. For the last few years the Prospect has found some kind of home, or at least a shelter, at the Edinburg Festival, where it mounts most of its new productions before mov ing on round the country. Last year, for example, the company had its most nota ble success so far with pro ductions of Shakespeare's Richard II and Marlowe's Edward II, both starring Ian McKellen.

title: GIANTS AND JETS STUDY OFFENSES
description: The radically inconsistent of fenses of the Giants and Jets were on the teams minds yes terday as they went through final drills for the contests to morrow.

title: GENERAL TIRE BID ON BYERS WEIGHED
description: The A. M. Byers Company of Pittsburgh announced yester day that a plan was under consideration under which the General Tire and Rubber Com pany of Akron, Ohio, would acquire the remaining minority interest in Byers.

title: Roche Eliminates Cox and Laver Beats Stone in 4 Sets at U.S. Open
description: Tony Roche thought he had the day off. Or he thought that that's what Mike Gibson, the referee at the United States Open tennis championships, told him on Wednesday night.

title: GUERRILLAS GET HUSSEIN APPEAL
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 3 King Hussein of Jordan, in a radio speech tonight, appealed for peace between his troops and the Arab commandos here.

title: Industry Blamed in Fish Deaths
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., Sept. 3 (AP)Millions of dead men haden covered Escambia Bay today as fishermen, their profits dwindling after 52 fish kills in 18 months, de manded an end to industrial pollution in the bay.

title: Alan Wilson, 27, Guitarist Of Canned Heat Ensemble
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 3 (UPI) Alan C. Wilson, a member of the rock group, Canned Heat, was found dead in his sleeping bag yesterday behind the home of a friend in Topanga Canyon. He was 27 years old.

title: WHEAT GAINS CUT BY PROFIT TAKING
description: A sharp increase in wheat exports sent the futures of this grain up 3 cents a bushel in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange yesterday but profit taking trimmed the advances late in the session.

title: Hardhats March in Miami
description: MIAMI, Sept. 3 (AP)More than 4,000 working men in hardhats, most of them carry ing small American flags, marched through downtown business streets here tonight to demonstrate their patriotism.

title: Indiana Democrats Pin Hopes on a Young Professor
description: ANDERSON, Ind., Aug. 30  To an outlander, East Central, Indiana looks deceptively rural and Republican. The counties clustered near the Ohio border are flat, sparsely populated and awash with corn fields, their somnolent little farm towns seemingly little changed from the days of James Whitcomb Riley.

title: All CopperExport Curbs Are Discontinued by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) The Commerce Department today lifted all restrictions on exporting copper.

title: Veterans for Peace Simulate the War
description: BERNARDSVILLE, N. J., Sept. 4More than 100 veter ans and reservists in battle dress began a march today through western New Jersey toward a Labor Day peace rally in Valley Forge, Pa., where they will demand an immediate United States withdrawal from South Vietnam.

title: Pledge of Allegiance Law Overturned in Maryland
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 4 (AP)A Circuit Court judge in Anne Arundel County yesterday overturned a law requiring all students and teachers in Mary land public schools to begin each day with a Pledge of Al legiance to the United States flag.

title: LIBYA IN ACCORD WITH OCCIDENTAL
description: The Occidental Petroleum Company announced in Los Angeles yesterday that it had reached a mutually accepta ble agreement with the Libyan Government ending a sharp dispute over oil prices.

title: Wholesale Price Index Fell Last Month by Only 0.4%
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4The final version of the August wholesale price index showed a slightly smaller decline than the preliminary figures, the Labor Department reported today.

title: MISTAKE ON 18TH THWARTS MURPHY
description: WETHERSFIELD, Conn. Sept. 4As Pete Brown finished in fourway tie for the lead in the $100,000 Greater Hartford open golf tournament today, the scorer's tent, the clubhouse and the press tent had been evacu ated because of a bomb scare.

title: Diaz Ordaz Says Trade Curbs by U.S. May Threaten Latin Economy
description: CORONADO, Calif., Sept. 4 (AP)President Gustavo Diaz Ordaz of Mexico has sounded a warning that United States re strictions on international trade may imperil the economy of Latin America.

title: 2 Bombing Suspects, Unrecognized, Freed
description: LITTLE FALLS, N. Y., Sept. 4For about an hour yester day afternoon the police in this Mohawk Willey commu nity had in their custody two of the four young men sought in the bombing of the Army Mathematics Research Center on the University of Wisconsin campus on Aug. 24.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Daylight Saving Time

title: Football Transactions
description: GREEN BAYAativated Dale Livingston, kicking specialist. Released Glen Keppy, Platteville State defensive tackle.

title: Con Ed. Temporarily Cuts Power by 5%
description: With Consolidated Edison's generating capacity taxed by airconditioners in hot, humid weather, the utility cut voltage by 5 per cent in the city and Westchester County yesterday and appealed to customers to trim electric usage.

title: Met Opera Tickets Go on Sale Tomorrow
description: Tickets will go on sale to morrow at noon at the Metro politan Opera box office for the first two weeks of the com pany's new season, which be gins Sept. 14. A revival of Verdi's Ernani, absent from the repertory for six years, will be the openingnight opera.

title: Television
description: 5:30 (4)Modern Farmer

title: Institute Honors Chemist
description: PHILADEDPHIA, Sept. 4 (AP)  The Franklin Institute an nounced today that it would present its John Price Wetherill Medal this year to Paul D. Bart lett, Erving Professor of Chem istry at Harvard. The institute said Professor Bartlett would be honored for many pioneer ing contributions in the field of physical organic chemistry:

title: U.S. SEEKS TO CURB USE OF JOB TESTS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court today to limit employers use of apti tude tests and educational re quirements that have the effect of retarding Negroes employ ment opportunities.

title: Ky and the Victory Rally
description: There is probably no legal or constitutional reason why Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky should not come to the United States next month to participate in the Rev. Carl McIntire's March for Victory in Wash ington. But that does not keep the projected visit South Vietnam's Number Two from being objection able on grounds of taste, propriety and judgment.

title: GETTING OUT WAS HALF THE BATTLE
description: The suitcases told the story.

title: Many Having Abortions Here Journey From Out of Town
description: A sizable number of women are coming here from out of town to get abortions under the state abortion reform law that went into effect July 1, ac cording to statistics made pubH lic yesterday by the city.

title: U.S. Nonenvoy in Egypt
description: CAIRO, Sept. 4Spanish Embassy. a voice answers when someone wishes to tele phone Donald Clayton Ber gus, the chief United States diplomatic representative in the. United Arab Republic.

title: BERTRAM WORK, 68; LED AIRCRAFT FIRM
description: Bertram Work, former pres ident of the Ireland Aircraft Company of Garden City, L.I., died Thursday in St. John's, Antigua, according to word received here yesterday. He was 68 years old and lived in Hicksville. L. I.

title: Antiques: Pewter of 1500's and 1600's
description: Now is the time for pewter collectors to acquire varieties of the 16th and 17th centuries that are beginning to dis appear from the market.

title: Lack of Size Expected to Keep Boston U. Running at Minimum
description: BOSTON, Sept. 51t is diffi cult to believe that Larry Na viaux and his Boston University football squad can equal last year's 91 regularseason won lost record, the finest in the Terriers history.

title: Commune Built by Republican Types
description: DUBLIN, N. H.T. T. Liang stood in the middle of the broad rolling lawn and moved his hands gently through the air in imitation of a white crane flapping its wings. Be hind him two dozen persons mirrored his every move with cranelike gestures of widely varying gracefulness.

title: REBOUND IS MADE IN NEW OFFERINGS
description: The newissue market stage a strong rebound this week from the depressed levels that have prevailed during the last few months. Four companies mace their first public offering of their shares this week and two of the issues were very well re ceived. Last week only one company we nt public.

title: Soviet Plans to Return A Space Capsule to U.S.
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 4.The Soviet Union announced to day that it had found an ex perimental capsule from the United States Apollo space program and would turn it over to a United States Coast Guard cutter in the northern port of Murmansk tomorrow.

title: Turkish Bus Collision Kills 15
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 4 (AP)  Fifteen persons were killed when two buses collided in a dust cloud raised by an accident involving two trucks on a highway near Istanbul, the police reported today.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Article 1  No Title

title: CAMBODIA DRIVE BEGUN BY SAIGOV
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 4 (UPI)  One thousand South Vietnamese rangers moved across the Cambodian border today against Commu nist forces in the socalled Fish hook area, military spokesmen reported. They said the action took place 52 miles west of Saigon and involved two bat talions.

title: NIXON BIDS JEWS HAPPY NEW YEAR
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Sept, 4 (UPI)President Nixon today wished Americans of the Jewish faith a new year of peace and happiness

title: 98 YACHTS MAKE A FAST GETAWAY
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 4 Hairraising downwind starts in a southwester of 25 knots and better sent 98 yachts on their way today under twisting, writhing, hardtohandle spin nakers in the Stamford Yacht Club's 36th annual Vineyard Trophy Race.

title: JAYS DEFEAT BULLS IN OPENER, 22 TO 21
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Sept. 4 The Jersey Jays, newcomers to the Atlantic Coast Football League, made a successful de but at Hofstra Stadium tonight by defeating the Long Island Bulls, 2221, in the season opener for both teams.

title: United Jersey Banks Elects
description: ELIZABETH, N. J. Sept. 4 William E. Shackleton of Ro selle has been elected treasurer of United Jersey Banks, which will be the state's largest multi bank holding company when it becomes operational this fall. Mr. Shackleton, president of the Central Home Trust Com pany here, began his banking career in 1930 with the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Com pany in New York.

title: KEY JET POSITIONS AT STAKE TONIGHT
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 4  Three players will be under Weeb Ewbank's microscope when the New York Jets try to stabilize their squad for the approaching National Football League season in tomorrow night's exhibition game with the New Orleans Saints.

title: GUARDS BACK ON JOB AT TWO CITY PRISONS
description: The Department of Correc zion reported yesterday that work attendance by correction officers at the city reformatory at Rikers Island and at the Women's House of Detention in Greenwich Village had re turned to normal.

title: I.R.S. to Set Up L.I. Facility; Jobs Are Expected for 4,000
description: The Internal Revenue Service plans to set up a dataprocess ing center on facilities leased from the Town of Brookhaven on Long Island, and expects to hire 4,000 people to staff it.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Opera Tonight

title: Classic Sculpture Is a Real Puzzler
description: At first glance, Miguel Berrocal's MiniDavid sculp ture looks like a piece of an cient classical sculpture that had been smashed, its frag ments put together again and the whole assemblage silvered. But the 5inchtall torso by the Spanishborn, 37yearold artist who now makes his home in a Renaissance palazzo outside Verona is actu ally a puzzle. Swivel the neck of the nickelplated metal figure and it disassembles, piece by piece, into 22 parts. Putting it together is some thing else again, with or without instructions. De pending on skill, it takes from minutes to hours. But the packaging helps. Ber rocal designed every aspect of this ingeniously conceived package, except the card board carton it comes in. Inside the carton is a tissue thin poster. It is an illustra tion showing how this puz zle is assembled.

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: Obituary 3  No Title

title: 2 Algerians Held in Israel Reported on Hunger Strike
description: PARIS, Sept. 4 (Reuters)  The Algerian charge d'affaires, Mourad Bencheikh, said here tonight that his government was becoming increasingly con cerned over the holding of two Algerians in Israel.

title: Egypt Denies Violations; Moscow to Study Charges
description: CAIRO, Sept. 4The United Arab Republic today rejected United States charges of cease fire violations as completely removed from the truth.

title: 70 Pupils Feared Dead In India as a Boat Sinks
description: NEW DELHI, Sept. 4 (AP) A boat taking a group of school children to a festival capsized in the flooded Krish na River yesterday and near ly 70 were feared to have drowned according to Indian press reports.

title: EXTRADITION FOUGHT BY BLACK PANTHERS
description: DENVER, Sept. 4 (AP)At torneys for two men wanted in Connecticut on charges of tnurder and kidnapping ap pealed to the United States District Court here today to prevent their extradiion.

title: Soviet Cites Desire for AccordU.S. Envoy Confers at Kremlin
description: MOSCOW, Sept 4The So viet Union, affirming its desire for a political settlement in the Middle East, has informed the United States that it will study Washington's charges that the United Arab Republic violated the Middle East ceasefire agree ment by moving new Soviet missiles into place near the Suez Canal.

title: Radio
description: 12:05 P.M., WNCN: Opera High lights with Francis Robinson. Julius Caesar Handel

title: Indian Head Is Proud of Its Liquidity
description: The mark of a merchant is his sales ability, but in too many instances failure to grasp the essentials of cap italization and investment has led merchants and man ufacturers into difficult po sitions. The lack of liquidity, for instance, is the bane of many corporations today.

title: Charts of Races at Belmont
description: Friday, Sept. 4. Fifth day. Weather cloudy, track fast.

title: KY TRIP FOR A RALLY DISCOURAGED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (UPI) The South Vietnamese Em bassy is understood to have advised Saigon that a visit to Washington next month by Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky to address a marchforvictory rally would not be wise.

title: TURNOVER SWELLS AS STOCKS CLIMB
description: The stock market moved im pressively higher yesterday and closed with a flourish on the eve of the long Labor Day week end.

title: Mrs. Meir Advances Trin
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 4Pre mier Golda Meir advanced today by a month the sched ule for her planned visit to the United States, which is now to begin within two or three weeks.

title: Books of The Times
description: Although Taplinger is performing a pub lic service in making available Ernest New man's 35yearold study of Franz Liszt, that fact will not make the book any more palatable. It must be one of the oddest books in the musical canon. It is an unrelieved, sustainedly hostile, petulant excoriation of the pianist and composer: his character, life and career. And

title: TRADING IS MIXED IN COMMODITIES
description: Contrary to the usual pre holiday type of activity, trad ing was mixed and active yes terday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Criticism From Rhodesians
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Sept. 4Leaders of Rhodesia's main religious denominations united today to condemn the World Council of Churches decision to give financial aid to guer rilla activities by African na tionalists.

title: Roundup: Corkins Begins Drive to Reshape Image
description: Michael Patrick Corkins, a highstrung young man with a tough exterior, has been assured a place in the major league record books but he doesn't particularly cherish the distinction.

title: Bus Crash Kills 9 in Chile
description: ANTOFAGASTA, Chile, Sept. 4 (Reuters)Nine persons were killed and several were badly injured early today when bus overturned a mile and half from here. Many of the passengers were on their way to vote in the presidential elec tion at Arica, 375 miles north of here, police said.

title: 5Nation Group Seeks Ban On Arms for South Africa
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 4 (AP)President Ken neth D. Kaunda of Zambia will lead a fivenation delegation to France, Britain and West Ger many to try to persuade them not to sell arms to South Africa, he announced today following the conference here of the lead ers of 41 African states.

title: Topics: Genetic Manipulation and Morality
description: The acceleration of biological engineering has been urged be fore Congress by Nobel Lau reate Dr. Joshua Lederberg. He has called for the establishment of a National Genetics Task Force to increase the momentum of efforts aimed at unlocking the genetic code of man. Such a breakthrough in biology could lead to the prevention of many illnesses whose origin is wholly or partially in the genetic code.

title: Preseason Football
description: Preseason Football

title: RAISE OVER 6% ENDS CANADA MAIL TIEUP
description: OTTAWA, Sept. 4The Gov ernment lifted its 6 per cent wage increase ceiling today to settle a yearlong dispute with the nation's 27,000 letter car riers and postal clerks.

title: Ulan of U.S. Sets 400Meter Record In Track at Turin
description: TURIN, Italy, Sept. 4 (AP) Tom Ulan of Rutgers University gained the United States 20th gold medal today in the sixth World University games by winning the 400meter run in 45.9 seconds for a games rec ord.

title: Dance: Kirov in London
description: LONDON, Sept. 2The six week season at the Royal Festival Hall, which Lenin grad's Kirov Ballet completes this coming weekend, has been curiously successful. The concert hall is far from an ideal place for ballet, and the Kirov has been forced into presenting largely divertissement programs that can never show, the full scope of this great company. Yet the dancing has been so good that no one has had time to worry about other short comings.

title: Jersey Crash Kills Youth
description: MAHWAH, N. J., Sept. 4 (AP)One person died and four were injured in a twocar crash in this Bergen county com munity this morning. Thomas Mullen, 21 years old, of Elmira, N. Y., was killed. Margaret Mullen, 19, of Elmira; Beth Terry, 19, of Warwick, N. Y.; David Illman of Iselin Park and David Pflomm of Ridgewood were injured.

title: U.S. Offers to Cut Strings On Aid if Other Nations Do

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) George Meany said today that the nation's workers would observe Labor Day in an angry mood over inflation and reces sion and would be determined to win big wage increases.

title: and Washington's Role
description: What can the United States do at this stage redress the situation? To call on Israel, as Washington his now done, to proceed forthwith into negotiations will yield, few results without a demonstration that the United States intends to carry out its renewed promise not to permit Israel's security to be adversely affected. In the last year, vast quantities of Soviet arms have been shipped to Egypt and other Arab states. Soviet military advisers in Egypt have increased from 41,000 to 10,000. Sovietoperated SAM3 missiles and rapidfire cannon have been brought in to provide lowaltitude protection for Egypt's SAM2 air defenses.

title: FOUR TV NEWSMEN ARE REPORTED DEAD
description: The National Broadcasting Company broadcast an uncon firmed report yesterday that its correspondent Welles Harigen, captured in Cambodia on May 31, had been killed by the North Vietnamese.

title: ELCOR CHEMICAL AGAIN HAS A LOSS
description: The Elcor Chemical Corpora tion announced yesterday that its net loss in the fiscal year ended June 30 increased to $8,786,136 from a deficit of $4,703,895 in the preceding fiscal year. Results for fiscal 1970 in clude an extraordinary loss of $4,897,253 and a deficit from discontinued operation of $1,017,371. The results for fis cal 1969 include an extraordi nary loss of $3,925,000 and a loss from discontinued opera tions of $328,000. Sales from continuing operations rose to $29,302,853 in fiscal 1970 from $17,003,621 in 1969.

title: Sewerage Aid for Rahway
description: RAHWAY, N. J., Sept. 4 The Interior Department yes terday approved a $1.3 million grant to the Rahway Valley Sewage Authority for the ex pansion and conversion of treatment facilities, the office of Senator Clifford P. Cab,: here announced today. The grant brings Federal funds received for the project to a total of $5.4million, with $10.9million yet to be allocated.

Coletti, an officer of Local 813 of the teamsters union and former president of the Long Island Federation of Labor, was killed today at 2 A.M. in an automobile collision on Southern State Parkway, one mile west of Nassau Road, here. He was 47 years old and lived in Farmingdale. The driv er of the other car, Michael Hart, 19, of 60 Rodney. Place, Rockville Centre, was taken to Nassau Hospital.

Rank Organisation made a small gain on, reaction to recent earnings reports, but other leaders drifted lower.

title: OS. PAIR UPSETS FAVORED AUSSIES

title: U.A.W. Gives Chrysler Notice
description: DETROIT, Sept. 4 (UPI)  The United Auto Workers ex changed termination  of  con tract notices with the Chrysler) Corporation today and sched uled talks with the Big Three auto makers through the Labor Day weekend to try to avoid a Sept. 15 strike. The notice to Chrysler, one of two strike targets, was a formality re quired to end the threeyear contract expiring Sept. 14.

title: Tia Pan an Easy Winner

title: Blood Needed
description: The response by New Yorkers to an appeal by hos pitals for blood donations has exceeded expectations. Lines formed at some donation centers; Mayor Lind say led a parade of donors who contributed more than 500 pints within several hours after the initial appeal went out. But, encouraging as this response has been, the need for additional blood donations continues. It will remain acute through this holiday weekend. Any one in position to donate blood can help ease the crisisand keep an ailing New Yorker aliveby tele phoning UN 17200 for an appointment.

title: 9 CITIES TO DRAFT ANTIBOMB ACCORD

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4  The United States Bureau of Mines abandoned a rule today that had required its coal mine safety inspectors to telephone Washington for permission be fore closing mines that had failed to correct violations of Federal safety regulations.

title: Film: Jerry Lewis at War:'Which Way to Front?' on Local Screens
description: Even the weakest and flabbiest Jerry Lewis comedies usually shine momentarily with some truly fine, funny mimicry. Such is the case in "Which Way to the Front? The Warner color release opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters.The picture has a rather original idea. The trouble is that each gag is painstakingly repeated, flattening the pace and squelching the sparkle. Could be, as before, that Lewis's triple undertaking as star, director and producer simply weighs the project down.The new comedy opens brightly and tarty, with Lewis as a millionaire tycoon classified 4-F during World War II. He airily bands together a group of fellow rejects into a small private "army," floats the boys overseas on his yacht and sneaks them into the Italian mountain lair of some key Nazi officers. The idea is for Lewis to impersonate a German bigwig and somehow turn the tide of the war.All this takes about an hour, a fairly amusing hour adhering to the old Lewis format, with the star front and center and his bewildered "recruits" alongside, among them Jan Murray, John Wood and Steve Franken. Injections of documentary footage suggest a war actually going on.Disguised as a goateed Nazi officer and spewing a gutteral falsetto, Lewis is quite funny for a while. But it wears thin. Fortunately, it takes two to tango, even in Jerry Lewis's Third Reich. And this cues in a really hilarious scene toward the enda warm reunion and strategy session between Lewis and Sidney Miller, who does a devastatingly clever take-off on Hitler, no less. Here, finally, the picture, and the dialogue of the two screen writers really shines.This sequence almost makes the rest of the picture worth sitting through, with Lewis even stepping aside a bit for Miller's sputtering Hitlerian lunacy, which includes yelps about '"Eva" and the cooking at Berchtesgaden."Who is that?" abruptly asks the Fuhrer, pointing to a human speck in a wall photo of a huge Nazi rally. "That's Max," he adds slyly."Max who?" says Lewis. "Max no difference!" screams Miller and they both howl. It plays much funnier than it might sound.There are no curvy cuties this go-round. But credit Lewis for also recruiting that durable doll, Kaye Ballard, as a volcanic Italian in one rib-tickling bit. The picture also happens to be clean. And on that happy note, let's leave itat least to the children.
