description: EL KHANA, Jordan, Sept. 10  Passengers and crew members of a British airliner that was hijacked and flown here yesterday told visitors today that their Arab com mando captors had provided them with no food in the al most 24 hours since the plane landed.

title: JOHN T. DUFFY
description: ORADELL, N. J., Sept. 10 John T. Duffy, a circulation sales representative for The New York Times, who had worked for The Times 50 years, died today at his home after a long illness. He was 64 years old and lived at 479 Bergen Boulevard.

title: CITY INQUIRY DUE ON FUELOIL COST
description: Benjamin Altman, the city's Commissioner of Rent and Housing Maintenance, said yes terday that he had asked the Corporation Counsel to investi gate rumors that fuel oil com panies were rigging prices.

title: The Cast
description: The Cast

title: Italy to Shift Funds From Roads and Rails to Social Reforms
description: ROME, Sept. 10  Premier Emilio Colombo announced today that his monthold Government had decided to slew construc tion of new railroads and superhighways In a socialmind ed shift of economic priorities.

title: INTERNATIONAL LEAGUE
description: INTERNATIONAL LEAGUE

title: Permit Granted for WaterTunnel Work in Park
description: Parks Commissioner Aug ust Heckscher reluctantly granted a permit yesterday for digging a shaft for a water tunnel in Central Park.

title: 50,000 EXPECTED AT STADIUM GAME
description: Southern University and North Carolina A. and T. will be quite serious when they Meet in the third annual Invita tion FOotball Classic at Yankee Stadium tonight, but there will be Plenty of fun arid frolic be fore and after the game.

title: S.E.C. BACKS N.A.S.D. ON MAY PENALTIES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 The Securities and Exchange Commission upheld today decision by the National Asso ciation of Securities Dealers that a securities underwriter had received an unreasonably high compensation when the stock he received as part of the underwriting deal was taken into account. The case involved May & Company, a brokerage firm in Portland, Ore., and a public offering, in 1968, of the stock of Fibers, Inc.

title: Harvard Has Good Backfields, But Interior Lines Are Weak
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 10 In his 13 seasons as head football coach at Harvard, John Yovicsin brought the Crimson back to respectability, even moments of glory. Under Yovic sin, Harvard shared three Ivy League championships and completed an undefeated cam paign in 1968 by tieing Yale in that memorable 2929 finale.

title: City Moves to Review poverty Fund Cuts
description: As demonstrators shouted in the streets below, a city anti poverty panel recommended last night reconsideration of proposed cuts in the antipov erty program. The proposal had angered Puerto Rican commu nity leaders.

title: Plan for DecentralizedSchool Funds Is Criticized
description: The Board of Education's proposed plan to allocate Fed eral and state funds for dis advantaged pupils to the 31 community districts under de centralization was sharply criticized yesterday. Remarks ranged from, a waste of money to it's illegal.

title: Belmont Jockeys
description: Belmont Jockeys

title: BIG BOARD OFFICER ASKS RATE CHANGE
description: William C. Freund, vice pres ident and chief economist of the New York Stock Exchange, suggested yesterday that com mission rates for stock trans actions be made to fluctuate in recognition of the cyclical na ture of the securities business.

title: Mercury Hazard Found Nationwide
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 10 Mercury pollution, which suddenly emerged as a new environmental problem six months ago to worry offi cials, industry and the pub lic, has proved a far more widespread hazard than was expected.

title: Planeload of Supplies Flies to Hijack Victims
description: GENEVA, Sept. 10 (Reu ters)A DC6 airliner loaded with supplies for use by the nearly 300 airline hostages held in the Jordanian desert by Palestinian commandos left Amman early today.

title: BIG BOARD LOWER ON LIGHT VOLUME
description: Stock prices moved low er yesterday for the second straight session as the mar ket's worriestension in the Middle East and a possible automobile strike in Detroit remained foremost in the minds of investors.

title: Flat Tires Close Schools
description: SAUGUS, Mass., Sept. 10 (UPI)Classes at all public schools in Saugus were can celed today after it was dis covered that the tires on the community's 19 school buses had been slashed. The police blamed vandals.

title: Scott Calls Vote Mistake
description: WASHINGTON, Sept, 10 (AP) The Senate Republican floor leader, Hugh Scott of Pennsyl vania, said today that he had made a mistake in voting to confirm President Nixon's nom inatkiii of G. Harrold Carswell to be aSupreme Court Justice. Judge Carswell was defeated this week in his bid to be nom inated as the Republican Sen ate candidate in Florida.

title: Armed U.S. Guards Reported Ordered On Flights Abroad
description: A contingent of Federal armed guards will begin flying on international flights of Unit ed States airlines starting to morrow, according to highly placed sources here and in Washington. The initial group will consist of some 100 Treasury agents, divided about equally between Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines.

title: Valentino and Ben Kahn Show Furs in. Twin Bill
description: What lovely advantages there are to be sitting under a corporate umbrella, par ticularly when it's raining $1,000 bills. The Kenton Corporation, which owns Ben Kahn furs, also has Valentino in the family. Yesterday, the siblings joined hands to pre sent some of the prettiest furs of the season.

title: JANET FRENCH
description: Janet French, a senior copy writer at SSC & B Inc., 575 Lexington Avenue, an interna tional advertising agency, died yesterday at Memorial Hospi tal. She lived at 136 East 56th Street.

title: The Wild Child Raises Curtain
description: As if to satisfy the in creasing curiosity about Nat ural Man, that is, man un contaminated by civilization, there began to be found throughout Europe in the 17th and 18th centuries all sorts of wild children, boys and girls who had apparently been raised in messy but graceful states by wolves and bears, and by just about everything ex cept kangaroos, which aren't often found in Europe in any state.

title: Faint Hope Raised As Polemics Ease At Peace Parley
description: PARIS, Sept. 10  Accusing each other of taking inflexible stands, participants in the Viet nam peace talks remained stale mated today at the 83d meet ing. The Vietnamese Communists again demanded the unilateral withdrawal of American troops and the ouster of the present Saigon Government before prog ress could be made at the talks here. But faint hopes were raised because of a reduction in the polemics at the three hour meeting and because of a softening from last week in the position taken by the Vietcong, press spokesman on the make up of a provisional government for South Vietnam.

title: 17 Films Bow as Festival Opens Here
description: The Eighth New York Film Festival opened yesterday at Lincoln Center in a 13hour whirl of sometimes overlap ping events in which 17 films were shown.

title: Cairo Charges U.S. Undermines Truce
description: CAIRO, Sept. 10The United Arab Republic warned today that the United States.was un dermining the 90day cease fire and Middle East peace ef forts by its decision, reported yesterday, to sell 18 more Phantom fighterbombers to Is rael by the end of the year.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Article 4  No Title

title: New Books
description: A Classical Storybook, edited by Morris Bishop (Cornell Univer sity, $6.50). Nineteen Greek and Roman stories.

title: Wednesday's Fights
description: TokyoKuniaki Shibata, 130 pounds, Japan, outpointed Kim Hyon, 129, South Korea, 10 rounds.

title: Foreign Affairs: Skyjack Gnats and Sledges
description: Throughout its history the United States has had intermit tent trouble with Arab pirates and kidnappers. Our first over seas conflict was that with Tripoli (18011805).

title: AMEX PRICES DIP IN SLOW TRADING
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange finished mixed yes terday for the second consecu tive session in slow trading.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Entertainment Events

title: An Italian, Restaurant With Difeerente
description: The restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cast Credit cards are honored where indicated.

title: Bernstein, in Tokyo, Assays Japanese Character
description: TOKYO, Sept. 10  To Leonard Bernstein, the Japa nese are a people who have wrapped themselves in layer after layer of rules, cour tesies honorifics and bowing as protection against an in ner violence.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Long, 66, Recalled to Run Company
description: In a highly unusual move, Texaco, Inc., recalled from re tirement its former chairman, Augustus C. Long, to take over the company's management.

title: Market Summary
description: Thursday, Sept. 10, 1970

title: Mazzinghi Outpoints Pace
description: MILAN, Italy, Sept. 10 (AP)  Sandro Mazzinghi of Italy gained a 10round split deci sion tonight over Eddie Pace of Los Angeles in a middleweight fight in outdoor Vigorelli Ve lodrome. Mazzinghi weighed 160 pounds, Pace 161.

title: List of U.S. War Dead for Week Put at 87
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 10 (UPI)United States headquarters reported today that 65 Americans were killed fighting in Vietnam last week and added to the list 22 names of those killed in a helicopter crash Aug. 27. The total, 87, was the highest reported in 10 weeks.

title: SCHOOL START OFF IN PHILADELPHIA
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10 (UPI)A judge today ordered the city's 275 public schools reopened tomorrow but then agreed to postpone the effec tive date of his injunction pend ing a hearing Monday.

title: $270Million Set For Ore Expansion In Canadian Plant
description: The Iron Ore Company of Canada, Ltd., a joint venture of United States and Canadian mining and steel concerns, said yesterday it would spend about $270million in United States funds to enlarge and improve an ironore complex that strad dles the QuebecLabrador boundary.

title: Belmont Entries
description: Belmont Entries

title: U. S. Panel Blames Air Control System in Crash
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP)The National Transporta tion Safety Board blamed de ficiencies of the Federal Avia tion Administration air traffic control system today for an aerial collision near Indianapo lis a year ago in which 83 people were killed.

title: KENNEDY ARGUES VOTING AGE CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 Senator Edward M. Kennedy told a threejudge Federal Dis trict Court today that Congress responded to an invitation from the Supreme Court when it passed the statute that lower ed the voting age to 18 years.

title: Mrs. Henry Nelson Rose, Mother of U.S. Officials, 93
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 10Mrs. Grace Chapman Rose, who with her late husband, Henry Nelson Rose, had been active in the oil, coal and molding sand busi ness, died Aug. 28. She was 93 years old, and formerly lived in Columbus, Ohio.

title: Yonkers Results
description: Yonkers Results

title: Mayor Offers Leary's Job To Detroit's Commissioner
description: The job of Police Commis sioner has been offered by May or. Lindsay to Detroit's Police Commissioner, Patrick V. Mur phy.

title: Bridge Semifinals in Trial Matches   For World Play Begin Tonight
description: The semifinal trial matches that will help to determine part of the North American representation in the 1971 world championship in For mosa begin here tonight at the New York Hilton. The matches will be of 144 deals and will end Sunday.

title: PLAN FOR HIJACKING CALLED A MONTH OLD
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 10 (AP)  Palestinian guerrillas started to plan this week's air plane hijackings shortly after the United Arab Republic and Jordan accepted the proposal for a Middle East ceasefire, a spokesman for the commandos said today. The ceasefire began Aug. 7.

title: ROSTER PROBLEMS GROIN FOR GIANT
description: Life was more hectic than usual in the training camps of the Giants andJets yesterday as both clubs prepared for their final preseason games.

title: Outlook at a Glance
description: PROSPECTHarvard is coming off a losing season after a decade of success under John Yovicsin. This is his last year. His players are determined to send him off a winner.

title: O'BRIEN EXCORIATES PARTY EXTREMISTS
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 10 (UPI) The Democratic National Chair man, Lawrence F. O'Brien, said today that extreme and irre sponsible statements by some socalled Democrats might hurt the party in the fall elec tions.

title: Money
description: Thursday, Sept. 10, 1970

title: Carter Scores Upset in Georgia; Will Meet Sanders in a Runoff
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 10Geor gia voters, both Democrats and Republicans, brushed aside sea soned politicians and gave im pressive margins to their op ponents in the state's first joint primary for governor.

title: Advertising: Seagram Piping Louder Tune
description: Seagrams Distillers, eager to move its fiveyearold 100 Pipers Scotch brand line into the bestseller list, is about to start a new advertising campaign through its new agency and adopt a new mar keting stance as well.

title: Market Place:
description: Shareholders, of Benguet Cdnsolidated, Inc., flew into a tizzy yesterday on the heels of an announcement by the Bahamas Government that a Royal Commission wouldlook into the future of Freeport, Grand Bahama Island.

title: U.S. CANADAASKED TO SAVE THE LAKES
description: TORONTO, Sept. 10Eight American states and three Canadian provinces called on Washington and Ottawa today to give the International Joint Commission new powers to help combat air and water pol lution in the Great Lakes re gion.

title: U.S.BACKED BOND WILL YIELD 8%
description: A longterm issue of bonds guaranteed by the Federal Gov ernment was priced yesterday to yield 8 per cent.

title: Executive Changes
description: Edward J. Hudson has been elected chairman of J. Ray McDermott & Co. filling the post left vacant by the death of R. Thomas McDermott July.

title: Charts of Races at Belmont
description: Thursday, Sept. 10. 10th day. Weather cloudy for three races, clear thereafter; track sloppy.

title: Foe's Aim Is Puzzle in Cambodia
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 10The United States Em bassy here began moving into larger quarters today in antici pation of the arrival Saturday Of the new American AmbaS sador Emory C. Swank, and a few more hands to help ad minister the increased Ameri can aid program.

title: Rejection in Panama
description: Three treaties involving the future of the Panama Canal, which required three years of painstaking negotiations to produce and represented major con cessions by the United States, have been formally rejected by Panama. Whatever lame explanations the Panamanians put forward, it is clear that the rejection is due much more to the domestic political needs and desires of Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera's Government than to the content of the treaties.

title: Where Mercury Pollution is a Problem in the United States
description: Where Mercury Pollution is a Problem in the United States

title: Suit Seeks to Shut and Improve Tombs
description: In a suit filed yesterday on behalf of all prisoners of the Manhattan House of Detention, the Legal Aid Society asked for a Federal Court order to shut down the overcrowded facility, known as the Tombs, until such time as it can be made safe, sanitary, and decent for its inmates.

title: AIR FARE PROPOSAL SCORED BY OTTINGER
description: Representative Richard L. Ottinger charged yesterday that proposed Federal restrictions on lowcost charter flights would virtually strangle nonsched uled airlines.

title: Quest II, Aussie Challenger, Gains 30 Lead in Denmark
description: COPENHAGEN, Sept. 10 (AP)  The Australian challenger, Quest II, beat Denmark's Slejp ner, the defending champion, by 12 minutes today to take a 30 lead in the fourofseven series for the Catamaran Little Amer ica's Cup on Oeresund Strait.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Delaware Bans 2 Candidates
description: DOVER, Del. Sept. 10 (AP) Two American party candidates for statewide office in Delaware were ordered stricken from the ballot today by Burton C. Wil lis, commissioner of elections. Mr. Willis said the nominations of Howard T. Ennis Jr., for at torney general, and Jim E. Wort man; for insurance commis sioner, had violated provisions of the state election code, which says that candidates must either by party conven tion or in a primary election.

title: NIXON ENDORSES MODEL CITIES AID WITH LOCAL RULE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 The White House endorsed the Model Cities program today as a means of helping to achieve President Nixon's new federal ism, which would give more money and authority to the state and local governments.

title: Steps Taken for a Recount On 2 Colorado Democrats
description: DENVER, Sept. 10 (UPI) Representative Byron Rogers, a 20year member of Congress, and Craig Barnes, a Denver lawyer who ran as a peace can didate, may have to wait 10 days before getting final word as to who won the Democratic primary Tuesday in Colorado's First Congresstional District.

title: Trolley Adds Homey Touch at Boggs Party
description: BETHESDA, Md., Sept. 10 The streetcar was named Desire in honor of the trolley that still goes by Representa tion Hale Boggs's home in New Orleans.

title: PRICES ARE MIXED ON LONDON BOARD
description: The London stock market finished mixed yesterday in light trading.

title: GOVERNORS ASK U.S. TO PAY FOR WELFARE

description: STONINGTON, Conn., Sept. 10 Mrs. Henry Chapin, the for mer Paula Van Dyke, drowned in a sailing accident near her home on Thursday. She was 71 years old and lived at 52 Main Street.

description: BAKERSFIELD, Calif., Sept. 10  The short, heavy man in the middle of the crowd in the hot campaign headquarters pointed to the picture of the handsome man and said, Be fore this race is over, we're going to expose to the people of California the man behind that face.

title: 5 Negro Pupils Arrested In Alabama Disturbances
description: MOBILE, ALA., Sept. 11 (UPI)  The police arrested four. Negro teenagers in disturbances today at integrated Murphy High School, which became pre dominantly black this fall al though it is in a white neigh borhood. A fifth Negro youth was arrested for disorderly conduct at Central High School. Seventeenyearold Bernard Little, a Murphy student, was arrested for assault and battery and placed under $1,000 bond after the police said he attacked a white student at the school. The others were arrested for failing to comply with an offi cer's orders.

title: Godard Film in Festival:'Wind From the East' at Alice Tully Hall
description: At one point towards the middle of Jean-Luc Godard's "Wind From the East" (Vent D'Est), which was shown at the New York Film Festival at Alice Tully Hall yesterday evening, an actor dressed like a Civil War soldier in the film-within-the-film, more or less flops on the ground, after which, an off-screen prop man throws red paint on him. Whether or not you find the scene funny, stupid, alienating, beautiful, boring or provocative, it sums up quite perfectly the methodology of the man who now calls himself "the ex-great (bourgeois) filmmaker."Consequences precede actions and effects give birth to their causes, and all in the name of the sort of Marxist-Leninist truth that is defined pretty much in terms of what is needed as truth to carry the class struggle onwards and upwards."Wind From the East" begins with fleeting bits of business from the movie-within-the-movie, a Western, being shot by a group of would-be Third World moviemakers. "My uncle managed the exploitation of aluminum for the Alcoa Company near Dodge City. . . ." says the woman narrator."Almost immediately it turns into a soundtrack debate of Godardian dialectics, set against images that could be from some kind of crazy Western. This evolves into auto-critique ("What does it mean to ask the question: 'Where are we now?' for a militant moviemaker?") that is followed by a coda, which is nothing less than some pretty pictures of a school girl planting bombs in an open-air market."To dare to rebel, for us, here, now," says the woman narrator, "is to fight on two fronts  against the bourgeoisie and against its ally, revisionism.""Wind From the East" was written by Godard with Daniel Cohn-Bendit, who is seen briefly, during the auto-critique session, wearing a red sweater and a vaguely worried expression. Godard calls it his Marxist Western, which it actually is, but it's an example of a genre to which Godard (at least, so far) is the only contributor.It is full of outrageous statements (I was particularly intrigued by one to the effect that napalm was being dropped on Palestinian peasants) and the sort of lofty moralizing that would condemn Eisenstein for making "Potemkin" instead of concentrating on the struggles of his own times.However foolish, arrogant and paranoid Godard may now be, he is not quite yet the ex-great filmmaker he so humbly proclaims. There is a rhythm and a logic to the film itself that has nothing to do with truth and that recalls the rhythm and logic of such great, conventional Godardian films as "Vivre Sa Vie," "La Chinoise" and "Two or Three Things I Know About Her."Godard's narrators spend an awful lot of time in "Wind From the East" talking about revisionism, about the primary and secondary duties of the revolutionist, about the class struggle (what to do about workers who themselves have become capitalists), but the real drama of the movie is provided by Godard's search for some kind of perfect wedding of sound to image. He doesn't find it, and he may still be looking for it. Indeed, he has considerably altered the sequence of events in the film from the version I saw at Cannes last May.Godard says his search is prompted by the need to create a new cinema, free from bourgeois repression, which will depict the class struggle, not simply the class misery that is so favored by liberal and revisionist filmmakers. (To Godard, cinema vrit is beneath contempt.) Whatever his motives, Godard is the ony man today making such manic attempts to create a didactic film form, and the form is often fascinating. The content, however, is almost pure junk.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: To the Editor: Your Aug. 28 editorial No American Mercenaries implies by its title that our armed forces would become a group of mercenaries, men who sell their combat services to other countries, under an allvolun teer system. This clearly was not the case in our over 170 years experience with an all volunteer military nor has it been with our less than 35 years experience with a con scripted force.

title: Bank Holding Unit Drops Merger Bid
description: The First National Bancorpo ration of Denverin yet an other setback for banks seek ing to extend their activities into insurance  has quietly withdrawn an application to the Federal Reserve Board for approval to acquire two in surance agencies, it was disclosed yesterday. The multibank holding company owns the First National Bank of Denver, the largest bank in Colorado, with deposits at mid year of nearly $470million.

title: Jet Engine Eliminates Turbine
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 A New Jersey electrical en gineer believes the jet engine for which he was granted a patent this week may turn out to embody the greatest advance in such propulsion since jets were introduced. In the engine invented by J. Dominguez Rego of Newark, the gas turbine Patents is eliminated. Ac cording to Patent of the 3,527,055, this Week will remove limi tations on the heat and quality of the ex haust gases, increasing effi ciency and permitting the use of cheaper fuels.

title: Mrs. Hemingway Recalls Islands in the Stream
description: Thomas Hudson does not die because I asked Ernest not to kill him, to give the guy a chance. He did that once before  he was going to have Santiago die in The Old Man and the Sea and I said no, he is too nice a man, please let him live,  Mary Hemingway said the other day.

title: Dr. Ladislav Radimsky Dead; Author and ExU.N. Delegate
description: Dr. Ladislav Radimsky, au thor and a former deputy chief delegate of Czechoslo vakia at the United Nations, died Wednesday at the DeWitt Nursing Home, 211 East 79th Street, after surgery early this year. He was 72 years old and lived at 205 East 82d Street.

title: Sports of The Times
description: When I'm gone, boxing be nothing again, oft said Muhammad Ali before he went away. It's going to be back to the fighter who comes to town, smells a flower, visits a hospital, blows a horn and says he's in shape. Old hat. Since the spring of 1967 there has been a lot of old hat, and although the sport never became nothing again, as Ali might have wished, it suffered through many drab days with heavyweight pretenders who preferred to do my talk ing in the ring. The remembered laughter and heavy drama of Ali's three years as sanc tioned champion made everything that came after ward stale and unsatisfying. In retrospect, none of Ali's 10 championship bouts were truly memorable fights, heartpounding epics be tween evenly matched men. Rather, the fights were al most codas, short, selfcon tained passages seemingly composed to wrap up neat ly what had been two weeks or more of themes and va riations. Boxing did not miss Ali's fights, rather it missed the buildups to those fights. How the nation's pulse skipped when Cassius Clay stomped around Miami Beach with honey and a bear trap for Sonny Liston: how can this pure and sim ple youth be sacrificed to that hateful beast? Well, no his big mouth. Still and all, there ought to be a law. Poor boy.

title: Museum Expansion
description: Three great additions are coming to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in this, its centennial year: the Temple of Dendur, saved from the rising waters the Nile; the Robert Lehman collection of Western European art, and the Rockefeller collection of primi tive art. But since the museum stands inside Central Parka green treasury that is also pricelesscon servationists and others have been aroused by the danger that the museum will expand into parkland to house the acquisitions.

description: Earnings of the Utah Con struction and Mining Company rose 40.8 per cent in the third quarter, lifting profits for the nine months ended July 31 by 25.6 per cent, the compa ny reported yesterday. The gains were attributed to ex panded mining operations.

description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange mostly rose yester day as the list registered good gains in moderate trading. There was no economic news to account for the upswing, but at the final bell 528 issues were up while 284 stocks were down.

title: Women's Smoking Found to Decline for First Time
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 11For the first time since the emtin cipated female of a halfcen tury ago dared defy conven tion by smoking in public, cigarette smoking has declined among adult American women, a new national survey has shown.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. II  A law professor who once op posed the equal rights amend ment told Congress today that its enactment would cause few, if any, of the dire consequences that its opponents have pre dicted.

title: Adams Bolts Democrats To Endorse Rockefeller
description: Francis W. H. Adams, Police Commissioner under Mayor Robert F. Wagner and a found er of the Democratic Reform movement, yesterday endorsed the candidacy of Governor Rockefeller for a fourth term and agreed to serve as his campaign chairman for the city.

title: Educational Isolationism
description: The reported decline of foreign language studies the nation's high schools raises the specter of a dismal chapter in American education history repeating itself. In the late 1920's, many educators dismissed foreign languages, along with mathematics and science, as ir relevant frills. The illusory politics of isolationism made it easy to deride the skills needed to communi cate with foreign people and cultures.

title: A Fair Where People Who Do the Work Share in the Fun,. Too
description: ONEIDA, N. Y., Sept. 11By the time David Goff, who is director of the Madison County Historical Society here, had made the last of his calls for the day, he was laden with boxes of blueberries and bags of homemade choco late fudge and johnnycake. He'd already eaten the poppy seed cake and enjoyed the elderberry wine. All were gifts from the craftsmen he had been visiting. Most of the people he had seen were to be among the 80 or so partici pants in a crafts fair, which is being held tomorrow on the lawn of the historical soci ety's headquarters.

title: Japanese Seek U.S. KnowHow And Fear AntiDumping Steps
description: TOKYO, Sept. 11The Toyota Motor Company has announced that it was negotiating a technical tieup with Texas In struments, Inc., a leading Amer ican electronics company, as part of its program to produce a pollutionfree car. The pro gram requires miniaturization of many parts, so there is a need for sophisticated elec tronic eauiument.

title: GERALD DEAKIN, 86, A PHONE EXECUTIVE
description: MANHASSET, L. I., Sept. 11  Gerald Deakin, who retired as a vice president and general technical director of the Inter national Telephone and Tele graph Corporation in 1951, died last night in St. Francis Hos pital. He was 86 years old and Jived at Harbor Road. Harbor Acres, Sands Point.

title: Tel Aviv Team Greeted

Garelik welcomed the 24 players in his office in the 158yearold City Hall. Yariv BenEliezer, a grandson of David BenGurion, presented an engraved silver cup to Garelik. The council president gave each player a tiebar bearing the seal of New York City.

title: India's Maharajas File Suit On Loss of Their Incomes

title: Buckley Urges State to Find Out If There's a Plot Against Police
description: James L. Buckley, the Con servative party candidate for Senator, said yesterday that he had asked Governor Rockefeller to appoint a citizens commis sion to investigate charges that recent shootings of policemen were part of a state or national conspiracy.

title: U.N. EXPERTS ASSESS ISSUE OF ALGERIANS

Y., Sept. 11United Nations legal experts said today that Israel might have been within her legal rights when she arrested two Algerians on a British plane in transit at the Lydda airport last month. ine experts added, however, that the case was debatable and that there was no prece dent.

title: Angels Retain Phillips

title: New Lucia by the City Opera, Starring Sills, Gets Better Yet

title: Brazilian City Plans for Man and Industry

title: Galvanized Steel From Bethlehem Cut by $5 a Ton
description: The Bethlehem Steel Cor poration said yesterday that it had eliminated extra charges on certain galvanized steel products, effective Sept. 1. The change amounted to a reduction in price of about $5 a ton and was directly responsive to a competitive situation in the market place, the company added.

title: Bomb Threat in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 11 (AP)  Three floors of the Board of Trade building in downtown Chicago were evacuated today following a telephoned bomb threat. The police found no bomb.

title: Teacher Strikes in Connecticut Continue in 7 Areas for 3d Day
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 11  Teachers in seven Connecticut communities throughout the state continued to strike today. There was no guarantee that teachers would be on their classrooms Monday morning when school is to resume.

Because each is a winner of one of the world's four major champion ships, the four professionals are here for the World Series of golf, a special twoday event tomorrow and Sunday at the Firestone Country Club.

title: Vandals Halt Project In the Study of Cancer
description: FALMOUTH, Mass., Sept. 11 (AP)A key cancer research project directed by Dr. Albert SzentGyorgyi, a Nobel lau reate biochemist who says his experiments were at decisive stage, has been brought to a halt by vandals.

title: Topics: Five Minutes to Twelve in the Middle East

We thought Israel would be in trouble, and the United States would be drawn into war against the; whole Moslem world, We thought it would be worse for America than Viet nam. But we underestimated the Israelis, and overestimated the Egyptians. And the United States says it is neutral. What a disaster.

The office and the man became so merged that it as difficult to tell where one began and the other left off.

title: You Needn't Feed These Pets
description: There is a lovable, hugable snake, an outsized punching bag of a frog, a toothless crocodile with a mouth the size of a watermelon and a whale large enough to double as a slide, a sofa or, in a pinch, even a chair. In fact, seats are what all these ani mals are supposed to be. But the children who have been leap ing over lying on, kicking and hugging each of the supersized an imals in Bloomingdale's me nagerie of furnishings on the store's fifth floor, think of them primarily as toys. The 60inchlong whale ($100) is of shiny blue vinyl on top, shiny white vinyl underneath and thousands of polystyrene beads inside. The beadsfar less weighty than beans make the whale light enough to be moved about, but too heavy to throw.

title: Rafelson's 'Five Easy Pieces' Bows
description: "Five Easy Pieces," which played last night at Philharmonic Hall (the one American fiction movie in the regular events of this year's Film Festival) and opens today at the Coronet Theater, is the second feature of Bob Rafelson, a young director whose name will probably not be remembered in connection with his first film, "Head.""Head" suffered from its cast, the Monkees, and from an ad campaign that perhaps did more for the publicist than for the client (you may recall a month when New York was inundated with mysterious poster - photographs of John Brockman's head), but it was a better movie than most critics allowed  largely because it had at least as many ideas as it had technical resources and because it kept turning its excesses into playful but responsible style. "Head" was a movie that had nowhere to go except down, but in retrospect, doesn't seem all that bad.I'm not sure how "Five Easy Pieces" will seem in retrospectperhaps not all that good. It has its own red-herring equivalent to John Brockman's headin the form of a title that everybody seems to find terribly provocative but that refers more logically to piano pieces for the beginner. And it has a tripnorth to Alaskawhich is part of a fairly elaborate central metaphor. And it is full of ideas, and a stylein this case, a rigorously deliberate and plain stylethat is not less insistent than the canny exuberance of "Head.""Five Easy Pieces" is an open-ended story, like much recent American fiction, satiric in thrust (notice the names in the cast of characters) and elegiac in mood, about a young California oil worker (Jack Nicholson) who travels up to his family's island home on Puget Sound where he sees his dying father, makes a sexual conquest, and visits his pastbefore heading further north.By inclination the young man is very rootless-contemporary-American, with a country-and-Western loving mistress (Karen Black), beer in the refrigerator, and nights out at the bowling alley. But his family is well-off, musical and eccentric; his brother and sister (Ralph Waite and Lois Smith) concertize; and he himself has given up a careermore or less in the name of aimless integrity. Before he seduces his brother's fiance (Susan Anspach), he plays for heran easy piecebut scorns her reaction: "I faked a little Chopin. You faked a little response."Something of this exchange carries into my feeling about "Five Easy Pieces," which at first appears to be rich with a quantity of felt life, but on reflection seems both more carefully studied and more coldly casual than profoundly understood. In all non-essentials it is movie-making of a very high order. But scene by scene I find myself moving from sympathy, to admiration, to respectfor a performance, for Laslo Kovacs's evocative photography, or merely for the superior quality of the color film used in capturing the soft, wet lovely ambience of the Pacific Northwest.The acting is generally good, but except for Karen Black's pathetically appealing vulgarian, it lives in bits and pieces, rather than in a quality of sustained characterization. Almost everybody in "Five Easy Pieces" is a caricature but plays for all-round sentiment, and in context the one pointedly funny single-dimension role (Helena Kallianiotes as a tough Lesbian hitchhiker on her way to Alaska to escape America's accumulated filth) looks like a tour de force."Five Easy Pieces" is built around a series of good-bys. As the central character divests himself of responsibilities, of people and possessions, finally of the coat off his back (rather too pointedlyjust before hitching his own symbolic ride North) the film grows heavy with a kind of poignancy that for all its understatement leans heavily on a stock of quite unearned response.Rafelson is expert at supporting this movement, and the film proceeds from scene to scene with a quiet competent modernism that bespeaks quality, but that more often begs than provides expression. Greater things seem always to be in the offing. But I think they are an illusion. "Five Easy Pieces" is a film that takes small risks and provides small rewards.

title: Boston Bank Lowers Rate

It is the second small bank in New England to lower the rate charged its best customers. On Aug. 28 the Canal National Bank of Portland, Me., lowered its prime rate to 7 per cent.

title: Screen: G.I.'s vs. Civilians
description: A brashly freewheeling new comedy at the Astor and neighborhood theaters called "Suppose They Gave a War and Nobody Came" has the same trouble as that titletoo arch, too unwieldly and too long. And too bad. For until the fun is awkwardly squashed out of the picture in the final reel, this is a bright, brisk and scathingly funny satireon a number of things. And that is the real trouble.The "battlefield" is a large, peacetime Army post and a nearby town, apparently near the Southwest border. The undeclared war is the natural hostility between the soldiers and the wary, suspicious civilians.Everything gets a sharp, amusing going-over at first, from the country-club atmosphere of the post to the squarehead domination of the town, both uneasily linked in a new program of "community relations." This shaky operation is the peg of the script, whose wry, often lancing dialogue is catnip for a good cast that tackles its roles with relish, under the nimble direction of Hy Averback.The ribald humor and the characterizations hold fast for a while. Tony Curtis is fine as the slightly paunchy post wolf in pursuit of Suzanne Pleshette, a svelte canteen employe. Brian Keith as a professional soldier and Ivan Dixon as a leathery sergeant are both excellent, as is Don Ameche, the post commandant. And Bradford Dillman is surprisingly dexterous in the most interesting role, that of a wry, Army egghead.Trouble is, toward the end the story flounders for a way out and drags in an awkward, overdone device of a tank roaring toward the terrified town. And the townspeopleamong them Ernest Borgnine, Tom Ewell and Arthur O'Connellemerge as either outright or fringe caricatures of bigotry, meanness or timidity. The final flavor is that of smart-alecky cynicism and scattered buckshot.But the first half of the picture is genuinely knowing, sassy and thoroughly enjoyable although nobody wins the war in the final showdown.

title: Art: Out of the Mailbox
description: Certain artists retain an underground reputation be cause their work is too powerful, too disruptive, too original and troubling to fit comfortably into our conven tional categories of apprecia tion. But others retain their underground status simply because their work is too slighttoo perishable and inconsequential  to survive the clear light of day. What may be amusing as the pri vate sport of a happy few often looks merely inane when mounted as a museum exhibition for the public at large.

description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 11 Each of the four University of Pittsburgh football victories last season was a plus in the opinion of Coach Carl DePasqua, who said today, I didn't see a year ago how we could win one game. That was when DePas qua was about to start his first season as Pitt coach.

title: Chester Morris Is Dead at 69; Created Role of Boston Blackie
description: Chester Morris, who created the role of Boston Blackie, was found dead of an overdose of barbiturates yesterday in his room at the Holiday Inn in New Hope, Pa. Mr. Morris, who was 69 years old, had been starring as Captain Queeg in The Caine Mutiny CourtMartial at the Bucks County Playhouse.

title: Philadelphia to Be Bicentennial Hub
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP)President Nixon formally approved today plans for bring ing the, entire nation into the celebration of its 200th anni versary in 1976with Philadel phia as an exciting focal point for international participation.

title: NineStore.Looting Stopped
description: RIDGELY, Tenn., Sept. 11 (AP)A burglar who used stolen automobile for a batter ing ram smashed down the back doors of nine downtown business places early yesterday. The police said he entered and robbed five of the stores be fore he was arrested. The sus pect, Robert Lewis Black, 18 years old, of Memphis, was charged on nine counts.

title: Calm, Cool Policeman
description: His hair is gray and thin ning. His build is slight, al most frail. His voice is soft, his language scholarly. He does not fit the stereotype of the tough, burly IrishCath olic cop from the streets of New York, but he is the son of a policeman and the brother of two more. The things he says sometimes in cense conserve tives. The things he does some times antagonize policemen. Yesterday Patrick Vincent Murphy came home to New York where he will be the new Police Commis sioner. He has been a police man or law enforcement offi cial for half of his 50 years, and in that time, rising from a beatpounding patrolman on the streets of Brooklyn's Red Hook, he has developed strong opinions about his profession.

title: Burton Brody Marries Mary Myerson
description: Miss Mary Clement Myer son, director of public rela tions for the United Planned Parenthood Campaign of New York City, was married yesterday to Burton H. Brody, a member of the law firm of Jezer, Slade & Weiss here. Rabbi Martin J. Zion performed the ceremony at the Carlyle Hotel.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Shipping/Mails

title: Save the Mason Act
description: The long campaign to halt commercial exploitation of certain imperiled animals and reptiles has again been stopped short of victory. The Mason Act passed by the Legislature would have banned as of Sept. 1 the sale in New York State of alligator and crocodile hides and of furs from the tiger, leopard, cheetah and other spotted cats.

title: Pocket Rocket Takes Jumpoif In HorseShow at Stony Brook
description: STONY BROOK, L. I., Sept. 11 Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Butler's Pocket Rocket won his second preliminary jumper class after a testing double jumpoff today at the North Shore horse show.

title: 4 Men Crave Sun After 90Day Test In Space Simulator
description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, Calif., Sept. 11 (AP)  Four men stepped out of a space station simulator today saying that they, craved a shower and sunshine after 90 days of confinement, the longest test yet in a regen erative lifesupport system.

title: Miss Carole E. Baker Is Betrothed
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 11 Mr. and Mrs. Carlyle M. Baker have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carole Ellen Baker, to R. Woodward Millen, assist ant vice president of Bache & Co., stockbrokers. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert S. Millen of Brook ville, L. I. A November wed ding is planned. Miss Baker attended Co lumbus School for Girls and was graduated from Brian cliff College in 1967. Her father is chairman of the board and chief executive of ficer of Certified Oil Company here.

title: 3 From Bu's Line Charged in Deaths Of 7 in July Crash
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., Sept. 11 (UPI)Frank Tedesco of Jersey City, N. J., a bus line principal, and two of his company's em ployes were held today for grand jury action in connection with the deaths of seven Eong Island school children in a bus crash last July 15.

title: ARABS RELEASE SOME PASSENGERS, BUT HOLD MANY ON JETS IN DESERT; NIXON PUTS GUARDS ON U.S. PLANES
description: Eightyeight hijacked passen gers were flown out of Amman yesterday and early today, but the status of negotiations to free 300 other passengers held by Arab commandos remained unclear.

title: 100 Airliner Guards Reach Kennedy for Cram Course
description: Almost 100 Federal agents arrived at Kennedy Interna tional Airport yesterday to be gin a cram course that might be called How to Fire a Gun Inside a Jetliner Without Shoot ing It Down.

title: and Deterring Skyjackers
description: This week's crisis in international civil aviation has finally overcome the inertia which for so long pre vented nations other than Israel from mounting ener getic, organized efforts to prevent aerial hijacking. The program President Nixon announced yesterday will by its very existence create strong pressure on other major nations to take similar steps.

title: Girard Trust Is Authorized To Take Bank's Liabilities
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UPI)The Federal Reserve au thorized today the Girard Trust Bank of Philadelphia to assume the liabilities of City Bank of Philadelphia clearing the way for reopening the City Bank, which has been closed since last Friday.

title: Scribner Urges Teachers to Innovate
description: Dr. Harvey B. Scribner, the new Chancellor of the city's public schools, was warmly re ceived by teachers last week when he told them they were in a new ball game that would require new methods and approaches to take stu dents into the planning process.

title: HAD YOUR VACATION YET
description: If not, read The New York Times Travel and Resorts Section and get the urge to go, go, go.

title: Ulbricht Now Faces A Really Tough Challenge
description: BONNThe German Demo cratic Republic has faced many severe tests in its 21 years under Walter Ulbricht: a work er uprising in 1953, loss of So viet confidence for a while thereafter, the loss of millions of citizens as refugees and a con tinuing boycott by Western countries.

title: 2 FOREIGN PLANTS AID U.S. ON SPACE
description: HOUSTON, Sept. 12 (AP) Two European aerospace com panies will Join with North American Rockwell In design studies for spacecraft to be used in America's space shut tle program planned for the late Nineteen Seventies.

title: Crusaders Beaten, 260
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Sept. 12 Army was supposed to have an easy football game in its opener against Holy Cross to day, since the Crusaders had canceled their last eight games in 1969 because an epidemic of hepatitis had hit the entire squad.

title: Goodell, Ottinger and Buckley Meet for the First Time At San Gennaro Festival on Mulberry Street
description: Broad smiles on their faces, the three candidates for United States Senator from New York met yesterday for the first time at about as spirited an occasion as the city can furnishthe San Gennaro Festival on Mulberry Street.

title: Willner TopSeeded Player In Eastern 35 Tournament
description: Robert Willner, a New York stockbroker, is the topseeded player in the third annual East ern tennis championship for players 35 years of age and over. The tournament, spon sored by Westchester County, will start tomorrow at the Memorial Field courts on San ford Avenue in Mount Vernon, N. Y.

description: Outgoing Passenger and Mail Ships

title: A Walk On London's Wild Side
description: LONDON. NOTTING HILL, like many other parts of London today, was once a de sirable residential area. That was a long while back, and al most in another country. To day the district is running slowly to seed. The squares still rustle with privileged trees; but the tall white hous es around have started, reluc tant as society beauties, to doff their elegance. The fa cades crack and peel. Gray housewives plod past to ward the shops. Children of many colorstough, unbathed dwarfsyell at the house wives, and each other, down the saddened streets.

title: Plant Shopping Begins with Homework
description: SUCCESS in shopping at a nursery depends on how well you do your homework. Before visiting nursery, any homeowner should plan first what he wants to buy.

title: T. W. Haggerty Fiance of Ellen Kaufman
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Sept. 12Mr. and Mrs. Lionel M. Kaufman have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen Faith Kaufman, to Thomas William Haggerty. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Haggerty of Glenwood Landing, L. 1. A wedding here on Nov. 21 is planned. Miss Kaufman, a graduate of MacMurray College in Jacksonville, Ill., is with Pub lication Corporation in Green wich, Conn. She plans to study for a master's degree in mathematics. Her father is assistant publisher of Media Decisions, an adver tising business paper in New York.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Three hijacked jetliners in the Jordanian desert were emptied of passengers and blown up yesterday by the Arab guerrillas who had commandeered them: Then all but 40 of the captive passengers were released; 15 arrived in New York City last night. The 40 Swiss, West German, British, Israeli and United States nationals, including about five women, were held at an un disclosed site as the guerrilla organization called for separate deals in which the nations involved would receive their nationals in exchange for guerrillas held in their prisons. title: Leslie Solbert Fiancee Of Joseph G. Fogg 3d
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I., Sept. 12Miss Leslie Kirk Solbert, whose grandfather, the late Adm. Alan G. Kirk, U. S. N., was Ambassador to Belgium and the Soviet Union, plans to be married in January to Joseph Graham Fogg 3d.

description: JERSEY CITY, Sept. 12 Architecture buffs and land mark preservationists were elated this week when it was made known that the aban doned 60year old Hudson County Courthouse was being listed in the National Register of Historic Places.

description: The manager of a Fifth Ave nue Woolworth store and a porter accompanying him to a night depository were shot and badly wounded at 39th Street and Madison Avenue yes terday afternoon by three gun men who fled with $13,000 in canvas bags.

title: A bird'seye view of Victorian England
description: The reading public, always a confederation of wildly dif ferent tribes of people with exceedingly different tastes in books, was never so frag mented as it is today. One man's memorable and signifi cant novel is another's abomi nation. Another man's thor oughly enjoyable novel is an other's mess of commercial pottage. Which brings us to the news that R. F. Delderfield's new novel, God Is an English man, is now published.

description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Sept 12 (AP)  A fire today des troyed Somalia's biggest hotel, the Juba. Twentythree pesrons were injured.

description: DIET is a magic word to most Americans. C., Sept. 12 (AP)Bobby Isaac has taken the prize in the richest 100mile race of the season, becoming the first driver to win four con secutive Grand National races at Hickory Speedway. description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12A Senate Foreign Relations sub committee disclosed today that the dispatch of 50,000 South Korean soldiers to fight in South Vietnam had cost the United States more than $1 billion in the last five years.

title: Tis Possible to Plant Roses This Fall
description: IN the metropolitan New York area, roses may be planted either in Novem ber or in early spring. In autumn, the days are pleasant, the soil friable, and there is a good choice of desired rose varieties. The plants come directly from the nursery so roots are out of the ground the shortest possible time. Some nurseries, however, do not harvest in time for November planting and in some climates, springplanted bushes have a slightly better chance of survival.

Certain neural networks that are similar in cats and men? Learning pat terns that are similar in pig eons mice and men? Or

title: TriState Golf Tournament Again Won by Connecticut
description: EAST PROVIDENCE, R. I. Sept. 12 (AP)Fred Kask, John Ruby, Bill Brew, Dr. Ted Lenczyk and Sam Petrone each won two matches today as Connecticut scored its fourth straight victory in the annual TriState golf matches at the Metacomet Country Club.

title: Out of My Mind On Bluegrass
description: SEVERAL months ago, I was rid ing home in a taxi through downtown Manhattan, trying simultaneously to keep up my end of the inevitable exchange of opinions on the world and read the evening sports news. Suddenly, in a corner of my mind I became aware of a pleasant, longago sensation. It was the taxi's radio, of all things A cataract of orange and yellow notes was pouring out of ita rhythmical waterfall of sound that flowed straight into my brainpan and sizzled there like boiling sunlight.

title: 16 Named to State Health Ad.visory Unit
description: ALBANY, Sept. 12 (UPI) The appointments of 16 new members of the Advisory Council to the State Health Planning Commission were an nounced this week by Governor Rockefeller.

title: POWER OF MAYORS IN JOB ROLE RISES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12  Although the nation's Mayors have undergone a decline in authority in several respects in recent years, they appear to be emerging In a potentially powerful new role In the administration of the Federal Government's vast manpower training programs.

title: Barbara Share Plans Nuptials
description: SYRACUSE, Sept. 12Mr. and Mrs. Nathan I. Share have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Barbara Suzanne Share, to Donald Alan Kaplan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Kaplan of New Brunswick, N. J. The couple plan to marry. March 28.

title: A Friedman doctrine- The Social Responsibility Of Business Is to Increase Its Profits
description: WHEN I hear businessmen speak eloquently about the social responsibilities of business in a freeenterprise system, I am reminded of the wonderful line about the Frenchman who discovered at, the age of 70 that he had been speaking prose all his life. The businessmen believe that they are defending free enterprise when they declaim that business is not concerned merely with profit but also with promoting desirable social ends; that business has a social conscience and takes seriously its responsibilities for providing employment, eliminating discrimination, avoiding pollution and whatever else may be the catchwords of the contemporary crop of reformers. In fact they areor would be if they or any one else took them seriously preaching pure and unadulterated socialism. Businessmen who talk this way are unwitting puppets of the intellectual forces that have been undermining the basis of a free society these past decades.

title: O'Brien Outpoints Johnson
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 12 (Reuters)Johnny O'Brien of Scotland scored a decision to night over Don Johnson of Los. Angeles in a junior lightweight 10round fight.

title: Photography
description: THERE could hardly be a time more opportune for the presentation of a largescale exhibit on the theme of Woman than the presentnor a less auspicious one. Woman, the 2d World Exhibition of Pho tography (which opened at the New York Cultural Cen ter, 2 Columbus Circle, on Sept. 2, and will run through Nov. 8), arrives  in this country, at any rateat an extremely delicate transition al point. Though none of those involved in this sizable projectSTERN magazine, of Germany, which organized it; the 261 art museums in 36 countries which offered assistance; Dr. Karl Pawek, who came up with the origi nal idea and designed the show; and the 236 photogra phers whose work is repre sentedcould have foreseen at the outset the sociosexual matrix in which woman would ultimately be presen ted, the subject to Which it is devoted now gives promise of becoming one of the ma jor controversies of our time.

title: Point of View
description: The destruction of our environment by uncontrolled pollution is no longer accept able to the American public or its officials. Strangely, the destruction of our environ ment by the continuous on slaught upon remaining open space has produced no similar alarms or calls for court ac tion, new legalation, or boycotts. Yet, of the two, the second type may be even more damaging, since it is virtually irreversible and not subject to corrective action either through dollars or tech nology.

title: Hijackings: A Costly Diversion
description: Airline bookkeepers are being forced to add a new item to their system of ac counts: hijacking expense. The typical hi jacking can cost from $5,000 up with the average probably $10,000. The total bill for the two years since hijackings became frequent may amount to $15million, ac cording to one unofficial estimate.

title: English Catholics are different from other people
description: English Roman Catholics, for the most part, are contentedly estab lished in the odor of social sanctity. Yet they preserve background vi sions of martyrdom, and to some it seems disappointing that a history of persecution ends in the deep indif ference of godless England. They comfort themselves through a net work of institutions and customs: out of selfrepression comes the special satisfaction of being consciously dif ferent from other people. Pieis Paul Read is able and witty enough to diaw a modern fable out of this difference.

title: What About Winter Survival?
description: WINTER survival of roses depends more on the condition of the bushes in autumn than on any type of winter covering. A summer spraying program that prevents defoliation from black spot and spider mites is more important than mounding with earth in November. It is nearly twenty years since last hilled roses for winter and I have almost never lost a bush due to lack of protection. Occasional losses can usually be traced to other causes, such as crown gall, too crowded or too shady a location, or to chipmunks chewing on the roots.

title: NEW ENVOY OF U.S. NOW IN PNOMPENH
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia. Sept. 12Emory C. Swank, the new United States Ambassador to Cambodia, arrived here today to take up his duties. He is Washington's first Ambassador to Pnompenh since 1965.

description: The schooner Bowdoin, used for 26 trips to the Arctic by Rear Adm. Donald B. Mac Millan, who died last Mon day in Provincetown, Mass., at the age, of 95, lives on in Camden,. Me.

description: MARY KATHLEEN; Austra lia, Sept. 1Soon the handful of people left here when the uranium mine closed nearly, seven years ago will no longer have to endure hearing the place called a ghost town by tourists who stop to photograph the silent streets and empty buildings.

title: Letters
description: I would be very interested to learn the evidence on which Julian Moynahan claims Henry James suffered a peculiar groin injury and never mar ried. Unless I have overlooked some unimpeachable recent ev idence, I know only of a refer ence to an obscure hurt which apparently made James think he was unfit for military duty in the Civil War and that he was something less than a man of complete physical soundness. I am of course aware that James's unmarried state and his often very heavi ly veiled references to physical passion have greatly influenced critics familiar with postFreu dian literary analysis into as suming that James's injury had made him impotent and thus prevented him from marrying. But our lack of information about the injury makes the theory highly speculative. The more reasonable assumption has, I believe, always been that James's obscure hurt was a back injury.

title: Tulsa Tops Cincinnati, 73; On 6Yard Pass From Dobbs
description: TULSA, Okla., Sept. 12 (AP) Johnny Dobbs threw a 6 yard touchdown pass to Jim.: Butler in the third quarter tO lead Tulsa to a 73 victory over Cincinnati today.

title: An American Indian argues for a new America like the old America
description: The Red Indian in America has tremendous forensic advantage, if he will take command of the dialectics. Every other minority outnumbers him, but he is the Original Man, the proprietor, the human equivalent of the buffalo and the passenger pigeon, and now the bald eagle, osprey, pere grine and whooping crane. He is in the literature, in The Last of the Mohicans and The Last of the Curlews.

title: Wyoming Quarterback Drowns in Boat Mishap

title: BISHOP MEDEIROS DISCUSSES ISSUES
description: BROWNSVILLE, Tex., Sept., 12The Most Rev. Humberto S. Medeiros sat quietly behind his desk this week, staring out a glass wall of his office toward the Fort Brown Resaca, a sort of slough of the Rio Grande, while a Boston television cam eraman finished loading into his camera.

title: A steam machine. For whenever your sharkskin suit has elephant knees.
description: Today, Remington ends this pressing ordeal. With a 1 lb, device that srriooths out wrinkles simply by jetting out steam. Every time you touch a button.

title: Mercury Found in Birds
description: BOISE, Idaho, Sept. 12 (UPI) Seventyfive per cent of game birds tested in Idaho showed traces of mercury poisoning, the state health administrator said today. The official, Dr. Terrell O. Carver, said the re sults of testing 300 game birds showed cause for some con cern but no cause for alarm regarding potential health haz ards from eating game birds killed in Idaho. But he warned Idahoans not to cat more than one meal of pheasant a week.

title: Goldberg Accuses Rockefeller of Forming BackDoor Alliance With the Conservatives
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 12 Arthur J. Goldberg charged today that there was an al liance between Governor Rock efeller and the Conservative party to win the Governor's reelection.

title: M'NITT REGISTERS 3D SHIELDS VICTORY
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 12 James D. McNitt sailed Im bat to a third straight Shields Class victory on Long Island Sound today during the sea son's 38th championship re gatta for Yacht Racing Asso ciation fleets based east of Rye.

title: HAYSTACK FIRES SPREAD ON COAST
description: EPHRATA, Wash., Sept. 12 Fires in more than 100 hay stacks have baffled the police and spread tension through the rich farmland of the Columbia River basin.

title: Stephen Karper And Diane Hoyt To Be Married
description: FAIR HAVEN, N. J., Sept. 12Dr. and Mrs. C. Douglas Hoyt have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Diane Hoyt, to Stephen J. Karper of New York. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. A. Singer Karper of Miami Beach. The wedding is planned for December.

title: The novelist as sun, the novels as planets revolving around him
description: Angus Wilson is the most out standing British novelist today, and he has written before of his haunt ing by Dickens. They share certain gifts and obsessions: the deepening concern with selfdiscovery that dom inates Dickens's later novels, an understanding of their characters lifestyles and their relation to soci ety, and the power of mimicry aided by a sharp eye and sensitive ear.

title: Hugh Gormley, Retired at 53, Stages Riding Comeback at 55
description: Two years ago, at the age of 53, Hugh Gormley figured he was finished as a competi tor in horse shows.

title: MacMillan's Bowdoin Carries On in Camden
description: The schooner Bowdoin, used for 26 trips to the Arctic by Rear Adm. Donald B. Mac Millan, who died last Mon day in Provincetown, Mass., at the age, of 95, lives on in Camden,. Me.

title: Old Lightship Is Sought for Museum or Training
description: The lightship Huron, oldest on the Coast Guard's roster, is headed for new service afloat as a museum piece or a training ship, instead of the usual scrap heap, as au tomated floating buoys and fixed stations replace an chored vessels as offshore aids to navigation.

title: A Questionable Agenda
description: When asked what the chances are for adjournment of the Senate by Oct. 15, Senator Mike Mans field, the majority leader, replied, Well, to be honest, very questionable.Inasmuch as the Senate has two constitutional amendments to decide uponwomen's rights and abolition of the Electoral CollegeSenator Mans field's doubts are entirely understandable. Moreover, with onethird of the members, including both party floor leaders, concerned about their own reelection campaigns this fall, it will be more than ordinarily difficult to get full attendance. It is questionable whether the Senate ought to try to act in such haste on so many major measures.

title: Released Hostages Tell of Their Ordeal in Desert
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 12  Joy mixed with anguish was in the dusty faces of the American women and chil dren who arrived here today after six days and nights of captivity in the desert aboard a hijacked jet of Trans World Airlines.

title: Lindsay to Get Award
description: Mayor Lindsay will receive the 1970 Family of Man Award of the Council of Churches of the City of New York at a din ner Oct. 26 at the New York Hilton hotel 'for his continued efforts toward solving what has seemed to many the massive problems of the inner city and urban living. Previous recipi ents include Presidents Eisen hower, Kennedy, Johnson and Nixon, Lester Pearson and Jean Monnet.

title: Steven Dingfelder To Wed Ruth Rapp
description: MANHASSET, L. I., Sept 12Mr. and Mrs. Mack Rapp have made known the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Rapp, to Steven Dingfelder. He is a son of Mrs. William Martin of Miami Beach. A December wedding is planned.

Green Jr. and the late Mrs. Josephine Taft Green, was married here this afternoon to Robert Park Palmer, a reg istered representative with Estabrook & Co., Inc., stock brokers in Boston. He is the son of Mrs. Stephen Palmer of Sotogrande, Spain, and South Hamilton, Mass., and the late Maj. Harry Win field Schenck, U.S.A., and adopted son of Mr. Palmer. The Rev. Halsey DeWolf Howe performed the cere mony in St. Martin's Episco pal Church.

title: DETAIL FROM THE ANNUNCIATION
description: Gently the lilacs curtsey in the beating Wash of the great wings gold and indigo Where, down the stairs, a bare two flights below, The Angel stalled to glide into God's greeting.

description: DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 12 Miss Ann Pinckney Buek was married here this afternoon to James Harry Beggs. The Rev. H. Arthur Lane Jr. per formed the ceremony in St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

title: Stamps
description: THE United States Postal Service (formerly Post Office Department) is making its bow to in ternational philately with a souvenir commemorating the 1970 international exhibition, Philympia, which opens Fri day at Empire Hall, Olympia, in London.

title: AIR FORCE ELEVEN ROUTS IDAHO, 457
description: AIR FORCE ACADEMY, Colo., Sept. 12 (UPI)The Air Force Academy crumpled mistake riddled Idaho today, 457, with Bob Parker, the Falcon quarter back, running for two touch downs and passing to Ernest Jennings for three more.

title: AVERAGE AGE Is 32 IN GRETEL'S CREW
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 12 Can Gretel II accomplish by force what Mayor Fred Alofsin of Newport failed to achieve by diplomacy?

title: FLORIDA SCORES OVER DUKE, 2119
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 12 (AP)  Carlos Alvarez re turned a punt 67 yards for a touchdown tonight that gave heavily favored Florida a 2119 victory over Duke.

title: New Works, No New Trends
description: ALOOK at the programs that some of the symphony orchestras will present this season does not re veal much in the way of new trends. Predictably, there will be a great deal of music by Beethoven played, be cause of the 200th anniversary of the composer's birth. The Ninth Symphony will come in for more performances than usual. Some of the tributes will include the Missa Solemnis, the Triple Concerto, the Mass in C, the Cantata on the Death of Emperor Joseph II or the Choral Fan tasy, and the San Francisco Symphony is reviving the Wellington Symphony, which scarcely does justice to Beetho ven even if ithas the virtue of novelty.

title: Miss Douglas Married
description: POINT O WOODS, L. I., Sept. 12The marriage of Miss Isabelle Frothingham Douglas to Robert Sydney O'Hara Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. O'Hara of Old Lyme, Conn., took place here today. The ceremony was per formed in the nondenomina tional Point O Woods Church by the Rev. Thomas P. Stewart of Roslyn.

title: Koreans Weighing Shift in Role and Combat Tactics
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 12After five years of fighting in South Vietnam, the South Koreans are reevaluating their role and tactics.

title: To Make The Taxis Safer
description: Added to the many occupa tions that can be classified as hazardous is that of the New York City taxicab driver. Already this year, seven drivers and a dispatcher have been slain in holdups.

title: Wendy Hoyt Is Wed to Rex Walden
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I. Sept. 12Miss Wendy An nette Hoyt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Grey Hoyt, was married here this after noon in St. Peter of Alcan tara Roman Catholic Church to Rex Prescott Walden, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Wit telsey Walden of Guilford and Leete's Island, Conn. The Rev. Denis J. Whelen per formed the ceremony.

title: The spacious days of Virginia's glory
description: The history of colonial Vir ginia exerts a perennial fas cination upon Americans, and there is no end to the making of books on the subject. Perhaps the restoration of Wil liamsburg has dramatized the history of the colony with greater vividness than has been the fortune of other regions. At any rate, no matter how oft& the story of preRevolu tionary Virginia is told, a readymade audience is waiting to listen, and with good reason, for Virginia developed a remarkable society in the pe riod and produced a galaxy of extraordinary personalities.

title: New River System In South Attracting Plants for Industry
description: The affinity of waterways and industrial plants has been demonstrated again by the as yetuncompleted ArkansasVer digris River system.

title: The marriage was mixed, the child confused
description: Stelmark is a word formed from the first names of the author's parents, and as this book is a family recollection, the title is thematically sound. The implication is that a spirit ual return to the sources of our being can put us more in touch with a real present and thus launch us all the more bravely into the future.

title: NASA Plans New Facility
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) The National Aeronautics and Space Administration says it is setting up an earth resources program facility at its Missis sippi Test Facility, Hancock County, Miss., and expects to have 75 Government workers and contractor employes there by next July 1.

title: Village Gate Offers Happy Experience By Family Jewels
description: Jake and the Family Jewels is simply a wonderfully happy musical experience.

description: MONTREAL, Sept. 12 (UPI) Sam Pollock, the general mana ger of the Montreal Canadiens of the National Hockey League, announced today that Mickey Redmond and Ralph Backstrom have signed their contracts for the 197071 season.

description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 12 (AP) The Cincinnati Royals of the National Basketball Association signed today Bill Turner for the 197071 season.

title: Pope Said to Ask Guerrillas For Release of Hostages
description: ROME, Sept. 12The Vati can announced today that Pope Paul VI had made a personal intervention with the responsi ble authorities to obtain the speedy release of the hostages held in Jordan after the hijack ing of three airplanes.

title: Last Stolen Item Returned
description: MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Sept. 12 (AP)A silver beaker, the last of 25 pieces of antique sacramental silver stolen last year from the Old North Con gregational Church, has been returned.

description: KITCHENER, Ontario, Sept. 12The Rangers finally shot the puck in training camp today, but Coach Emile Fran cis halted the machinegun ning a few minutes after it had started at 9 A.M.

title: CAROLINA RIVALS STRESS WAR ISSUE
description: RALEIGH, N. C.The Fourth Congressional District of North Carolina is a region of sharp contrastsof farms and great universities, of organized labor and organized blacks, of re bellious youths and disapprov ing adults, of partly decaying downtowns and sleek new sub urban shopping centers.

title: A Short History Of the Mail Service
description: This is not a book for stamp collectors. Nor, in spite of the global map on its dust jacket and a short background sec tion (the Assyrians had a going postal service as early as the 19th century B.C.; the Chi nese were the first to send mail by pigeon), is it a history of mail services in general. It is specifically a history of mail service in the United States.

title: U.S. Pressing 8City Project To Improve Building Methods
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12. (UPI)  Confident that it has overcome a spring and summer of neighborhood opposition, the Government is pushing ahead with a project in eight communities intended to sub stitute modern technology for older methods of building homes.

title: Russian Finds Setbacks for the Nixon Administration
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 12Georgi A. Arbatov, the head of the Soviet Union's research insti tute on the United States, says in an article published today that the Nixon Administration has failed to solve pressing domestic and foreign problems facing the country.

description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 12  Mike Yancheff, who has yet to start a game, and the experienced Mike Pellowski were elected co captains of the Rutgers foot ball team today.

title: News of the Camera World
description: ANEW movie cassette sys tem for 8mm and su per8 movie film has been introduced by Bell & Howell. Special cas settes which come in 80, 100, 200 and 400foot sizes are designed so that once loaded with processed film, the user can show the film, re wind it, store it in indexed files, and show it again at any time without ever actu ally handling, the film itself.

title: Bob Woodhouse Wins 5
description: Mrs. Whitney Stone's Shuvee shared honors with young Bobby Woodhouse at Belmont Park yesterday. Shuvee, ridden by Ron Turootte, won the $83, 750 Beldame and, as favorite paid $4.60. Woodhouse, who did not have a mount in the main race, nevertheless thrilled the crowd of 42,563 by riding five winners and one runnerup in seven attempts during the afternoon.

title: Student Fund Is Proposed For Property Damage Costs
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept 12 (AP)The dean of the Univer sity of Wisconsin Law School and a professor of insurance at the University of Pennsyl vania have come up with a plan to cover costs of property damage caused by student dis orders. Make the students pay for it.

title: Rebecca D. Willlams Is Bride Of Comte Loic de Kertanguy
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Sept. 12Miss Rebecca Dixon Williams, daughter of Eugene F. Williams Jr., president of the St. Louis Union Trust Company, and Mrs. Williams of St. Louis, was married here this afternoon to the Comte Loic de Kertanguy, son of Comte Herve de Ker tanguy of Lyons, France, and the late Comtesse de Ker tanguy. The Rev. Peter Garry perfornied the ceremony in the Most Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church. A reception followed at the Williams summer home here.

title: Bullets to Open Camp
description: FORT MEADE, Md., Sept. 12 (AP)  The National Basketball open thier preseason training camp at Fort Meade Wednesday with seven rookies and eight regulars expected to report to Coach Gene Shue.

title: Prince Siena3Length Victor In Stakes at Rockingham
description: SALEM, N. H., Sept. 12 (AP) Philip Wise's Prince Siena led all the way today en route to a threelength victory in the $16,250 Granite State Stakes, before a crowd of 15,824 at Rockingham Park.

title: SESSIONS PLANNED ON NEW HOUSING
description: The City Planning Commis sion has scheduled public hear ings at City Hall for Sept. 23 on eight proposed housing de velopments with a total of 3,656 dwelling units.

title: From Trondheim to BergenA Camper's Odyssey
description: BERGEN, Norway Our decision to drive the 500odd miles from Trondheim to Bergen instead of making the trip by coastal steamer was based on economic factors, but it was the wisest decision we made during our entire European vacation.

title: Sutherland's Singing Musical HighWire Act
description: THE ladies with the highest notes are the vocal acrobats of the musical circus. In their highwire acts, spotlighted in the center ring, they probably win the attention of more people than do other singers. Musicians may look on them disdainfully as performers who can offer only a set of unnatural tricks, yet their mass appeal cannot be ignored. They provide excitement and pleasure in their way, and just as the grace and skill of some trapeze artists can add up to an esthetic  experience, so can the trills and cadenzas of the best coloratura sopranos.

title: GoneThe Male Animal's Last Lair
description: AMERICA'S FOREST primeval, traditionally the exclusive province of the dominant, toughtalking male, has been invaded by the female of the speciesand the trend shows no sign of letting up.

title: Influential Paper in Cairo Bids Arab Regimes Curb Hijackers
description: CAIRO, Sept. 12Action by Arab governments to control air, hijackings by irrespon sible guerrilla organizations was suggested today by an in fluential Cairo weekly, Akhbar el Yom.

title: Home Improvement
description: ESPECIALLY made for doityourselfers, a new typd of cushioned sheet vinyl flooring recently introdueed to in 36inch wide rolls to make the ma terial easier to handle. It is pliable enough to be easily cut and fit with an ordinary scissors and the edges of each roll are precision cut so that the finished seams butt together perfectly and are almost invisible when the job is done. To further en hance its appearance and add to its easymaintenance char acteristics as a seamless floor, a special seam sealer is applied to all joints after the job is done.
