description: Ballou, Esther WilliamsonPrelude and Allegro (1955). Adler, Vienna Orchestra. CRI 115

title: Gov. Burns Facing Struggle in Hawaii
description: HONOLULU, Sept. 12Land and housing problemstwo of Hawaii's biggest headaches have become major issues in a primary election campaign that threatens to dash Gov. John A. Burns's hopes for a third term. The primary is Oct. 3.

title: Rosamond H. Heroy Bride of Lieut. Thomas Miller
description: HUNTINGTON, L, I., Sept. 12Miss Rosamond Hoyt Heroy, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Ward Heroy of Lloyd Harbor, was married here this afternoon to Lieut. Thomas Hayes Miller, U.S.N. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry M. Miller of Elizabeth town, Ky.

title: FALCONS DEFEAT DOLPHINS, 2017
description: MIAMI, Sept. 12 (AP)Bob Berry rifled a 9yard touch down pass on fourth down to Jim Mitchell with 34 seconds remaining tonight to give the Atlanta Falcons a 2017 victory over the Miami Dolphins.

title: M'ANDREW EXCELS
description: Jim McAndrew pitched the New York Mets to a 30 vic tory over the St. Louis Cardi nals yesterday and kept them in the thick of the threeway scramble for the Eastern championship of the National League.

title: GOSS BEATS MARIN IN JERSEY FAIR BOUT
description: TRENTON, Sept. 12In clinchless, action packed fight that kept a history making crowd of over 4,000 persons screaming for their hometown favorite, Sammy Goss of Tren ton, the world's fourth rated junior lightweight, scored a near shutout over Jose Marin of Costa Rica and New Ro chelle. N. Y. in 10 rounds.

title: 16 Challenges by British
description: Of the 20 previous challenges for the America's Cup, 16 were made by Britain, two by Can ada and two by Australia.

title: VIRGINIA CONQUERS VIRGINIA TECH, 70
description: BLACKSBURG, Va., Sept. 12 (UPI)  Jimmy Lacey bulled through the middle for 3 yards and a touchdown in the final period to give Virginia a 70 upset victory over Virginia Tech in football today.

title: Alison Lee Palfrey Fullerton Is Married to Bruce Whitman
description: Miss Alison Lee Palfrey Fullerton, daughter of Mrs. Harold W. Fullerton of Brook line, Mass., and the late Dr. Fullerton, who was Regius Professor of, Medicine at the Univerity of Aberdeen in Scotland, was married here yesterday afternoon to Bruce Whitman, son of John S. Whitman of Brooklyn and the late Mrs. Whitman. The ceremony in Bethlehem United Church of Christ, Brooklyn, was performed by the Rev. Allen MacLean.

title: Democrats Nominate Kane For State Supreme Court
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 12 (AP) Judge James L. Kane of City Court was chosen by Demo crats today as their candidate for State Supreme Court in Western New York's Eighth Judicial District.

title: Gonzales Finds Partner, 18, for Doubles
description: If you eat your spinach, tennis playing parents ex horted their sons two decades ago. You can grow up and play like Pancho Gon zales. In 1952, with Gon zales already having won Wimbledon title and two United States champion ships, a boy was born in Illinois who not only ate his spinach, but also grew up to become Gonzales's doubles partner.

title: Charge of Guilt for Songmy
description: Who was responsible for the massacre in which an estimated 500 Vietnamese civilians are said to have been slaughtered by American troops in the vil lage of Songmy on March 16, 1968?

title: A Forest Rail Trip In Ontario
description: SAULT STE. MARIE, On tarioThe train rarely trav els at more than 25 miles an hour, so passengers have plenty of time to admire the cliffs splashed with waterfalls and maybe a moose or bear cavorting by a lake or stream as it rolls through the deep forests. The hardwood trees here in south central Ontario are beginning to turn, and a busy season is coming for the Algoma Central Railway, which plunges into an area northeast of Lake Superior where no roads yet reach.

title: LATE RALLY FAILS
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 12If Leo Durocher had as much faith in Ferguson Jenkins's ability to bunt as the Chicago pitcher has, the Pittsburgh Pirates might have tumbled out of first place today.

title: Big Grape Crop Due in State
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UPI)New York's 1970 grape crop is expected to increase this year, in contrast to a national decline, the crop reporting board has reported. The crop was estimated at 140,000 tons, compared with 121,000 last year.

title: The Disparate Worlds of Cambridge
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.The silver touring bus, its oncegleaming flanks dimmed by a layer of road grime and exhaust, lumbered around the corner into Har vard Square. A sign on the front trum peted the origin of its journey: Charlotte, N. C. On the sidewalk beneath the bus's tinted windows a little boy was losing his lunch, while a pregnant woman and a cop bent over him. A young black man with an intricate array of scars on his cheek hawked the Black Panther news paper, and there was the square's usual parade of frizzedup hair and freaked out fashion.

title: Beethoven Is Alive in London
description: IS it possible to apply computer technology to the com position of new music by old composers? Why not? Some time ago I suggested that if a computer were fed all the facts of Be'thoven's musical development and all of his extant work, it could very well be asked to compose a new work by Beethoventhe next point on the Beethoven curve. And so we arrived at a Beetho venIBM production of his 10th Symphony!

title: What must we do in, for and to the world after Vietnam?
description: The trouble with conventional wis dom is that almost everyone pays homage to it but virtually no one follows it. In foreign policy the main tenet of the new conventional wis dom is that America should not be the world's policeman. But 25 years after World War II, Americans are still at it, acting as watchmen on the walls of world freedom, as John F. Kennedy put it in an address sched uled to be delivered in Dallas, on Nov. 22, 1963. Take, for example, Hanson W. Baldwin, the former New York Times military editor, in his new book Strategy for Tomorrow. Af ter disclaiming any need for us to impose a Pax Americana upon the world, he then totes up the balance sheet of our commitments versus our resources; the former list is stagger ing.

title: Stories that deal with the violence we do to others and ourselves
description: When writing of this quality ap pears, one must deplore the fact that the words moving and com passionate have grown meaningless with overuse. Frank Tuohy writes with Chekhovian simplicity of events and sensations that are, like his title, palpable, recognizable and a painful part of everyone's experi ence. He does not strike attitudes or harp on popular themes: these stories deal with violence, but it is the violence we do to our friends and to ourselves.

Where this doesn't happen, a lot of pat tern does, as in a mottled black patent ankle boot at $40, a snakeskin  printed shiny vinyl slipon shoe at $36 (it is referred to as snake under glass), or, for the really daring, a shoe handpainted in a checked or abstract pattern at $42.

title: The Hostages
description: A new phase has begun in the major crisis precipi tated last week by the assaults against international civil aviation. World public opinion won a partial victory by forcing the Arab hijackers to release the great majority of their innocent victims. Anger at this involuntary retreat was probably an important motive for the senseless and criminal destruction of three additional jet airplanes. Now the core of the problem is the terrorists effort to use their remaining hostages as the means of blackmailing Western na tions and Israel.

title: Straub's 'Othon' Plumbs Love and Drive for Power
description: Jean-Marie Straub's "Othon," which played in Alice Tully Hall on Saturday evening, is an adaptation of a late drama by Corneille, derived from the career of Marcus Salvius Otho, who, in the year A.D. 69, murdered his leader, Servius Sulpicius Galba, and had himself proclaimed Emperor of Rome. Corneille's play is very largely concerned with the affections of two young women, Camille, Galba's niece, and Plautine, daughter of the senator Vinius, who are both in love with Othon; and it is at pains to juxtapose the irreconcilable requirements of a drive for power with the urgencies of tragic love.By placing his film in ancient settings (the Palatine Hill, and later, the Villa Doria Pamphili) that are however surrounded by the sights and sounds of contemporary Rome (traffic is the background noise for the earlier parts of "Othon"; an unnaturally loud fountain for the later parts) Straub, co-directing with his wife, Daniele Huillet, has included himself in an historical time scheme of considerable, multi-layered complexityincluding, of course, 17th-century France (and the Rome of 17th-century France) as well as the ancient and the modern worlds.Such complexity is perfectly typical of Straub, as is his ease with history, with literature and art. He has already filmed literary and dramatic works by Heinrich Bll and Ferdinand Bruckner and has made a movie, a great one, consisting almost wholly of concertized excerpts from Johann Sebastian Bach. Although he has the best kind of serious reputation he has little commercial appeal, and each of his previous features, "Unreconciled" and "Chronicle of Anna Magdalena Bach," owes its introduction here to the New York Film Festival.This year, as in the past, the festival paid Straub its greatest tribute (the only valuable, though not infallible, objective test of a film's importance I know of) when at the press screening of "Othon" half the audience got up and walked out.Although in color, and quite handsomely costumed, "Othon" makes very few concessions to ordinary sensuous response. Characters speak Corneille's verses rapidly and with minimal expression (actually, expression varies: The older men, Galba and Vinius, are allowed both gesture and inflection; the young are allowed scarcely so much as a turn of the head). The camera pans, often so as to avoid the face of the character speaking, and moves in and outand except for one glorious tracking shot, that is almost all the camera does.And yet this Puritan cinema offers rewards for the sustained contemplation it demandsnot the rewards of special insight, or of mystical vision, but rather of a perfectly controlled probity, assurance and understanding of a movie subject's rhythms and spacial potential. A love for Straub's work will comebut only with time and to the astute and the properly disposed."Othon" is magnificently performed by its almost expressionless cast. I admired especially the film critic Adriano Apr as Othon and Straub himself (a significant casting) as the murderous prefect Lacus. But, within the range allowed by the direction, beautiful Olimpia Carlisi, as Camille, gave me a fuller appreciation of what ancient royalty should have been like than has any other actress I have seen in the movies.

title: Stockholm: Conformism and Rebellion
description: STOCKHOLMSwedish lit erature never has had an easy time. Even today Swed ish is a language understood by a number of people hardly exceeding that of the metro politan area of New York City; and of that number, the progress of centuries has evolved only a small percentage educated highly enough to The receptive to a Swedish litera ture. Born in the songs and pamph lets of the Lutheran Reforma tion at the early beginnings of the 16th century, the Swedish language was buf feted for the next 300 years by attacks from poverty, Lutheran orthodoxy and roy al centralism (for the main tradition of Swedish history was and still remains a cen tralistic one). It is therefore perhaps not surprising that this gave rise to a literature of social protest. Strindberg in Sweden (like Georg Bran des in Denmark) made the breakthrough to literary nat uralism, but his greater im pact was as an opponent of the established order, and he created a Swedish literary tradition of being in op position.

title: I. M. F. BARS SHIFT IN MONETARYRATE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13  The executive directors of the International Monetary Fund, in the first major official study of more flexible exchange rates among currencies, ruled out to day any major change in the current world system of fixed rates but disclosed disagree ment on suggested minor changes.

title: Pilot Held by Arabs Complains of Jews With 2 Passports
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 13 A captive Trans World Airways pilot complained tonight that many Jewish Americans are allowed to have two passports.

title: John Savage, Judy Gibson Sign for Sensation Leads
description: Two performers who are ap peering in Broadway musicals have been signed for the lead ing roles in Sensations, de scribed as a musical experience based on excerpts from Romeo and Juliet.

title: Lawyer Says 10,000 Violate Alabama Integration Order
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 13 Somewhere along the red ridges and winding roads of the suburbs that surround the gritty industrial city of Bir mingham, thousands of white school children might as well have vanished. At least no one here except a black civil rights lawyer seems willing to say where they have been since the schools opened two weeks ago.

description: Deaths

description: Exhibition Football

title: News Summary and Index
description: Israel, in an apparent attempt to put pres sure on the Palestinian guerrillas holding more than 50 airline passengers, yesterday arrested more than 450 Arabs in the occu pied westbank and Gaza Strip areas. Those in custody were said to be suspected of be longing to or aiding the guerrilla group that is holding the hijacked passengers in Jordan. [Page 1, Columns 78.]

title: 14 NEWSMEN NAMED FOR GRADUATE STUDY
description: Fourteen journalists have been selected as Fellows in Columbia University's Advanced International Reporting Program for 197071 and will devote the academic year, beginning this week, to graduate studies in international affairs. Ten are from the United States and four are from foreign countries.

title: Talks Set on Spanish Sahara
description: RABAT, Morocco, Sept. 13 (Reuters)The heads of state of Morocco, Algeria and Mauri tania, the three countries around the Spanish Sahara, will hold a brief summit meet ing in Mauritania tomorrow to plan strategy for the libera tion of the Spanish desert colony.

description: Mets Records

title: ERROR HELPS CUBS WIN IN NINTH, 32
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 13As the ball rose into the air, Steve Blass leaped off the mound and began jumping up and down like a little boy, his arms waving jubilantly. As the ball descended, Blass's legs and arms became still. Instead of falling into Matty Alou's glove for the last out in a 21 Pittsburgh victory, the ball dropped to the ground for an error and the Chicago Cubs were on their way to a 32 tri umph today.

title: OILERS TROUNCE EAGLES, 26 TO 7
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 13 (AP)Charlie Johnson's pass ing and a stout defense led the Houston Oilers to a 267 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles today in an exhibition game.

title: TV Review
description: The long siege of reruns finally began to lift'last night as the fall season of tele vision opened, a ritual that will run until the end of Sep tember on the commercial TV networki and then move into October on noncommer cial TV. Twentytwo shows will be bowing under adver tising auspices and about 14 without benefit of the hard sell, at least on a nonprofit local outlet, Channel 13.

title: Peruzzi Madonna by Raphael Is Stolen From Coast Investor
description: A painting by Raphael, the Peruzzi Madonna, that was sold here at auction for $27,500 in 1950 and later evaluated by museum officials to be worth at least $1.2million, was stolen Saturday night from the Hollywood home of Charles F. Elkins.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Special Committee on Colonialism, subcommittee on petitions10:15 A.M.

title: Astros Beat Braves, 106; 6 Unearned Runs Set Stage
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 13 (AP) The Houston Astros poured six unearned runs across in the first inning today and coasted to a 106 victory over the At lanta Braves.

title: LLOYD E. BUDD
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 13 Lloyd E. Budd, who retired as an accountant for The New York Times In 1952 after 30 years with the newspaper, died yesterday in his home at 21 Partridge Road. He was 82 years old. Mr. Budd, who was graduated from Pace Institute, was a certified public account ant.

title: FAIRFIELD TRIUMPHS IN CUP POLO, 12 TO 4
description: DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 13 With Bob Lubash and Al Maren holz scoring four goals each, the Fairfield County Hunt Club's No. I team turned back Salem View of North Salem, N. Y., 124, today in a first round game of the Governor's Cup polo championship at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club.

title: Queen of All Courts
description: Mrs. Margaret Court is known around the world for her serve, volley and over head, but her husband, Barry, will tell you that no one cooks roast lamb or barbe cued ribs better than his wife.

title: Tax Revolt: 46,000 Shut Out of School
description: A major revolt of taxpayers believed to be the biggest and most serious of its kind to date has shut 46,000 pupils out of classes in four suburban school districts north of St. Louis, and threatens to do the same for 35,000 students in two neigh boring districts next month.

title: 500 Youths Plan Antiradical Crusade
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 13It was a meeting of young counterrevolutionaries.

title: Freed U.S. Citizens Tell of Their Fears
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Sept. 13 United States citizens freed after six days aboard their hijacked planes in the Jor danian desert said today that their Arab captors had kept them, as a psychiatrist put it, in a state of controlled fear and uncontrolled anxiety.

title: VAN ARSDALE SCORES TAXILOCKBOX PLAN
description: Harry Van Arsdale, head of the Metropolitan Taxi Driv ers Union, said yesterday that the installation of cash lock boxes in cabs would not solve the problem of attacks on cab drivers.

title: Pollution and Taxes
description: The testimony of Secretary of the Treasury David M. Kennedy on tax issues the other day verged on the incomprehensible. He asserted that the Ad ministration desperately needed the estimated $1.1 billion from the proposed tax on the lead in gaso line in this fiscal year. But he refused to produce any fresh estimates of expenditures and revenues which would support this request.

title: SNEAD BEATS BRITON IN SENIOR GOLF FINAL
description: PORTSMOUTH, Va., Sept. 13 (AP)Sam Snead surging back strongly after being five down at the 1,5th hole in the morning round, defeated Max Faulkner of Britain, 3 and 2, today in the 36hole world professional se nior golf championships.

title: REAGAN ANSWERS UNRUH ON ETHICS
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 13Gov. Ronald Reagan, after a week of listening to Jess Unruh, his Democratic opponent, criticize the Governor's relations with his wealthy backers, replied today that for an honest man codes of ethics are meaning lesss.

title: Randy L. Kalikow Wed to S.G. Ketive
description: Miss Randy Lyn Kalikow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Kalikow of New York and Atlantic Beach, LI., was married here yesterday to Samuel G. Ketive, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Ketive of New York and Fort Lauder dale, Fla. The ceremony was performed at the Plaza by Rabbi Sol Roth, a vice presi dent of the New York Board of Rabbis.

title: Screen: 3 Visit Pig Butchery in Fontaine's 'Double Pisces Scorpio Rising'
description: Toward the end of "Double Pisces, Scorpio Rising," three people whimsically look in on a pig slaughterhouse, as the color camera bobs around, cinma-vrit, catching their casual reactions to the commotion around them  the piteous squealing of the terrified animals who are dangled, butchered and quartered. Some of the close-ups of these poor critters are pips.One of the human trio is Dick Fontaine, the director, a thin, long-haired youth who has put together this highly personal exercise on something or other that runs, mercifully, for 58 minues and comes from an English group of movie folk called the Tattooists. The second visitor to the animal abattoir is a pretty girl. The third is a porky, middle-aged man addicted to the expression, "Ya know?"The two men carry on a running argument about whether they should make a picture about pigs. "Are we making a movie, ya know?" says Fatso. "Where is it, ya know?" Then a bit later: "I'm making a movie about pigs, ya know?"The pigs, the ones we see, don't stand a chance, ya know? Nor does anyone else who doesn't happen to know Mr. Fontaine personally and wonders what he's getting at. The first part shows smiling glimpses of Norman Mailer, in a neat suit and tie, amiably campaigning for Mayor. We see him riding the Coney Island roller coaster.Then we're off on Mr. Fontaine's own visual roller coaster, watching and hearing him inside a television studio as he chats and clicks his camera. At home he dials the phone repeatedly. He visits his childhood home and reminisces with a pensive woman portraying his mother.The chapter also includes close-ups of the pretty model, Jean Shrimpton, reading a fable that implies soul-searching. And we see Mr. Fontaine again, this time crouched on the roof of what appears to be a school, assembling a machine gun. "The audience," he tells us, "waits for me to begin." Amen.Paired with this film at Philharmonic Hall on Saturday afternoo was another exercise called "Zorns Lemma," made by Hollis Frampton, an American. For five minutes, with the screen blank, a woman's voice recites from "The Bay State Primer," whatever that is. The real goody follows.For 45 minutes the screen clicksone, two, three, etc.the course of the alphabet, as pinpointed to the first letter of various photographed signs, labels and images implying the letter. Over and over and over it goes. And never, at least so far during the Film Festival, have so many Philharmonic Hall viewers slithered outside for a cigarette.For his brief coda, Mr. Frampon shows us two human figures and a dog distantly tramping around in the snow, then disappearing as the screen turns white. The sound track here is a group of women's voices, eking out a medieval text on light and form, one word apiece. The Andrews Sisters did it better.

title: Black Panthers Open Office in Algiers
description: ALGIERS, Sept. 13The Black Panther party opened an international section today. Eldridge Cleaver, the party's minister of information, said the section would serve as a rival to the Rogers State Department.

title: Meadowbrook Conquers Oyster Bay in Polo, 75
description: BETHPAGE, L. I., Sept. 13 Tom Monaco scored four goals and Alan Corey 3d tallied three today as the Meadowbrook polo team scored a 75 victory over Oyster Bay in the opening round of the, Shaw W. Robin son Memorial tournament at Bethpage State Park.

title: Newport Celebrates on Eve of Cup Races
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 13 One couple arrived in a chauffeurdriven Volkswagen and another curtsied to an astonished receiving line. An elegant young man lost a blue white diamond from a ring on his pinkie and some of the committee cast a watchful eye on another male guest who showed up in a suspicious outfita bril liantly colored shirt and a startling patterned tiejust in case he steals the silver, as someone explained.

title: Goldberg Says Governor Turnsto Right
description: With a newly acquired Amer ican flag emblem glittering on his lapel, Arthur J. Goldberg accused Governor Rockefeller yesterday of going to the right in his bid for election to a fourth term.

title: Thousands of Fish Killed By a Chemical in Alaska
description: SITKA, Alaska, Sept. 13 (AP) A biologist for the Alaska Department of Fish and Game said yesterday that hundreds of thousands of fish had been killed by an unknown chemical floating on the waters of Silver Bay near Sitka.

title: Mrs. Court Wins Title
description: Mrs. Margaret Court of Australia achieved the grand slam of tennis yesterday by beating Rosemary Casals, 62, 26, 61, for the United States Open title. Ken Rose wall of Australia won the men's title with a 26, 64, 76, 63 victory over Tony Roche, a countryman, in the Forest Hills stadium before 14,502. (Details on Page 50.)

title: Sports of the Times
description: Antonio Valentin, a small, slender, 29yearold Puerto Rican who speaks little English, is scheduled to sentenced tomorrow in Queens Criminal Court on a third degree assault charge, reckless endangerment, to which he has already pleaded guilty. Judge Philip 1 Chetta's de cisionwhich can range from a suspended sentence to a year in jail and a thousand dollar fine is not likely to be a milestone in American jurisprudence, but the background of the case is a milestone in the social history of American sports.

title: ClosedEnd Funds
description: Following Is a weekly listing of the net asset value of dosedend Investment fund shares as reported by the companies through the Association of ClosedEnd Investment Companies at the close of business Friday. Also shown Is the closing market price of each fund's shares, with the percentage difference discount or premium. Where the stock Is traded over the counter, the market price Is the N.A.S.D. dealertodealer asked price.

title: BURTON BOWMAN, 60, CYANAMID OFFICIAL
description: FRANKLIN LAKES, N. J. Sept. 13Burton F. Bowman, a vice president of the Ameri can Cyanamid Company since 1968, died today of a heart at tack in his home at 822 Scioto Drive. His age was 60.

title: List of Persons Presumed Held
description: Following is a list of passengers and crew members of the three hijacked airliners who are not known to have been released and are presumably still held as hostages. The com pilation is based on passenger lists, which may have in cluded the hijackers under pseudonyms; current information from the airlines and news agency reports. The three air lines are Trans World Airlines, British Overseas Airways Corporation and Swissair.

title: Political Endorsement
description: Endorsements seem to be in this year in New York politics. They are being pre sented to the public with a flourish that sometimes dis guises the fact that most poli ticians believe that most politi cal endorsements usually mean nothing to anyone except to the men giving and receiving them.

description: HONG KONG, Sept. 13 Communist China has belatedly attacked the treaty of coopera tion signed by the Soviet Union and West Germany last month, accusing Soviet leaders of hav ing betrayed the interests of the people of Europe.

description: A mass of thanksgiving was celebrated yesterday in St. Pat rick's Cathedral for the safe re turn of the Most Rev. James E. Walsh, the Maryknoll bishop held captive by Communist Chi na for 12 years until his release from a Shanghai prison last July 10.

Rogers met for several hours today with other top State De partment officials to consider what could be done to obtain the release of the hostages, estimated, to number 54, in cluding 30 United States citi zens, still being held by Pales tinian guerrillas in Jordan.

title: Screen: Mizoguchi Borrows From an Ancient Kabuki Drama:A Scrollmaker Flees With Master's Wife Other Festival Entry Limns a Revolutionary
description: "Chikamatzu Monogatari," which played yesterday afternoon at the New York Film Festival, is a story from the work of the Kabuki dramatist Chikamatzu Monzaemon (1653-1724), who, according to one text, is considered the Japanese Shakespeare. Compared with the films of Kenji Mizoguchi with which we are already familiar (for example, "Ugetzu"1953, "The Bailiff"1954, or the sublime "Life of O'Haru"  1952), "Chikamatzu Monogatari," made in 1954, seems less lyrically poetic, less picturesquely strange, less immediately beautiful. But on the basis of just one viewing, I should guess that it is no less great.It is, however, enough different in feeling to deserve some description. It is the story of how the scrollmaker Mohei, in attempting to help his master's wife out of a financial embarrassment, is virtually forced into running away with her so that he becomes indeed the adulterous lover of a woman he has long worshipped in secret.The couple have no peace, partly because the husband's position will not allow the dishonor, and in time they are returned (with the help of Mohei's father), and, as is the custom with adulterers of a certain rank, they are taken off in ritual procession to be crucified. The husband is ruined anyway, and as the film ends, his scroll factory, the most prosperous in the imperial city of Kyoto, is confiscated.For much of its length, "Chikamatzu Monogatari" takes place within a single household, and it is given to a massive exploration of the master scrollmaker's office, workrooms, kitchen, and living quarters. The interiors at times resemble a constructivist stage set, with its allocation of levels, spaces, and connecting stairways; and the action, at least up until the actual flight, borders on the edge of bedroom comedy.It is only after the flightand especially during one breathtaking scene at night in a small boat, when the couple decided against suicide and suddenly learn that they are loversthat the film opens out, just for a few moments at a time, into that gorgeous misty countryside that we have come to expect as the metaphysical universe of the Mizoguchi dramas.I think the reason is that "Chikamatzu Monogatari" is in profound ways really about the rigorous complexity of its interiors and courtyards; that it is about relationships (man-woman, brother-sister, child-parent, servant-master) and responsibilities, and about the absolutely fantastic interdependency of everything upon everything else. Therefore, the film's appearance is moment-by-moment an extension of its theme, and the stultifying closeness of every life with every other above it, below it, and next to it is in fact the metaphysical universe of this particular Mizoguchi drama.That universe is somehow incomplete without its adulterous lovers (we see one pair at the beginning of the film, and then, of course, the hero and heroine at the end) and their sacrificial murders. They stand as if for all the potential of a responsive personal life that is rigorously excluded from the social structure of the public and familial worlds. They are outlaws and yet they are representative (everybody's life in "Chikamatzu Monogatari," just below the surface is, or could be, a mess); they are dangerous and beautiful; they are necessaryand they are genuinely intolerable. The master scrollmaker Ishun, an unpleasant character is brought to ruin because he has been cuckolded  and his punishishment is not less real, or less unjust, than his wife's.I don't want to give the impression that "Chickamatzu Monogatari" is all scheme (though it is highly schematic) and without more sensuous pleasures. The performances are graceful, gentle, individualized and lovely. The music, which is mostly Japanese, ranks with the most expressive I have ever heard in a film. And the look of the film, indoors or out, is like a tribute to the traditions of Japanese genre painting and the pictorial logic of the old almost square-shaped movie screen.During the main title credits to Lasse Forsberg's "Mistreatment," which played last night at the New York Film Festival, a sign flashes on the screen to announce that "the actors are responsible for their lines." In so far as this is true, and at the press-screening news conference Forsberg assured the audience that it is quite true, "Mistreatment" is blessed with a remarkably articulate group of actors. And the most remarkable is Knut Pettersen, a nonprofessional (though he has had some training) with a fine aggressive manner and a notable ability to talk his head off.Pettersen plays a 31-year-old Stockholm radical who one day assaults the owner of a Jaguar (class exploitation; Pettersen figures the car is rightly his) and six months later, after several polite interrogations and much psychological testing, finds himself strapped and drugged in a progressive and well-managed state insane asylum.The central question of who's really insane (a question suggested by the film's title) is complicated by the fact that Pettersen picks his fights, mercilessly abuses the official machinery intended to help him, turns social awareness into paranoia, and generally acts as crazy as the well-adjusted types around him seem to think he is. He writes dreadful tracts full of revolutionary insight, in his personal accusations he is unjust, and he makes difficulties where none seem to exist. But he has the wisdom of his maladjustment, and each time he feels himself trapped, it turns out that there is indeed a cage to hold him. He is in some degree a function of the society he protests, and it is proper to ask of him not the blueprint for a brave new world, but a few truculent insights into this one.I greatly like the Pettersen character (and I greatly like Pettersen), but I am not so impressed with his revolutionary peer (Bjorn Granath) or the pleasant shop girl (Berit Persson) whom Bjorn seduces and abandons as a chapter in his own more cerebral protest diary.Most of Forsberg's dullest filmmaking centers on this pair, who live together in an apartment decorated like a handbook in revolutionary rhetoric, and who, even in bed, do uninteresting things with one another. In its subplot, if you will, "Mistreatment" too often settles for elaborate but inexpressive gestures and for the kind of empty irony that sometimes gives young filmmakers a bad name.Forsberg isn't all that young (37), but this is his first featureand it is important not for its failures but for moments of success, which are unusual, difficult, and most moving when apparently most annoying. Much of "Mistreatment" looks like a lot of other recent movies (the new freedom in subject matter has led, of course, to the most boring insistence on relevance) but where it becomes individual, and almost always where it is informed by the mind and style of Knut Pettersen, it is funny, strong and healthfully uncomfortable.

title: Bachelor's Cheesecake Beats Women's at Fair

title: Screen: Chabrol Examines a Very Delicate Balance:'Le Boucher' Stars His Wife as Schoolteacher
description: Claude Chabrol's "Le Boucher" is a love story about a gentle, self-possessed butcher, Popaul (Jean Yanne), who may or may not spend his off-hours carving up young women in the woods, and a lovely school mistress, Mile. Hlne (Stphane Audran). The setting is the tiny village of Tremolat, not far from the Lascaux caves, but Mile. Hlne is no ordinary small-town school mistress. She is a woman who obviously buys her clothes in Paris, who can smoke in the street  a Gauloise hanging from her mouth apache-style  without ever losing her chic, and who responds with genuine pleasure when a student writes in a theme that "it was so hot the air hurt you . . ."Popaul and Mile. Hlne meet at one of those exuberant, traditional wedding feasts at which they are the apparent but not unhappy outsiders. He is just out of the regular Army (where, as he says, he did a lot of butchering in Algeria and Indo-china), and she has been living in a very feminine kind of sexual isolation ever since a love affair ended disastrously 10 years earlier.They make an odd but immensely appealing pair as he courts her with specially cut legs of lamb and as she draws him into her life by having him join her on mushroom hunts and as a participant in a school fete, for which she teaches the butcher an 18th-century court dance (one of the movie's most touching moments). On one excursion to the country, he asks her how she can do without a lover. "There are other ways," she answers. "Disgusting," says the butcher, and she laughs. Later he wonders what she would do if he tried to kiss her. "Nothing," she answers, adding, in a way that is both vulnerable and absolutely chilling, "but I wish you wouldn't."Like all of Chabrol's recent films, "Le Boucher" has to do with decisions made moments too late, of love just missed like a train. It is also second only to the practically perfect "La Femme Infidle" as the most elegant, most sorrowful of Chabrol's recent films, better than both the very stylish but geometric "Les Biches" and "Que La Bte Meure" (which will be released here as "This Man Must Die").I'm not sure that "Le Boucher" works for me on the level of psychological realism. I find it impossible to accept the suggestion that Chabrol ultimately makes, that is, that Mile. Hlne could have saved the psychotic killer from himself had she not been afraid to love, and that, by withholding her love, she is in some way as much of a beast as he is, fit to be condemned to eternal loneliness.Ironically, however, it is completely credible as romantic realism of the kind that has its models in Hitchcock's "Spellbound" and Lang's "Scarlet Street." Although Chabrol will probably never attain the seeming spontaneity of his masters (he is simply too intellectual a filmmaker), he can excel both when it comes to creating deeply felt characters and their relationships with each other as well as with their environment.The tempo and the temper and even the weather of the little town of Tremolat are very much a part of "Le Boucher" and of the lives of Popaul and Mile. Hlne, who emotionally, anyway, pass in the course of the storm from late summer into irrevocable autumn. This is not to say the movie is without some conscious Hitchcockian details. Chabrol builds his suspense obliquely and although he uses blood sparingly, it is done with a sense of spectacle.There is one particularly outrageous moment when a little girl, who has been on a group outing to the caves, sits beneath a cliff and unwraps her sandwich, only to have a large dollop of red fall on the bread. It's the first indication that the killer's been at work again and that his victim, dead but still warm as pie, is hidden above."Le Boucher," however, is not primarily interesting as conventional mystery, which the film makes little effort to maintain after a certain point. Rather it's as a moving love story that it makes sense, and this because Chabrol has respect and admiration for his stars as performers and as characters. Yanne's Popaul, for example, who does such terrible things off-screen, is never seen on screen as anything but completely sympathetic.It's no casual coincidence that each of Chabrol's best movies recently has starred Miss Audran, who, in private life, is Mrs. Chabrol and, in public, is the most beautiful and enigmatic screen personality to emerge in France since the early appearances of Jeanne Moreau in the 1950's. In "Le Boucher" there is something about Miss Audran's intelligence, her wit, her style and her wardrobe that makes her seem a very unlikely provincial schoolmarm, but (as it used to be with actresses like Garbo and Dietrich) it's this very unlikelihood that makes the character of Mile. Helne appear to be unique, thus special and worth caring about."Le Boucher," which was shown Saturday night at the New York Film Festival, has not yet been acquired for commercial release.Billy Casper (David Bradley, a 15-year-old Yorkshire lad, who is small for his age, is always the last to be taken when sides are chosen for a soccer match. It's not only because his gym shorts are so big that he can hitch them over his shoulders; it is also because he is awkward and clumsy and likely to be daydreaming at crucial moments in the game. In real life, he'd probably be as difficult to live with as everyone says he is.On the screen, however, he's the tough-minded, blithe-spirited totally enchanting hero of "Kes," an honorable, decent sort of movie that is, however, never quite as interesting as the people within it. The film was shown last night at Philharmonic Hall at the New York Film Festival.Kenneth Loach ("Poor Cow") shot "Kes" entirely on location in the north of England, mostly with nonprofessional and semiprofessional actors who are, without exception, superb, as are individual scenes, seemingly improvised, that erupt with enormous vrit. Nevertheless, vrit alone does not necessarily make great cinma. It has, in fact, a way of reducing the tragic to the merely sad, almost commonplace.In its implications, if not in its execution, "Kes" is a tragedy, as classic and inevitable as Franois Truffaut's "The 400 Blows" seemed (at least until we learned, from subsequent films, that Truffaut's Antoine Doinel was to turn out rather well). Billy is the younger son in a household that consists of a tired mother, abandoned by her husband, and a bully of an older brother, with whom he has to share a very narrow bed. Billy, who has been abandoned too, makes one triumphant gesture toward maturityhe finds and trains (as opposed to tames) a young kestrel, only to have his brother, in a moment of rage, kill the hawk.For some explicable reasons, "Kes" left me, at the end, not terribly moved, partially because Loach never indicates whether this defeat for Billy simply marks the end of his childhood, or whether it will be permanent (in which case, of course, Billy might grow up to be the hero of something like "Saturday Night and Sunday Morning," which isn't too terrifying).Loach, instead of imposing the kind of discipline that would have given Billy's story greater point, opts to let the film simply run on, and it runs on most entertainingly, but always in ways that somehow cheat Billy.There are lovely scenes depicting Billy's training of the hawk, and the hawk is the star. There's a hilarious chaotic soccer game refereed by the coach, who is also the captain of one of the teams and thus inclined to favor himself with a magnificent lack of embarrassment.Billy is also a supporting player in the most moving scene in the film, in which he and a group of friends, smokers all, are ushered into the office of the headmaster, who promptly puts the switch to a tiny, innocent boy who has come to deliver a message. "A regular tobacco factory," the headmaster calls him, as the boy, tears in the corners of his eyes, mutely accepts the injustice.Loach is not a director of notable style, nor can he often refuse the obvious shot, but he seems to have a remarkable talent for handling actors and obtaining performances that are truly memorable. I was not especially bothered by one bit of authenticity, the Yorkshire accents that sometimes make key lines of dialogue unintelligible. But then I originally saw the film at Cannes, where the French subtitles were an enormous help.

title: RAYMOND BRUNER, 70, WRITER ON SCIENCE
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 14  Raymond A. Bruner, a self taught writer on science and medicine who won many na tional writing awards in 17 years as science editor of The Toledo Blade, died after a heart attack yesterday in his home here. He was 70 years old.

title: Martin Foresees New Central Bank On a Global Basis
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 William McChesney Martin Jr. in his first public address since retiring as Chairman of the Fed eral Reserve Board, said today, We are in a process of evolu tion toward a world central Bank.

title: ULYSSE MAB JOINS U.N. TROT'S FIELD
description: YONKERS, Sept. 14Ulysse Mab will replace Dart Hanover, his stablemate, in the $50,000 United Nations Trot at Yonkers Raceway on Friday night, Ed Parker, racing secretary, an nounced today. Dart Hanover was reported sore by his train er. Lee Broalio.

title: 3 Major Lines Involved; Court Enjoins 4 Unions
description: WASHINGTON, Tuesday, Sept. 15 Four railroad unions or dered a strike against three major railroads at 12:01 this morning after contract negotia tions with the carriers collapsed late last night.

title: Business Aid Pushed
description: PLEASANTVILLE, Sept. 14 More than 150 minority busi nessmen met 195 purchasing agents and top management personnel at a Minority Busi ness Day on the Pace College campus here today. Although the planning committee report ed satisfaction over the effort, no hard contracts for business were reported.

title: Drop Is Shown for Sept. 110 by Big Four
description: DETROIT, Sept. 14  The four big car makers reported today 123,304 sales of new United Statesbuilt cars in the first third of September, down from 133,241 retail deliveries la year earlier.

title: 91GREATMYSTERY SCORES IN JEROME
description: It was a bull market for longshot players at Belmont Park yesterday as an Uncle Sam daily double of $1,315.40the largest of the New York season had the bigods fraternity in the crowd of 25,202 beating a trail to the payoff windows for much of the afternoon.

title: 3 Held as Counterfeiters
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 14 (AP)Secret Service agents have seized $45,000 in counter feit money and printing para phernalia In a raid on a Kansas City residence. Three persons were arrested. They were William L. Curtis, Mrs. Rosemary Dolores Ramirez and Patrick J. Goulding.

title: Daughter to Mrs. Trilling
description: DURHAM, N. C., Sept. 14 A daughter was born Sept. 4 to Prof. and Mrs. Richard J. Trilling at the Watts Hos pital here. The child has been named Beth Raina. Her father is on the graduate faculty, of political science at Duke Uni versity. Her mother is the, former Miss Faye Goldberger of Cleveland.

title: ROCK ISLAND PICKS CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 14  Theo dore E. Desch, 38 years old, was named a vice chairman of the board and chief executive officer here today of the Chi cago, Rock Island & Pacific Railroad. William J. Dixon, 51, was named president and Peter Kiewit, 70, was named acting chairman.

title: 5 Nations Firm on Hostages By BERNARD WEINRAUB
description: LONDON, Sept. 14Five na tions agreed today on an all ornothing settlement over the release of the 50 or more hos tages held by the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine.

title: Tennis Smells Success
description: The signs of success were everywhere: record crowds, sizable prize money, national television, the introduction of a sudden death scoring sys tem, a grand slam, a public protest by women players, complaints against the press, renewed talk of synthetics re placing grass, manufacturers peddlling their wares, and, of course, politics.

title: Japan Had August Surplus In Foreign Trade Payments
description: TOKYO, Sept. 14 (Reuters) The Finance Ministry said to day that Japan had a balance of international payments surer plus of $180million in August, compared with a revised sur plus of $79million in July and $97million in August, 1969.

title: South African Court Acquits 19 Blacks
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 14Nineteen black Afri cans accused of black nation alist activities were acquitted today in Supreme Court. A prosecution appeal on a ques tion of law was allowed.

title: PANELISTS AGREE ON SMUT REPORT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 In a surprise compromise, the chairman of the President's Commission on Obscenity and Pornography and the commis sion's leading dissident cleared, the way today for the publi cation of the panel's much disputed final report at the end of the month.

title: Two Producers Lift Newsprint Prices
description: A move toward higher news print prices announced last week by AngloCanadian Pulp and Paper, Ltd., received support yesterday from other major producers.

title: Filipinos Find 144 Bodies After Typhoon in the North
description: MANILA, Sept. 14  Search and rescue teams at Casiguran Sound in the eastern Philip pines, recovered 144 bodies by yesterday and were still looking for some 50 persons missing since a typhoon struck Friday.

title: U.S.Japanese Talks End
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP) United States and Japanese officials today ended a series of meetings on military prob lems affecting the two coun tries.

title: Aemorial Seroices
description: EMMERICHHerbert. Memorial service In memory of Herbert Emmerich to be held Sunday, Sept. 20, 1970, at 4 P.M. at the University Chapel, University of Virginia, Charlottesville, Va. The family requests flowers be omitted and suggests donations be made to International Institute of. Ad ministrative Sciences, Room 300, 1225 Connecticut Ave. N.W., Washington, D. C. 20036, or Emmerich Public Affairs Fellow ship Fund, Treasurer's Office, University of Virginia, Charlottesville, Virginia.

title: Back to Barbarism
description: The Arab aerial hijackers have apparently settled in for what they expect to be a longdrawnout process of negotiation with the nations they are trying to blackmail.

title: Eban Doubtful on Jordan
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 14Foreign Minister Abba Eban said today that he thought the Jordanian Government no longer had the capacity to negotiate a peace treaty with Israel.

title: Peter Yarrow, Folk Singer, Gets 3Month Jail Sentence
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 AP)  Peter Yarrow of the Peter, Paul and Mary folksing ing group was sentenced today to three months in jail after having pleaded guilty last March to charges of taking in decent liberties with a 14year old girl in a Washington hotel room.

title: Gain of 8 to 10% in World Trade Is Forecast by GATT for 1970
description: GENEVA, Sept. 14World trade should expand in value by 8 to 10 per cent this year after increasing by almost 14 per cent in 1969 to $272billion, according to a staff study pub lished by a leading international trade agency. The 1969 rise was the fastest since the Korean War price boom.

title: Mansfield Says Agnew Errs On Senate's Crime Action
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UPI)Senator Mike Mansfield said today that Vice President Agnew was illinformed about Senate action on the Adminis tration's anticrime legislation.

title: Delays Stymie Nonwelfare Applicants for Food Stamps
description: Elderly pensioners, mem bers of working poor fami lies and other nonwelfare ap plicants are experiencing de lays of seven weeks and longer in entering the city's new food stamp program.

title: Bank Merger in Yonkers Is Approved by Controller
description: Controller of the Currency William B. Camp has approved the proposed merger of the Na tional Bank of North America and the First National Bank of Yonkers. The combination, if it is not challenged by the Jus tice Department on antitrust grounds, would add $142mil lion in assets and 11 offices to the North America's existing total of more than 100 offices and $2billion in resources.

title: Deaths
description: Abrams, Anna Anderson, Rotted W. Ba Oman, Louts Bendow, Esther Boehm, Mildred Ilene Bonaudl, Jacques F. Bowman, Burton F. Budd, Lloyd E. Childs, Elmer E. Chodosch, Patti Young Crimp, Anthony J. Sr. Day, Alice Lavinia Digiorgl, Matthew Feingold, Abraham D. Fischman, Isidore M. Fisher, Violet O. Fortuin, Ross Franke, Joseph Friedman, Gussle Friel, Arthur J. Geiger, Hertha Glangreco, Samuel H. Gilder, Anne R. Goldschmidt, Sigmund Greenberg, Harry Gruskin, Geraldine Gulney, Cornelius, Sr. Haimowitz, Philip Hall, Caroline D. Hertzberg, Dorothy Hillman, Murray E. Hunter, Henry Mitchell Karp, Henrietta Kleyal, Mildred

title: Library Told to Open Records to Inspection
description: ITHACA, Sept. 14 II any one wants to find out who checked out a book about bombs, or revolutions, or how to ski, the Tompkins County Public Library has been di rected by the county govern ment to open up the records.

title: Service for Commuters Expected to Be Normal
description: Service for 196,000 daily commuters into New York City will be normal this morning, railroad officials said although late last night Westchesterbound trains of the Penn Central were halted briefly in anticipation of a strike.

title: Minority Enterprises Exhibiting
description: Six small businesses in the New York area, all owned by members of minority ethnic groups, have joined some 600 wellknown national suppliers for this year's National Mer chandise Show, which runs through Wednesday at the New York Coliseum.

title: Lawyer Pleads Guilty
description: WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 14A Yonkers lawyer, Alan B. Adler, 45 years old, of 19 Pelton Street, pleaded guilty today to three counts of grand larceny in con nection with indictments charg ing him with defrauding three clients of $225,000. Westchester County Judge George B. Burch ell accepted the plea after re fusing to grant an adjournment. No date for sentence was set, pending a probation report. Adler could get up to 10 years on each count.

title: State Lets Hanover Bank Plan Investment in Belgium
description: The New York State Banking Board has approved an appli cation by the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company to in vest more than $8  million in the Banque d'Escompte et de Travaux, a Belgian bank with $31.5 million in assets and seven offices.

title: Guerrillas and Peace
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14In the judgment of some of the bestinformed officials here, the Palestinian guerrillas have now shown themselves able to wreck any Middle Eastern set tlement that might be negoti ated without them.

title: Chevrolet Displays Its Big 1971 Models
description: DETROIT, Sept. 14Chev rolet showed off its new big 1971 models to the press to day even as the workers of the General Motors Corpora tion were walking off the job, starting what may be a long strike.

title: Rockefeller Endorsed by Procaccino
description: Mario A. Procaccino, who was defeated for Mayor last year by defections of fellow Democrats, made his long anticipated endorsement yes terday of Governor Rockefel ler, a Republican, for election to a fourth term.

title: JACQUES F. BONAUDI
description: HARTSDALE, N. Y., Sept. 14 Jacques F. Bonaudi, a New York restaurant, banquet and catering manager for many years, died today in a Green wich, Conn., nursing home after a long illness. He was 87 years old and lived at 192 Pinewood Road here.

title: BELGIAN IS ON WAY TO U.S. SPACE TALK
description: BRUSSELS, Sept, 14 The Belgian Minister  for Scientific Planning, Theo Lefevre, flew today to Washington to dis cuss the possibility of. Euro pean countries taking Part in the postApollo space program.

title: Lloyd's Will Pay B.O.A.C. Full Insurance for Plane
description: LONDON, Sept. 14 (AP) Lloyd's, the London underwrit ers, said today that the British Overseas Airways Corporation would receive $8.4million as an insurance settlement for the VC10 airliner destroyed by Arab guerrillas in Jordan.

title: Couve Plans Private Visit To Red China in October
description: PARIS, Sept. 14 (Reuters) Former Premier Maurice Couve de Murville will make a three week private visit to China next month, informed sources said today.

title: FOURRUN RALLY SETS BACK EXPOS
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 14  The New York Mets survived all sorts of international entangle ments for three hours tonight when they, scored four un earned runs in the 10th inning to defeat the Montreal Expos, 95.

title: Mrs. Cushing, With 77, Wins Medal in Cross County Play
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Sept. 14Mrs. Cutting Cushing of Meadowbrook posted a 40 3777 to win the medal in the qualifying round of the Wo men's Cross County Golf As sociation match play cham pionship today at the Cold Spring Country Club. Par for the 5,861yard course is 36 37 73.

title: Man Leaps to Death Here
description: A young man leaped to his death yesterday from his 16th floor apartment in the Gram ercy Park section of Manhat tan as hundreds of onlookers watched and dozens of police men attempted to save him. The man, 23yearold Charles McCord of 201 East 25th Street, dived out of the window only seconds after he unlocked his apartment door for the police who had been waiting outside attempting, to talk him out of suicide.

title: Colleges Tighten Security To Check Student Unrest
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14  College officials across the country appear to be more de termined this year than eves to crack down on disruptive students.

title: Nonaligned Nations to Press U.N. on Red China
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Sept. 14 President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia, who presided over a conference of leaders of non aligned countries here last week said today that he was bound by the decisions of that conference to do his utmost to get Communist China into the United Nations.

title: Cambodians Reported Hurled Back in Battle for a Key Highway
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 14 (AP)Communist troops to day hurled back advance ele ments of a Cambodian task force that was trying to gain control of a 50mile segment of a key highway north of this capital, a military spokesman said. In fighting that lasted from midnight until after daybreak, 20 Cambodian soldiers were re ported killed and about 60 wounded. Government com manders said 20 enemy dead had been left on the field, and they estimated that 200 more dead and wounded had been carried away in the darkness.

title: MRS. JAMES ALLAN SR
description: WEST PITTSTON, Pa., Sept. 14Mrs. James W. Allan Sr., the former Anna Hibbs, died today. She was 78 years old and lived here.

title: New Substitute Heart Valve Tested
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 14Doc tors at Jewish Hospital have implanted an inert plastic material molded in the shape of a heart valve under the skin of dogs and are experi menting with the resulting fibrous membrane as a sub stitute heart valve.

title: LINDSAY FOR HALT TO FLAG POLITICS
description: Mayor Lindsay told the coun try's National Guard leadership yesterday that neither hawks nor doves should use the flag for narrow political purposes.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: Ernanf Soars to Pure, Passionate Singing
description: Socially, the Metropolitan Opera opening last night might not have had the glamour it has had in the past. Musically, with Verdi's Ernani, it did not provide much of interest, for Ernani is an early and rather un formed Verdi opera. But vo cally the evening was magni ficent, even resplendant. If singing, pure passionate sing ing, is what opera is all about, then the Metropolitan Opera opening was a tri umph.

title: Tuxedo Ball on Oct. 17 Has Only 3 Debutantes
description: When the Tuxedo Autumn Ball, the New York area's old est and most prestigious deb utante presentation; is held for the 81st time at Tuxedo Park, N.Y., next month, only three debutantes will be in troduced to society.

title: Collapse of a NonPolicy
description: Responsibility for the strike of some 350,000 work ers at General Motors rests more on the failure of the Nixon Administration effectively to combat wage price inflation than on either the company or the United Automobile Workers.

title: FEMINELLI, ON 70, QUALIFYING LEADER
description: PURCHASE, N. Y., Sept, 14 Al Feminelli of the Dellwood Country Club in New City scored a par 70 over the 6,517 yard Old Oaks course today to lead the Westchester sectional qualifying round for the Metro politan Golf Association open championship by one stroke.

title: Rose Garden and a Statue Are Planned as Memorial to Franklin Roosevelt
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (AP)  After 15 years and $285,000 worth of planning, the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial Commission has decided to plant a rose garden and erect a statue to honor the nation's, 32d President.

title: Group for Mentally Ill Sets Luncheon Oct. 15
description: DOBBS FERRY, N. Y., Sept. 14The Association for Men tally Ill Children of Westches ter has arranged a lunch eon and fashion show fon Oct. 15 at Schrafft's in East chester to raise funds for its Clear View School here. Mrs. Howard L. Harmon of Irvington and Mrs. Patrick Grasso of Scarsdale are co chairmen of the benefit, for which tickets at $10 each are available from the associa tion's office in Echo. Hills.

title: 2D JUROR PICKED IN PANTHER TRIAL
description: An Iowaborn teacher of American history in a private school in Manhattan was se lected yesterday as the second member of the jury to try 13 Black Panthers accused of plot ting to bomb public places.

title: WOMEN'S LEADER CRITICAL OF NIXON
description: The president of the National Organization of Women, Inc., accused President Nixon yes terday of being totally insen sitive to the problems of women.

title: POTATO FUTURES CLIMB SHARPLY
description: Maine potato futures prices rose sharply yesterday in heavy trading on the New York Mer cantile Exchange. All contracts closed at their highs for the day and within a few pennies of the highs for the year.

title: At the Front's Amman Office, the Mood Is Defiant
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 14 Ignoring the photos of na palm wounds, the rifle niches in the walls and the goings and comings of armed youths, a young man trans fixed his visitors with his steely eyes and barked We've won the first round!

title: Bonwit Teller Appoints
description: The appointment to the board of directors of Bonwit Teller of Miss Helen Galland and Dan Zarem was announced yester day by Arthur P. Davis Jr., the specialty store's executive vice president. Miss Galland also has been named associate gen eral merchandise manager, and will continue as merchandise manager of the accessory divi sion. Mr. Zarem will continue as the store's fashion director and merchandise manager of the men's shop.

title: Who Counts the Ballots?
description: It has been almost three months since voters NeW York City went to the polls to select party nominees for a variety of high political offices. The results in most of the races were known on Tuesday night, June 23 shortly after the polls closed. However, the results in some of the races still are not known. There has been an inexcusably long delay on the part of the courts in disposing of election challenges.

title: AMEX ISSUES FALL AFTER BRIEF RISE
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange finished lower yes terday on moderate trading de spite a brief rally following a cut in the prime rate by a one bank holding company.

title: Agnew Assails Songs and Films That Promote a Drug Culture
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 14 Vice President Agnew said to night that American youths were being brainwashed into a drug culture by rock music, movies, books and underground newspapers. He called these part of a depressing life style of conformity that has neither life nor style.

title: Jackson Likely Winner in Vote Today
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 14In the primary election campaign fail the State of Washington, at tention has focused on the challenge to Senator Henry M. Jackson, a moderate Democrat who is seeking a fourth term.

title: CONCERNS BACK LIST OF TARS, NICOTINES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 Seven major cigarette manu facturers have notified the Fed eral Trade Commission that they are willing to include tar and nicotine ratings in their ad vertisements on a voluntary basis.

title: Open Interest
description: Open Interest

title: GIACONIELLI KEY IN BUCKNER PLAN
description: LEWISBURG, Pa., Sept. 14 Don Giacomelli was as am bitious a college football player as there was to be found last year. His participation should have warmed the heart of Walter Byers, the executive director of the National Col legiate Athletic Association, who blames twoplatoon foot ball for most of the high costs of intercollegiate athletics.

title: Aid Parley Lacks Agreement
description: TOKYO, Sept. 14 (Reuters) A conference of leading indus trial nations today failed to reach an agreement on the principle of removing all strings on government aid to develop ing countries.

title: Favorites a Flop on TV
description: Underdog football teams might find it advisable to pres sure the American Broadcasting Company for the opening col lege television game each sea son. When Stanford defeated Arkansas in the nationally tele vised season opener Saturday it was the fourth time in five years that the favorite lost the first TV college game.

title: Green Patterson Square Off Tonight
description: For the first time in two years, Floyd Patterson will compete as a boxer tonight. The former twotime world heavyweight champion, now 35 years old, will oppose Charlie (Devil) Green in a 10 round bout at Madison Square Garden.

title: Five Missing in Coast Fire
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 14 (UPI)At least five residents of a 60yearold hotel were missing today after a lice that left 12 persons dead and des troyed the fourstory structure. Wrecking crews began de molishing the shell of the faded Ponet Square apartment hotel, officials were certain more bod ies would be found. Of the 84 persons registered in the build ing Saturday night, 79 were ac counted for but Fire Chief Elvin C. Thompson said, We think there may have been oth er visitors.

title: Can the U.N. Act?
description: Is it conceivable that the aerial hijackings by the Palestinian terrorists could have one enduring posi tive result? Could they provoke or inspire the 126 member governments of the United Nations to concur on a modest advance of the rule of law in inter national affairs to deal effectively with this crime?

title: Colette Casts Miss Fielding
description: Fenella Fielding, the English actress, will make her New York stage debut in the title role of Colette, the Elinor Jones play based on the auto biographical writings of the French novelist, which feopens Oct. 14 at the Ellen Stewart Theater. The production, by Cherise Crawford in associa tion with Mary W. John, was forced to close after 101 per pormances on Aug. 2 when its original star, Zoe Caldwell, left the cast to fulfill a prior Lon don stage commitment.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: Article 7  No Title

title: CAR PACT EXPIRES
description: DETROIT, Tuesday, Sept. 15 The United Automobile Work ers began a strike at 12:01 A.M. today against the General Mo tors Corporation, the world's largest manufacturer, after fail ing to reach a contract settle ment.

title: CLIMB IN OIL OUTPUT FROM CANADA URGED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14 (UPI)The National Petroleum Council, said today that more oil output from Canada was the only practical way to meet a fueloil shortage outside the United States.

title: Fordham to Return To Varsity Football With Good Offense
description: As yet, nobody at Fordham has managed to uncover any more blocks of granite on the Rose Hill campus that might facilitate the successful return of the Rams to varsity football this season.

title: Miss LadaMocarski Engaged
description: MURRAY HILL, N. J., Sept. 14Miss Virginia Loomis LadaMocarski, assistant pho tographer with the Peabody Museum in Salem, Mass., and David Spanton Pennock, a lawyer with Alexander & Green in New York, will be married next month.

title: KnapsackToters Carry Load of Freedom
description: He was walkingtrudg ing might be a better word stoop shouldered, with the steady gait that most knap sackers acquire, toward a friend's apartment on East Ninth Street in, the East Vil lage. His name was Neil Boch man, he was 22 years old and he had spent the last three months living out of the knapsack on his back, first as a tourist in Europe, then as a caretaker on a Greenwich, Conn., estate, then as a camper.

title: BALTIMORE VOTE TESTS 2 IN HOUSE
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 14As a rule, Congressional politics in Baltimore are about as volatile as threedayold ginger ale.

title: 3YEAR RING BAN DECLARED UNFAIR
description: The New York State Athletic Commission cannot deny a box ing license to Muhammad Ali because he was convicted of refusing to submit to the draft, according to a Federal Court order issued here yesterday.

title: OTHER COMPANY REPORTS
description: OTHER COMPANY REPORTS

title: MAYNARD WINNER IN EWBANK'S MATH
description: In the higher mathematics pro football, as adhered to by Weeb Ewbank, 551 for 10,373 remains much more significant than 15 for 375.

title: Chimp's Brain Signals Itself by Computer
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 14Di rect twoway radio communi cation between an animal's brain and a computer has been established for the first time by a team of scientists at Yale University. It was used to en able the brain to control arti ficially one of its own func tions.

title: TOP PUSHER HELD, US. AGENTS ASSERT
description: A man described by. Federal authorities as the No. 1 push er of narcotics in Harlem was arrested by United States mar shals and custom agents here yesterday and charged with conspiring to smuggle cocaine into the country.

title: 23 Begin Theater Studies At Eugene O'Neill Center
description: The National Theater Insti tue, newest venture of the Eu gene O'Neill Memorial Theater Center in Waterford, Conn., opened last night with 23 stu dents from 19 universities be ginning studies in the arts.

title: Figaro Back at State Theater With Moments of Radiance
description: Mozart's The Marriage of Figaro is an iridescent opera with endless facets. Every time it's given, something surprising or new shines out from it, even in a relatively glib performance such as the New York City Opera's on Sunday night at the New York State Theater.

title: Nets Hope Barry Will Lift Club's Stature
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 14Lou Carnesecca, in his fa mous coaching crouch, watched Rick Barry go to the basket today during the New York Nets workout and said, I helped make this boy an all America at Miami University.

title: STRIKE THREATS DEPRESS STOCKS
description: The stock market wobbled to a decline yesterday as news events in the economic sphere seemed to establish the trad ing pattern.

title: Israel Clears and Frees 75 of 450 Arrested Arabs
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 14 Israel today released 75 of 450 Arab residents arrested during the weekend in the occupied area of the west bank of the Jordan River and in the Gaza Strip. Officials said interroga tions had shown that the 75 had no connection with the Palestinian airline hijackers.

title: Most Charges Dropped in Raid On Minneapolis Antiwar Affair
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 14A Hennepin County Municipal Court judge dismissed today all but one of 20 charges growing out of a police raid on the home of a University of Minne sota professor during an anti war fundraising party last May.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Article 3  No Title

title: FORD MOVE IN FRANCE BRINGS ACCUSATIONS
description: PARIS, Sept. 14The Pre mier of France and the political leader trying to unite the non Communist Opposition accused each other of lying today in an explosive exchange over timing of a Ford Motor Com pany decision to build a plant in Bordeaux.

title: Spirits High as Teacher And Pupils Seek Rapport
description: The first thing Mrs. Joan Grant, one of the city's 6,000 new public school teachers, told her sixthgraders yesterday was her name. The last thing one of her pupils asked her as he raced away from school at 3 P.M. was her name.

title: Football Transactions
description: Football Transactions

title: A Dance to Open Fund Drive for Flushing Hospital
description: The trustees and auxiliary of doctors wives of the Flushing Hospital and Medi cal Center in. Queens have arranged a dinner dance for Saturday at the Garden City (L.I.) Hotel to open a drive for $10million for the hos pital's new wing.

title: APARTMENT UNION GOES ON STRIKE
description: Building service employes struck 3,000 apartment houses in the Bronx and parts of West chester and Rockland Counties today, following the midnight suspension of contract negoti ations under the auspices of state mediator.

title: DR. GEORGE TRUSTAN
description: TOMS RIVER, N. J., Sept. 14 Dr. George D. Trustan, Ocean County Medical Exam iner, died at his home here this morning after a heart at tack. He was 50 years old and lived here.

title: 29 ARRESTED ON IN NARCOTICS RAIDS
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 14 Twentynine persons who were indicted by a Nassau County grand jury last week for the illegal sale or possession of, narcotics were arrested at their homes today in a dawn raid by detectives and policewomen of the county Police Depart ment's narcotics bureau. Six others are being sought.

title: Titan Group Elects
description: Harry W. Rosen has been elected president, chief execu tive officer and director of Titan Group, Inc. He replaces John C. Spence who has re signed as president and di rector. The company is a national operating real estate, construction, insurance and business services company.

title: POPE PLANS MESSAGE DURING VISIT TO ASIA
description: ROME, Sept. 14The Vatican announced today that Pope Paul VI would deliver a message to Asia while in Manila during his trip to the Philippines and Australia from Nov. 27 to Dec. 3.

title: BILL TO CURB BUSING IS SIGNED BY REAGAN
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 114  Gov. Ronald Reagan signed legislation today aimed at preventing busing of stu dents to achieve racial integra tion in classrooms. Officials of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said they would force a court test of the constitution ality of the law as soon as it takes effect in November.

title: Women Unionists Back Equal Rights Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14  Women members of a number of major unions responded to day to allegations that only upperclass women, not work ing women, advocated enact ment of the equal rights amend ment to the Constitution.

title: NATHAN BERLIN
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 14 Nathan Berlin, an advertising executive, died in Veterans Hos pital here yesterday following twoyear illness. He was 62 years old.

title: PRIME RATE CUT IN PHILADELPHIA
description: The First Pennsylvania Banking and Trust Company, Philadelphia's largest bank, an nounced a cut in its prime rate yesterday to 7 per cent from 8 per cent, effective this morn ing.

title: ECOLOGICAL BILL PASSED IN JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Sept. 14Legis lation that gives the state vast new power to regulate further development of New Jersey's coastal wetlands and thus at tempt to restore their ecologi cal balance was given final approval late today in the As sembly.

title: PICKETING DELAYS FESTIVAL ON PIERS
description: Mayor Lindsay's Office said yesterday that the City's cul ttiral festival on the New York piers will be put back at least a week because of picketing by longshoremen.

title: Hurricane Watch Is Posted On LouisianaTexas Coast
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 14 (UPI) The Weather Bureau posted a hurricane watch today along 400 miles of the Louis ianaTexas Gulf Coast and or dered the evacuation of Sabine Pass, Tex., in advance of tropi cal storm Felice.

title: CONSERVATIVES DENY A ROCKEFELLER DEAL
description: The chairman of the New York State Conservative party, J. Daniel Mahoney, denied al legations yesterday of a deal between Governor Rockefeller and the Conservative party be cause of the widespread sup port James L. Buckley is re ceiving from prominent Repub licans throughout New York State.

title: TEACHERS RETURN IN NIAGARA FALLS
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., Sept. 14Teachers returned to their classrooms today after strike that began last Tuesday.

title: Fight Closes Schools in Bogalusa, La.
description: BOGALUSA, La., Sept. 14 A twohour fight today between white and black students at an integrated high school was broken up by policemen using tear gas.

title: Lena Horne's Son Dies

title: Film Festival: Resnai's 'Je T'Aime, Je T'Aime':Experiment in Science Surrounds Story Wall St. Clashes Seen in Other Feature
description: Like most of the previous films of Alain Resnais, "Je T'Aime, Je T'Aime," made in 1968 but first seen here last night at the New York Film Festival, is science fiction of a sort. And like virtually all of Resnais's previous films, including the 35-mm. shorts of the 1950's, its concern is for the past recaptured. To support this concern it proposes a story, the most fragmented of all Resnais's stories, deal- (as do the rest of the collected work of Alain Resnais) with a perhaps intense but nevertheless transitory love affair.Claude (Claude Rich), having recovered from an unsuccessful suicide attempt, is picked for an experiment by a secret research center that studies nothing less than time. After much preparation Claude, along with a laboratory mouse, is placed inside a large soft brain-shaped structure, from which he is to be transported back to relive one minute at 4 in the afternoon exactly one year ago. He does relive that minute (he is snorkeling on vacation in southern France, and "underwater" becomes a recurring image and idea for the film), but he begins reliving it several times overand then in bits and pieces he begins to relive other moments scattered through the seven years he lived with Catrine (Olga Georges-Picot), whom he thinks he killed and for whose death he had tried to kill himself.Assuming that they have lost him forever, and sadly admitting that their experiment has been a most incomplete success, the research scientists wander out of the laboratoryonly to discover Claude, a bullet in his gut (he has most recently relived his botched suicide) lying on the grass. They carry him to help, but in their despondency and concern they forget the little mouse, who did come back, and who now sniffs forlornly inside his container within the giant brain.I am disturbed by that mouse, not only for the bathos of the image but also because his situation so ludicrously (and, I think, so intentionally) recalls that of the wife Simone looking for her husband, already light-years away, inside another woman's deserted apartment at the end of Resnais's one masterpiece "Muriel." For "Je T'Aime, Je T'Aime" resembles "Muriel" in so many close ways that the success of the older film (1963) stands in almost total reproach to the general banality of the newer one.Although obsessed with time, memory, the past, the physical material of "Je T'Aime, Je T'Aime" is its love story and the daily lives of the couple involved in it. But in that story and in those lives it finds so little of interest or urgency that with all its perceptual complexity it comes to seem an enormous and ingenious structure with almost nothing inside it.Unlike "Last Year at Marienbad" its people and its events are resolutely ordinary. But unlike ordinary people and events, nothing is ever bodied forth to suggest real life. Resnais is among the most romantic of directors, but in this film there is neither present passion nor rich remembrance, and we are left with a kind of arid speculation on the theme of lost romance.
