title: Oven Cooking Made Easy, but With Drawbacks
description: The people who brought you Reynolds Wrap have come up with a new cooking aid: BrowninBag. The 10 by16inch nylon film bags for oven useeliminate the need for basting, scouring baking pans and wiping spat ters off the inside of the oven.

title: Issues of Strike at G.M.
description: General Motors Corporation, world's largest manufac turer, $24billion in sales last year, $1.7billion profits, 7.2 million vehicles sold in 1969, 787,000 employes around the world.

title: BIG BOARD LOWER IN STRIKES WAKE
description: What is unsettling for Gen eral Motors is unsettling for the stock market generally.

title: Rahman Ends Thai Visit
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 15Prime Minister Abdul Rah man of Malaysia left for his capital, Kuala Lumpur, today, ending a fourday official visit to Thailand. He will retire Mon day after 13 years in office, broken by a brief retirement in 1959.

title: Nassau G.I. Killed in War
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UPI)The Defense Depart ment today listed Specialist Donald R. Huey, of the Army, from Farmingdale, L. I., as hav ing been killed in the war in Ineochina.

title: Rites for 4 Set at Kent State
description: KENT, Ohio, Sept. 15 (AP) Kent State University an nounced plans today for its fall opening, beginning with a me morial service for the four stu dents who were shot to death by National Guardsmen. The service will be held Monday, Sept. 28, the start of classes for the fall quarter.

title: RCA Introduces Four New Computers
description: MARLBORO, Mass., Sept. 15 The RCA Corporation today introduced a new computer line and marketing policy that the company hopes will catapult it into the No. 2 position in the multibillion  dollar, domestic dataprocessing business.

title: Yankee Records
description: Yankee Records

title: Court Enters School Strike
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 15 (UN) The Toledo Board of Educa tion was ordered today by a Lucas County judge to show cause why it had not invoked a state law to dismiss 2;500 striking teachers. The order was issued in a taxpayers suit contending that the striking teachers were violating an Ohio law that prohibits work stop pages by public employes. The teachers have boycotted classes since school opened Sept. 2.

title: A Priest Captures Massachusetts Race
description: The Rev. Robert J. Drinan, Roman Catholic priest, upset Representative Philip P. Philbin in a Democratic House primary race in Massachusetts yester day.

title: President of the Assembly
description: Assessing the United Nations last year in a fore word to a new edition of a book he helped write on the Charter, Edvard Hambro wrote: From crisis to crisis it lives on, and as any living organism grows and changes. Each new crisis is disturbing but strengthens the determination to survive and succeed.

title: Cash Prices
description: Cash Prices

title: Books of The Times
description: Easy writing makes hard reading, ob served S. J. Perelman somewhat crypti cally in a published interview the other day. He might have added that the less one has to write about, the more one tends to write; that it takes time to be brief; and that brevity is the soul of coherence. Perelman almost certainly would have elabo rated thus had he read in quick succession, as I did, Edward Hannibal's first novel, Chocolate Days, Popsicle Weeks, and Pieri Paul Read's third, Monk Dawson (his first and second novels having been Game in Heaven With Tussy Marx and The Junkers). Because if any two books, illustrate and elaborate the opposite sides of Perelman's paradox better than these two do, I can't think of them offhand.

title: Upstairs, Shopping Mall on 34th Street
description: There isn't much point in being the world's largest store without taking advantage of it and Macy's is not one to miss a point. After a year of planning and rethinking its fashion presentation, Macy's has come up with a floor sized shopping mall called Fashion III, the name indicat ing that the 23 shops and all the goodies are on the third floor. Each shop has its own display and interior and the inner core of three moreorless parallel rows is given extra depth with freefloating units of steel and glass.

title: Charts of Races at Belmont
description: Charts of Races at Belmont

title: Theatricality Still Hallmark of Bejart
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 14  There are bigger, grander, more comfortable and more flamboyant opera houses in the world than the The Atre Royal de la Monnaie, but few I think that are prettier. The interior evokes that kind of bourgeois baroque that seems typical of Brussels it self.

title: POLICEMAN IS SHOT IN HEAD IN HARLEM
description: A 25yearold policeman was shot through the head early today on a Harlem construction site.

title: TYDINGS TAKES MARYLAND RAG
description: BALTIMORE, Wednesday, Sept. 16  Senator Joseph D. Tydings won renomination early today in a surprisingly close Democratic primary.

title: Chase Bank Answers Patman: Wishing Can't Reduce Rates
description: The chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank responded to a letter from the chairman of the House Banking Committee yesterday by asserting that banks do not like high inter est rates and tight money any more than you do.

title: YANKEES DEFEAT RED SOX, 86, 32
description: A threerun pinch homer by Curt Blefary, with one out in the ninth inning of the second game, completed a thoroughly satisfying evening for the New York Yankees at the Stadium last night and a deeply em barrassing one for the Boston Red Sox.

title: State Seeks Eased Rule For Degree
description: SARATOGA, N. Y., Sept. 15  Ewald B. Nyquist, the State Commissioner of Ed ucation, announced today that he would soon estab lish an external degree program to enable qualified persons not enrolled in col lege to earn degrees through independent study and ex aminations.

title: OFFICIAL EXPECTS RISE IN MAIL RATE
description: Postal rates for handling magazines and newspapers will have to be more than doubled under the new Post Office Re organization Act, James W. Har grove, Assistant Postmaster General for Finance and Ad ministration, said here yester day.

title: Jockey Strike Cancels Card at Finger Lakes
description: CANANDAIGUA, N. Y. Sept. 15 (AP)Jockeys went on strike at Finger Lakes Race Track today, forcing the cancellation, of the day's rac ing program.

title: Powell Petition's Fall Short Of Needed Total of 3,000
description: While withholding a formal ruling on Representative Adam Clayton Powell's nomination pe titions, the Board of Elections read into the record the offi cial report of its clerk, show ing them to be 1,624 short of the required 3,000 valid names.

title: CHEMICAL SOCIETY ASKS WARGAS. BAN
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 15  The American Chemical Society, reversing a 45yearold stand, urged the United States Senate today to ratify the Geneva Protocol banning the use of poison gases and biological weapons in war.

title: Tension Termed Guerrillas Aim
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 15 A number of diplomats and analysts of Arab affairs here believe that terror and tension are more important to the Palestinian hijackers than the release of their comrades im prisoned in Western Europe and Israel. Such an attitude might help explain the Palestinians tactics In negotia tions to exchange all the hostages from the hijacked airliners for impris oned guerrillas. The Palestinians are evincing no urgency.

title: Dividends Announced
description: Dividends Announced

title: DECAVALCANTE PLEA FOR DELAY IS DENIED
description: NEWARK, Sept. 15 (UPI) The selection of a jury began in the conspiracy trial of Simone Rizzo (Sant the plumber) Decavalcante after the defense lost three motions for a delay.

title: Museum Bars New Expansion in Park
description: Officials of the Metropolitan Museum of Art promised yes terday that the museum would build no further on Central Park land after completion of its present Master Plan, and said they would be willing to amend their 1878 lease with the city to include such a pro vision:

title: Nixon's Gradualism Path
description: Ten days before President Nixon took office 20 months ago, Dr. Paul W. McCracken, who was about to become Chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers.

title: Britain Says Israel Holds Key
description: LONDON, Sept. 15British officials are now convinced that Israel holds the key to negotiations for the release of the airline hostages and arc pressing the Israeli Govern ment to express some willing ness to exchange Arab guerril la prisoners.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Foreign Minister Abba Eban told parlia ment yesterday that Israel would not par ticipate in any package deal to free Arab prisoners held in European jails in exchange for hostages held by Palestinian guerrillas. Mr. Eban said that Israel would not object to the freeing of the seven prisoners by Brit ain, Switzerland and West Germany if those nations wanted to do so. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Patterson After 2Year Layoff, Knocks Out Green in 10th Round at Garden
description: Nearly upstaged by the bodi ly ejection of the originally selected referee during the main event introductions, Floyd Pat terson returned to boxing after a twoyear absence last night and knocked out Charlie (Devil) Green in the 10th and last round at Madison Square Gar den.

title: Cubs Down Cards. 53
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 15 (UPI) Billy Williams drove in two runs with a pair of singles and Ron Santo hit an eighth inning homer today as the Chi cago Cubs remained in the thick of the National League's Eastern Division race with a 53 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: Outlook for Consumers
description: Capitalgoods spending by consumers is expected to rise 11.1 per cent in the first quar ter of 1971 from the level of this year's similar period, ac cording to Consumer Buying Prospects, a quarterly report published by the Commercial Credit Company. The report is based on a survey of 15,000 households.

title: PRICES ADVANCE ON LONDON BOARD
description: The London Stock Exchange closed moderately on the up side yesterday after a weak opening.

title: MOSCOW AND MADRID TO TRADE NEWSMEN
description: MOSCOW, Sept., 15 (UP) The Soviet Union announced today that the official press agency Tass, would open an office in Madrid.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Shipping/Mails

title: PRESIDENT PLANS A VISIT TO EUROPE AND SIXTH FLEET
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 President Nixon will leave Sept. 27 on an eightday European tour, the White House an nounced today. The journey will focus'on America's Medi terranean allies and is also ex pected to include a visit to Yugoslavia.

title: FIELDSTON SCHOOL DEDICATES LIBRARY
description: Dedication ceremonies for the Tate Library, a $1.25mil lion addition to the campus of the Fieldston School, were held last night in the auditorium of the school at Fieldston Road and Manhattan College Park way in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: Wheels on 150,000 Trucks Held Unsafe
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 The Transportation Department, reversing itself after a court challenge by Ralph Nader, said today that wheels installed on 150,000 General Motors pickup trucks were unsafe.

title: Business Records
description: Business Records

title: Goodell Tops 2 Rivals in First Confrontation, Newsmen Agree
description: ALBANY, Sept. 15Senator Charles E. Goodell scored a clearcut and possibly signifi cant victory in the first formal confrontation of the United States Senate campaign, report ers, editors and publishers who witnessed the confrontation agreed yesterday.

title: Egg Program Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP)  Representtive Neal Smith, Democrat of Iowa, said today Congress should provide Ameri can consumers with a program designed to make certain that the eggs and egg products they buy are wholesome.

title: Supreme Court Gets Plea From Victims of Oil Spill
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) Victims of the oil spill off Santa Barbara, Calif., in Janu ary, 1969, appealed to the Su preme Court today to require public hearings before the Gov ernment can turn over public land to oil companies for drill ings.

title: Three Found in Pacific After 6 Weeks on Craft
description: HONOLULU, Sept. 15 (AP) Two men and a woman who apparently subsisted on algae and spices for six weeks on a sailboat in the Pacific were reported today to be recovering aboard a Navy ship.

title: Mrs. Cooperstein Victor
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., Sept. 15  Mrs. Walter Cooperstein of Glen Oaks, the defending champion, scored a 6and5 victory over Mrs: Vincent Larkin of Nassau in the opening round of the 15th an nual Women's County Golf Asr sociation's match play cham, pionship at the Cold Spring Country Club today.

title: Major League Baseball
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: It Was Unlucky Day for Gretel And 2d Time She Lost Crewman
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 15 No one asked Jim Hardy, the skipper of Gretel II, if he planned to practice man overboard drills tomorrow, but someone might have wanted to.

title: Evidence is Reported of Flights Over Egypt
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 American officials said today the United States had evidence that Israel had been violating the terms of the ceasefire in the Middle East by making re connaissance flights over Egyp tian territory and by strength ening fortifications along the Suez Canal.

title: Harold M. Wick Is Dead at 73; Aide of Merchant Shipping Unit
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Sept. 15Harold M. Wick, re tired assistant vice president of the American Bureau of Ship ping, died in North. Shore Hos pital, Manhasset, last night after a short illness. He was 73 years old and resided at 23 Winthrop Road.

title: Cambodian Army Improving but It Remains. Untested
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 13  When Communist forces attacked Saang in early April and the Cambodian war began in earnest, the Cambodian Army numbered about 30,000 men who had few modern weapons and who had been trained in nothing more rigorous than building dikes, draining pad dies, and repairing roads.

title: Intrepid Beats Gretel II by 5 Minutes 52 Seconds in Protested Cup Opener
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 15 Speculation turned to fact on the America's Cup scene today, and the cold facts were not at all encouraging for Gretel II.

title: Open Interest
description: Open Interest

title: OFFENSE REVISED AT NORTHEASTERN
description: BOSTON, Sept. 15  The severest critic of Northeastern University  football is Coach Joe Zabilski. Last year his Huskies suffered their first los ing campaign in nine years and only Zabilski's sixth in 22 sea sons. He termed it unpalatable, and the tone of his voice indi cated that the Huskies would have to rectify the situation this season.

title: 60 Cars for Subway And 200 More Buses Ordered by the City
description: The city announced yester day that it had contracted to buy 60 additional airconditioned subway cars and 200 aircondi tioned buses at a total cost of $19.3million.

title: No Progress Reported
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 The State Department spokes man, Robert J. McCloskey, said today that he was unable to re port any significant progress in the fivenation effort to free the hostages.

title: Guerrillas Raise Their Price
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 15 Arab guerrillas, at a news con ference today, denounced the Fled Cross, rejected inter national law and raised their asking price for the release of the airline passengers and crew members they are holding.

title: Stans Says a Long Auto Strike Would Slow Economic Recovery
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UPI)  Commerce Secretary Maurice H. Stans said today that if a long auto workers strike took place it would be bound to slow down the re covery of the economy.

title: ISRAEL AND ARABS STIFFEN POSITIONS ON HOSTAGE DEAL
description: Israel and the commandos stiffened their positions yes terday as the Arabs continued to hold 54 or 55 hostages from hijacked airlines.

title: Senator Jackson Renominated In Race Called War Referendum
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 15Senator Henry M. Jackson won renomi nation by an overwhelming margin today in the Demo cratic primary.

title: Robert Dowling Honored On His 75th Birthday
description: Associates and friends in the City Investing Company hon ored Robert W. Dowling, chair man of the company's execu tive committee, last night on his 75th birthday at a dinner dance at the Pierre Hotel.

title: Radio
description: Radio

title: AMEX PRICES DIP IN SLOW TRADING
description: The American Stock Ex change took its worst beating in more than a month yester day as stocks declined in slower trading.

title: Employes of 3 Carriers Obey Order of Court
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 Four railway unions that had struck three major carriers early this morning instructed their 40,000 striking members to go back to work today.

title: Hearingon Princeton Project
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Sept 15The Princeton Regional Planning Board voted 6 to tonight to reconsider its Aug. 4 rejection of a plan to build an 11story office building here.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. The President saw Gerhard Schroeder, lead er of the West German Chris tian Democrat party. Mr. Nixon sent a foreign assist ance program to Congress. The President saw Represent ative William C. Cramer, Re publican of Florida, and then drove to the Capitol to attend a luncheon given by Repre sentative William Colmer, Democrat of Mississippi.

title: Rugby Results
description: Doncaster 2, Wakefield Trinity 9.

title: 15 INDICTED HERE IN GAMBLING CASE
description: Fifteen men, including 12 who were arrested a year ago and charged with running a $70millionayear illegal gam bling operation in Westchester and Rockland counties, were indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday.

title: Phone Walkout Upstate
description: OSWEGO, N. Y., Sept. 15 Some 180 employes of the New fork Telephone Company here and in three other upstate cities walked off their jobs to day. A company spokesman in Syracuse called it a wildcat strike over the discharge of an employe in Oswego last month. The walkout was also staged in Auburn, Newark and Geneva. Those involved arc members of the Communica tions Workers of America. Local 1101.

title: Executive Changes
description: John T. C. Low has been elected senior vice president and trust officer of the Fidelity Union Trust Company.

title: New Religious Style is Evolving, Theologian Tells Catholic Group
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 15A well known Canadian theologian declared here today that dissi dent Roman Catholics were developing a religious style that enabled them to remain within the church, but on their own terms rather than those of the bishops and the Pope.

title: OTHER COMPANY REPORTS
description: OTHER COMPANY REPORTS

title: Gala at the Philip Johnson Estate Will Benefit New Canaan Group
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Sept. 15The 81yearold New Canaan Historical So ciety will benefit from a Philip Johnson Gala on the ' architect's estate here on Saturday evening and on Sunday afternoon.

title: First Blacks Rehearsing In Philadelphia Orchestra
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15 (AP)  The 70yearold Phila delphia Orchestra was inte grated today as two Negroes  a violinist and violist  joined 103 other fulltime mem bers in the new season's first rehearsal.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: To the Editor: America's economy today is a hydraheaded monster. Infla tion is rampant. Unemployment is increasing. The dollar buys less and less. Average weekly wage of the factory worker is $26 more in gross pay than five years ago. Yet after higher prices and taxes, the worker currently has $2.20 less for himself and his family. Good economics? Good for the coun try?

title: The Beers Family Gets Together for a Concert
description: The Beers familyBob and Evelyne and their daughter, Marthacame down from Fox Hollow in Petersburg, N. Y., on Monday night to give a rather special concert at the Washing ton Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street.

title: THOMAS H. O'NEIL
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 15 (AP)  Thomas H. O'Neil of Chestnut Hill, an Associated Press editor for 34 years, died yesterday in Sancta Maria Hos pital.

title: A Woman Joins Secret Service Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP)Phyllis Frances Shantz of Rome, N. Y., today became the first woman member of the Secret Service auxilliary formed to help protect the President and his family and foreign diplomats in the greater Washington area.

title: Cadillac Stresses Smoothness and Less Noise in Restyled 71 Models
description: DETROIT, Sept. 15The Cadillac Division of the Gen eral Motors Corporation dis played its 1971 cars to the press today, and while the new models are restyled, they still look like Cadillacs.

title: Mary B. Bullitt, Nicholas Prahl To Be Married
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15 Mr. and Mrs. Logan M. Bullitt 3d have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Benson Bullitt, to Ens. Nicholas A. Prahl of the United States Coast and Geo detic Survey Service. He is stationed in Ketchikan, Alaska.

title: Youth Arrested in Shooting Of Policeman in the Bronx
description: A suspect in Saturday's shoot ing of a policeman in the Bronx was arrested yesterday morn ing by detectives of the Mor risania station as a result of information gathered during the questioning of more than 400 persons, the police said.

title: State's Publishers Elect Kennedy of Hudson, N.Y.
description: ALBANY, Sept. 15 (AP)  Baymond C. Kennedy, publisher of The Hudson RegisterStar, today was elected president of the New York State Publishers Association. He succeeds Allen H. Neuharth, president of the Gannett Company, Inc., based in Rochester.

title: D.C. Delegate
description: Congress has taken a small, timid step toward justice for the citizens of the District of Columbia. Both houses have now approved a bill giving the District a nonvoting delegate in the House of Repre sentatives. The new delegate will, in effect, be a fulltime paid lobbyist for the voteless people in the city of Washington.

title: Boston to See Stanley Cup
description: BOSTON, Sept. 15 (UPI) The Stanley Cup will be shown in Boston at a bank for nine days beginning Sept. 23. The cup, won by the Boston Bruins last spring, will then be re turned to its permanent home, the Hockey Hall of Fame in Toronto.

title: U.S. Extends Travel Curbs
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) The State Department today announced an extension for six more months of restrictions on travel to Cuba, Communist China, North Korea and North Vietnam.

title: HUMPHREY WINS MINNESOTA TEST
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 15  Former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey began his attempt for a political comeback to night with a convincing tri umph over Earl D. Craig Jr. a Negro peace candidate, in Min nesota's Democratic senatorial primary election.

title: Agnew Will Debate 6 College Students On Television Show
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M. Sept. 15  Vice President Agnew said today he would confront group of militant students on a national teleyision program in an attempt to persuade them that they should work within the political system.

title: CON EDISON SEEKING NEW RISE IN RATES
description: The Consolidated Edison Company has asked for elec tric rate increases of $11.7 million a year atop the $90 million annual increases that took effect Sept. 8.

title: THRIFT UNITS TO GET SOME OF RULES SOON
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today it would soon issue its new regu lations concerning conflict of Interest in savings and loan as sociations but would devote further study to other sec tions of its proposed regula tions.

title: Proceedings in the U.N.
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M.

title: Led Zeppelin Supplants Beatles in British Poll
description: LONDON, Sept. 15 (UPI) A poll printed today in Britain's most widely read popmusic newspaper shows that Led Zeppelin has re placed the Beatles as the nation's most popular group the first time the Beatles have not been No. 1 in eight years.

title: National League Race
description: National League Race

title: High Aide at Hayden, Stone Named Executive at Blyth
description: Alfred J. Coyle, former chair man of the executive commit tee of Hayden, Stone, Inc., has become a senior vice president and director of Blyth & Co., according to an announcement yesterday by Paul Devlin, Blyth's chairman.

title: To Win the Wetlands
description: The salt marshes and other coastal wetlands are the zone of life where many fith and shellfish spawn, where birds find sustenance, and where nature estab lishes its own defenses against wind and wave.

title: High Aide Resigns At F. I. duPont Unit
description: Archie E. Albright, presi dent of the investment bank ing subsidiary of F. I. duPont, Glore Forgan & Co., the largest partnership In the se curities industry, and chair man of the executive com mittee of the partnership, has resigned to become a special limited partner of the firm.

title: Major League Box Scores
description: Major League Box Scores

title: Dr. Corcoran Weds Carol Serpa
description: Miss. Carol Ann Serpa and Dr. David Michael Corcoran, son of Thomas G. Corcoran, former adviser to President Fanklin D. Roosevelt, were married in a private family ceremony at the Roman Cath olic Church of the Blessed Sacrament here on Saturday. The Rev. Patrick J. McCor mick officiated.

title: Fort Marcy Is Favored in $125,000 Jersey Race Today
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 15 Fort Marcy of the Rokeby Sta ble, the 6yearold who has es tablished himself as one of the best campaigners on grass on the continent, will make anoth er attempt tomorrow to win the $125,000 United Nations Han dicap.

title: U.S. and Agency Bonds
description: (Prices In 32nd of a point. Composite bill ylelds In Dasis poinls.)

title: Entertainment Events
description: R.P.M., a drama starring Anthony Quinn and AnnMargret, produced and directed by Stanley Kramer, released by Columbia Pictures, at Loew's State I and Loew's Orpheum Theaters.

title: REPORTER RETURNING AFTER FLEEING ARMY
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 15A re porter who went to Canada rather than report for 19 moths of active duty in the United States. Army apparently changed his mind today arid was said to be returning home.

title: European Soccer
description: Coleraine (No. Ireland) 1, Kilmarnock (Scot land) I.

title: I.T.T.Grant to Help Bejart Ballet Group Makelts U.S. Debut
description: The International Tele phone and Telegraph Cor poration announced yester day that it was contributing $50,000 td the Brooklyn Academy of Music to help meet expenses of the United States debut of Maurice Bejart's Ballet of the 20th Century from Brussels this winter.

title: High School Tackle Dies
description: TYLER, Tex., Sept. 15 (UPI) Kenneth Wayne Williams, highschool tackle who collapsed on a Lindale, Tex., football field yesterday during practice, died today.

title: PRICES SHOW DROP IN CORN FUTURES
description: Profit taking sharply trimmed early rises in corn and wheat futures prices on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday re sulting in both commodities closing lower than the day before.

title: Danny the Red Apologizes
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Sept. 15 (Reuters) Slander charges against Daniel. Cohn BenditDanny the Redwere dropped today after the former student leader apologized for calling a public prosecutor pig.

title: Cairo Terms American Peace Initiative Dead
description: CAIRO, Sept. 15  Foreign Minister Mahmond Riad de clared today that the United States peace initiative for the Middle East was dead, but he said that the Egyptians would continue to respect the 90day ceasefire which began on the night of Aug. 78, in the strict est definition of the term.

title: Bridge:
description: How to respond to strong artificial opening bids is a subject that provokes much theoretical argument. Wheth er the opening bid is two clubs, as in standard methods using weak twobids, or one club, as in several modern systems, the choice lies be tween natural responses, apart from an artificial nega tive, and conventional con trolshowing responses.

title: DIRECT VOTE PLAN FACES SHOWDOWN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 Senator Mike Mansfield and bipartisan group of colleagues forced the Senate today to schedule a showdown vote on direct popular election of the President.

title: Children's Nursing Homes Add New Dimension to Medical Care
description: A hospitalized child, re covering from the effects of lead poisoning, is ready to return home. But the cracked plaster and paint on the walls of the housethe source of his poisoninghave not yet been repaired. Where can he safely go?

title: PRICE TAGS READ BY CASH REGISTER
description: A new electronic cash regis ter and information system for stores that uses an optical wand to read credit cards, price tags and other coded tickets was introduced here yesterday by the National Cash Register Company.

title: Beverly Fanger Will Be a Bride
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Sept. 15  Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Fanger have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Beverly Anne Fanger, to Herbert Stanley Chase Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Chase of Woodmere, L. I.

title: Foreign Affairs: Power Is as Power Does
description: WASHINGTONA curious misconception argues the para dox that strength is tantamount to weakness in this compli cated postindustrial age of cybernetics. The idea is poetic but untrue. The logic of power remains but it is worthless if it is not applied.

title: It Was G. M. All the Way
description: DETROIT, Sept. 14  From the beginning of this year's auto negotiations there was not much doubt that they would end in a battle of titans, the United Atuo Workers against the General Motors Corpora tion. And through the talks three dominant factors emerged as follows: 1. Both sides were trapped in a world they did not make. 2. There was a strange lovehate relationship between the union and G.M. 3. It was not the same without Walter.

title: In Memoriam
description: EPSTEINM. J. Sept. 16/1964 Lovingly remembered ELSIE.

title: BrokerFailure Insurance Bill Gains; Devonshire Customer Suing Exchange
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 The Senate Banking Committee approved today a greatly mod ified version of legislation cre ating a Governmentbacked pro gram of insurance for investors against losses resulting from bankruptcies of brokerage firms.

title: Ground Is Broken at Court Site
description: Ground was broken yester day for the new $27million Manhattan Family Court as part of a civic center master plan.

title: A.F.L.C.I.O. Aide Asks 30% Social Security Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Indus trial Organizations, urged the Senate Finance Committee to day to increase Social Security benefits 30 per cent over the next 15 months instead of per cent as provided in a Housepassed bill.

title: StrikeBesieged Economy
description: The nation, steeling itself for the chilling economic impact of what may prove a long strike by 350,000 General Motors workers, can take little comfort from the week's delay a Federal judge has ordered in the threatened shutdown of the country's railroads.

title: Building Cavein in Spain
description: ALMERIA, Spain, Sept. 15 (AP)A ninestory building un der construction in this south ern Spanish city collapsed to day. At least one worker was killed, officials said.

title: The Palestinian Problem
description: The world has been treating us as if we did not exist, a spokesman for the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine complained the other day. Now let the world treat us as people. However, most Palestinians must recognize by now, as have most of their Arab and other supporters, that the Popular Front tactic of hijacking international airliners and holding innocent air travelers is not the way to gain recognition and respect for their claims to national identity. Rather, the criminal barbarism of a few extremists in pursuit of wholly unreasonable demands has tended to brand an entire people as bandits in the eyes of the world and to discredit any sugges tion that they might assume a responsible role in the community of nations.

title: Ann Mulgrew, 1965 Debutante, Plans Nuptials
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Sept. 15Mr. and Mrs. Felix A. Mulgrew have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Stuart Mulgrew, to John Marshall Goldsmith Jr. of Radford, Va. A November wedding is planned.

title: City to Offer a Toll Plan for East River Bridges
description: Transportation Administra tor Constantine Sidamon Eristoff said yesterday that the Lindsay administration would have a plan ready next year to charge tolls on the East River bridges.

title: Ottinger Urges Simpler Laws On Taxes for Small Business

The company said it would continue to buy from outside sources about $300mil lion worth of petrochemical products a year that could have been produced by the proposed refinery.

description: WASHINGTON, Sent. 15 Rechecks so far indicate that the 1970 census was accurate, the Census Bureau said today.

title: Sales and Profits Up In U.S. Manufacturing
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UPI)Sales and profits of United States manufacturing corporations rose in the sec ond quarter of this year from the preceding three months, a Government report said to day, but the gains were sea sonal in nature and indic ated little real change.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 The White House announced to day that President Nixon in tended to nominate Mrs. Carol M. Khosrovi as director of Volunteers In Service to America.

Justice Gerrit Viljoen has acquitted nineteen black Africans charged under the drastic Terrorism Act with plotting to overthrow white rule.

description: Earnings of the American Enka Corporation for the 12 and 36 weeks ended Sept. 6 declined from the previous year's periods despite higher sales, due primarily to gen erally depressed conditions in the textile industry, the com pany reported yesterday.

description: DETROIT, Sept. 15  The United Automobile Workers and the General Motors Corpo ration have clashed headon four times  once in the De pression, once after World War II, once by error and oncein the last yearin a strike that revealed the hard lines that are now drawn between the union and the company.

title: Bronx Special Poll Denied
description: The Appelate Division yester day overturned a State Supreme Court order for a special election to determine the Democratic party's candidate in the 78th Assembly District in the Bronx. After meeting with Premier Golda Meir of Israel in Washington this week, he will go to Europe on Sept. 27 for eight days, and then meet with visiting heads of government here and at the United Nations through most of October.

title: Albert C. McIntyre Dead; Retired Rail Executive, 84
description: EAST ORANGE, N. J., Sept. 15Albert C. McIntyre, a re tired railroad executive, died today in a nursing home in New Providence. He was 84 years old and lived at 112 Lincoln Street here.

title: Yablonski Slaying Suspect Ordered to Be Extradited
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 15 (UPI) Judge John T. Patton ordered Paul Gilly extradited today to Pennsylvania to stand trial for the murder of Joseph A. Yablonski, official of the United mine workers, and his wife and daughter.

title: Men Prepare Behind the Scenes To Put on Races at Lime. Rock
description: About 200 natty little sports cars are being tuned up for the Sports Car Club of America Area One races at Lime Rock, Conn., Saturday. There are also about 150 club members preparing to handle all of the chores that are necessary to make the racing program go as smoothly as the drivers hope their cars will. Racing drivers need pit crews to take care of a number of technical details and race program chairmen find that dozens of knowledgeable and energetic workers are also necessary. They have to be sure that all of the drivers and cars meet the standards required for safe, well organized and properly bal anced racing competitions.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (UPI)  The Interstate Commerce Commission rejected today a request by railroads in the South for a 15 per cent freight rate increase.

title: Credit Markets: Jersey Bonds Unsold

title: DRUGTAKING CIItRGE COSTS LIFTER TITLE
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 15 (Reuters)  The International Weightlifting Federation stripped the Hungarian fly weight, Sandor Holczreiter, of his world title today for alleg edly having taken drugs. Holcz reiter won the title Saturday.

Greer's Rucala, a pretty young filly who had been unable to reach the win ner's circle in her four previous career starts, had just won yes terday's opener at Belmont Park by seven lengths. We had 14 juvenile fillies in this race but none have amounted to much, Tommy Trotter, the track's racing sec retary, said. But take Wednes day. We have 14 more of the same age and sex going in the Astarita. Almost all of these have displayed considerable talent.

Abbatiello sustained possible fractured ribs on they left side and was taken to St. John's Hospital in Yonkers.

description: Charles Hendrickson Brow er, the chairman of the board of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn who will be 69 yearsold on Nov. 13, an nounced yesterday that he will retire at the end of the year.

title: Madison Square Merger Deal With Raceway Is Set
description: The Madison Square Garden Corporation scored a cleancut decision yesterday by finally getting the Transnation Devel opment Corporation and Roose, velt Raceway, Inc., to agree in principle to merge with it. The Gar den and Transna tion have been trying unsuccess fully for months to gain control of Roosevelt, Raceway with both companies buying large blocks of stock in the Long Island trotting track. However, neither company gained enough stock to con trol Roosevelt Raceway.

title: Brooklyn Youth Is Killed By Man Clothed in Black
description: A man dressed entirely in black and wearing a black knee length cape, entered Chris's Restaurant at 771 Sutter Ave nue in the East New York sec tion of Brooklyn just before 8 P.M last night, approached one of the patrons, said This is what you deserve, and shot him twice, killing him almost instantly, the police said.

title: Hospital Fund Seeks Helpers
description: The United Hospital Fund is seeking volunteers, aged 18 and older to work in its facilities in Brooklyn, Queens, Nassau and Suffolk Coun ties, and Westchester and Rockland Counties.

title: E. M. Laski Fiance Of Susan Milberg
description: Dr. and Mrs. Max B. Mil berg have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Jayne Milberg, to Edward Martin Laski, son of Mr. and Mrs. Tobias Laski. Both families are of Brook lyn. The wedding is planned for late November.

title: SCHOOLS GET GOING AS PROTESTS DROP
description: All 2,400 pupils were kept out of two city schools for the second day yesterday in par ents protests over school con ditions.

title: Woman Hit by Car Dies
description: One woman was killed here and two were injured yesterday when an automobile went out of control. The police said the victim was Flora Spector, 65 years old, of 37 Payson Street. She was killed as she was walk ing near Dyckman Street and Vermilyea Avenue, when a car driven by Mrs. Clara Lyles, 40, of 2185 Exterior Street skidded and hit her.

title: WPIXTY DEFENDS NEWS PRACTICES
description: The Federal Communications Commission hearings into the challenge to WPIXTV's broad cast license began here yester day with Francis M. Flynn, chairman of the board of The Daily News and of WPIX, and Fred M. Thrower, president of the station, defending its news presentation.

description: Yanks Box Scores

title: U.S. TEAM DEFEATED IN CHESS IN GERMANY
description: SIEGEN, Germany, Sept. 15 The United States team lost to East Germany, 21, last night in the completion of the first round of the 19th chess Olympiad in Siegerland Hall.

title: SAIGON'S FORCES SAID TO QUIT BASE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 15 (AP)South Vietnam ese field commanders said to day that their forces had with drawn from one mountaintop base in the northern sector of the country and were planning to pull out of another because of the approaching monsoon season.

title: Film Festival: 'Musica'
description: Marguerite Duras's "La Musica," which she adapted from her own short two-character play, is about a husband and wife who meet three years after their formal separation, when they return to the provincial town where they once lived to pick up their divorce decree.In the film's longest sequence, which I suspect is pretty much the total of the play, He (Robert Hossein) and She (Delphine Seyrig) come together in the lobby of their hotel, at first acting like anxious, rueful ghosts. They circle each other in carefully choreographed movements; alternately each literally frames the other by his own person and by his mirror image. (Miss Duras loves to see things in and through glassmirrors, windshields, windows). The revelations, though obliquely made, are quite specific. She was unfaithful. He once planned to murder her, She, unknown to him, once tried to commit suicide.With the revelations comes the ironic realization that, although each is committed to someone else, they've just fallen in love. The most that they can hope for themselves is that they'll possibly meet again, sometime in the future, by accident. In some peculiar, cockeyed way, this seems to be a bridge beyond death, a lot more austere but no less romantic, in the context, than the faith that was to reunite Spencer Tracy and Irene Dunne in the clouds over Hollywood in "A Guy Named Joe."Because Miss Duras writes so elliptically, there is no special sense that she has padded her original play until the confrontation in the hotel lobby. At that point, however, one realizes that all that has gone before has been rather superior but ultimately superfluous vamping, including the introduction of a character not in the play, a young American girl (Julie Dassin), who appears to be simply the reflection of one of the husband's long-ago infidelities talked about in the play."La Musica" is intellectually chic moviemaking of the sort that is quite entertaining while it is going on but practically ceases to exist, even as a memory, when it's over. Hossein and Miss Seyrig read their lines with style and look marvelously unhappy, she, especially, in blond bob that evokes the 1930's and the image of Lilyan Tashman.The New York Film Festival, which showed "La Musica" last night at Philharmonic Hall, is presenting Miss Duras, in her role as a film director, in a reversed-time sequence. Having shown "Destroy, She Said," the French novelist-playwright's second directorial effort last year, the festival this year selected her first film "La Musica," made in 1966 and co-directed with Paul Seban, who had earlier collaborated with her on a series of television productions.

title: U. S. Appeals Court Overturns Ban on a Swedish Film on Love
description: A Federal appeals court here overruled a lower court jury verdict yesterday and held that a Swedish motion picture called Language of Love was not obscene and must be released to its owners by Customs of ficials.

title: Lottery Ticket Sales Fall
description: ALBANY. Sept. 15 (AP) Sales of the $1 state lottery tickets dropped to a new month ly low during August.

title: NIXON PROPOSES VAST AID REFORM
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 President Nixon outlined to Congress today a series of fundamental and sweeping re forms in economic and in mili tary foreign aid to make both more consistent with his plan to maintain a low profile in foreign policy.

title: TV: Cutbacks in Aerospace Industry Create Problems on Julia
description: What may be a hint of how Hollywood proposes to touch on reality and yet preserve the tradition of the happy ending was suggested last night in the seasonal pre miere of Julia on the net work of the National Broad casting Company.

title: No New Offer Expected at Auto Talks Today
description: DETROIT, Sept. 15  Both sides braced today for a long struggle to reach a settlement in the first major strike against the General Motors Corpora tion in a quartercentury.

title: JETS CAREER ENDS FOR BAKE TURNER
description: Don't write any sad ballads for Country Bake Turner. He may never play Shea Stadium again, but there's always Las Vegas and television and records.

title: Sports of The Times
description: For the last three years Cassius Clay has been deemed a nonperson by that monu ment of Orwellian wisdom, the New York State Athletic Commission. At the instant that Cassius refused to accept induction into the armed services, these peerless box ing overseers were nudged by patriotism, politics and expediency. They stripped Clay of his heavyweight championship recognition and of his boxing license.

title: New Red Cross Team Sent
description: GENEVA, Sept. 15  Bow ing to pressure from Bonn and London, the International Com mittee of the Red Cross de cided tonight to send a new team to Amman to help nego tiate the release of the hostages.

title: U. N. Session Opens With. Hope
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 15  The United Nations General Assembly opened its 25thanniversary session today amid expressions of hope that the world organization might recapture some of the glamour, prestige and youthful en thusiasm it once had.

title: Pope's Envoy Back in Rome
description: ROME, Sept. 15The Very Rev. Jean Rodhain, whom Pope Paul VI had sent to Jordan as his personal representative, re turned today after three days of fruitless effort to free the hostages.

title: New Books
description: A Bait of Perjury: A Novel of Sus pense and Legal Intrigue, by Wallace Savage (Droke House: Grosset & Dunlap, $4:95).

title: World Champion Bruins See Themselves a Target
description: LONDON, Ontario, Sept. 15We're the world cham pions, said Derek Sander son, not far from a color poster of a Men's cologne advertisement depicting a model sprawling over him. And being world champions means that if some humpty dumpty team has a 16game losing streak they're gonna wait for you, and if they beat you, then they think they've been successful.

title: INQUIRY CITES DATA ON PENNSY INSIDERS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (Reuters)The chairman of the House Banking Committee, Wright Patman, said today his staff investigation of the Penn Central bankruptcy action had produced evidence of additional insider trading in the com pany's stock.

title: John J. Kenny, Ousted Hudson County Leader, Is Indicted for Extortion
description: TRENTON, Sept. 15  The State. Grand Jury that is in vestigating organized crime and corruption in New Jersey in dicted today John J. Kenny, the former chairman of the Hud son County Democratic organi zation, on a charge of extorting $50,000 in a 1966 land deal in Secaucus.

title: MRS. WILLIAM F. O'NEIL
description: AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 15 (AP) Mrs. W'lliam F. O'Neil, widow of the founder of the General Tire & Rubber Company, died yesterday in St. Francis Hospi Ital, Miami Beach. She was 84 years old.

title: Mets Yield Share of Lead by Losing to Expos as Pirates Win
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 15 The New York Mets dropped from tie for first place into third place tonight when they were defeated by the Montreal Expos, 54, in 10 innings after they had tied the game on a pinch hit home run in the ninth and gone ahead on another home run in the 10th.

title: Negro Killed, by Police in New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS, Wednes day, Sept. 16  One young Negro was killed and three others were wounded by po lice gunfire last night in grocery shootout near a black militant headquarters raided in a big gun battle earlier in the day. The grocery store was owned by Henry Brous sard, a Negro, who also owned the house where the militants established their lo cal headquarters. A group of Negro males armed with Molotov cocktails assaulted Broussard Grocery, the po lice said. Four police of ficers were assigned inside the grocery store and return ed the fire of these individ uals. The police spokesman said three blacks were wounded by police fire and the fourth Negro was lying in the street; we don't know if this person is dead or alive. The spokesman said rescuers trying to reach the boy in the street were kept at bay by snipers firing from buildings in the neighbor hood. However, the youth was finally dragged from the street, pronounced dead and taken to the city morgue.

title: FREI PARTY SEEKS CHARTER CHANGES
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 15 The Christian Democratic par ty, defeated in a Presidential election Sept. 4 after six years in power, is under pressure to decide quickly whether it will give Dr. Salvador Allende, the Marxist candidate, the support) he needs to become President.

title: GIBSON DISCLOSES ATTEMPTED BRIBE
description: NEWARK, Sept. 15  Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson said today that he had had indications that he could have received $31,000 under the table if he had responded to offers made to him since he took office on July 1.

title: Italian Basso No Stranger to Success
description: Ruggero Raimondi, the 28 yearold bass who scored notable success in his debut at the Metropolitan Opera on Monday night, is no stranger to triumph on the operatic stage but he still finds its taste very sweet.

title: U.S. HOPES MORE CUT PRIME RATE
description: NEWTON, Mass., Sept. 15 The Administration would be pleased if other major banks were to join the First Pennsyl vania Banking and Trust Com pany in reducing their prime lending rates to 71/2 per cent from the present level of 8 per cent, a Treasury official said here today.

title: Women's Leader Says U.S. Suffers Because Sexes Have Separate Roles
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 The head of the National Or ganization for Women told Con gress today that the whole na tion was suffering because of its adherence to ideas, thou sands of years old, that assign separate roles to men and women.

title: Daley Says Chicago Seeks Both Conventions in 1972
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 15 (Reuters) Mayor Richard J. Daley, an nounced today that Chicago would bid for both the Demo cratic and the Republican con ventions in 1972.

title: Whitney Fund Expands Aid
description: Trustees of the, John Hay Whitney Foundation announced plans yesterday for a tenfold expansion of its support of individual fellowships, which would raise it beyond the $1 millionayear mark. This year, the foundation awarded $108, 000 in opportunity fellowships to 42 men and women.

title: Inexperience Drops Penn's Rating Low As Ivy Contender
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 15 Pennsylvania's second game of 1969 was a victory in score only. It was as costly a triumph as the Quakers ever suffered. Penn lost its No. 1 and No. 2 quarterbacks in that 232 deci sion over Brown at Franklin Field.

description: Deaths

title: KAISER ALUMINUM IS REVISING PRICES
description: The Kaiser Aluminum & Chemical Corporation an nounced yesterday that it was revising price schedules to limit discounts on basic wire products used in overhead transmission and distribution wires.

title: National City Bank Lifts Payout; 2for1 Split of StockIs Planned
description: Directors of the First National City Corporation, the holding company of the First National City Bank and other subsidi aries, raised the quarterly divi dend yesterday to 66 cents a share from 60 cents. This marks the sixth consecutive year of increased dividends. The board also announced it plans to recommend a twofor one split. The board will take formal action on the split at a later meeting prior to present ing it for stockholder approval at the annual meeting next March.

title: Nixon Going to Kansas And Then to Chicago
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP)President Nixon plans to speak on water in our society at Kansas State Uni versity tomorrow and will ex tend his trip to an overnight stay in Chicago, the White House said today.

title: A. O. Smith Forms Unit
description: The A. O. Smith Corporation announced yesterday that it had formed a German subsidiary near Hamburg to manufacture petroleum meters to be sold in Europe.

title: Pope Drops All Corps But the Swiss Guard
description: ROME, Sept. 15Pope Paul VI disbanded all armed and uni formed Vatican organizations today except the halberdwield ing Swiss Guards.

title: NATO CHIEF URGES CAUTION ON DETENTE
description: DUSSELDORF, West Ger many, Sept. 15Gen. Andrew J. Goodpaster, supreme com mander of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, said to day West Germany's negotia tions with the Soviet bloc would be welcomed if they led to the reduction of EastWest tensions.

title: Brink's Man Shoots A Hijacker to Halt Coast Plane Seizure
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 15 A hijacker who wanted to go to North Korea was shot down today'by a Brink's courier in a Trans World Air lines jet parked on a runway at San Francisco International Airport.

title: House Modifies Plan on Reform To Avoid Antagonizing Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 The Senate practice of attach ing extraneous proposals to House bills came under sharp attack today as the House re sumed debate on a Congression reform bill.

title: Miss Ruth Miller Prospective Bride
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 15 Mr. and Mrs. William Miller have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Ruth Lois Miller, to Paul Joel Leyden, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Leyden of Brooklyn. The wedding is planned for June.

title: Top Economists Oppose SST As Unwise, Fulbright Declares
description: Senator J. W. Fulbright yes teiday introduced new economic arguments against committing huge funds for a supersonic transport by citing strong anti SST views of an array of prom meld economists.

title: Priest Who Opposes War Wins Over Philbin in Massachusetts
description: BOSTON, Wednesday, Sept. 16The Rev. Robert J. Drinan, a Roman Catholic priest on leave as dean of the Boston College Law School, turned antiwar sentiment into a lever to defeat Representative Philip J. Philbin in a Democratic pri mary.

title: Rail Strike Seems Likely as 2 Sides Fail to Bargain
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 Four railway unions and the nation's carriers moved today toward a major strike next Thursday despite Government efforts to start negotiations.

title: RICHARD M. POTT, ARCHITECT, WAS 75
description: Richard Moncrieff Pott, the architect of the New Senate Office Building in Washington, died of heart failure Tuesday in his home at 66 Park Avenue. He was 75 years old.

title: BUIICH MAKES BID 1 FOR CHILDREN'S TV
description: Dean Burch, chairman of the Federal Communications Com mission, questioned yesterday the commitment of the com mercial television networks to children's programing and urged cooperative efforts among the networks for the creation of better children's shows.

title: Heller, Security National Bank And Abacus Weighing Merger
description: The Walter E. Heller Inter national Corporation, one of the nation's leading commer cial finance houses, announced yesterday that it was holding preliminary merger talks with the Security National Bank, Huntington, L. I., and the Abacus Fund, Inc., a closedend investment company that owns 24.9 per cent of Security. The merger if com pleted, would cre ate a financial conglomerate with almost $2billion in assets and worldwide scope to its opera tions. The brief announcement emphasized that, while the talks were expected to continue in the near future, no conclu sions had been reached. The statement did not say so, but the key to the negotiations is to be found in Security's pending deal to acquire Royal National Bank, a $245million institution based in Manhattan.

title: Susan Froehly To Be a Bride
description: VANDALIA, Ill., Sept. 16 Miss Susan Yvonne Froehly, an assistant district attorney for Bronx County, New York, and Leonard Max Teich, a senior analyst for the Eastern Hemisphere Petroleum Divi sion of the Continental Oil Company in New York, plan to be married here on Nov, 28

title: Panel Backs Antibomb Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) The Senate Judiciary Com mittee approved today an Ad ministrationbacked bill to strengthen Federal laws against bombing and bomb threats. The bill also provides for increased penalties for illegal transporta tion or receipt of explosives or other incendiary devices with intent to kill, intimidate or in jure people or damage property.

title: Miss Sarah Tyson to Become Bride
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16 Mr. and Mrs. Charles Roeb ling Tyson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah Tyson, to Alejandro Jose Valenzue laBock, a student at Wes leyan University. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Aldo Walterio Valenzuela Pefia of Toconilla. Chile.

title: Belmont Entries
description: Belmont Entries

title: Seizing the Time
description: The vote in the Senate today on whether to shut off debate on an amendment abolishing the Electoral College and substituting instead the simple, popular election of President and Vice President is a vote on the merits of the issue itself. To prolong debate is to kill reform at the present session of Congress. It is even more than this. The amendment has already passed the House. To kill reform at the present session is to lose vital momentum and very probably to delay, action for years to come.

title: BRITAIN ASKS DELAY ON MARKET BURDENS
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 16Nego tiators renewed talks here to day on Britain's application to join the European Common Market. The British asked for a year's grace from the finan cial burdens of membership if she is accepted.

title: In The Nation: The Electoral College Debate
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 The direct popular election of Presidents is a proposition that has been steadily growing in popular favor. The George Wal lace Presidential campaigns and the Supreme Court's oneman, onevote decisions provided a favorable climate for such a sweeping change in the politi cal system. Polls now show it to be the strong desire of most Americans. It has the support of the American Bar Associa tion, it won overwhelming ap proval in the conservative House of Representatives, and then received the endorsement of President Nixon.

title: Dance to Mark the 10th Year Of Hospital Ship's Dedication
description: A $100aperson benefit dinner dance will be held on Tuesday at the Shoreham Hotel in Washington to com memorate the 10th anniver sary of the dedication of the bosnital shin S. S. Hope.

title: Tacoma, in Recall Election, Votes Five Councilmen Out of Office
description: TACOMA, Wash., Sept. 16  The voters of Tacoma last night in a special recall elec tion voted five of their nine City Councilmen out of office  and left the city with the problem of how to replace them.

title: French Believed Piqued
description: PARIS, Sept. 16  President Nixon is understood to have turned down an invitation to visit Paris during his forthcom ing European tour.

title: 40 HERE SEEK CLUES TO WHY DC8 SPLIT
description: Forty investigators gathered yesterday at Kennedy Inter national Airport at the site where an Alitalia DC8 jetliner split in two while landing. The accident injured 76 of the 156 people on board, none seri ously.

title: EXPOS WIN, 4 TO 2, AS RENKO EXCELS
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 16Not even Tom Seaver could stop the slide of the New York Mets tonight as Steve Renko pitched the Montreal Expos to a 42 victory and dropped the Mets two full games out of first place.

title: Yarn Prices Raised Across the Board By American Enka
description: The American Enka Corpora tion announced yesterday that it had raised prices by 10 per cent across the board on all B.F.C. (bulk continuous fila ment) carpet nylon yarns, ef fective immediately.

title: HOMER CALVER, 77, A HEALTH EDUCATOR
description: Homer N. Calver, a noted health educator, died Tuesday in Memorial Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in Clin ton Corners, N.Y.

title: ARBITER ROLE LAID TO DE CAVALCANTE
description: NEWARK, Sept. 16A key prosecution witness testified to day in the extortion conspiracy trial of Simone Rizzo (Sam the Plumber) DeCavalcante that the defendant had received $3,800 to adjudicate a shakedown dis pute among participants in a crooked dice game.

title: PRESIDENT URGES END TO VIOLENCE AND INTOLERANCE
description: MANHATTAN, Kan., Sept. 16  President Nixon made a strong appeal today for the restoration of civility and an end to violence and intolerance in American society.Delivering the annual Alf Landon Lecture before 15,000 faculty members and students in the Kansas State University Fieldhouse, Mr. Nixon used the taunts of a few and the over whelming sympathy of most of those present to fashion one of the most enthusiastic public ap pearances of his Presidency.

title: Wearily, Ineffectually, War Widows Fight Saigon's Red Tape andInflation
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 16The widows of South Vietnamese soldiers are angry, and their reasons are the same ones that so many South Vietnamese cite the growing inflation, the red tape in Gov ernment agencies that are sup posed to help them, the lack of housing in the cities.

title: Japanese Set Deal in Chile
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 16 (UPI)The Economy Ministry said today that two Japanese companies had been authorized to invest nearly $56million in exploitation of iron deposits in Chile. Mitsbuhishi Mining and Ataka & Co., Ltd., the Ministry said, will be active in northern Chile.

title: Nixon's Plans for Yugoslavia Confirmed
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 16Ronald L. Ziegler, the White House press secretary, today confirmed reports that President Nixon would visit Yugoslavia during his projected European tour.

title: Michigan Banker Indicted
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UPI)The president of an Au burn, Micn., bank was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of misapplying $2.7 million of bank funds. The Jus tice Department said a 31 count indictment against Don old Pickelman, 41yearold president of People's State Saving Bank, was returned by a grand jury in Detroit.

title: Easier F.H.A. Loan Terms Approved by Senate Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UPI)  The Senate Banking Committee approved today a bill that would lower down payments for dwellings insured by the Federal Housing Admin istration. It would also sub sidize, for the first time, mass transit systems that operate in the red.

title: WPIX CONCEDES BID FOR RATINGS
description: Fred M. Thrower, president of WIPXTV, spent his second day on the witness stand yes terday telling a Federal Com munications Commission exam iner of a series of moves made by his station in an effort to make news programing a fi nancial and ratings success.

title: Sports Car Buff's Doberman Is Winner
description: DORADO, P. R., Sept. 16 Ponce de Lean, the first gov ernor of Puerto Rico, made a fruitless trip to Florida in 1513 to find the Fountain of Youth. Alexis J. Rodriguez Pou of Bayamon went to Florida 450 years later to at tend the University of Miami and had much greater suc

title: Eight Catholic Bishops Protest To WCBS on Abortion Report
description: Eight Roman Catholic bish ops of the metropolitan area complained yesterday that a WCBSTV newscast on abor tion had conveyed antiCatho lic bias and ignored moral and ethical questions.

title: In Memorial
description: CURRANFrank P. In cherished memory the beloved husband, father and grand father whose kindness and unselfishness will always be remembered.

title: Controversial Phone Book Will Continue in Britain
description: LONDON, Sept. 16 The Post Office announced today that it was going ahead with its controversial plan to com puterize Britain's telephone di rectories, in which names ap pear out of strict alphabetical order.

title: Children's Psychiatric Hospital In Queens Assailed by Ottinger
description: Representative Richard L. Ot tinger yesterday toured the Queens Children's Hospital, a psychiatric institution, and charged that conditions there were a real fright and that children were being treated like animals.

title: Collision Kills 1, Hurts 4
description: BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 16 (AP)A 19yearold employe of the New York Telephone Company was killed today in a headon collision that also critically injured four other persons. A car driven by Rose mary De Pippo, who was killed in the crash, crossed the center line of the highway and col lided with one driven by Dom inick de Luca, 44, who was rushed to Lawrence Hospital with his wife, Genevieve, 41, and two teenage sons, Michael and Richard.

title: DR. SURESH CHINAI, RESEARCH CHEMIST
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., Sept. 15 Dr. Suresh N. Chinai, manager of the Acrylic Fiber Research Division of the American Cy anamid Company in Stamford, Conn., died here today while attending a business meeting. He was 42 years old and lived at 845 West End Avenue in New York City.

title: Lloyd's Chairman Expects Airline Coverage to Go On
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 16 (Reuters)Harry Mance, chair man of Lloyd's of London, said today that aviation insurance rates would rise but that he could not foresee that airlines would be refused coverage be cause of the hijacking menace.

title: State Grant to Help Whitney Sponsor 12 Scholarships
description: The Whitney Museum of American Art has received a grant of $57,000 from the New York State Council on the Arts to be used for 12 scholarships for state students of art and art history and for the muse um's exhibition program.

title: Subways in City Get First BulletProof Change Booth
description: The subway system's first bulletproof change booth went into operation yesterday at Times Square.

title: Padres Down Dodgers To Give Reds Title Tie
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 16 (AP) Clarence Gaston slammed his 27th home run and Ivan Murrel singled in two runs tonight, supporting Dave Roberts sevenhit pitch ing as the San Diego Padres tripped the Los Angeles Dodgers, 40.

title: Signals Are Crossed On Mrs. Meir's Hotel
description: The Israeli Consulate here refused yesterday to divulge the name of the hotel at which Premier Golda Meir would stay, but the Waldorf Astoria issued a press release announcing, Golda Meir ar rives at the WaldorfAstoria today.

title: TRIAL BEGINS HERE IN CRESCENT CASE
description: A Federal jury of nine wom en and three men was seated yesterday for the trial of eight men from New Jersey, Penn sylvania and Florida accused of unlawful security transactions involving control of the Cres cent Corporation, a New York based conglomerate, and the Pakco Company, Inc., an in vestment holding company.

title: RED CROSS SENDS ANEWNEGOTIATOR
description: GENEVA, Sept. 16A new chief negotiator for the Inter national Committee of the Red Cross left for Amman today to try to obtain the release of the hostages from airliners hijacked by Arab commandos.

description: The French Foreign Minister. Maurice Schumann, arrived yes terday on route to Washington for a meeting with Secretary of State William P. Rogers.

title: Elaine L. Berol, Scott B. Taylor Are Wed in Rye
description: RYE, N. Y., Sept. 16 Miss Elaine Lois Berol, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Berol of New York and Waynesboro, Ga., was mar ried here this afternoon to Scott Bevan Taylor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm P. Taylor of Darien, Conn., and Pompano Beach, Fla.

description: LONDON, Sept. 16 (UPI) Britain today ordered all min isters on official business to travel by special aircraft to avoid hijackers. The Chancellor of the Exchequer, Anthony Barber, transferred to a Royal Air Force jet from a British European Airways flight to travel to a conference in Cyprus.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. The President flew to Manhattan, Kan., to speak at Kansas State Uni versity. Later in the after noon he flew to Chicago for an overnight stay.

title: Federal Report Calls Them Insignificant to Trivial
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16In a report, to the White House Council on Environmental Qual ity, the Department of Trans portation said today that the supersonic transport plane might have some effects on the environment. But it rated these effects as ranging from insig nificant to trivial.

title: Metal Workers Elect
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) Edward J. Carlough, 38 years old, was elected today as presi dent of the Sheet Metal Work ers International Association, becoming one of the nation's youngest labor union chiefs Mr. Carlough replaced his fa ther, Edward F. Carlough, 67, who retired. The action took place at a closed session of the union's convention in Atlantic City, N. J., and was announced here.

title: Rights Nominee Backed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept.16 (AP) The Senate Judiciary Com mittee approved today the nomination of Manuel Rtdz, a Los Angeles lawyer, to be a member of the United States Civil Rights Commission.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: A recent letter from Carlos Barrantes of San Jose, Costa Rica, with whom I angled for tarpon last spring, tells of the splendid fishing for snook to be had at the mouth of the Parismina River this month and next.

title: Nursing Homes Get Refun
description: Four Seasons Nursing Homes of America, Inc., received a Federal tax refund of $1.8mil lion on estimated taxes paid for the year ended June 30, Norman Hirschfield, Court ap pointed trustee for the com pany now in bankruptcy pro ceedings said yesterday. He said that for about two years before fiscal 1970 the company paid Federal taxes of $3.65 million. Depending on an audit now being conducted by Arthur Andersen & Co., he said, the company might collect the en tire amounts.

title: Joseph Hardy Puts Quiet Stamp on Show
description: What the Butler Saw, Child's Play and You're a Good Man, Charlie Brown have two main things in com mon. They are hits and their director is Joseph Hardy. Most successful directors leave a stamp on shows, or the shows by the similar nature of the material leave a stamp on the directors. In Mr. Har dy's case, you can tell that he directed a show only by looking in the program.

title: Huk Leader, Captured, Sees Marcos
description: MANILA, Sept. 16Gov ernment forces captured Faus tino del Mundo, second in command in the older faction of the Hukbalahap dissident movement, today. He surren dered after being sealed off in a tunnel connecting two houses in Angeles City, near Clark Air Force Base.

title: Football Transactions
description: BUFFALOClaimed en waivers Greg Jones, running back, from Chicago; Mike McCaf frey linebacker, from Minrieseta, and Jim McFarland, tight end, tram St. Louis. Waived Jim Ward, quarterback; J. C. Col lins, linebacker; Mike Richey, tackle, and John Love, receiver.

title: CAMPBELL SOUP CITES RISE IN NET
description: The Campbell Soup Company achieved an increase of 22 per cent in earnings for the fiscal year ended Aug. 2 on a sales gain of 9.1 per cent, while its fourthquarter net income was up 4.4 per cent and sales were 5.5 per cent above the year earlier level.

description: Mr. Ierardi retired four years ago as editor, but continued as a consultant of Weekly News, which became the National Braille Press, a nonprofit or ganization devoted to helping the blind help themselves, of which he was also a trustee.

description: Radio

title: 4 MORE LIFTERS ARE DISQUALIFIED
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept 16 (AP)  Four more competitors, three from Eastern Europe countries, were disqualified and deprived of their medals in the world weightlifting championships today. They were charged with taking stimulants.

title: Man Held in Alleged Threat
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Sept. 16 (AP)Just one hour before Vice President Agnew arrived in Grand Rapids today, a man reported to have threatened his life was arrested in a down town store across the street from the hotel where Mr. Ag new was to address a dinner.

title: 'Dwarfs Started Small'
description: The world of "Even Dwarfs Started Small," which was shown at the New York Film Festival last night, is a barren, white-washed correctional institution, set on a subtropical, lava island, all of whose inmates (and even its passers-by) are out of scale with their environment and with one another. Some midgets and dwarfs are bigger than other midgets and dwarfs, but none of them  in this film anywaycan easily get in or out of a standard-sized automobile or negotiate a door knob set at a conventional height. They live in a system that ignores them."Whether we're good or bad, the treatment is all the same," says one of the inmates, whose voice has the high, hollow, brain-bending, midget timbre of a Winston Churchill LP played at 78 r.p.m.The inmates take over the asylum and the entire film, which is without system of any kind as sustained metaphor (except for the initial Man-and-God thing), is devoted to exuberantly recording the details of the minidebauch, 24 hours of destruction and cruelty defining midget's inhumanity to midget, animal and vegetable.The cast, in addition to 28 dwarfs and midgets, includes a dying sow, a one-legged chicken, which is tormented by the other chickens, and a droopy camel that, in one of the film's last frames, defecates as he tries to make up his mind to stand or sit, assuming finally a frustrated, stalemated kneel."Even Dwarfs Started Small" is the second feature by Werner Herzog, a 28-year-old German director whose highly regarded "The Signs of Life" was shown at the 1968 New York festival. At a press conference following the screening of his film earlier in the week, Herzog, quite correctly, declined to explain the film and turned aside suggestions of any relationship to the more calculated, surreal work of Buuel. His film, he said, came on him "like a nightmare."Herzog is a highly skilled director, but his images, because of their essential meaninglessness, become their own reason for being. "Even Dwarfs Started Small" eventually is indistinguishable from its Germanic, side-show spectacle, as if it were a movie that had been conceived by the same kind of perverse, uninvolved intelligence that had created the world of the film.

title: OilAllowable Level Is Increased to 87% in Texas
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Sept.16 If the Texas oil and gas indus tries are ever to get well, now would appear to be the time for them to do it.

title: Suspect Cleared in Shooting
description: An apparent case of mistaken identity was resolved yesterday in the Bronx when one brother was replaced by another as the defendant in a case involving the shooting of a child and a man during a purported robbery attempt last year.

title: CONSULTANT FEES FROZEN BY BERME TO PROVOKE SUIT
description: Controller Abraham D. Beanie stopped payment yester day on all new management consultant contracts because, he said, the Lindsay adminis tration continued to award those contracts without Board of Estimate approval.

title: Some PostPrimary Observations
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 16 The 1970 primary election sea son, which began in Illinois on March 17, came to an end yes terday, with the exception of runoffs in Florida and Georgia and Hawaii's bolloting on Oct. 3.

description: Treasury Statement

title: Youth Guilty in Georgia Death
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., Sept. 16 (AP) A second teenager has been convicted of voluntary man slaughter and stentenced to 10 years in prison in the death of Charles Oatman, 16 years old, in the Richmond County Jail. The youth is a juvenile and was not identified. Sammy Lee Parks, 17, was earlier con victed and sentenced to 10 years in prison.

title: I.M. F. DEAL CUTS U. S. GOLD STOCK
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 The United States and the In ternational Monetary Fund an nounced today a complex set of transactions whose net effect will be to reduce the United States gold stock by $322 million.

title: Orioles Clinch Title Tie in East Despite Losing to Senators, 20
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) The Baltimore Orioles clinched a tie for a second straight American League East ern Division title tonight de spite losing to Washington, 20.

title: Liberal Shift Detected in Massachusetts Vote
description: BOSTON, Sept. 16 The nomination of a Jesuit priest to replace a 2Syear veteran of Congress and the hardwon primary victory of Mayor Kevin H. White of Boston has political analysts studying a voter profile they thought they knew well.

title: WarCrime Investigation Of Msgr. Defregger Halted
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 16 (Reuters) The Mu nich public prosecutor an nounced today that he had discontinued his investigation of Msgr. Matthias Defregger for Ihis role in the execution of Ital ian civilians during World War II.

title: Jackson Is Winner in Race Called War Referendum
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 16 An ef fort by the peace movement to defeat Senator Henry M. Jack son failed yesterday as the threeterm Democrat won eas ily in Washington's senatorial primary. With almost 95 per cent of the ballots counted, Senator Jackson had more than 459,000 votes while his opponent, Carl Maxey, a Negro, had only 73, 000.

title: For Formal Wear, a Tieless Shirt?
description: The cop on the beat stopped by to see what was going on, and when he was encouraged to take a seat, he did so. Which is how Patrol man Fred Swedish ended up in the front row at the fash ion show of men's clothes by Hardy Amics at Whitehouse & Hardy yesterday.

title: SANGUILLEN STARS FOR PITTSBURGH
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 16 (AP)Manny Sanguillen got three hits and scored twice in leading the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 53 victory over the Phila delphia Phillies tonight.

description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 The President's Box ac Ford's Theater was empty. But most of the orchestra seats were full of Congressmen at the opening last night of Will Rogers, U.S.A.

title: J. WILLIAM ROBBINS
description: CAMBRIDGE, Md., Sept. 16 J. William Robbins, director of the Environmental Hygiene Di vision of Dorchester County for 36 years, died of a heart attack yesterday in his home at 301 Glenburn Avenue. He was 58 years old.

description: The New Yorker Club, an integrated business and so cial club for businessmen, Government officials and oth ers, got under way yesterday with a firm base, great ex pectations  and a cocktail party.

description: DETROIT, Sept. 16 The Ford Motor Company raised its 1971 car prices today an aver age of 5 per cent, or $153, and hinted that it might raise prices again, depending on its contract settlement with the United Au tomobile Workers.

description: FORT HOOD, Tex, Sept. 16 (UPI) The military judge in the trial of a Louisiana soldier charged with assault to mur der 30 South Vietnamese civili ans at Songmy delayed a de cision today on whether to sub poena President Nixon and other top government officials to testify. Col. George R. Rob inson said that he would rule on defense motions on other matters before the start of trial testimony.

title: Modern Museum. Adds 10 Trustees
description: Ten Persons from the fields of education, civic affairs, business and the arts have been added to the board of trustees of the Museum of Modern Art. They bring to 39 the number of trustees on the board, one short of the full 40 allowed the museum by the New York State Board of Regents, which recently granted it permission to ex pand.

title: POVERTY PROTEST IS DUE IN CAPITAL
description: Officials from antipoverty programs throughout the New York Region plan to go to Washington next Tuesday to oppose an anticipated drop of $3.6million in Federal funds that they say will cast hun dreds of existing jobs.
