description: OTHER COMPANY REPORTS

title: PLAYERS ANNOYED AT LACK OF TALKS
description: With only four days remain ing until Monday night's Ameri can Conference opener in Cleve land, six members of the New York Jets remain unsigned to 1970 contracts.

description: A stylish symbol of British history and military tradition, got up in scarlet tunics and pleated kilts, marched into Madison Square Garden last night, piping a rousing musical affirmation by Irving Berlin There's No Business Like Show Business.

title: Theater: Slice of the Past
description: LONDONIf any find the classic theater a pain then the English have an undeni able genius for making pains. In New York play restaged after 20 or ?? years tends to have the all of revival about it;. in London even after little more than a decade a new staging begins to take on the gleaming patina of a classic. It is an agreeable, and even useful, habit.

title: 45 Coeds at Williams
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Sept. 16 (AP)  Williams College opened its doors to women students today for the first time in its 177year history. Fortyfive girls began classes with a male population of 1.250.

description: PARIS, Sept. 16The United California Bank in Basel A.G., closed its doors at 2 P.M. today as known losses from what is now regarded as Switzerland's biggest banking scandal were reported at $40million.

title: MRS. REGINA RUBICAM
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 15 Mrs. Regina M. McCloskey Rubicam, who was married for 25 years to Raymond Rubicam, founder of the advertising firm, Young & Rubicam died today in the Lawrence Hospital after a long illness. She was 77 years old and lived at the Gramatan Hotel here for 12 years.

title: Goldberg Assails Nixon's Role in Mideast Crisis
description: Arthur J. Goldberg told a crowd of 500 in a Brooklyn synagogue last night that the Nixon Administration had made one of the worst mistakes ever made by an American Ad ministration, in its handling of the critical Middle East ceasefire negotiations.

title: Peppard Plays Agent in 'Executioner'
description: If you like espionage thrillers with pounding drive, a cunning plot tangle that yields two astonishing surprises and truly colorful backgrounds splashing the screen from London to Corfu, then catch "The Executioner." This Columbia release, which has an uncommonly sensible performance by George Peppard as a thunderball sleuth, flanked by some crisply expert Britons, opened yesterday on the circuits.Let the prologue slide past. The opening is the aftermath of a country estate massacre, with Peppard extracting Joan Collins from the gore, cueing in some boing-boing music and angular flashback snippetsthe only persistent clutter in an extremely complicatedbut fascinating plot.Then listen hard to every word, as Peppard, playing an American-reared British agent, accuses his superiors of harboring a traitor and butts his hard head into dangerous areas, sprinting from London to Athens (a nifty sequence making use of a floodlit Acropolis) and a pile-driving showdown on the exotic island of Corfu.Sam Wanamaker (welcome back), the director, and his ace photographer cram in vivid details accelerating the action. The others are fine, too, especially Nigel Patrick, Charles Gray and Keith Michell. Miss Collins and Judy Geeson are neatly ornamental. The only ruband it lingersis that final flip reference to eight human sacrifices. Otherwise Jack Pulman's screenplay is a sizzling winner, served and played accordingly.

title: Democrats Lead Poll on Prosperity
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 16 As campaigns in the nation's Congressional districts get under way, a Gallup Poll in dicates that voters are expres sing greater confidence in the Democrats than in the Republi cans as the party better able to keep the country prosperous.

title: LEWIS ZIENTS
description: Lewis Zients, brother of Ber nard P. Zients, who is president of the 10 Gimbels Departmet Stores in the New York Area, died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 312 South Bridge wood Drive, South Orange, N. J.

title: Jumping Derby to Dutch Tide

De Leyer also was up on the sec ond place finisher, Royal Dutch, who had two clean rounds and eight faults in the third round.

title: U.S. IS SAID TO SEIZE 374 P.O.W. LETTERS
description: Ten persons who visited the Communist capitals of Asia re turned here last night and said that 374 letters from American prisoners of war to their fam ilies had been seized by United States Customs agents at Ken nedy International Airport. The Iservice declined to confirm or deny the allegation.

title: Memorial Seruires
description: BERGERMANMilton M. Memorial Service Monday, September 21, 10 A.M., Carnegie Hall, 57th Street and Seventh Avenue. Please omit flowers.

title: LABOR TO RESUME CONVENTION FIGHT
description: The controversial convention of the New York State A. F. L. C. I. O. is scheduled to re convene Oct. 14 to reconsider a disputed endorsement of Gov ernor Rockefeller for reelec tion.

title: Market Place:
description: Let's take a look at the computer industrythat bur geoning industry in which nothing can go wrong.

title: WalkUp Elevators in the Bronx
description: The strike that has cut off garbage collection, elevator service and hot water in many Bronx apart ment houses is another round in the battle of the city's landlords against the revised rentcontrol law that went into effect last July.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: To the Editor: Any confusion about the dual United States and Israeli citi zenship allegedly possessed by a few of the hijacked hostages of the Palestinian guerrillas may be dispelled by some under standing of the nature of dual citizenship.

title: Shipments of Mobile Homes Showed a 4% Rise in July
description: Shipments of mobile homes rose 4 per cent, or 1,460 units, to 36,830 units in July, the Mobile Homes Manufacturers Association reports. For the second month this year, the monthly figure surpassed last year's. July shipments were up 5 per cent, or 1,620 units above those for July, 1969.

title: ExJustice James W. Bailey Of State Supreme Court Dies
description: COLD SPRING, N. Y., Sept. 16Former Justice James W. Bailey of the State Supreme Court died yesterday. He was 80 years old and lived at 30 Pauldine Avenue.

title: Mrs. Fahnestock Married in Paris
description: Mrs. Eppes Hawes Fahne stock, widow of William Fahnestock, senior partner in Fahnestock & Co., stockbrok ers, was married in Paris Tuesday to Le Ray Berdeau, a widower of Palm Beach, Fla. The couple sail Friday for New York aboard the France. The bride, like her friend, the Duchess of Wind sor, does not fly.

title: U. S. FOUL CLAIM ALSO IS REJECTED
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 16 If Gretel. II intends to beat Intrepid, she's going to have to do it on the water and not on the blackboard.

title: O'Brien Backs Nixon View
description: ALBANY, Sept. 16 The Democratic National Chairman, Lawrence F. O'Brien, asked to comment on President Nixon's speech today in Kansas con cerning violence in American society, said, That's a reason able statement. It comes awful ly late, though.

title: House Panel to Begin Hearings On Industry Pollution Inventory
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 16 Get out the boat! has been a recurrent war cry in 15 years of Federal efforts to clean up polluted waterways.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space10:30 A.M.

title: Unofficial Sex Booklet Draws Mixed Notices at Yale
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 16 Young men and women reg istering at Yale University this week are being handed a 64page booklet entitled Sex and the Yale Student.

title: MR LEADER THIRD AT ATLANTIC CITY
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 16 Fort Marcy has finally suc ceeded in adding the United Nations Handicap trophy to his extensive collection. The star grass campaigner from the Rokeby Stable of Paul Mellon had tried three times in the last three seasons to take the 1 316mile event, but his best previous finish had been third.

title: Guerrillas Dig In for Showdown in Jordan Town
description: ZERQA, Jordan, Sept. 16  Arab commandos in this bulletpocked provincial town today openly defied Govern ment orders to turn in their weapons. They began digging in for a showdown with King Hussein's new military re gime.

title: Bradshaw Hopes to Put on Glory Road
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 16 Terry Bradshaw, the Pitts burgh Steelers ebullient rook ie quarterback, stripped off his wet working clothes in the team's deluxe new locker room today at Three Rivers Stadium and had a dialogue with himself.

title: Police Version of Killing Disputed in New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 16 Black residents of a public housing project have challenged police accounts of the slaying of one Negro and the wounding of three others last night.

title: CORE Head Assails Arab Guerrillas
description: One of the nations leading spokesmen for black national ism, Roy Innis, the national di rector of CORE, has criticized Arab guerrillas for holding American Jews as hostages, and has asked our wing of the black movement not to ignore what happened in Amman.

title: Jockeys Back at Finger Lakes
description: CANANDAIGUA, N. Y., Sept. 16, (AP)Jockeys at Finger Lakes Race Track a oneday strike, but they threatened to walk out again Friday if a high er pay scale is not posted by then.

title: TopLevel U.S. Unit Confers on Options In Jordanian Crisis
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 The Nixon Administration, increasingly concerned that a showdown between King Hussein and Palestinian guer rilla groups may be imminent in Jordan, is preparing con tingency plans.

title: Showdown in Jordan
description: The showdown between King Hussein and the Pales tinian guerrillas in Jordan is a dangerous but inevita ble development. The King, his Bedouin supporters, and an unknown number of the Palestinians who make up a majority of his subjects support American efforts through the United Nations to achieve a settlement of the ArabIsraeli dispute. The commandos, who have increasingly usurped the King's authority while studi ously evading the ultimate responsibility of govern ment, have renounced any compromise with Israel and have vowed to wreck the peace initiative.

title: Chairman of Quaker Oats Retires
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 16 (AP) The Quaker Oats Corporation said today that Donold B. Lourie had retired as chairman of the board.

title: Bridge
description: One of the two biggest tournaments on the New York calendar, the Long Island re gional championships, begins today at Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L. I. Scheduled events are:

title: House Passes Money Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) The House passed and sent to the Senate today a compro mise bill appropriating $3bil lion for the Treasury and Post Office departments for the cur rent fiscal year. The total is $42million less than the Presi dent requested.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: KINGPIN OF CRIME APPEARS IN JERSEY
description: TRENTON, Sept. 16Angelo Bruno, the reputed boss of or ganized crime in Philadelphia and Southern New Jersey, testi fied for nearly an hour in secret today before the State Com mission of Investigation.

title: Major League Leaders
description: Major League Leaders

title: A. & P. Will Drop Charges Against Harry Belafonte
description: CHATHAM, N.Y., Sept. 16 (AP)A spokesman for the A.&P. supermarkets said today that a petty larceny charge against Harry Belafonte would be dropped, although the village police justice said he was un aware of any such action.

title: STOCKS PULL OFF A SURPRISE RALLY
description: With the first major strike against General Motors in a quarter of a century grinding through its second day, the stock market assembled a sur prising rally along a broad front yesterday.

title: Defensemen's Days Numbered, Whether Rangers Keep 5 or 6
description: KITCHENER, Ontario, Sept. 16Four young players, in cluding the battering Andre (Moose) Dupont and Bob Jones, were dropped from the New York Rangers A team today as Coach Emile Francis began cutting the squad to workable size.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Front Page 1  No Title

title: Dividends Announced
description: Dividends Announced

title: European Football
description: European Football

title: Sports of The Times
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 16The 12's begin their journey to the sea, at 9 o'clock in the morning, dragged out of Newport harbor by their power tenders. Only one man is visible on the deck of each boat; neither has yet raised a sail. The day has broken somber and chill, the world seems filtered through a gray lens and the only sounds are the churning of motors and the slap of the sea, sounds so steady and nressina that they become part of the silence.

title: Hijacking Hero Given $5,000 Brink's Bonus
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 16 (AP) Robert E. DeNisco, the Brink's Inc. security guard who shot and wounded a former mental patient and thwarted the hijacking of a Trans World Airlines jet at San Francisco Airport yester day, received a $5,000 bonus check today from Edgar A. Jones, president of Brink's.

title: DECEIT CAPTURES HUN ASTARITA
description: Windfield Farm's talented filly, Deceit, who started her career last March by beating everything in sight while put ting together a string of six victories, finally returned to the winner's circle at Belmont Park Yesterday.

title: FUNDS DEPOSITED FOR MODEL CITIES
description: Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that the Federal Gov ernment had deposited $1mil lion in Model Cities funds in five Brooklyn banks to encour age and assist the development of minority business ventures.

title: Pentagon Discounts Effect Of Drive Against R.O.T.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP)A Pentagon official said today that attacks by campus militants and antiwar critics have had little effect on the Reserve Officers Training Corps program and that it would con tinue to be used as the pri mary source of officers for the military.

title: FRANCIS IERARDI, A BRAILLE EDITOR
description: SOMERVILLE, Mass., Sept. 16Francis B. Ierardi, the blind man who founded in 1927 Weekly News, the first Braille newspaper published in the Western Hemisphere, died Monday at his home. His age was 84.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: Peace Scientists Oppose SubmarineFinding Device
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 16An in ternational group of scientists dedicated to peace issued a warning today that the next possible stepup in the arms race may come in antisub marine warfare, and they urged it to be avoided.

title: Charts of Races at Belmont
description: Charts of Races at Belmont

title: Senate Adopts Resolution Condemning Air Hijackings
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) The Senate adopted today a resolution condemning aircraft hijackings and calling on the United States and other coun tries to prevent future air piracy.

title: ANNE V. GORDON
description: Anne V. Gordon, a teacher of children with language dis abilities at the Willis School in Plainfield, N. J., died Tuesday in New York Hospital. She was 61 years old and lived at 74 South Munn Avenue, East Orange, N. J.

title: Al Del Greco, a Columnist For Bergen Record, Dead
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., Sept. 16 Al Del Greco, sports colum nist for The Record of Bergen County for more than 40 years, died in the Hackensack Hospital today of a coronary embolism. He was 64 years old and lived at 36 Park Avenue in Lodi.

title: Cycling Lane Likely for a Major City Street
description: High officials of the Lindsay administration said yesterday that it was very, very likely that a special lane for bicycles would soon be set aside on maior avenue.

title: WILLIAM F. MOORE
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 16 William Frederick Moore, a member of the board of direc tors of the Washington Natural Gas Company in Seattle for 20 years, died here Monday in Greenwich Hospital after a brief illness. He was 68 years old and lived on Parsonage Lane.

title: MRS. ROBERT J. LEWIS
description: Mrs. Ellen James Lewis, wife of Robert J. Lewis, an invest ment banker, died Tuesday in Presbyterian Hospital. She was 70 years old and lived at 10 East 70th Street.

title: A New President, 43, Is Elected by Motorola
description: Motorola, Inc., announced yesterday the election of Wil liam J. Weisz as president of the electronics company. Mr. Weisz, 43 years old, suc ceeds Elmer H. Wavering, who was named vice chair man.

title: British ExNewsman in Amman Works for Release of Hostages
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 16 The only mediator who has thus far been successful in freeing a single hostage from his Palestinian commando cap tors is a slender, softspoken Oxonian name Michael Adams. Mr. Adams said that he heard news of the hijacking opera tion from television at his home in Sussex last Sunday. I had just been watching Tom and Jerry my favorite program  an absolute parable of the Mideast situation, he said.

title: 9 U.S. HELICOPTERS DESTROYED BY FOE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Sept. 17  Enemy gunners shot down and de stroyed nine United States hell copters and damaged eight oth ers in the last six days, killing four Americans and wounding six, the United States command reported today.

title: SENATE APPROVES BANK LEGISLATION
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 The Senate passed the bank holdingcompany bill today, after approving one restrictive amendment and one liberalizing one. The final vote was 77 to 1. The lone opposition vote was cast by Senator William Proxi mire, Democrat of Wisconsin.

title: Labor and Business Fight LeadedGas Tax as Costly
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 The idea of introducing unlead ed gasoline to help clean up the nation's air ran into oppo sition today from both business and labor on the ground that the cost would be too high.

title: 10 City Narcotics Clinics Given $2.5Million Grant From State
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Sept. 16  Governor Rockefeller an nounced today that the State Narcotic Addiction Control Commission had approved $2, 534431 in grants to 10 organ izations to finance drug abuse treatment programs for youths in New York City.

title: Pulaski Day Proclaimed
description: Governor Rockefeller yester day proclaimed Oct. 4 Pulaski Day in New York State to honor Gen. Casimir Pulaski, Polishborn cavalry leader who died of wounds received in the Battle of Savannah in the American revolution. The day also marks the 34th annual Pulaski Day parade from 26th to 52d Street on Fifth Avenue.

title: Jersey Justice Has Prestige, but Problems, Too
description: TRENTON, Sept. 14This is not a state where a lot of judges sleep late on week days and take an early leave on Friday. Chief Jus tice Joseph Weintraub won't let them; he checks up to see if they're working and, as he puts it, gives them the needle if they're not.

title: Tel Aviv 50 Soccer Victor
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, Sept. 16Tel Aviv University, the national intercollegiate soccer champions of Israel, registered its third straight victory of its ninegame United States lour tonight at Sprague Field by downing Montclair State, 50. Yoran Arnstein, the winner's Inside right, scored three goals.

title: Rival Forces in Jordan Are Estimated at 60,000
description: According to the most re cent estimates of military strength in Jordan, King Hussein's army has 50,000 to 52,000 men, including four armored brigades, as it faces the Palestinian commandos who have vowed to destroy the state of Israel.

title: Cassese Calls for Stricter Measures to Halt Attacks on Police
description: More assistance from citi zens, closer surveillance of militants and stiffer sentences for assailants were recom mended yesterday to combat the growing number of attacks on the nation's police.

title: National Stock Exchange
description: National Stock Exchange

title: PRIESTS AT PARLEY ASK MORE REFORM
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 16Partic ipants in the Roman Catholic theological congress here as serted today that the reform of church structures must be ex tended well beyond the changes prescribed by Ecumenical Council Vatican II.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON RISE IN QUIET DAY
description: The London stock market moved ahead yesterday in quiet trading.

title: Wall Street District's Merchants Detect A Touch of Optimism in the Air at Last
description: The first faint signs of op timism are creeping back into Wall Street, infusing the den izens of downtown Manhat tan with hope, if not outright confidence, that the worst of the bear market is over and that life will be better once again.

title: Public Relations Piece Looks at Christianity
description: A message both promo tional and devotional has been created as a mailing piece by Patrick Carr Asso ciates. It goes, If ever you have occasion to doubt the importance of Public Rela tions, consider Christianity without Matthew, Mark, Luke and John.

title: Minuteman 3 Fired
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Sept. 16 (UPI)The Air Force fired a Minuteman 3 missile to an Atlantic target area 5,000 miles away today in a test of the new multiple warhead system.

title: Hijacked to the Desert: Account by Passengers
description: It was just after noon on Sunday, Sept. 6, and Trans World Airlines Flight 741 was cruising 30,000 feet above Belgium. Capt. C. D. Woods's voice announced placidly that the plane was over Brussels and that the 141 passengers aboard could expect to arrive in New York six hours later.

title: United Nations Handicap Chart
description: United Nations Handicap Chart

title: Hundreds Evacuated in IND Because of Disabled Train
description: Hundreds of IND subway riders were evacuated from trains between the Canal Street station and 42d Street at the height of the evening rush hour yesterday after a south bound A express train had brake trouble at Canal Street.

title: FULTS IS KILLED IN SPEEDBOAT TEST
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 15 (AP) Tommy Fults, a favorite in the Gold Cup hydroplane championships, was thrown from his speedboat and killed in a trial run today.

title: The Cast
description: THE EXECUTIONER, directed by Sam Wanamaker; screenplay by Jack Pul man frorg, a story by Gordon Mc Donnell; music by Ron Goodwin; photographed br Denys coop; produced by Charles H. Schneer and presented by Columbia Pictures. At neighborhood theaters. Running time: 103 minutes. (The Motion Picture Association of America's Production Code and Rating Administration classifies this film: GPall ages admitted, parental guid ance suggested.)

title: New Faces and Old
description: The new politics scored two major victories in this week's primary contests for the House of Rep resentatives. Democratic voters in Baltimore rejected Representative George Fallon, chairman of the House Public Works Committee and loyal servitor of the highway lobby. In Massachusetts, Representative Philip J. Philbin, vice chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, was turned out of office after 28 years.

title: Ari to Open Jan. 24
description: The Leon UrisWalt Smith musical, Ari, based on Mr. Uris's bestselling novel, Exo dus, has been booked to open at the Mark Hellinger Theater on Jan. 24, after a series of previews beginning Jan. 4. Ken Gaston, Leonard Goldberg and Henry Stern are producers of the show.

title: FEDERATED KOREA OFFERED BY NORTH
description: TOKYO, Sept. 16 (AP)North Korea proposed today a con federation of North and South Korea as a transitional step to eventual reunification. At the same time it demanded the withdrawal of United States troops from South Korea.

title: Students Art Is Junk To Janitors at College
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 16 (AP) Janitors did a thorough job of cleaning out Trinity Col lege's art building over the summer but apparently had some trouble deciding what was art and what was junk.

title: Jersey Proposes the Passaic River for a Model Cleanup of Pollution
description: NEWARK, Sept. 16The Pas saic River, generally regarded as one of the country's dirtiest waterways, was proposed to day as a model demonstration project where the nation's best minds would be concentrated on finding more effective ways to control pollution.

title: Wesleyan and Trinity Hopeful Despite Reliance on Newcomers
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Sept. 16  Last season, Wesleyan University had its fourth un defeated team since it took up football in 1883 and won its ninth Little Three champion ship.

title: Census System Is Faulty, Lindsay Tells Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 Mayor Lindsay sharply chal lenged present censustaking methods today as clumsy and and antiquated. He charged they produced inaccurate data, forcing the Government to op erate in a nevernever land where the facts are never seen and the needs of the urban poor are evaded.

title: CHILEANS CHOOSE ARGENTINE STAY
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 16 An invasion of refugees, panic stricken by the prospect of a Marxist President in Chile, as a result of the election Sept. 4, has packed hotel rooms here and jolted the Argentine econ omy.

title: Brooklyn G.I. Killed in War
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UPI)The Defense Department today listed Specialist 4 Mi chael Asep of the Army, of Brooklyn, as having been killed in the war in Indochina.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Article 3  No Title

title: 8 AIRLINER HIJACKERS CONVICTED IN MUNICH
description: BONN, Sept. 16West Ger many's first trial of airplane hijackers ended in Munich to day with prison terms ranging from two ana a half years to eight months for eight Czecho slovaks who diverted a domes tic flight into West Germany last June. The sentences of five defendants were suspended.

title: C. W. POST TO FIELD A YOUTHFUL SQUAD
description: BROOKVILLE, L.I. Sept. 16 When only 52 candidates showed up for the first day of football camp at C.W. Post, Dom Anile, starting his third year as the Pioneers coach, took a good look and imme diately crossed his fingers.

title: U.S. Gives Import Quota To Textiles From Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 16 One of Brazil's chief complaints against United States trade policy was satisfied today with the signing of an agreement giving an American import quota to Brazilian textiles.

title: Miss Donna Moran Fiancee of Doctor
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 16 Miss Donna Louise Moran, a psychologist at the Harvard Medical School, and Dr. Michael D. Robbins, an instructor in psychiatry there, plan to be married next Month.

title: TV: Socially Involved Storefront Lawyers Bows
description: The Storefront Lawyers, which had its debut last night at 7:30 on the Colum bia Broadcasting System, gives every appearance of handily making the grade. Its concept was inspired by the increasing number of young lawyers who want to become socially involved. But, more than that, last night's pre miere was a professional hour of television that car ried a warning to the gul lible not to sign contracts for house repairs at a seem ing bargain.

title: Books of The Times
description: For decades Louis Zukofsky has been writing very good poems appreciated mostly by other poets. He has translated Catullus, with his wife, Celia. He has trifled with fiction in the Borgesian man ner (Ferdinand). He is the father of a concert violinist. Now he appears with an odd, playful, thoroughly charming novel about a child prodigy, Little Baron Snorck von Chulnt, on his way up the musical ladder to a violin recital at the Great Hall, and the parentsDala Baballo and Madame Verchadet von Chulntwho help him climb.

title: Furs for Grande Dames and Wild Kids
description: At the beginning of his fall fur collection, Jacques Kaplan promised every thing for everyone. Then he marched out 123 coats to an audience of 600 customers and press crowded into the grand ballroom of the Plaza Hotel yesterday and kept his promise.

title: JUNIOR WORLD SERIES
description: Syracuse (I.L.) 5. Omaha (A.A.) 1. (Syracuse leads fourofseven series, 20).

title: Utility Awards Contract
description: The Louisiana Power and Light Company, a subsidiary of Middle South Utilities, has awarded Combustion Engineer ing, Inc., a contract valued at about $50million, for an 1165 megawatt nuclear steam supply system and nuclear fuel. The system is scheduled for opera tion in late 1976.

title: Broadcast by WNYC To Open HiFi Show
description: A television program with four channels of sound will he broadcast by WNYCTV (Channel 31) and WYNCFM at 8 P.M. Friday to mark the opening of the 1970 New York High Fidelity Music Show that day. The broad cast will be presented by the Institute of High Fidelity, which is sponsoring the show. Viewers with a twochan nel stereo system will be able to hear the program over their hifi systems by turning down the television sound. For those who have four channel systems, WYNC has engineered the program ac cordingly.

title: Primary Won by 3 Votes
description: FARGO, N. D., Sept. 16 (UPI) Robert McCarney won the Republican Congressional race in North Dakota's western dis trict by three votes. The North Dakota canvassing board today certified Mr. McCarney, a Bis marck businessman, as the win ner over Richard Elkin, who had been endorsed by the state Republican organization. The final count in the election, held Sept. 8, was 17,380 votes for Mr. McCarney and 17,377 for I Mr. Elkin.

title: Director of Union's G.M. Section
description: DETROIT, Sept. 16When a break comes in the General Motors strike and positions begin to change hour by hour, the leaders of the United Automobile Workers will take each new offer from G.M. and ask, What do you make of it, Irv? In most instances, Irving Bluestone, the director of the union's Man General Motors department, who In the is head of the News union's negotiat ing team at G.M., will be able to come up with a quick assessment.

title: Fireman Accused Of Ignoring Alarm In Syracuse Blaze
description: SYRACUSE, Sept. 16A vet eran city fireman was sus pended today and charged with failing to dispatch trucks last Friday night after a citizen called to report smoke odors at a house in which a woman was later found burned to death.An hour and a half after Ger hard Seetge, 17 years old, called both the Police and Fire Departments, other calls report ing flames finally resulted in the sending of fire equipment to the house. In addition to the woman who died, seven per sons, including two policemen and three firemen, were in jured.

title: U.S. IN GOOD POSITION IN CHESS OLYMPIAD
description: SIEGEN, Germany, Sept. 16 The United States team, fol lowing a firstround setback and fighting a cautious battle, drew two games with Rumania and adjourned two, one in a winning position and the other with a fair chance, in the sec ond round of the 19th Chess Olympiad today.

title: Mrs. Binh to Attend Session
description: PARIS, Sept. 16 (AP)The Vietcong delegation to the Paris peace talks said today that Mrs. Nguyen TM Binh, Foreign Minister of the pro visional Vietcong government, would resume her place tomor row at the talks.

title: MISS DE COZEN WINS PLAYOFF BY 2 SHOTS
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., Sept. 16 Charlotte De Cozen of Westchester Country Club de feated Mrs. Albert B. Bower of Pelham C.C. by two strokes at Winged Foot Golf Club today in an 18hole playoff for the Elizabeth Wheeler Trophy and the 41st annual open cham pionship of Fairfield and West chester counties.

title: AMEX PRICES RISE AS TRADING GAINS
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange moved steadily higher after a slight setback in the first hour of trading and finished near their best levels of the day on moderate trading.

title: Chess:
description: In the recent fourth Pan American chess tournament in Havana, 18 players from 15 countries competed. At the end of the round robin there was a threeway firstplace tie among International Mas ters Eleazar Jimenez and Eldis Cobo of Cuba and Orestes Rodriguez of Peru.

title: Police Aid Rushed to Town In South of Italy After Riots
description: REGGIO CALABRIA, Italy, Sept. 16 (Reuters)  Police re inforcements were rushed to this town near the southern tip of Italy today after a night of some of the worst violence it has seen since unrest broke out two months ago.

title: Judicial Nominee Vetoed
description: AUGUSTA, Maine, Sept. 16 (AP)The allRepublican Exec utive Council killed today, 4 to 3, the nomination of Armand A. Dufresne Jr. as the state's Chief Justice: Gov. Renneth M. Curtis, a Democrat, immediate ly announced he would again post the name of Mr. Dufresne, also a Democrat, for the post.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Boston Red Sox, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 2 P. M. (RadioWHN, 1:55 P.M.)

title: Court Enjoins Chavez Union
description: SALINAS, Calif., Sept. 16 (AP)A temporary injunction against mass picketing by Cesar Chavez's United Farm Workers Organizing Committee in the Salinas Valley was granted to eight large growers today by Monterey County Supreme Court. Judge Anthony Brazil, ruled that the union's effort to break teamster contracts was a jurisdictional dispute, not a strive.

title: Yonkers Results
description: Yonkers Results

title: Advertising: Old Crow Set to Fly for Ogilvy
description: Ogilvy & Mather's first campaign for its new client National Distillers Old Crow bourbon breaks tomorrow in newspapers in 137 markets and will be followed by a fat schedule in national maga zines starting in October.

title: Commercial Paper Shrank in August, 3d Month in Row
description: The commercial paper mar ket contracted during August for the third month in a row, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yester day.

title: Carlisle Corp. Elects
description: The Carlisle Corporation has elected Malcolm C. Myers as president to succeed George F. Dixon Jr., who becomes chair man. Mr. Myers also was elected a director.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Boston 3, New York 1. Washington 2, Baltimore 0. California 5, Minnesota 1.

title: Outlooks at a Glance
description: PROSPECTSMay not go through another undefeated campaign, but the winning attitude is intact in the return of key players.

title: Educators Hail Nyquist's External Degree Proposal
description: Education officials around the state enthusiastically praised yesterday a proposal by Ewald B. Nyquist. New York's Com missioner of Education, to cre ate an external degree pro grain for people unable to attend regular college classes.

title: Cards Sign Draft Choice
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 16 (UPI) The St. Louis Cardinals signed Greg Terlecky, a righthanded pitcher today. Terlecky was the top choice of the Cardinals in the June freeagent draft.

title: On African Safari, She Bagged Native Recipes for Her Book
description: Last year, before leaving for East Africa, Beatrice Sandler packed a satchel full of what she considers one of the greatest kitchen gadgets, the swivelbladed paring knife. She took them as gifts on a cooking expedition, and when she came back from Senegal, Liberia, Ghana, Kenya, Tanzania, Zanzi bar and Ethiopia, she had replaced them with a satchel full of recipes.

title: Thorns to Leave Williams
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Sept. 16 (AP)Frank R. Thorns Jr., the athletic director of Williams College since 1950, announced today that he would retire on July 1, 1971.

title: 2,000 Coast Youths Clash With Police
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 16 (AP) Sheriff's deputies used tear gas tonight against 2,000 young persons throwing rocks, bot tles and fire bombs at them after a Mexican Independence Day parade.

title: NEW SAGAN PLAY HAS PARIS DEBUT
description: PARIS, Sept. 16Twenty years ago with the publication of her initial novel, Bonjour, Tristesse, Francoise Sagan, then still in her teens, emerged as the child star, the wunder kind, the veritable Shirley Temple, of French letters. In her new playher sixth Un Piano dans l'Herbe (A Piano io the Grass), which opened at the Theatre de l'Atelier last night, Miss Sagan, now near ing 40, casts a bittersweet backward glance at those who were coming of age two dec ades ago.

title: AMMAN CRITICIZED BY SYRIA AND IRAQ
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 16 The leftist governments of Syria and Iraq assailed the mili tary regime imposed in neigh boring Jordan today as the work of reactionary imperial ist authorities.

title: Con Ed Granted An Earlier Date For Rise in Rate
description: The State Public Service Commission yesteroay author ized the Consolidated Edison Company to make an addition al 1.4 per cent rate increase in bills for electricity effective Oct. 1.

title: BUCKLEY DRAWS WALL ST CHEERS
description: James L. Buckley, Conserva tive party candidate for United States Senator, drew cheers yesterday as he assured thou sands in his audience at a noontime rally in Wall Street that the silent majority will no loneer remain silent.

title: 'Une Simple Histoire'
description: Marcel Hanoun belongs to that diminishing company of French directors (including Jacques Rozier, Roger Leenhardt, Alexandre Astruc, and until very recently, Eric Rohmer) whose work is known to American movie lovers by reputation, but whose films are rarely, or even never, seen here. Hanoun, who is 40 years old, has been making feature movies for 13 years, and of these, "Une Simple Histoire," which played last night at the New York Film Festival, is the earliest.Hanoun made "Une Simple Histoire" in 1958, but it looks more like 1938, with its dark, low-contrast photography (it was shot in 16-mm.), its unglamorous realism, and its heroine with her penciled eyebrows and her unstylishly bobbed hair. The heroine (Micheline Bezanon, the only player given credit in the program, although there are several other important roles) is a poor youngish woman who, with her little daughter, comes to Paris looking for a job. She doesn't get a job, and when, eventually, she can't afford a place to sleep she spends a night out of doors. She is discovered by a kindly older woman who takes her in (this is where the movie actually begins), and in whose apartment, in one extended flashback, she tells her story.The telling of the story, the young woman's narrative, is imposed on the action in such a way as to deny each scene any ordinary dramatic interest and instead to substitute a counterpointing between the description (which is very flat) and the actual realization (also very flatand with dialogue subdued beneath the narrative voice). At first this method seems pregnant with understated tension, but in time you come to realize that nothing more is happening than appears to be happening, and the method begins to seem silly. And at a certain not exceptional moment, when the young woman, very disconsolate, stands by a tunnel and says: "I found a tunnela place where cars went in. They came out a bit further on."at that moment I began to find the simple story rather silly, too.There is an overwhelming temptation to compare Hanoun with Robert Bresson, whose work "Une Simple Histoire" greatly resembles. But Bresson, for all the spare severity of his style, has never professed to tell a simple story, and (for example, in "Mouchette" and "Une Femme Douce") has often tended to make more complex the fictions upon which he bases his films.Hanoun's simplicitylike his almost stationary camera (which is just stationary enough to make for some very fancy corner-of-the-frame interior shots that might have been centered), like his depressed view of Paris, like his leading lady's eyebrowsseems finally less a matter artistic asceticism than of artful calculation. And in the midst of the many deprivations that constitute his style there is a kind of pretentiousness  ostentationsness, really  as if he were taking pride in poverty.

title: U.S. AFFIRMS REPORT OF ISRAELI BREACHES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (Reuters)The State Depart ment confirmed today that Is rael had been conducting re connaissance flights over the Suez Canal area beyond the limits agreed upon in the Mid dle Eastern ceasefire and standstill agreement.

title: Crime Bill Introduced
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15 (AP) Senator Richard S. Schweiker, Republican of Pennsylvania, in troduced a bill today to make killing, assaulting or injuring state and local policemen, fire men and judges a Federal crime. A similar bill already has been introduced in the House by Representative Wil liam C. Cramer, Republican of Florida.

At neighbor hood theaters. Running time: 103 min utes. title: People
description: Richard Keegan has Joined Jack Tinker & Partners, Inc., as director of account management.

title: Steele Buys Two Theaters
description: Robert L. Steele announced yesterday the purchase for an undisclosed price of two Off Broadway theaters, the Gate and the Cricket, both situated at 162 Second Avenue. He plans to present a new musical, Stag Movie, at the Gate on Oct. 16. Mr. Steele, who produced Nol Coward's Sweet Potato on Broadway, plans to acquire ad ditional OffBroadway theaters and to offer other OffBroad way and Broadway productions under the corporate name of R & A Productions.

title: NEWSPAPER UNION RATIFIES CONTRACT
description: Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Work ers and the Publishers Associa tion of New York City have reached agreement on a new threeyear contract, it was an nounced yesterday by Michael Takvor, business representative for the local. He said a mem bership meeting last night had ratified the aareement.

title: After 11 Months, 3 Top Singers Join to Give  Cavalleria at Met
description: Three leading singers finally had a chance Tuesday night to appear in roles at the Metro politan Opera, for which they had been scheduled 11 months earlier.

title: The Assets and Liabilities of Banks Reporting Weekly to the Federal Reserve System
description: The Assets and Liabilities of Banks Reporting Weekly to the Federal Reserve System

title: REP. FALLON LOSES IN MARYLAND RACE
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 16 Representative George H. Fal lon, the 68yearold chairman of the House Public Works Committee, conceded today his defeat in Maryland's primary election by a young lawyer who had campaigned against the big Federal highway program spon sored by Mr. Fallon's committee.

title: The Cast
description: R P.M., directed by Stanley Kramer; written by Erich Segal; director of photography, Michel Hugo; music by Barry DeVorzon and Perry Botkin Jr.; produced by Mr. Kramer; released be Columbia Pictures. At Loew's Orpheum, 86th Street at Third Avenue and Loew's State I, Broadway and 49th Street. Running time: 97 minutes. (The Motion Pictunt Association of America's Produc tion Code and Rating Administration classifies this lim: Rrestricted, Persons under 17 require accompanying parent or adult guardian.)

title: Housing Patrolman Held In Shooting in the Bronx
description: The indictment of a suspend ed New York City Housing Authority patrolman on charg es of assault and felonious weapons possession arising from the shooting of a man aft er a traffic altercation was an nounced yesterday by Bronx District Attorney Burton B. Ro berts.

title: PROFIT OF A.T. & T. FELL IN QUARTER
description: Net income of the American Telephone and Telegraph Com pany fell in the third quarter of 1970 despite an increase in revenues, the utility reported yesterday.

title: P.S.C. Turns Down Request For Stay on Phone Rates
description: ALBANY, Sept. 16The Pub lic Service Commission today insisted the New York Tele phone Company must file new rates, calling for a $120.8mil lion increase, by Sept. 21.

title: Belmont Tockeys
description: Belmont Tockeys

title: Putt Is Worth $15,000
description: FREEPORT, Grand Bahama, Sept. 16 (AP)Dick Florin of Atlanta scored an ace on the first suddendeath hole today to win the $15,000 first prize in the $100,000 World Putting championship. Florin edged the 21yearold defending cham pion, Ricky Smith, a student at Purdue University.

title: National Gallery Giving Course on Humanities
description: The National Gallery of Art in Washington has intro duced a multimedia program in the humanities called Art and Man. The first install ment of the eightpart pro gram will be distributed to participating museums and schools throughout the coun try starting Monday. The program is being published and distributed by Scholas tic Magazines, Inc., under the direction of the gallery.

title: Soviet Reports 3 Deaths From Cholera in Crimea
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 16 (Reu ters)  Three persons have died of cholera in the Crimean city of Kerch, the Soviet Gov ernment newspaper lzvestia re norted today.

title: A New Western
description: For 103 minutes, James Stewart, who has inherited it, and his equally genial, dimwitted cowpoke pal, Henry Fonda, shuffle around the refined premises of The Cheyenne Social Club in popeyed reverence. Yes, it's a house not a home, and that's the one joke in the tired, arch prairie comedy opening yesterday, directed and produced by Gene Kelly, of all people.

title: EILEEN J. GARRETT, SPIRITUALIST, DIES
description: Eileen J. Garrett, trance me dium, psychic researcher and author, died Tuesday at St. Roch's Hospital in Nice, France, near where she was attending a conference of the Parapsychol ogy Foundation, Inc., of which she was president. She was 77 years old and lived at 50 Sutton Place South.

title: Cabinet Shifted in Libya
description: CAIRO, Sept. 16The revo lutionary government in Libya shuffled the country's cabinet today, replacing Foreign Minis ter Salah Buysir and three others, according to the Middle East News Agency. The new Foreign Minister is Mohammed Najm.

title: Fairfield Rallies to Defeat Ox Ridge in Cup Polo, 118
description: DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 16 The Fairfield County Hunt Club's No. 2 team broke a tie with four goals in the last chukker today to defeat the Ox Ridge Hunt Club, 118, and advance to the semifinal round of the Governor's Cup polo cham pionship. The game was played at Ox Ridge.

title: BRITISH CLEAR TWO IN ARMS CACHE CASE
description: LONDON, Sept. 16Charges were withdrawn today against two men, one of them an Amer ican, who were arrested last month in connection with an arms cache found at the Lon don Hilton Hotel.

title: ExVietnam GI., 15, A Fafher in 8th Grade
description: ARCADIA, Fla., Sept. 16 (AP)Walter Lee Martin, a twicewounded Vietnam vet eran who is now 15 years old, became the father of son today as he prepared to reenter the eighth grade.

title: MRS. MEIR FLIES TO NIXON MEETING
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 16 Premier Golda Meir left for the United States today to meet with President Nixon. Israeli officials believe that the time is ripe to try to bring together Israeli and American policies on peace and war in the Middle East.

title: Business Records
description: Business Records

title: Credit Markets: State Issues Find Ready Response
description: Kidder, Peabody & Co. head ed a group of underwriters who were awarded yesterday two issues of New York State Housing Finance Agency tax exempt bonds totaling $76, 320,000 with an effective in terest rate of 6.8575.

title: CONTRACT SET UP IN BONELESS BEEF
description: Rising imports of frozen bone less beef has led the New York Mercantile Exchange to estab lish the world's first commodity futures contract for this pro duct. Llewellyn Watts Jr., chair man of the board of the ex change, announced yesterday.

title: Health Leader Says Abortion Law Works Well Here
description: After two months experience with the state's new abortion lawthe most permissive in the countryNew York City's health chief yesterday pro claimed the program a success, offering an array of encourag ing statistics to experts who had forecast heartbreaking chaos.

title: Yonkers Drivers
description: Yonkers Drivers

title: RED SOX NIP YANKS WITH 3 IN 7TH, 31
description: Rogelio Moret of Guayama, P. R., made his 21st birthday memorable one at Yankee Sta dium last night as he acquired his first major league victory by pitching four shutout relief innings in a 31 decision the Boston Red Sox scored over the New York Yankees.

title: No Place to Cry
description: Within a few minutes, on a recent evening, three television channels presented these three episodes:

title: TOP AIDES SHIFTED BY BANKERS TRUST
description: The Bankers Trust Company announced yesterday a broad reshuffle of its senior manage ment that will bring Chester Baylis Jr., previously the bank's only executive vice president, into the inner circle of top of ficers with fulltime responsi bility for general management of the bank. Mr. Baylis, who is 62 years old, will be chairman of the executive committee of the bank.

title: MENTALLY RETARDED GET BROOKLYN HOME
description: The first community resi dence for mentally retarded young adults was officially opened yesterday by Governor Rockefeller.

title: New Books
description: The AllPurpose Bodies, by Philip McCutchan (John Day, $4.50). Espionageintrigue featuring Com mander Shaw.

title: GIBSON OF CARDS BEATS CHICAG0, 81
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 16 (AP) Ted Simmons's homer started a threerun fourth inning and Joe Torre hit a tworun homer in the ninth today as the St. Louis Cardinals downed the Chicago Cubs, 81, for Bob Gib son's 22d triumph.

title: 2 Borough Chiefs Promise to Fight Tolls on East River
description: The considerable political power of Brooklyn and Queens will be joined against any ef fort to impose tolls on the East River bridges, the chief execu tives of the two boroughs said yesterday.

title: Infiltration of Palestinians Reported by Bonn Official
description: BONN, Sept. 16 (UPI)Pal estinian refugees trained in guerrilla terrorist techniques have been infiltrated into West Germany, a top official in the West German counterintelli gence agency said today.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: KRAUEVICA (Crossocean), Casablanca Sept. 26 and Rijeka Oct. 4; sails from Columbia St., Brooklyn.

title: Congo Moves Up Elections
description: KINSHASA, the Congo, Sept. 16(Agence FrancePresse) Presidential and legislative elec tions in this former Belgian col ony will be moved up a month, the central committee of the ruling Popular Revolutionary Movement announced today. The presidential election will now be held on Oct. 31 and Nov. 1, and the legislative elec tion on Nov. 14 and 15.

title: Bronx Landlords Cut Services As Defense in 2d Day of Strike
description: Organized Bronx landlords reported yesterday that they had begun a defensive shut down of services, even in apartment buildings not yet struck by service employes.

title: Conaressto Meeton P.O.W.'s
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (UPI)John W. McCormack, speaker of the House, an nounced today that a special joint meeting of the House and Senate would be held Tuesday to deplore North Vietnam's in humane treatment of United States prisoners. He said that wives of prisoners had sought the session.

title: Setback Conceded in Fight For DirectVote Presidency
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) The chief Senate sponsor of a constitutional amendment providing for election of the President by direct, popular vote, conceded defeat today on a key test of strength.

title: Luna 16 in Moon Orbit
description: BOCHUM, West Germany, Thursday, Sept. 17 (Reuters) The Soviet moon probe Luna 16 went into a lunar orbit early today, scientists at the Bochum Space Observatory here report ed. Luna 16 was launched Sat urday, and an official Soviet announcement said it would study the moon and nearmoon space.

title: Quinn and AnnMargret Star in R.P.M.
description: Stanley Kramer's R.P.M., which opened yesterday at the Loew's State I and Loew's Orpheum Theaters, is about one of the gut questions of our time. Should AnnMar gret, a graduate student in sociology, continue to Sleep with Anthony Quinn, her bleeding heart liberal of a professor, after he becomes acting college president and sends the pigs in to clear out the administration building?

title: Television
description: Television

title: HIJACKING ACTION BY U.N. IS SOUGHT
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 16 The newly elected President of the United Na tions General Asembly, Dr. Edvard Hambro, today put his personal prestige behind moves to have the Assembly take action against aerial hijackings and the seizure of hostages.

title: BOMBED By CHIEF, LEVITT RIVAL SAYS
description: Edward V. Regan, the Re publican candidate for State Controller, said yesterday that a bomb had been dropped on his campaign  and that the bombardier was his own run ning mate, Governor Rockefeller.

title: Soldier Loses War Challenge Based on 1787 Law
description: A soldier's challenge to or ders sending him to Vietnam on the ground that the war is unconstitutional was dismissed yesterday by a Federal judge in Brooklyn.

title: LENINGRAD LEADER APPOINTED IN SOVIET
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 16Grigory V. Romanov was named today as First Secretary of the Lenin grad Communist party organi zation, replacing Vasily S. Tol stikov, who has been appointed Ambassador to Communist China.

title: Dent's Brother Indicted
description: ORANGEBURG, S. C., Sept. 16 (AP)William P. Dent, brother of Harry S. Dent, an adviser to President Nixon, and two other men have been in dicted for simple assault. The charges against William Dent, Sam Robinson and Theodore Zeigler were brought by Ellis Vandegrift of Hopkins, near Co lumbia, a competitor of Mr. Dent in the lowcost housing business,

title: Patrolman Shot Uptown Is in Critical Condition
description: Patrolman Raymond Schue, 28 years old, assigned to duty in the East 126th Street Pre cinct, Manhattan, was in criti cal condition in the Hospital for Joint Diseases Yesterday after suffering a gunshot wound from his service revolver late Tuesday night.

title: Executive Changes
description: Alfred Strogoff has joined the Sun Chemical Cor poration as executive vice president for corporate development.Ronald C. Waranch has been elected executive vice president of Lear Siegler Properties, Inc., a subsidiary of Lear Siegler, Inc.

title: BROKERS PAYMENTS APPROVED BY PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 The House Commerce Subcom mittee approved today a sched ule of assessments on broker age housesto be used to fi nance a new program of insur ance against brokers failures that was the same as the one approved by the Senate yesterday. The assessments are higher than those a secu rities industry study group agreed to.

title: Waste Standards Defended
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (AP) John P. Badalich, executive director of the Minnesota Pol lution Control Agency, said today the Atomic Energy Corn sion felt that Minnesota's standards for nuclear power plants were unreasonable, whereas he considered them part of the first complete set of standards and regulations for disposal of solid wastes in the nation. He appeared before a Senate Government Opera tions subcommittee to discuss the dispute over construction of a nuclear power plant by the Northern States Power Com pany at Monticello, Minn.

title: AGNEW IS HECKLED AT CAMPAIGN STOP
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Sept. 16Vice President Agnew ended his first campaign tour today in a shouting match with antiwar demonstrators and with a plea to bluecollar Democrats to prove their patriotism by voting Republican.

title: Tax Status of Newburgh Congressman Scanned
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 The Internal Revenue Service said today that it was looking into the tax status of Repre sentative Martin B. McKneally, Republican of Newburgh, N. Y.

title: DEAL ESTIMATED AT $15MILLION
description: In another significant show of financial muscle, reminiscent of his struggle to solidify the American Football League, Lamar Hunt signed Arthur Ashe to a fiveyear contract with World Championship Tennis yesterday.

title: Eisenhower Dollar Voted
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 (Reuters)The Senate approved today a bill authorizing the minting of 150 million Eisen hower dollar coins containing 40 per cent silver and sent it to the House for a conference committee meeting.

title: YARD EXPERT JOINS THE PENN CENTRAL
description: The Penn Central Trans portation Company, whose freight yards and terminals have been incredibly snarled, hired a vice president yester day to try to restore order. He is J. Hansford Sharp, president of the Terminal Railroad Asso ciation of St. Louis, a job in which the Penn Central's pres ent president, William H. Moore, preceded him.

title: JORDANIAN ARMY AND GUERRILLAS BATTLE IN AMMAN
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Thursday, Sept. 17Heavy fighting began at dawn today between Pales tinian guerrillas and Jordanian Army troops in what the guer rillas said would be a final confrontation.

title: Court Challenges Plohn Plans To Sell Its Seat on Big Board
description: Federal Judge Constance Baker Motley has ordered the receiver for Charles Plohn & Co., a liquidating brokerage house, to show cause why he should not be restrained from selling the firm's remaining seat on the New York Stock Ex change to cover obligations to customers and other creditors. Sale of the exchange mem bership, worth about $200,000, had been proposed by the firm and later by Robert M. Bishop, vice president and director of the exchange's Department of Member Firms. However, the seat is owned by Alexander Edelman, a former Plohn part ner, and not by the firm.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Heavy fighting between Palestinian guer rillas and the Jordanian Army began early this morning in Amman. Yesterday, King Hussein in an attempt to ease the deepen ing crisis, installed a military government and proclaimed martial law. He called on the guerrillas to lay down their arms, but the Palestinians in defiance called for a gen eral strike today. [Page 1, Col 8]

title: Excerpts From Nixon's Kansas Speech on Violence in the U.S.
description: Following are excerpts from President Nixon's address yesterday at Kansas State University in Manhattan, Kansas, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: TURNOVER CLIMBS IN AMEX ADVANCE
Cosmos 363 Launched
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 19 (AP) The Soviet Union announced today the launching of the 363d satellite in its Cosmos pro gram.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: To the Editor: Joseph Shattan's letter of Sept. 2 again raises that oid Arabists canard so frequently resorted to by Senators Javits, Kennedy and Hughes.

title: Druggists Score Rivals
description: DUBLIN (AP)Supermarkets are cutting into this country's drug store business, according to Irish pharmacists.

title: Officials in Saigon Cool
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 18The proposals by the Vietcong were being studied here today, but the immediate reaction among officials was that they provided no grounds for hope of an early settlement.

title: Film: Cinema of Privileged Moments
Unmanned Soviet Spacecraft Goes Into Orbit Around Moon
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 17 The Soviet Union announced today that its unmanned Luna 16 spacecraft, launched on Satur day, had gone into orbit around the moon.

title: Theologians Urge Democracy In Choice of Popes and Pastors
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 17A con gress of ranking Roman Cath olic theologians called today for more democratic methods of selecting popes, bishops and pastors.

title: RULES TIGHTENED ON ABORTION HERE
description: The city's Board of Health ruled yesterday that physicians here must stop performing abortions in their private of fices by Oct. 19.

title: Greek Publisher Paroled
description: ATHENS, Sept. 17  Achil leus Kyriazis, one of the pub lishers of the now defunct newspaper Ethnos who was im prisoned last April for publish ing an article advocating a return to democracy in Greece, was granted a sixmonth parole for medical treatment today.

title: Phil Foster Charged With Lying To Crime Task Force in Jersey
description: NEWARK, Sept. 17  Phil Foster, the television and night club comedian, was indicted on perjury charges today by Federal grand jury investigat ing organized crime in New Jersey.

title: SINGERS CONVEY ENGLISH FLAVOR
description: Two unrelated performers, Dave Cooper and Reg Cooper, brought a touch of the English folk clubs on Wednesday night to the Folklore Center, 321 Avenue of the Americas.

title: Swiss Art Dealer Files Suit Against Publisher of Fake
description: Fernard Legros, an art dealer living in Switzerland, filed a $55million libel suit here yes terday against the author and publisher of the book Fake, which was published last year.

title: Prisoner of Elba Wins His 12th Poetry Award
description: PESCARA, Italy, Sept. 17 (Reuters)  Alfredo Bonazzi, a convicted murderer, has received his 12th poetry prize after a special trip from jail to get the award in this eastern Italian town.

title: Bridge:
description: Winning two national titles in one tournament is a rare feat, and it is necessary to search the record books care fully to find cases in which a single player has won three major events.

title: Rise in Rumsfeld's Influence Is Noted
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 The influence of Donald Rumsfeld has been rising and continues to rise in President Nixon's inner circle of advis ers. Mr. Rumsfeld wears two hatsassistant to the Presi dent and director of the anti poverty agency, the Office of Economic Opportunity  but most bureaucrats have tended to treat him simply as the antipover ty chief. A clear indication of Mr. Rumsfeld's power at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue is that he is now a member of the handful of aides who meet regularly over coffee at 8 A.M. to discuss Mr. Nixon's prob lems and to plan the day ahead.

title: BUYERS CAUTIONED ON LONDON MORGAN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17  The Securities and Exchange Commission warned investors, banks and others today to be ware of accepting what it flat ly labeled the spurious fi nancial instruments of J. P. morean & Co. Ltd. of London.

title: HAROLD GOLD, AIDE OF WPIX, DIES AT 54
description: TEANECK, N. J. Sept. 17 Harold Gold, public relations manager of WPIX, Inc., died here yesterday at the Jersey City Medical Center after a brief illness. He was 54 years old and lived at 728 Chestnut Avenue.

title: Weekend Fishing and Boating
description: AREA A  Blues, of the twotofivepound variety, are running well on the New Jer sey shore, especially at dawn and dusk on the surf between Barnegat and Beach Haven Inlets. Blues of lighter weight are also abundant in deeper waters, four or five miles off shore. In the bays, kingfish, blues and weakfishand an occasional blowfishare bit ing. Crabbing, which has been excellent all summer, continues good in all of Bar negat Bay.

title: Senate Votes Plan Giving Public Jobs To the Unemployed
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (UPI)The Senate voted today to revamp Federal manpower training programs drastically and create 150,000 public service jobs for the hardcore unemployed before next sum mer.

title: BID FOR A PULLOUT
description: PARIS, Sept. 17The Viet cong, with the support of North Vietnam, declared today that in exchange for an agreement on the withdrawal of all American and other foreign forces from South Vietnam by June 30 of next year, the Communists would refrain from attacking the withdrawing troops.

title: lets to Start Two Rookie Cornerbacks in Opener Monday
description: When the the New York Jets open their American Confer ence season against the Cleve land Browns on Monday night, two rookie cornerbacks will be in their starting defense ,Earlie Thomas and Steve Tan Inen.

title: DUN &
description: Dun & Bradstreet, Inc., and Vance, Sanders & Co., Inc., large, Bostonbased manager and distributor of mutual funds, were sued here yester day in Federal District Court, in an effort to block the sale for $450,000 by Moody's In vestors Service, Inc., a Dun & Bradstreet subsidiary, to Vance, Sanders of the right to man age the $30million Moody's Capital Fund.

title: Soviet Officials Say Mideast Peace Hinges on Israel's Return to Talks at U.N.
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 17Soviet officials have told diplomats and journalists here that they believe a Middle East solution is still possible, but only if the United States applies enough pressure to end Israel's boycott of the United Nations peace talks.

title: Nixon Goes Shopping
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 17 (UPI) Like many visitors to Chicago, President Nixon went shopping today at Marshall Field & Co.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: WALSH SUSPENDS LOANPLAN HEAD
description: The director of the city's $35million loan program for building owners was suspended yesterday after he refused to ,complete a financial question naire for the Department of Investigation.

title: Arabs of West Bank Keeping a Close Eye On Strife in Jordan
description: RAMALLAH, IsraeliOccupied Jordan, Sept. 17The men and women of this quiet town on the west bank of the Jordan felt close to the civil strife in Jordan today, knowing their personal and political futures were at stake.

title: Yugoslavia Says Nixon Visit Will Aim at Better Relations
description: BELGRADE, Sept. 17  The scheduled meeting between Presidents Nixon and Tito, the first visit by a United States head of state to Communist Yugoslavia, will be an op portunity for asserting and fur ther promoting the good re lations between the two countries as well as for an exchange of views on topical international issues, an official Foreign Ministry spokesman said here today.

title: SHARP RATE DROP SPURS BOND SALES
Twins Rehire Rigney
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn. Sept. 17 (AP)The Minnesota Twins extended Manager Bill Rigney's contract today through the 1971 season at a raise in sal ary. Rigney's entire coaching staff was also retained.

title: Brazil Devalues Cruzeiro
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 17 (Reuters)The Brazilian cen tral bank tonight devalued the cruzeiro against the United States dollar to 4.69 to 4.72 from the previous level of 4.62 to 4.65, announced on July 24.

title: Proposals Termed Propaganda Move
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 Administration officials found nothing promising for nego tiation in their initial read ings today of the Vietcong's revised peace proposals at Paris.

title: Orioles Clinch Title as Yanks Lose to Red Sox in 10th, 54
description: In beautiful weather, with no more than 6,000 people in Yan kee Stadium to disturb the peacefulness of the Bronx, the New York Yankees messed themselves up in various ways yesterday and officially elimi nated themselves from the American League East pennant race by losing to the Boston Red Sox, 54, in 10 innings.

title: M.T.A. Agrees With Union Ads Charging Years of City Neglect
description: A spokesman for the Metro politan Transportation Authority said yesterday that the agency's officials were in general agree ment with criticisms of the sub way system cited in advertise ments by the Transport Work ers Union.

title: PRICES OF GRAINS SHOW A DECLINE
2 Years of Racial Protest Stall Buffalo Campus Project
description: BUFFALOOn Halloween, 1968, Governor Rockefeller broke ground on a 1,200acre tract of land in suburban Am herst near here for a new campus of the State Univer sity at Buffalo that he said was the most promising new development to emerge in Buffalo since the opening of the Erie Canal in 1825.

title: 14 Union Leaders Are Jailed In New Haven Teacher Strike
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 17  Fourteen union leaders were jailed today after they had re fused to pay fines of $100 each for continuing the sevenday strike by 2,000 teachers here and in West Haven, a suburb.

title: lvanchenko Sets World Lift Mark Of 1,113 Pounds
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 17 (AP)Gennady Ivanchenko of the Soviet Union lifted a world record 1,113 pounds tonight to capture the lightheavyweight title in the world weightlifting championships.

title: Peace Positions Compared
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 Following is a comparison of the position taken in Paris to day by the Vietcong with those put forth in May, 1969, plus (those set out by President Nixon in a June, 1969, speech and by President Nguyen Van. Thieu of South Vietnam in various statements.

title: Toll in Hotel Fire Rises to 17
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 17 (UPI) Four more bodies were discov ered yesterday in the ruins of the Ponet Square Hotel. The dis covery brought to 17 the total killed in last Sunday's fire.

title: Leary, Travelling in Europe, Continues His Policy of Silence
description: ROME, Sept. 17  Howard R. Leary, who resigned as New York City's Police Commissioner less than two weeks ago, is vacationing in Europe in a new rolethat of ordinary tourist and very pri vate citizen.

title: Some Colleges Lose Freshmen to City U.
description: Some private universities and colleges in the New York area enrolled 30 to 40 per cent fewer freshmen this month than they had antici pated and officials of the schools attributed the falling off to the City University's openadmissions policy, which guarantees a grace to any high school graduate in the system's tuitionfree colleges.

title: Man With Pistol Jailed
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Sept. 17 (UPI)A 20yearold former mental patient who allegedly made a threat on the life of Vice President Agnew was sentenced today to 30 days in jail for possession of a starter's pistol. Acting on a tip sup plied by his parents, the police arrested Melvin Stusse, an ex marine, at a store across the street from the Pantlind Hotel about onehalf hour before Mr. Agnew arrived yesterday.

title: Francis Suspends Four Ranger Stars for Refusing to Play Without Contracts
description: KITCHENER, Ontario, Sept. 17The longawaited clash in hockey between management and players erupted at the New York Rangers camp to day as Coach Emile Francis suspended four of the team's stars for refusing to play preseason game tonight with out contracts.

title: Romulo Seeks to Put Hijacking on U.N. Agenda
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 17International action against hijacking and the kid napping of hostages was urged here today in speeches and in private meetings.

title: 2,000 March Here for Clothing Aid
description: More than 2,000 welfare mothers and children paraded from City Hall across the Brooklyn Bridge yesterday, de manding Federal aid to buy school clothes.

title: Advertising: N.B.C.'s Season Is Virtually Sold Out
description: The new television season is upon us in case you haven't noticed. And the word from the three net works is that for the fall at least the commercial time has sold pretty well.

title: Tinkle Creek Sets Track Mark in Belmont Steeplechase
description: Mrs. Wallace Whittaker's Tingle Creek covered the 2 mile steeplechase course in the record time of 4 minutes 37 seconds yesterday in taking the $17,500 Broad Hollow at Bel mont Park.

title: Mrs. Finch Takes Crown. By 2 Shots in Senior Golf
description: HARRISON, N. Y., Sept. 17 Mrs. E. C. K. Finch of the Coun try Club of New Canaan, Conn, scored 40, 3575 over the 5,655yard, par72 South course at Westchester Country Club today in rallying to win the 47th annual championship of the United States Senior Women's Golf Association by two strokes. She totaled 161 for 36 holes.

title: Edmond Nouri, Mrs. Redington Married Here
description: Mrs. Diana Crocker Reding ton of New York, daughter of the late William W. Crocker, who was president of the Crocker Citizens Bank of San Francisco, was married here yesterday to Edmond J. Noun of New York and Amagansett, L. I., president of E. J. Noun Associates, gen eral agents for the New Eng land Mutual Life Insurance Company.

title: Baltimore Judge Is Indicted On Disposition of Tickets
description: BALTIMORE, Sept. 17A lower court judge has been indicted on charges of mis conduct in office in connection with the disposition of traffic tickets.

title: U.S. to Request Pollution Data From Plants Using Waterways
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 The Department of the Interior announced today that it would soon begin sending question naires to all segments of Amer ican industry in order to com pile an inventory of the plants that are polluting the nation's waterways, and the nature and amount of the pollutants,

title: VIOLENCE ABATES IN NEW ORLEANS
description: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 17 Major violence in this city gave way to sporadic firebombings last night.

title: Swissair Says Hostage Is ExVietnam P.O.W.
description: GENEVA, Sept. 17Among the more than 50 hostages still held by the Arab com mandos is Specialist 4 Ken neth Hubler, an American soldier who was on his way back to the United States after he escaped from Viet cong captivity, a spokesman for Swissair said in Zurich today.

title: Yale Names Music Dean
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept.17 (UPI)  Yale University announced today the appointment of the chairman of music at the State University of New York at Binghamton as dean of the Yale School of Music. Yale president Kingman Brewster Jr. an nounced the appointment of Philip F. Nelson to succeed Dean Luther Noss who is re tiring after serving since 1954. Dr. Nelson is a former director of the TriCities Opera in Binghamton.

title: Mrs. Cooperstein to Play Mrs. Cushing in Golf Final
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Sept. 17Mrs. Walter Cooper stein of Glen Oaks, the de fending champion, led the way into the final of the 15th annual Women's CrossCounty Golf As sociation matchplay champion ship today with a 4and2 vic tory over Mrs. Gordon Mc Grath of Piping Rock at the Cold Spring Country Club. Par for the 5,861yard course is 37, 3673.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The Plunger

title: Mrs. Elston Married in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 Mrs. Dorothy Andrews Elston, the Treasurer of the United States, and Walter Lawrence Kabis, a Wilmington school principal and Delaware state official, were married here tonight, at the chapel of the American University.

title: Envoy Given Authority to Issue Order
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17The United States, reacting to the outburst of heavy fighting in Jordan, stepped up precaution ary military moves today and left open the possibility of an intervention if American lives were put in peril.

title: Hussein Takes Time Out To Talk to Hams in U.S.
description: LONDON, Sept. 17 (AP)  King Hussein of Jordan talked over his amateur radio set with fellow hams in the United States last night as troops and guerrillas battled in Amman.

title: Air Crewmen Tell Congress Unit Armed Guards May Be Perilous
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17  The president of the Airline Pilots Association International, an official of the airline stew ards union and a stewardess who had flown aboard a hi jacked plane expressed strong reservations today about Presi dent Nixon's decision to put armed guards on passenger planes to prevent aerial piracy.

title: CITY WILL SERVICE STRUCK BUILDINGS
description: City housing officials moved yesterday to restore essential services in Bronx apartment houses where they found health hazards resulting from a strike by maintenance workers.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. President Nixon, in Chicago, met with news paper editors. He conferred with leaders of Chicago's Polish community and marked Citizenship Day by attending naturalization cere monies for more than 100 immigrants before returning to Washington. The Presi dent also requested Charles W. Yost to revaluate the United States role in the United Nations.

title: German Fiber Maker Cuts Capacity Almost Half
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, Sept. 17  Prosperous West Germany is currently watching the rare spectacle of a troubled chemicalfiber company seek ing reorganization through the abrupt cutting of almost half of its producing capacity.

title: JOB SAFETY BILL STALLS IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17The occupational health and safety bill, which organized labor and most Democrats are committed to passing in this session of Congress, appears to be in trou ble in the Senate.

title: Mutual Fund Group Buying Goodbody; Buff Board Seeks Fuller Member Data
description: Goodbody & Co., one of the nation's largest brokerage houses, will be acquired by the Shareholders Capital Corpora tion, a major mutual fund or ganization, for about $9.4mil lion in securities under terms of an agreement disclosed yes terday.

title: 92 DEFEAT DROPS CHICAGO TO THIRD
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 17 (AP) The St. Louis Cardinals pounded their season high of 22 hits today  including four each by Lou Brock, Joe Torre and Luis Melendez  and trounced the Chicago Cubs, 192.

title: Chavez Calls Lettuce Boycott
description: SALINAS, Calif., Sept. 17 (UPI)Cesar Chavez declared a national boycott today on all lettuce not bearing the United Farmworkers Union label, the black Aztec eagle. The boycott will be on until the last grower is signed, he said, adding that the boycott will be in 64 cities.

title: Books of The Times
description: Cocteau. The name's effulgence is unde niable, though to some eyes the radiance is the slick of slime. Puns come to mind. Are they apt? Cockatooa parrot and a bird of paradise: Cocteau mimicked others (Or phee, Antigone, Oedipus Rex) and preened his feathers in Parisian salons. Cocktailan appurtenance, a concoction: Cocteau was never autonomously him self, it seems, but was forever collab orating and draw ing inspiration from the Other people and media: his heroes, his friends, his male lovers; painting, poetry, theater, ballet... the list here is endless. Can Cocteau really pro vide the substance for a biography of an artist? Or is he simply a kaleido scope of focal points for cultural history, for enthralling evocations of past social eras? Did he himself ever stand for anything? Or did he simply adorn and fash ion adornments? Stern moralists may worry, too: there was the evasiveness, the self dramatization, the looseness with the truth. Worse: the sexual culture on which he thrived, the pederasty. And perhaps most serious of all, the apparent moral fri volity: the praise of Hitler's sculptor, Arno Breker, and the nearcollaboration with the Nazis.

title: Rudd Is Named Publicist For City OffTrack Betting
description: Irving Rudd, a former Yonk ers Raceway publicity director, was named yesterday to an identical post for New York City's OffTrack Betting Cor poration. Howard Samuels, the president of the corporation, made the announcement.

title: RAISES END STRIKES IN 2 SCHOOL AREAS
description: MILFORD, Conn., Sept. 17 The strike of teachers here which began Sept. 9, the third day of the new school year ended today following unani mous acceptance last night of a contract giving raises ranging from $780 to $1,300.

title: MITCHELL VOICES HOPE ON BOMBINGS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 17  Attorney General John N. Mit chell expressed confidence to, day that the terrorist bombings, occurring around the country could be brought under con trol by curtailing the supply, of e*losives and rounding up the maniacs he said werel committing the bombings.

title: At Talks in Paris
Two 747's Experience Difficulty But Come Through Unscathed
description: Two Boeing 747 jetliners, one headed for Kennedy Interna tional Airport yesterday and the other taking off from it, ran into contrasting;troubles but came through unscathed.

title: Publishers and Union Talk With Chief State Mediator
description: Vincent D. McDonnell, chair man of the State Mediation Board, met yesterday with negotiatiors for the Publishers Association of New York City and for Paperhandlers Union No. 1 in an effort to help re solve the impasse in their bar gaining talks.

title: Sutton Criticizes Lindsay On Plan for Arts at Piers
