title: EXALLY OF BATISTA ARRESTED IN MIAMI
description: MIAMI, Sept. 19Rolando Masferrer Rojas one of the most dreaded men during the regime of Fulgencio Batista in Cuba, is hack in custody again.

title: Are We Fed Up with? The Artist? Is the Work of Art Over?
description: IS the age of the work of art draw ing to a close? Are we approaching a time when discrete, individual objectspaintings, sculptures, draw ings and their various hybrids and amalgamswill no longer command our esthetic interest? Indeed, has the time already arrived when we feel a little distant fromperhaps even a little superior tothese niggling, highly indi vidualistic efforts to achieve some per sonal statement, some personal form for ideas and emotions that would otherwise go unstated? Are we already, perhaps, a little fed up with the artist as an individual, harboring his own special feelings, arduously defining and refining the materials of his craft and bending them to the purposes of his own inner vision?

title: In The Nation : Violence, Corrosion and Mr. Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 Mr. Nixon appeared this week at Kansas State University in one of the vital roles of the Presidencythat of teacher and preceptor. By all reports, he scored a personal triumph, not only with his platform appear ance in overcoming a band of hecklers but with the theme that no cause justifies violence in the name of change.

title: Weather Balloon Crashes
description: REGINA, Saskatchewan, Sept. 19 (AP)A weather balloon launched Sept. 5 In California crashed today about 25 miles southwest of Regina. The police in Regina said that the balloon landed four miles east and three miles south of Pense and took out four or five power poles. southwest of Regina. The police in Regina said that the balloon landed four miles east and three miles south of Pense and took out four or five power poles.

title: A Giant But An Intimate One
description: OLIVIER MESSIAEN'S Vingt Regards sur L'Enfant Jesus is a monster of a piano suite, two disks long, full of everything, especially repeti tion. It has conventional, even sweet, popsounding harmonies mixed in with wild ones. Simple figurations abound side by side with furious ones.

title: Daniel Wright Weds Nancy Sengstaken
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Sept 19The marriage of Miss Nancy Lynn Seng staken, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. title: Property Insurance for Retail Stores Soars
description: Renewals of property in surance policies for hundreds of stores and shopping cen ters are becoming far more costly where coverage is available at all, according to owners, brokers and risk rat ing specialists.

title: K. W. Perry Weds Claire Begley
description: St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church was the set ting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Claire flor ence Begley to Kenneth Wil liam Perry of San Francisco. The Rev. Regis Ryan per formed the new liturgy cere mony with readings and vows chosen by the couple. Close friends of the couple par ticipated in the readings.

title: A STATEMENT ON THE MIDDLE EAST
description: The construction of numerous new missile sites by Egypt in the ceasefire zone has, after several weeks of hesitation, been acknowledged by the United States. This violation of the terms the ceasefire not only raises the most serious questions about the longterm objectives of the Soviet Union and the United Arab Re public, it also directly challenges the American role as peacemaker in the Middle East. Israel agreed to the ceasefire only on the assur ance of the United States that this acceptance would not be used to weaken her security, already endangered by the massive Russian presence in Egypt. Israel's democratically elected government put the case to its own people with great candor, stressing the risks entailed by the ceasefire and the American assurance. Yet, today, Israel's position has been weakened by the Egyptian and Russian exploitation of the truce, and America's credibility has been placed in doubt.

title: Women of St. Thomas Church Prepare 8th Annual House Tour
description: The St. Thomas Church Choir School and Episcopal Social Services of New York will benefit from the eighth annual house tour presented by the Women of St. Thomas Episcopal Church Oct. 6 and 13 from 1 to 5 P.M.

title: Art
description: IN THESE days of rising costs and faltering standards, when the first consideration in staging an exhibition has to be whether or not it will pull them in at the gate, the Art Institute of Chicago's new show, Painting in Italy in the Eighteenth Century. which opened yesterday, is a risky project. Obviously this is a great show for scholars, students, and se rious amateurs of art his tory  an audience increas ingly illserved by exhibi tions that rehash and re rehash popular material from Monet to Frank Stella in ex hibition after exhibition, an audience so small that its en trance fees would hardly pay the ticLcettaker's salary. But fortuna[ely Painting in Italy in the Eighteenth Century also turns out to be such a beautiful show purely as a visual spectacle that word of mouth should bring in a public for whom the subject per se holds no allure.

title: Woman Writer, Man's World
description: AT this moment the theater is stirring again, producers and directors are reading new plays, playwrights are offering their manuscripts and holding their breath. For this year's twelve Eugene O'Neill Con ference playwrights, home after five exciting summer weeks in Waterford, Conn., now is the moment of truth. Their chances will never be better. Plays staged at Waterford have a special bloom for producers, who know how stiff the competition is among play wrights to he chosen, the attention the plays and playwrights get from theater visitors to Waterford, and the track rec ords of successful O'Neill alumni: Israel Horovitz (The Indian Wants the Bronx), Ron Gowen (Summertree), Oliver Hailey (Hey You, Light Man), John Guare (Muzeeka, CopOut), Frank Gagliano (Father Uxbridge Wants to Marry) and on and on.

title: A break with the past
description: The Dakota, that greengabled landmark overlooking Central Park, was built 86 years ago. Many of the apartments in and under its coppercrusted peaked towers boast paneling and stained glass dating from 1884. But not Stephen Rubin's duplex. He lives in a former storage attic (right) and in the rooms below it (left) that were originally servants quarters. William Machado, the designer, joined the floors with a circular staircase. A dumbwaiter (the lid is under the small Noguchi lamp in the foreground, right) transfers food and drink from the kitchen. Slate roofing was removed from one side of the attic and replaced by a wall of glass to open the room to the sky and a spectacular view of mid town skyscrapers. Mr. Rubin wanted an informal apartment where he could listen to music and enjoy his art and oriental rug collections. Machado de vised 7footlong divans, cov ered them with Turkish kilims (part of Rubin's orientalrug col lection) and installed them in al coves (left) which once held un sightly radiators. Suedecovered wicker chairs and a carpeted tablebench supplement the seat ing. Hifi speakers wrapped in in sulation are recessed, along with heating components, in the walls behind subway grating. Renais sance and German Expressionist drawings are hung on the linen covered panel against the wall that divides the living room from the bedsitting room. In these rooms, the ceiling was lowered to hide a water pipe and to recess the lighting fixtures.

title: VOTERS INTEREST UP IN HOUSE RACES
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 19  Interest in the November elections is slightly greater at this time than at the start of campaigns in earlier Congres sional election years, according to the Gallup Poll, but the poll indicates that voting for mem bers of the House is not likely to rise above 50 per cent.

title: At last a truly scholarly student
description: Many American novelists set out with each new book to write the Great American Novel at last, ignor ing the fact that it has already been written, twice. On the other hand British novelists settle down to write with disarming casualness, confident, matteroffact and realistically lim ited, never addling their brains with notions as absurd as writing the Great British Novel, knowing how many there already are. Big raw am bitions are for the Americans to try, and fail at; the British settle down to write, to get on with it without fuss.

title: Yes, We Know the Director, But Who Wrote the Movie?
description: THE director is the author of a film. This statement, which was first raised in the United States only a decade ago as a voice crying in the wilderness of socialrealist criticism, has become the majority chorus of the country's most respected film journalists. What began as a reaction to the party line is now itself the party line. The auteur theory, as it is called, has encouraged critics to write monographs on dozens of directors, both American and foreign. And it has opened to serious study the once despised Hollywood movie system and its hack directors.

title: From Zapata to Zorba to the Pope to...?
description: THE temptation is strong, when writing about An thony Quinn, to dwell on his face in the very first paragraph. That face! It is surely one of the movies most magnificent mugs. It has always fascinated word smiths, who have likened it to the face of a bloodhound that has just eaten an es caped convict. Or to the face of a Mediterranean peasant. Or to that of a cor nered bull, an Aztec, a long shoreman, a punchdrunk prizefighter, a smoldering halfbreed, a Sicilian prince, and, of course, a Greek named Zorba.

Gard ner that what corrodes a society even more deeply than violence itself is the acceptance of violence.

description: DOBBS FERRY, N. Y., Sept. 19James Macy Jutte, vice president of E. H. Scull & Co., 1441 Broadway, New York, management consultants, died Thursday in Dobbs Ferry Hos pital. He was 68 years old and lived at 100 Cedar Street.

title: Theologian Expects Trouble With Vatican Over Book
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 18Hans Ming, the controversial Roman Catholic theologian from West Germany, declared today that he was bracing for what he termed his most important battle yet with the Vatican over a new book attacking the traditional interpretation of pa pal infallibility.

title: The Berlin Knot
description: Reports that the Soviet Union has prevailed upon East Germany to make a number of unilateral concessions on Berlin are paradoxically less a cause for cheer than for concern in the West. Passes for West Berliners to visit relatives in the East and a halt in East German harass ment of civilian travel on the Berlin access routes ob viously would be welcomed.

title: Kline, Yank Rookie, Scatters Three Hits To Beat Tigers, 51
description: DETROIT, Sept. 20Rookie Steve Kline pitched the finest game of his brief major league career today, setting down the Tigers, 51, on three hits to give the Yankees a sweep of a three game series at Tiger Stadium.

title: Syria Charges Jordianians Entered and Seized 9 Men
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Monday, Sept. 21 (Reuters)Jordanian armored units entered Syrian territory and took nine Syrian soldiers prisoner, a military spokesman said here today.

title: Syria's Military Forces Match Those of Jordan
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 20 (Reuters)Syrian and Jor danian military strength is fairly evenly matched as far as the frontline army man power is concerned.

title: LARRS RETAINS TITLE IN ETCHELLS SAILING
description: RYE, N. Y., Sept. 20David and Timothea Larr of the Sea wanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club, Oyster Bay, L. I., retained their Etchells22 Class national championship today by placing fifth in the final race of the threeday, fiverace regatta on its Long Island Sound off the American Y. C.

title: Some Democrats Regard Lindsay as '72 Potential
description: Leading Democratic politicians in all sections of the country ex cept the Deep South regard John V. Lindsay as a potential Presi dential candidate who could run well as a Democrat in 1972.

title: Prof. James O'Neill, 88, Dead; Expert on ChurchState Ties
description: Prof. James M. O'Neill, edu cator, author and lecturer on the relations of church and state in the United States, died yesterday at the Emerson Con valescent Home in Watertown, Mass. He was 88 years old and lived in Lakeville Conn.

title: Authors Say F.B.I. Agents Misled Federal Officials on Carolina Student Slayings
description: Agents of the Federal Bu reau of Investigation deliber ately misled Justice Department officials during an investiga tion of the 1968 shooting of 30 black students at Orangeburg, S. C., according to a hook by two newsmen who covered the incidents.

title: Dr. Elliott Gross, Neurologist, Marries Sheilah Rae, Actress
description: GLENCOE, Ill., Sept. 20Miss Sheilah Rae Bernstein, an actress and singer known professionally as Sheilah Rae. was married here today to Dr. Elliott George Gross, an assistant professor of neu rology at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in New York.

title: Learning to Recognize the RightHanded Pretzel
description: LITITZ, Pa.To many peo ple, pretzels are merely crunchy, funnyshaped tid bits that taste best with a glass of foamy beer.

title: Personal Finance
description: Most prudent persons make out a number of wills over a lifetime to keep up with changing conditions.

title: Cork Takes Hurling Series
description: The New York AllStars beat County Cork, the Irish National League titlist, 1413, yesterday in the international Irish hurl ing championships at Gaelic Park, the Bronx. The visitors won the twogame aggregate total point series, 3634.

title: Cyclist Who Chased Police Reported Seized in Naples
description: NAPLES, Italy, Sept. 20 (UPI) The police announced the arrest today of a man be lieved to be the acrobatic mo torcyclist who touched off riot ing last month. They identified him as Antonio Mellino, 23 years old.

title: Duffey Opposes Dredging In Sound Near Norwalk
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 20 (UPI) The Democratic candidate for United States Senator in Connecticut, the Rev. Joseph D. Duffey today urged the State Water Resom??ces Corn mission to veto a dredging project that could endanger two unspoiled islands in Long Island Sound off Norwalk, Conn.

title: EXPOS SCORE, 64, ON 4 RUNS IN 8TH
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 20 (AP)Ron Fairly's disputed tworun double off Ferguson Jenkins sparked a fourrun rally in the eighth inning today as the Montreal Expos scored a 64 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

title: One Way to Improve the Air
description: Amid all the talk about air pollution, there's one cheerful note. Perfumers seem to feel that 1970 is a good year to introduce new per fumes. This fall, the air may not be cleaner, but it ought to smell a good deal better.

title: 10 Killed in Bombay Rioting
description: BOMBAY, India, Sept. 20 (AP)Ten persons were killed and more than 70 injured in HinduMoslem rioting here to night, the police reported.

title: Pope Speaks About Jordan
description: ROME, Sept. 20. (AP)Pope Paul VI, speaking today to crowds gathered in Saint Peter's Square,, expressed pro found sorrow about the fight ing between Government troops and Palestinian guerrillas in Jordan, which the Pope visited in January, 1964.

title: Stan Bell of the Braves Dies After Auto Crash
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 20 (AP)  Stan Bell, a 23yearold rookie pitcher for the Atlanta Braves, died early today from injuries suffered in an auto mobile accident yesterday.

title: BEAME ASSAILED BY MAYOR'S AIDES
description: Mayor Lindsay's two Deputy Mayors charged yesterday that Controller Abraham D. Beame was hurting city operations for political purposes by halting payment on new management consultant contracts awarded without Board of Estimate ap proval.

title: Miss Wilson Is Wed to R. I. Peer 2d
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., Sept. 20 Miss Mary Elizabeth Wil son, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Roberts Wilson of Hemet, was married here last night to Ralph Iversen Peer 2d, of New York and Ta homa, Lake Tahoe. He is the son of Mrs. Ralph Sylvester Peer of Los Angeles and the late Mr. Peer.

title: South Africa Found Reliable on Gold Pact
description: COPENHAGEN, Sept. 20South Africa has lived up to both the letter and the spirit of the agreement with the In ternational Monetary Fund on disposal of newly mined gold, PierrePaul Schweitzer said here on the eve of the Fund's annual meeting.

title: Article 78167430 -- No Title
description: UPPERVILLE, Va., Sept. 20"Horses are like potato chips; you can't stop with just one, said Mrs. Harry F. Stimpson, who almost al ways has one more horse than she has stalls.

title: Mrs. Meir Appeals to U.S. Jews for Aid
description: Premier Golda Meir of Israel appealed to American Jews last night to provide financial aid to Israel through the purchase of bonds. She said the contribu tion was needed not only for itself but also as a demon stration to your Government, a democratic Government, that you will it so.

title: Chess:
description: Among the distinguished competitors in the recent United States Open Chess Championship in Boston was Dinah Dobson, women's chess champion of England. She topped the women's con tingent in the 12round Swiss system by a 74 score.

title: Clear Pictures Reported
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 20 (AP)Scientists at the Institute for Space Research in Bochum, West Germany, monitored sig nals from Luna 16 during the landing and reported that it had begun transmitting picture of the lunar surface. The pic tures were of excellent quali ty, said Dr. Heinz Kaminski, the institute's director.

title: Crash Victim Robbed
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 20 (UPI) A thief grabbed a purse con taining $30,000 in jewels from, la wrecked car today. The police said the jewels were stolen from a car belonging to Stanley Meisel, whose car had collided with another in the Hough area. Mr. Meisel's wife, Clara, who suffered two broken legs in the accident, placed her jewelry in a purse and laid it on the car scat. As a crowd gathered, someone opened the car door, grabbed the purse and dashed away.

title: Bozell and Reach Agree on Deal
description: Reach, McClinton & Co., will merge its $15million in billings into the $35million of Bozell & Jacobs on Oct. But it will remain a corporation which, among other things, owns three radio stations.

title: Kes, a British Movie, Opens at Little Carnegie
description: Kes, the English film about a boy and his kestrel hawk that opened yesterday at the Little Carnegie The ater, was shown at the 8th New York Film Festival. In his review, which appeared last Monday in The New York Times, Vincent Canby called it an honorable, de cent sort of movie that is, however, never quite as in teresting as the people with in it.

title: Pirates Top Mets, 95, in 10th After 41 Loss
Soviet Moon Craft Lands; Begins Sending Back Data
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 20  The Soviet Union announced today that its unmanned Luna 16 spacecraft had made a soft landing in a relatively unex plored region of the moon's surface and had begun sending sianals back to earth.

title: COWBOYS TRIUMPH OVER EAGLES, 177
Upper East Side No Longer Dullsville to Young
description: The area around First and Second Avenues on the Up per East Side, once known for its dullness after sunset, has been transformed into a lively nightlife district that is attracting young people from throughout the city and out of state.

title: City Beats Montclair Nine On Pepper's 4Hitter, 54
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., Sept. 20City College gained its sixth victory in eight fall baseball games, downing Mont clair State College, 54, today.

title: Vikings Hand Chiefs 2710 Trouncing
Woman Dies in Fire
description: A 90yearold Manhattan woman died of smoke inhala tion in a fire early last night, fire officials said. She was iden tified as Jenny Fleischmann, of 120 West 70th Street.

title: BLACK ACADEMY PRESENTS AWARDS
description: Eight black men and women were honored last night by the Black Academy or Arts and Letters at its first annual ban quet.

title: U.S. Government and Business Resigned to a Marxist Chile
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20The Nixon Administration and the United States business com munitywhich has extensive operations in Chileare facing with resignation the prospect of a Marxist regime in Santiago and the expected nationaliza tion of American property.

title: OTTINGER URGES JETS FOR ISRAEL
description: Representative Richard L. Ottinger called upon the United States yesterday to make an outright gift to Israel of jets, antimissile missiles and other sophisticated military equip ment.

title: Miss Budweiser Captures Hydroplane Triple Crown
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 20 (AP)Miss Budweiser, the defending champion boat from Tampa, Fla., captured the triple crown of unlimited hydroplane racing today by sweeping the final Gold Cup heat with an average speed of 101.848 miles an hour on Mission Bay.

title: Leftist Syria Seeking to Export Revolution to Other Arab Lands
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 20Syria's role as a storm center in the Arab world was illustrat ed again today with the Jor danian charge that Syrian forc es had invaded Jordanian terri tory to fight along with Pales tinian commandos.

title: PALME'S MAJORITY IS LOST IN SWEDEN
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 20Pre mier Olof Palme's Social Demo cratic party lost its parliamen tary majority in the Swedish general election today, but strongerthanexpected show ing by the Communist party made it unlikely that there would be a change in the Gov ernment.

title: Furnishings Unit Formed By Burlington Industries
description: Burlington Industris, Inc., the country's largest textiles producer, has formed the Bur lington Contract Company, which will assist existing com pany divisions to offer the contract interior furnishings market comprehensive services.

title: Pocantico Hills to Be Saved By Rockefellers for Public
description: The Rockefeller family has decided that its 4,180acre es tate at Pocantico Hills in West chester County will eventually be preserved and dedicated to the public interest, and not chipped away by haphazard de velopment.

title: A 35YearOld Guru Ministers to Hippies of Northern California
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 20At dawn each Sunday, hun dreds of hippies worship on bluff overlooking the Pacific. For instruction, up to 1,500 fill a ballroom for Monday Night Class.

title: SOUTH AFRICA TO TRY BLACK AS TERRORIST
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, Sept. 20A South African civil rights lawyer, Joel Carl son, will go to court tomorrow once again to try to save black African from hanging.

title: COPPER CONSORTIUM SIGNS CONGO ACCORD
description: KINSHASA. the Congo, Sept. 20 (Reuters)An international consortium signed an agree ment this weekend to develop Katanga's rich copper deposits after beating a bid by the Bel gian mining company Union Miniere.

title: Parking Ban Begins In Lower Manhattan
description: A weekday parking ban from 7 A.M. to 7 P.M. in a triangular 50block area of Lower Manhattan goes into effect today in an effort to cut congestion and provide a freer flow for taxis, buses, emergency vehicles and trucks delivering mail, food and other supplies.

title: Two Seized in Kidnapping Of Staten Island Man, 21
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Sept. 20 (AP) Two men were arrested yes terday and charged here with firstdegree kidnapping of Staten Wand man.

title: 4,000 ASSAIL SOVIET ON PLIGHT OF JEWS
description: More than 4,000 people took; part in a mass meeting at Dag Hammarskjold Plaza, 47th Street at First Avenue, to pro test the treatment of Jews in the Soviet Union yesterday.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International Jordan charged Syria yesterday with in vading her territory with armored troops and heavy artillery for the second time. Tank battles were reported in northern Jordan. As King Hussein came under pressure from President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic to end the civil war, observers said the armored units from Syria could be Palestinian guerrilla forces attached to the Syrian Army. [Page 1, Columns 78.]

title: Television
description: Today's Highlights

title: LED ZEPPELIN BRINGS DRIVING STYLE HERE
description: Led Zeppelin edged the Beatles out of the No. 1 popularity spot in a recent British poll, and it showed evidence of that popu larity in two concerts in Madi son Square Garden Saturday.

title: United States Investment in Chile
$222,462 French Race Taken By Highest Hopes, an 181 Shot
description: PARIS, Sept. 20The fickle ness of the female of the species applies to equus cabal !us also. The winners of the English, Irish and French Oaks were to have made today's running of the $222,462 Prix Vermeille at Longchamp the European championship of 3 vearold fillies.

title: Israeli Revue Opens Nov. 8
description: Hagashash of Israel, a re vue with three Israeli artists known as Gavri, Poll and Shaike, will open Nov. 8 at Carnegie Hall. The program, which will be performed in English, Hebrew and Yiddish, is being presented by Charles Tishman.

title: CITY DRAFTS PLANS ON EXCESS LITTER
description: The city is planning to send the City Council proposals for reducing what it considers ex cess litter, including noreturn bottles and cans, a spokesman for Environmental Protection Administrator Jerome Kretch mer said yesterday.

title: GONZALES QUITS MATCH IN DISPUTE
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20 (UPI) Pancho Gonzales and his doubles partner, 18yearold Jim Conners, walked off the court at the Los Angeles Tennis Club during a firstround match in the $50,000 Pacific Southwest tournament today in a dispute over a change in the tiebreaker rules. About 2,000 of the 2,300 fans left with them.

title: United States and Asia: I
description: This is the first of three articles ex ploring the relation of our domestic agenda and our policy in Asia.

title: Italy Marks Centenary Of Conquest of Rome
description: ROME, Sept. 20The two houses of parliament met in joint session today to cele brate the 100th anniversary of the conquest of Rome by the troops of unified Italy, which ended the temporal power of the papacy.

title: After a Century as Italy's Capital, the Eternal City Suffers Modern Agonies
description: ROME, Sept. 20  On the morning of Sept. 20, 1870, ar tillery fire tore into the an cient Roman walls near the Porta Pia, and the soldiers of unified Italy, wearing plumed hats, penetrated through the 36foot breach into a city that received them with eerie si lence and offered no resistance.

title: Hodson Sees Jobs Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UPI) Labor Secretary James D. Hodgson said today that unem ployment might continue to rise for the next month or two but by the end of the year there will be a significant improve ment. Asked in an interview if he expected the turnaround in unemployment to coincide with the November election, he said, If it precedes Election Day, that'll he great. If it doesn't, we can anticipate that it will be improving shortly thereafter.

title: 6WeekOld Infant Given New Kidney in Minneapolis
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 20 (AP)  A sixweekold Minneapolis boy received a kidney trans plant today at the University of Minnesota Hospitals. He was believed to be the youngest person ever to undergo the pro cedure.

title: Op. Ed. Page
description: As the world has grown smaller, the nation more powerful, the problems besetting man infinitely more complex, the pressures more intense, the health of this democracy has increasingly depended on deeper public understanding of difficult issues. Through the new page opposite the Editorial Page that we inaugurate today, we hope that a contribution may be made toward stimulating new thought and provoking new discussion on public problems. All of The Times's regular Editorial Page columnists will appear with their usual frequency on the new page, but they will be joined by two or more outside contributors six days a week, writing on the widest possible range of subject matter and expressing the widest possible variety of opinion.

title: OILERS WIN, 197, AS JOHNSON STARS
MORE GAINS SEEN IN BOND MARKET
STYLE MARKS DEBUT OF CRESCE, PIANIST
description: At his piano recital debut in Town Hall late Saturday after noon, James V. Cresce showed how effectively one can use familiar musical materials in the building of a program with a fresh outlook. His way was to make Chopin and Liszt his principal composers and to add pieces by Poulenc and Liszt his principal composers and to add pieces by Poulenc and Bloch for variety.

title: Gentle View From India
Op. Ed. Page
description: The Times inaugurates today a new page oppo site the editorial page devoted to views and opinions. Obituaries, for merly found opposite the editorial page, will now appear regularly on the second page of the sec ond section.

title: Next Year We'll Have The Fire at Your Place
description: PINE BUSH, N. Y., Sept. 20  The firemen of Pine Bush, in the foothills of the Shawangunk Mountains in Orange County, got help in fighting a barn fire today from an unexpected source the firemen of North Mer rick, L. I., who had partici pated in a parade here.

title: Miami Jury Finds Morrison Guilty of Indecent Exposure
description: MIAMI, Sept. 20 (UPI)A sixman jury here found Jim Morrison, the rock musician, guilty today on two misde meanor charges for his be havior at a concert here last year. He was found innocent on two other charges.

title: Rockefeller Offers Plan to Cut Metal Pollution
description: Governor Rockefeller pre sented a fourpoint legislative package yesterday outlining ways to reduce the discharge of toxic metals and other haz ardous substances into the state's waterways.

title: HARVARD TO FORM ANAFRO INSTITUTE
description: Harvard University announced yesterday that its yearold Afro American studies department would give the highest prior ity now to developing a proj ected W. E. B. DuBois Institute for AfroAmerican Research.

title: Robert Colborn, ExEditor At Business Week, Was 58
description: NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 20 Robert Colborn, a writer and publisher and the former man aging editor of Business Week, died today of cancer in Nor walk Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived at 33 River Street in New Canaan.

title: 100 in N.Y.U. SitIn Charge Bias Against Homosexuals
description: About 100 male and female members of a group calling it self the Gay Students Libera tion began a sitin at a New York University building late, last night.

title: Disturbance at County Fair
description: SAGINAW, Mich., Sept. 20 (UPI)A group of teenagers leaving the Saginaw County Fair early today broke store windows and threw rocks at passing cars along a street near the fairgrounds. Two po licemen received minor injuries when they tried to control the crowd.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Wings Top Rangers, 52, in Garden Exhibition
description: Somewhere last night a law yer must have chuckled as the New York Rangers, whose ab sentees were conspicuous, dropped a freewheeling exhi bition game to the Detroit Red Wings. 52.

title: CANADA GRAND PRIX CAPTURED BY ICKX
description: ST. JOVITE, Quebec, Sept. 20 (UPI)Jacky Ickx of Belgium won the Grand Prix of Canada today, beating out his Ferrari teammate, Claude Regazzoni of Switzerland, at the Mont Trem blant track.

title: Giants Caught in Bears'
Colts Top Chargers On Third Field Goal By O'Brien,16 to 14
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 20 (UPI)Jim O'Brien, a rookie, kicked his third field goal of the game with 56 seconds remaining to give the Baltimore Colts a 1614 victory over the Sari Diego Charaers today.

title: FENTON B. TURCK, ENGINEER, WAS 68
description: Fenton Benedict Turck, an in ternational consulting engineer who specialized in problems of distribution and marketing, died Saturday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 150 Fast 72d Street.

title: Oh! Calcutta! on Film
description: A recently completed color film version of the revue Oh! Calcutta! will be shown next Monday at the Ziegfeld Thea ter, 54th Street, West of the Avenue of the Americas. Ad mission for the 7 P.M. and 9:45 P.M. screenings will be $10.

title: Major League Baseball
description: National League

title: IsraeliU.S. Relations
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20When Premier Golda Meir of Israel was asked this weekend whether a crisis of confidence had crept into the American Israeli relationship, she said no, there was a misunder standing. It might be put down as the $500million mis understanding. For that give or take a hundred million, is recog nized now by both Governments as the probable price of assuring Is rael's ability to cope, militarily and diplomatically, with the Sovietsponsored buildup of Egyptian forces along the Suez Canal this summer. More American aid to Israel was in the offing anyway, but Mrs. Meir played upon the recent tension between Washington and Jerusalem to press her case in talks with American leaders for much faster help and stiffer psychological support in the future.

title: Books of The Times
description: Asians are not like or unlike Euro peans, writes Dennis Bloodworth, who may be remembered from his first book, The Chinese Looking Glass. They are both. They are possessed of the human conscience, the sex urge, five senses or so, and fortysix chromosomes per cell nu cleus. They are hardwearing, edible, com

title: The Guns of September
description: WASHINGTON  Historians have shown us, with painful conviction, how the World Wars could have been avoided if a few men had been wiser. But the sovereigns and the generals and the diplomats acted as if they could not escape events; they marched toward disaster, saying stubbornly that there was no alternative.

title: Chaban Elected Easily Over ServanSchreiber
description: BORDEAUX, France, Sept. 20  Premier Jacques Chaban Delmas was reelected today to a seat in the National As sembly, gaining a decisive vic tory over JeanJacques Servan Schreiber, his reformist chal lenger.

title: Reserve Bank Here Elects
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York has announced the election of W. D. Eherle as a Class B director. Mr. Eherle who is president and chief ex ecutive officer of American Standard, Inc.. will fill the un expired threeyear term of Arthur K. Watson, recently ap pointed United States Ambas sador to France.

title: Study Disputes U.S. Report on Industry Accidents
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20An unpublished report drafted for the Department of Labor con tends that industrial accidents causing death and injury in the United States may be 10 times higher than shown in official figures.

title: EGYPTIAN DECLARES ROLLBACK POSSIBLE
description: Dr. Mohammed H.elZayyat, Egypt's delegate to the United Nations, said yesterday that there was a possibility of an Egyptian rollback of missiles to Suez Canal Zone positions that they occupied before the Mid dle East ceasefire began on Aug. 7.

title: Ky Confirms Intention to Appear At McIntire's Washington Rally
description: SAIGON. South Vietnam, Sept. 20Vice President Ngu yen Cao Ky went on South Vietnamese national television tonight to confirm that he would make his trip to Wash ington as planned and that he would participate in the con troversial prowar March for Victory rally to he held Oct. on the grounds of the Wash ington Monument.

title: Red Cross Accepts Appeal By Hussein to Aid Casualties
description: GENEVA, Sept. 20The In ternational Committee of the Red Cross has accepted in principle an appeal from King Hussein of Jordan asking it to coordinate relief operations for casualties in the Jordanian civil war, a spokesman said tonight. The King's message did not make any distinction between Jordanian and Pales tine guerrilla victims.

title: COLLIERS'S BOUVIER TAKES BEST IN SHOW
200 Walk to Honor First Jews in City, Who Came in 1654
description: Members of New York's contemporary Jewish com munity visited yesterday the site where the first Jewish immigrants to Americathe victims of a pirate's hijack inglanded in New Amster dam over 300 years ago.

title: Highway System Moves A Cosmic Traffic Load
description: When it is finished, accord ing to the Department of Transportation's Bureau of Public Roads, the National System of Interstate and De fense Highways will link more than 90 per cent of the na tion's cities with populations of 50,000 or more as well as hundreds of smaller cities and towns.

title: I.O.S, REINFORCES ITS IMAGE IN ITALY
description: GENEVA, Sept. 20 Sir Eric Wyndham White, new strong man of Investors Overseas Serv ices, has scored his first success in his search for partnerships of prestige and quality to bol ster his severely battered mu tual fund empire.

title: Thermal Ban Set for Lake Michigan
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 20The Federal authorities, in the most sweeping move to date against thermal pollution, have de cided to impose a ban on hotwater discharges from pow er plants into Lake Michigan.

title: Nixon Criticized on Inflation
description: SEATTLE, Sept. 20 (AP)Senator Birch Bayh accused President Nixon yesterday of dereliction of duty for not ask ing for controls to stop infla tion. The Indiana Democrat, speaking at nearby Mercer Is land honoring David Sternoff of Bellevue, Wash., national president of the Young Demo crats, said Congress would have granted Mr. Nixon mandatory wage level controls if he had asked.

title: BLACKS IN PARADE ON AFRO DAY HERE
description: It's beautiful, said Mrs. R. Greene, a slim young woman who was wearing a red and black African headdress called a nele.

title: CLASHES IN 2D DAY
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 20The Jordanian Government re ported tonight over the Am man radio that Syrian armored troops, backed by heavy artil lery crossed the Jordanian border during the day for the second time.

title: CAPITAL GETTING VOICE IN CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 Nearly 750,000 citizens of the District of Columbia at last will receive a portion of the democratic representation that most other Americans have taken for granted for genera tions.

title: Maine Sugar Industries,Inc., And Creditors Set Accord
description: Maine Sugar Industries, Inc., and its wholly owned sub sidiary, Maine Sugar of Mon tezuma, have entered into agreements with creditors hold ing about $8.8million of cur rent indebtedness, the refining company announced over the weekend.

title: Chile's Papers Exercise Caution Following Election
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 20A distinct caution has marked all but the most partisan newspapers and radio stations in Chile's capital since a Marx ist won a plurality in the presi dential election.

title: Mother Killed in Collision Of Cars: One Driver Held
description: SPRING VALLEY, N.Y., Sept. 20A woman was fatally in jured and her infant son was seriously hurt early today in an automobile collision that led to the arrest of a motorist on charges of criminally negligent homicide, driving while intoxi cated and driving with a sus pended license.

title: Levitt Attacks Nursing Home Billing
description: ALBANY, Sept. 20  State Controller Arthur Levitt charged in an audit report to day that a nursing home in New York City had billed the city for $8,185 for the care of five patients who had already died or been discharged.

title: Roswell Rudd and Jazzmen Tour Middle Ground
description: Roswell Rudd, a big, beard ed trombonist, has served as a bridge in recent years be tween the jazz avantgarde and listeners whose ears are accustomed to more tradi tional sounds. He has broad, burry, slippery style that fits as readily with the swoops and shrieks of the avantgardists as it does with the joyful exuberance of the older forms of iazz.

title: Upsets and New Heroes Feature College Football's Grand Opening
description: It was an auspicious start, to be sure: Texas and Pew State continued their winning ways with new quarterbacks and highscoring victories; Jim Plun kett and Archie Manning got Heisman Trophy head starts; a Cherokee Indian lighted fires at Washington, and a placekicker attending the University of the Pacific on a music scholarship provided his team's margin of victory.

title: Emmy Awards Telecasts To Be Held to 90 Minutes
description: The National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences has to decided the limit the an nual Emmy Awards telecasts, which have been running for two hours or more, to 90 minutes. The decision was an nounced yesterday following the fall meeting of the aca demy's trustees at the Essex House.

title: Lawyer Weds Miss Messing
description: Miss Madeline Ivy Messing was married at the Plaza last evening to Roger Lewis Levy, who is with the London law firm of Taylor and Humbert & Co. Rabbi Herbert Weiner performed the ceremony.

title: Virginia Horse Set, Sans Mounts, Aids Church
New Castings Listed
description: David Cryer, who appeared in 1776, has signed to play the title role in Ari, the mu sical version of Leon Uri's novel Exodus, which opens at the Mark Hellinger on Jan. 24. In other casting developments, Madhur Jaffrey has been en gaged for a featured role in Barry England's Conduct Un becoming, opening Oct. 12 at the Ethel Barrymore; David Selby will have an important role in Gandhi, opening at the Playhouse on Oct. 20, and Clebert Ford will be seen in a featured role in Les Blancs, the drama by Lorraine Hans berry starring James Earl Jones and Cameron Mitchell, which Oct. 21, at the Longacre.

title: CH. VAGABOND WINS LAURELS AT GOSHEN
Sihanouk Asserts His Regime Will Go to Cambodia Gradually
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 20The Pekingbased exile government of Prince Norodom Sihanouk announced steps today to trans fer its operations gradually to Cambodia.

title: BERKEY PHOTO ACTS ON MOVIELAB'S DEBT
description: Berkey Photo, Inc., announced yesterday that its directors have authorized creation of a reserve in the amount of $7.5 million against obligations owed to it by Movielab, Inc., from the sale in June, 1969, of the oper ating assets of its Pathe profes sional film processing and op tical effects division.

title: 3 SHOW CHAMPIONS RIDDEN BY JENKINS
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 20Rod Jenkins rode the win ners of three championships at the concluding session of the Pining Rock horse show today.

title: Knudson Takes 4Hole Robinson Playoff
description: ROBINSON, Ill., Sept. 20 (AP) George Knudson of Canada, after a close 40hole battle with George Archer. won the $100, 000 Robinson open golf classic today on the fourth sudden death playoff hole when Archer threeputted for a bogey.

title: Crash Kills Brooklyn Man
description: A 38yearold Brooklyn man was fatally burned early yes terday when a car he was driv ing went out of control on the Interboro Parkway, struck a pole and a divider, caught fire and burned the victim, tenta tively identified as Franklin Freeman, whose license listed his address as 921 Montgomery Street, Brooklyn, was driving west on the parkway shortly before 5 A.M. just west of the Myrtle Avenue ramp when the car went out of control and hit a pole. The Police said that Mr. Freeman was not known at the address listed on his license and that detectives had been unable to locate relatives.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Broadway to Move to 7 :30

title: Mrs. Ward, on Traveler, Is Open Jumper Winner
Chiefs WinMinors'
description: SYRACUSE, Sept. 20 (AP)The Syracuse Chiefs of the International League became the world champions of minor league baseball last night with a 53 victory in the 11th inning over the Omaha Royals of the American Association.

title: Goldberg Asks Reform of Disarrayed State Courts
description: Arthur J. Goldberg, a former United States Supreme Court Justice, asserted yesterday that the state's judicial system was in enormous disarray. He proposed a fivepoint program for its improvement.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: 72 Race Has Begun for Muskie
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 20 For Edmund Sixtus Muskie, United States Senator from Maine, the 1972 Presidential campaign has begun.

title: Dolphins Are Upset By Patriots, 2714; Broncos Top Bills
description: BOSTON, Sept. 20 (UPI)Trailing by 11 points, the Bos ton Patriots converted Ihree Miami errors into 17 points in the final 3 minutes 19 seconds of the first half today and went on to a 2714 victory over the Dolphins.

title: Cures Worse Than Ailment?
description: TOKYO (UPI)  Japanese drug stores sell a wide variety of purported hangover cures, including viper extacts, carrot extracts, scrapings from cattle stomachs, honey, musk, gin seng, caffeine, citric acid and vitamins.

title: A Reactionary Trade Bill
description: Under pressure from a strong combination of industrial and labor interests, Congress now seems ready to enactin the form of the trade bill approved by the Ways and Means Committeethe most protectionist and reac tionary trade legislation in forty years. This bill poses grave dangers to the national interest and to world trade.

title: Rockefeller's Strategy
description: Five months ago, Governor Rockefeller assumed that Ar thur J. Goldberg would be his Democratic opponent for Gov ernor and he privately said that he would defeat Mr. Goldberg by winning over the socalled white ethnic votethe vote professionals define as lower middleincome Roman Catholics or ??, Italian and Polish ances try. With the gu bernatorial cam paign in full swing for only two weeks, there is a growing belief among Republican and Demo cratic politicians that the Rock efeller ethnic strategy is begin ning to work. In fact, there were indications in the last week that Mr. Rockefeller was gaining in two of the areas his campaign is aimed at, the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn and Buffalo and its suburbs.

title: New Bar Discipline Panel
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 20 (UPI)The American Bar Association president, Edward L. Wright, said today a coordinating com mittee had been formed to im plement recent changes in the A.B.A.'s procedure of disciplin ing lawyers. The new proce dures, adopted by the A.B.A. House of Delegates at its an nual meeting in St. Louis, were recommended by an evaluation committee headed by Tom C. Clark, retired Supreme Court Justice.

title: Thurmond Urges Japan to Step Up Defense Effort
description: TOKYO, Sept. 20  Sena tor Strom Thurmond called on Japan today to step up her defense effort and to under take a greater proportion of the leadership necessary to the de fense of nonCommunist Asia.

title: Engineers Race to Finish Alaska Rail Link Survey
description: Engineers are racing the on set of the Arctic winter to com plete a preliminary survey on the feasibility of constructing ailroad and highway link to Alaska's far north.

title: Algerians Detention Extended
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 20The Israeli Chief of Staff, Lieut. Gen. Haim BarLev, today or dered an extension of the ad ministrative detention of two Algerians, suspected of being high security officials in their Government. The first 30day detention order expired today.

title: Philippines Getting a Major Newsprint Enterprise
description: MANILA, Sept. 20A fully integrated newsprint plant, the first in Southeast Asia, is rising at a cost of $100million in the remote town of Bislig, Surigao del Sur Province, far in the wilderness of Mindanao Island.

title: BENGALS CONQUER RAIDERS BY 3121
Ceausescu Due in Vienna
description: VIENNA, Sept. 20 (Reuters)President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania will arrive in Vienna tomorrow for a fiveday state visit, his second to the West this year. He visited France in June.

title: IRELAND OUTLINES HER TRADE NEEDS
description: BRUSSELS, Sept. 20 Ire land will ask the European Common Market for permission to continue helping her bur geoning industry with special incentives to foreign investors for some time after she has entered the Community. Ire land's External Affairs Minis ter, Patrick J. Hillery, an nounced this today upon his arrival here for the member ship talks, which start tomor row.

title: Article 3  No Title
Cameroon Head at Moonport
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Sept. 20 (AP)President Ahmadou Ahidjo of the Federal Republic of Cameroon saw two Saturn 5 rockets today during a one andahalfhour tour of the space center here.

title: Government Expenditures as a per cent of Gross National Product
Film: The Almost Perfect Symmetry of Tristana
G.M.STRIKEEFFECT ON STEEL ASSAYED; A MillionTon Cut in Use of Metal Is Foreseen if Walkout Lasts 45 Days; STORAGE SPACE IS SHORT; Officials at Mills Fearful of Disrupted ?? and Increase in Costs
description: PITTSBURGH, Sept. 20If it lasts 45 days, tA striKe at Gen eral Motors Corporation will re duce consumption of steel by million tons.

title: The Proceedings in the U.N. Today;Sept. 21, 1970
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10:30 A.M. Political and Security Com mittee3 P.M.

title: Broadway Curtains to Go Up at 7:30
description: In an effort to lure more patrons, all Broadway stage shows will raise their cur tains at 7:30 P.M., an hour earlier than usual, beginning Jan. 4.

title: Tropical Storm Reported
description: MIAMI, Sept. 20 (UPI)A weather reconnaissance plane reported a strong tropical de pression with winds up to 35 miles an hour today in the Atlantic Ocean southeast of Bermuda. The National Hurri cane Center here said that the depression was about 500 miles southeast of Bermuda and drifting west at five to 10 miles an hour.

title: Freighter Afire in Caribbean
description: MIAMI, Sept. 20 (AP)The Coast Guard said today it was searching in the Caribbean for a freighter reported afire. Her 24 crewmen were said to have abandoned ship. The vessel re ported it was burning about 200 miles southeast of Kings ton, Jamaica, the Coast Guard said.

title: Fishing W eight Sets Off Mine Scare at Newport
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 20 A trawler's fishing net weight, first thought to be a rusted World War II mine, created a flurry of excite ment today before the start of the second America's Cup race.

title: LUSTY CENERENTOLA SUNG BY CITY OPERA
description: A stylish, lustily sung La Cenerentola was given by the New York City Opera at the New York State Theater yes terday afternoon. The cast, all of whom were familiar in their Toles from previous seasons, did justice to the Rossini opera as actors, too. But then, this is one of the company's most delightfully staged productions.

title: Week's Votes in Congress
Store Explodes With Events
description: Altman's annual fall explo sion, This is Altman's, gets underway today, and as usual, the store has decided to stage a series of special events rather than concen trate on merchandise from one particular country. The storewide event, which runs through Oct. 3, will be high lighted by the opening of new shops, fashion events, beau ty happenings, cooking demon strations and home furnish ings displays. Today's hoopla will include the opening of three new shops: By Hand (main floor), which features homemade accessories such as belts, chokers, bags, vests and hats; Handcrafts from India (fifth floor), and The Fur Pad (fifth floor), which has fur rugs, pillows and wall hangings for the home.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: BALTIMORE  Baltimoreans find Implausible rumors that the Vice President proposes to become this city's second H. L. Mencken. Yet those most inclined to scoff are given pause by Karl Marx's comment on Hegel's assertion that, in a way, history does repeat itself. He might have added, said Marx, that it appears the first time as tragedy, the second time as farce.

title: Ellen R. Krieger Becomes Bride Of L. E. Heller
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Sept. 20The Central Syna gogue of Nassau County was the setting here at noon to day for the marriage of Miss Ellen Roberta Krieger, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L Krieger, to Lawrence Elliott Heller, son of Mrs. Ferdinand Heller of New York and the late Mr. Heller. Rabbi Georgc B. Lieberman performed the ceremony. He was assisted by Cantor Ira Shur.

title: Mrs. Mitchell Opens Own Assault on Educators
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (UPI)Mrs. John N. Mitchell, wife of the Attorney General, said today that professors and educators were destroying the country. They are totally re sponsible for the sins of our children. she said.

title: Unbalancing the SST
description: Discussions of the sonic booms and of the excessive noise at ground level of the supersonic transport make defenders of this project airsick. The question whether the Federal Government ought to invest $2 billion in this plane when so many other urgent human needs compete for money is also guaranteed to increase their queasi ness. They take comfort, however, today as they did nearly a decade ago when this project was first con ceived, in the economic argument that the SST is essen tial if this country is to achieve a favorable balance of payments.

title: Man Slain Near Chinatown
description: One man was killed and an other seriously wounded in an unexplained shooting incident near Chinatown yesterday afternoon, the police said. They reported that Jerry Ginn, 35 years old, of 50 Bayard Street, died after being shot in front of the Sun Sing Chinese Thea ter at 75 East Broadway, and that Larry Wong, 35, of 150 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, was wounded. Their assailant escaped.

title: Paris: Age Is No Drawback to the Genius of 2 Masters
description: PARISThis is no country for old men, wrote William Butler Yeats; whatever coun try he had in mind, it wasn't France. The two most talked about men of La Rentreethe return from the massive August migration that drives the French out of their cities are a writer of 85 years and an actor of 75: Francois Mau riac and Michel Simon. and an actor of 75: Francois Mau riac and Michel Simon.

title: TV Review
description: The second week or the television season opened last night with the American Broadcasting Company intro ducing The Young Rebels, the first of its 11 entries, while the Columbia Broad casting System came in with the last of its fresh contend ers, Tim Conway in his own variety show.

title: Adams Asks Death in Narcotics Cases
description: Dr. Paul L. Adams, the Con servative party candidate for Governor, stood firmly yester day behind his call for impos ing the death penalty on persons convicted of importing, wholesaling or distributing nar cotics illegally.

title: Dr. Robert Passy, 44, Dies; Shaped Math Curriculum
description: BARRINGTON, R. I., Sept. 20 (AP) Dr. Robert A. Passy, chairman of the elementary ed ucation department at Rhode Island College, died today after a heart attack at his home. He was 44 years old.

title: Gretel II Beats Intrepid and Evens Series, 11
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 20The America's Cup finally be came.competitive today when Gretel II of Australia caught Intrepid from behind and sailed on for a thrilling 1minute sevensecond victory.

title: Bank in Basel Thrived on Killings
description: PARIS, Sept. 19  We have a very active invest ment department whereby we not only trade on the main United States stock ex changes but also on most European markets. We also do trading in precious metals, commodities and foreign ex change.

title: 3 in a Balloon Leave for France
description: THE SPRINGS, L.I., Sept. 20Two men and a woman ventured aloft here today in a patched balloon, bound for Europe from a meadow that was dotted with wideeyed children and incredulous adults.

title: DON'T START SCORES IN STRATFORD SHOW
RUSSIAN WINS TITLE WITH RECORD LIFTS
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 20 (AP)  Vasily Alexeyev, 29 years old, a Soviet miner; claimed his first worldsuper heavyweight weightlifting title here today with a record lift in the clean and jerk of 501.5 pounds.

title: Peking In Autumn
description: PEKINGBy early September the weather in Peking has cooled from the tiger heat days; already everywhere there is cleaning and painting; the lit tle hutungs are swept clean; every hand seems busy; whether it is grand mothers who run bicycle stands and public telephones, or vegetable sellers with their carts.

title: Cars Help Plane to Land
description: CRAIG, Colo., Sept. 20 (AP) A power failure struck Craig last night, placing the passeng ers abroad a light plane circling above the community's un lighted airport in jeopardy. The pilot, Ross Evans, put his twin engine plane into a dive and buzzed the blackedout town twice, then flew back over the airport. His act apparently al erted motorists, who drove to the landing strip and played their headlights over the field. The plane landed safely.

title: Alouettes Take League Lead
description: TORONTO, Sept. 20 (Cana dian)The Montreal Alouettes defeated the Toronto Argo nauts, 2417, today to take over first place in the Canadian Football League.

title: FOE KILLS 11 G.I.'S; COPTER SHOT DOWN
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 20 (AP)  North Viet namese gunners shot down United States helicopter trying to land a reconnaissance team a mile south of the demilitarized zone today, then fired mortars into an armored relief force. Eleven Americans were re ported killed and 11 wounded in the two attacks.

title: Virus Is Injected Into 2 Children In Effort to Alter Chemical Trait
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20Scientists here and abroad are watching with interest the progress of two little girls in West Germany who have been infected deliberately with a virus that causes harmless wartlike growths in rabbits.

title: ARMORY DAMAGED; AMMUNITION STOLEN
description: NEWBURYPORT, Mass., Sept. 20 (AP)A National Guard armory here was heavily dam aged today by an explosion and fire that the authorities believe was set. Four hundred rounds of M1 rifle ammunition were reported stolen.

title: PRESIDENT CALLS PEACE ON CAMPUS EDUCATORS'
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20For the third time in as many months, President Nixon has asserted that the university community itself bears the re sponsibility for restoring order and discipline, and an at mosphere in which free aca demic inquiry can flourish, on college campuses.

title: CHIEF IN CAIRO, ILL., QUITS OVER HATRED
description: CAIRO, Ill., Sept. 20 (AP)The police chief of this South ern Illnois city has resigned, saying he could no longer work among citizens who ad vocate violence, hatred and an imosity to their fellow men.

title: MOSCOW WORRIED BY SYRIAN ACTION
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 20The So viet Union was believed to be seriously concerned today by reports of Syrian intervention in the Jordan crisis, and Soviet officials were believed to he trying to persuade Damascus to void further exacerbation of kite situation.

title: 6,000 Policemen Are Deployed In Tense Southern Italian City
description: REGGIO CALABRIA, Italy, Sept. 20At least 6,000 police men from many parts of Italy are now concentrated in this rebellious southern city of 150, 000 neoule.

title: THREAT IN CASINO DENIED BY SINATRA
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Sept. 20 (UPI)Frank Sinatra re plied today to accusations made against him after a Las Vegas casino altercation on Sent. 6.

title: Sports of The Times
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 20When Jim Hardy, the skipper of the Gretel II, was asked if he planned to take advantage of the early 61 odds against the Australian yacht, he shook his head and said, I'm a Corinthian, an amateur, you know. Above his head was an advertising display for Rolex chronometers, cleverly hung from the ceiling of the state armory here so it would appear in all televised news conferences.

title: Wildcat Strike Grounds 6 of 10 El Al Flights
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 20 (AP) El Al, Israel's national air line, was partly grounded to day as 450 mechanics and workship technicians walked off the job. Only 4 of the 10 international flights sched uled to leave here today were able to take off, a com pany spokesman said.

title: In Good Old Days of Juvenal: Slums, Traffic, Noise, Burglars
description: Prophets of doom like Ovid saw the city venal and doomed if it only could find a purchaser.

title: Cannibals, Modern Version of Antigone
Belfast Youths Stone Police
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 20 (UPI)  About 200 youths were reported to have stoned two police cars in the largely Roman Catholic Spring field Road area of Belfast to night. Three officers of the mainly Protestant police force were reported injured.

title: For Martin Abzug, Women's Lib Is an Old Story
description: It was after a violin concert on a warm summer evening in 1942 when Martin Abzug, 25 years old, stood up on a crowd ed bus in Miami Beach and of fered his seat to a young wom an he wanted to meet. Her name, he learned later, was Bella Savitzky.

title: Conflict Over Federal Powers Perils Nixon's Manpower Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 President Nixon's proposal for a sweeping reform of manpow er training  a major part of his new federalism  ap pears to be dead in the 91st Congress.

title: FISCHER IS DEFEATED BY SPASSKY IN CHESS
description: SIEGEN, Germany, Sept. 20The United States team met the Soviet aggregation today in the sixth round of the 19th chess Olympiad at Siegerland Hall.

title: International Loans Listed for Week
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20The following is a list of loans and other aid extended last week by United States and other international lending agencies here:

title: A Threat to Press Is Seen
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20The InterAmerican Press Asso ciation has charged that free dom of the press is being jeop ardized in Chile as a result of a concerted campaign of har assment and intimidation by the Communists and their Marx ist allies.

title: ELIZABETH LOSES, 10, IN SOCCER OPENER
description: The GermanAmerican Soc cer League began its 48th sea son yesterday with six Major Division games in the area, wit nessed by about 9,500 fans, and one game in Philadelphia be fore 2,086 paying spectators.

title: BRONX LANDLORDS WARNED BY CITY
description: One hundred and thirty buildings involved in the Bronx apartment strike were reported yesterday to have received tele grams from the city warning that they had become health hazards because of lack of services and that the city would restore such services if landlords did not do so within 24 hours.

title: A RESTUDY URGED ON CIRCUMCISION
JETS WILL MEET BROWNS TONIGHT
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 20With their cocaptains determined and their contract disputes mostly resolved, the New York Jets apeared organized today for their American Conference season opener against the Cleveland Browns tomorrow night before a national prime time television audience.

title: St. John's U. Appoints a Monsignor
description: St. John's University has announced the appointment of Msgr. George A. Kelly as university research profes sor. He will be the first hold er of the John A. Flynn Chair in Contemporary Catholic Problems.

title: Newport: One City for the Rich, Another for the Poor
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 20 Six miles north of a toss ing buoy that marks the America's Cup Yacht Race, the city of Newport sits like an uninvited guest at a party in his own front yard.

title: BAY STATE GROUP BARS 2D AIRPORT
description: BOSTON, Sept. 20 (AP)The Massachusetts Port Authority, which operates Logan Inter national Airport in Boston and Hanscom Field in Bedford, says it will not file legislation to construct a second international airport.

title: WIDENING FEARED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20Secretary of State William P. Rogers called on Syria today to end her invasion of Jordan and warned that Syrian inter vention raised the danger of wider war.

title: Black Family Fights L.I. Housing Bias
description: MASSAPEQUA, L. I., Sept. 20The house looked like al most any other being built, but large chunnks of concrete had been broken out of the founda tion, the chimney flue had been knocked down and a newspaper story had been nailed to the frame.

title: COLLEGE TO TRAIN URBAN MANAGERS
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Sept. 20Dr. Franklin R. Turner, dean of undergraduate studies at Cali fornia Slate College, Domini guez. Hills. announced plans yes terday for an institute to de velop a new breed of future managers who would be known as urban environmental man agers.

title: History of Long Island Blacks Shown in Hempstead Museum
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Sept. 20 Evidence that a black man was among the 23 founders of Brooklyn, that a Long Island slave was the first published black author in the United States and that Long Island slaveowners were among the cruelest in the nation were among the featured exhibits at the opening here today of the Black History Museum of Long Island.

title: Film Fete: Scavengers
Jewels Worth $30,000 Taken at Accident Site
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 20 (UPI)A thief reached inside a wrecked automobile while accident victims were still in side, grabbed a purse contain ing $30,000 worth of jewels, and raced away through a crowd of onlookers.

title: Kent Victim Jailed for Drugs
description: RAVENNA, Ohio, Sept. 20 (UPI)The Portage County au thorities have jailed on drug charges one of the nine stu dents wounded by National Guard gunfire during student disturbances at Kent State Uni versity last May. The student, Alan Canfora, 21 years old, son of a union official who is a Barberton, Ohio, City Council man, was in jail in ieu of $15,000 bond on three counts of selling hallucinogenic drugs.

title: Advertising: A Mixed View of 4th Quarter
description: Guess It's time to take a look at the (ugh!) fourth Quarter.

title: More Humanistic Schools Are Called Goal by Nyquist
description: GROSSINGER, N.Y., Sept. 20 (AP)State Commissioner of Education Ewald B. Nyquist told 1,000 school administrators today that his chief priority was to make the educational sy stem more humanistic.

title: The Hot Corner Third BaseIs Also a Warm Spot for the Umpire at Shea Stadium
12 Killed and 8 Wounded In Raid by Huk Guerrillas
description: MANILA, Sept. 20 (AP)Raiders described as proCom munist Huk balahap guerrillas killed 12 persons and wounded eight others in a town about 10 miles from two United States Navy facilities in Zambales Province, the police said today.

title: Proposed Charter Curbs Opposed by Airline Group
description: A campaign against proposed restrictions on the operation of lowcost charter flights has been started by the National Air Carriers Association, which represents 10 certified United States supplemental airlines.

title: Reporter's Suit Says His Callup Was a Punishment by the Army
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 20A mag azine reporter has charged in Federal Court that his call to active duty in the United States Army last week was punish ment for uncomplimentary ar ticles he wrote on the military.

title: Cholera Quarantine Lifted In Soviet Port of Odessa
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 20 (Reuters) The quarantine against chol era has been lifted in the Black Sea port of Odessa, Pravda re ported today, but Soviet travel organizations said they were still limiting travel to the city.

title: Amman, From the Inside
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 20 King Hussein's army ap peared to be winning the bat the for this capital today but the Arab commandos, after a terrific pounding, are hold ing out in pockets in the hope that the Syrians will come.

title: Devlin Scores 68 for 278 to Win Alcan by 7 Strokes in Ireland
description: PORTMARNOCK, Ireland, Sept. 20 (Reuters)Bruce Dev lin of Australia won the Alcan Golfer of the Year champion ship by seven strokes today with a final round of 68 over the par72 7,117yard Portmar nock course.

title: Libya Urges Arab Leaders to Allow Her Troops and Algerians to Aid Guerrillas
description: CAIRO, Sept. 20  The risk of entry by Arab armies into the fighting in Jordan was un derlined tonight when Libya urged that a LibyanAlgerian force be sent to Jordan.

title: Confusion, N.J., on Map With Roads Unnamed
description: Motorist are apt to have trouble finding the New Jer sey Turnpike, the Garden State Parkway and the At lantic City Expressway on the highway map just pro duced by the New Jersey Transportation Department. The mapmakers forgot to la bel the roads.

title: West GermanIsraeli Relations Are Reported Strained by Disagreement Over Efforts to Free Hostages
description: LONDON, Sept. 20  West German and Israeli relations have become strained and un easy as a result of efforts to free the airline hostages, held in Jordan by Arab guerrillas, Western diplomats said today.

title: Choice as VISTA Head
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20last Wednesday, the day after she was nominated director of the Volunteers in Service to America, Carol Mayer Khosrovi paid an un announced visit to the head quarters of the national VISTA Alliance here.

title: 2 Fairfield Teams Reach Governor's Cup Polo Final
description: DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 20Two Fairfield County Hunt Club teams advanced to the final of the Governor's Cup polo championship at different sites today.

title: CONFIDENCE STIRS AT ENERGY TALKS
description: TORONTO, Sept. 20Partic ipants in the recently resumed CanadianAmerican energy ne gotiations are quietly confident that, despite considerable oppo sition within Canada, the talks will lead to a permanent in crease in Canadian oil and nat ural gas sales south of the bor der.

title: A.B.A. Rockets Deal Guard
description: DENVER, Sept. 20 (AP)The Denver Rockets of the Ameri can Basketball Association traded Jeff Congdon, a guard, to the Utah Stars for a No. 2 draft choice last night.

title: Intrepid's Tactician Stung by Wasp
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 20 Despite a wasp sting that puffed his face to the size of a grapefruit, Steve Van Dyck hopes to return to ac tion as Intrepid's tactician for the next America's Cup race.

title: Arthur Lipper Corp.
description: The Arthur Lipper Corp. ra tion has announced that Edward J. Larkin Jr., previously a partner of Goodbody & Co., has joined the concern as a vice president and member of the executive committee. Mr. Larkin who was a member of Gondhodv's executive commit tee, will assume his new duties on Oct. 1.

title: DEMAND FOR SHIPS CONCERNS BRITISH
description: British shipping circles are expressing concern at the in flated demand for shipping ton nage all over the world, which may be further aggravated by the rising cost of building new ships.

title: Israelis Feel Hussein's Army Has Won Struggle
description: TEL AVIV, Sept. 20The Is raeli authorities indicated to night that they believed King Hussein's army had won its internal military struggle.

title: Brookville Beats Bethpage On Guest's Five Goals. 74
description: BETHPAGE, L. I., Sept. 20Fred Guest scored five goals,, three in the final period, as Brookville posted a 74 polo vic tory over Bethpage today at Bethpage State Park.

title: Bridge:
description: Teams captained by Ira Ewen of New York and Monroe Granovetter of Jer sey City were scheduled to meet last night in the finals of the knockout event of the Long Island Regional Cham pionships at Roosevelt Race way.

title: S.T. Agnew Is No H. L. Mencken
Columbia Honors Cordier
description: Dr. Andrew W. Cordier, for mer Columbia University Presi dent, has been named President Emeritus of the Ivy League in stitution, the Columbia Board of Trustees announced yester day. Dr. Cordier, who succeed ed Dr. Grayson Kirk in 196S as President of Columbia, re tired Aug. 31 to resume his post as dean of Columbia's School of International Affairs.

title: ExConvict Held in Murder Of Man on Brooklyn Street
description: A man suspected of being narcotics pusher was arrested in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn yesterday on charges of fatally shooting 31yearold Vincent Novella Saturday night.

title: 3 Killed in Clash in Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 20 (AP)South Korean securi ty forces kiled two armed Communist infiltrators on Yongjongdo Island off Inchon, 18 miles west of Seoul, the counterespionage command re ported.

title: Interstate Highways: Life Changes in Their Paths
description: MILESBURG, Pa., Sept. IS America's interstate high way system is opening new social and economic frontiers.

title: Danger From Syria
description: Secretary of State William P. Rogers has justifiably condemned the entry of Syrian tanks into the Jordanian civil war. This irresponsible and imprudent interven tion, as Mr. Rogers accurately termed the Syrian move, poses the greatest danger of broadening the present bloodletting in Jordan into a general Middle Eastern war that could also involve outside powers as well. The same dangers are threatened by the proposals for a joint LibyanAlgerian or unilateral Libyan military interven tion in Jordan.

title: GOLDBERG URGES AN AUTO TITLE LAW
description: Arthur J. Goldberg, the DemocraticLiebral candidate for Governor, said yesterday that the passage of autotitle legislation is long overdue and promised its enactment if he were elected Governor.

title: Jury Investigates Strike at Harlem Cooperative
description: A grand jury is investigating charges that the Harlem River Consumers Cooperative was struck because it would not deal with a food supply com pany in which the striking un ion's business agent had an in terest.

title: Strike in Central Islip
description: CENTRAL ISLIP, L. I., Sept. 21The Central Islip Teachers Association went on strike to day but schools for the town's more than 7,000 students re mained open, staffed by non union personnel. The strike came despite aroundtheclock negotiations that began last Thursday and broke off at 5:30 A.M. today.

title: Master of Survival Hussein Ibn Talal elHashim
description: In the tumultuous recent history of the Middle East, Jordan's tough young King, Hussein Ibn Talal elHashim, has achieved a reputation as a master of selfpreservation.

title: 2DSTORY BRIDGES TO LINK BUILDINGS
description: A system of wide pedestrian bridges over the street at the secondstory level will link at least three new buildings near Water and Fulton Streets, the Mayor's Office of Lower Man hattan Development reported yesterday.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Nothing is sacred any more. On Sun day an overflow mob of Shea Stadium faithful turned venomously on a former object of their affections, Tom Seaver, and supplied him with the sound track of their boos as he made a downcast exit from the second game. Once again he had failed them and all his glorious contributions to recent Met history were angrily erased from memory in favor of a more cynical query: What have you done for me lately?

title: In Philadelphia, the Spirited Prints of Harunobu
description: The idea of organizing a fullscale exhibition of the prints of Harunobu, commem orating the 200th anniversary of the Japanese master's death, with a big, wellpro duced catalogue including both Japanese and English versions of the main text, re flects great credit on the Philadelphia Museum of Art. What conies as a surprise is that, scholarly contribution aside, the show turns out to be so bright and lively. It is a delight and a beauty.

title: STEEL PRODUCTION FOR WEEK IS UP 0.8%
description: Production of steel in the week ended Saturday totaled 2,536,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute re ported yesterday.

title: Britain Calls on Soviet To Restrain the Syrians
description: LONDON. Sept. 21 Britain has urgently asked the Soviet Union to press the Syrian Gov ernment to call off troop move ments in Jordan.

title: Bartender Pleads Guilty To Several Bank Robberies
description: A bartender arrested in con nection with a series of bank robberies in the metropolitan area last spring pleaded guilty yesterday to five counts of an 11count indictment, United States Attorney Edward R. Neaher said.

title: Frazier Meets Foster in Heavyweight Title Bout Nov.
description: DETROIT, Sept. 21 (AP) Joe Frazier and Bob Foster signed today for a 15round world heavyweight title fight here Nov. 18. Frazier is the de fending champion and Foster the lightheavyweight title holder.

title: Army to Try Songmy Suspect
description: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Sept. 21 (AP)Plans to try Pvt. Max D. Hutson, 23 years old, of Williamsport, Ind., on charges stemming from an in vestigation into the alleged massacre in 1968 at Mylai 4, a hamlet in the South Viet namese village of Songmy, were announced today by the Army. But charges that could have brought the death penalty were dropped. The Army also re ferred charges of assault to commit murder and false swear ing against Sgt. Charles E. Hut ton, 22, of Tallulah, La., for trial. No date for either trial was announced.

title: MANY BIG BANKS CUT PRIME RATES TO 7% FROM 8%
description: The prime lending rate on business loans was reduced yes terday to 7 per cent by at least a score of major banks across the country.

title: In France, a Comeback for the Centime
description: PARIS, Sept. 21A French centime is worth less than one fifth of an American cent, and even though prices and wages are still lower here than in the United States it used to be that most Frenchmen couldn't be bothered holding such small change.

title: TV Review
description: The American Broadcast ing Company introduced pro fessional football last night as a regular Monday evening primetime attraction, pre senting Joe Namath and the New York Jets against the Cleveland Browns. The inno vation will be watched care fully by media students. They are curious to see how sports does in the ratings against a movie on the National Broad casting Company network and the regular situation sta ples on the Columbia Broad casting System.

title: Stocks in London Advance Sharply
Racial Fights Flare at New Brooklyn High School
Nixon Names Gen. Davis To Head Hijacking Fight
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21The Nixon Administration announced a series of arrangements today to deal with hijacking as a continuing menace to air transportation. In one step, President Nixon named Lieut. Gen. Benjamin O. Davis Jr., a retired Air Force officer, to the new post of Director of Civil Avi ation Security within the De partment of Transportation.

title: Industry Leaders Term Move Encouraging
description: Among leaders of the home construction industry, a sector of the economy that has felt the highinterest pinch acutely, the lowering of the prime rate yesterday was seen, around the country, as encouraging.

title: Galbraith Predicts No New Left Party in 1972
description: WASHINGTON, Sept 21John Kenneth Galbraith, who has long viewed his party from its left wing, is beginning to sound like a centrist Democrat.

title: McNamara Fears World Faces Wide Social Crisis
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 21Robert S. McNamara, president of the World Bank, painted a somber picture today of the outlook for poor coun tries and, hence, for the world at large.

title: The Cost of Clean Air
description: To clear the nation's air is an enormous and compli cated project in which science does not know all the answers and nobody can calculate the final cost. The deadly peril of pollution is becoming more evident every day, but Americans have only begun to face up to the probability that cleaner air means higher taxes, higher prices for certain products and some sacrifice in comfort and convenience.

title: TEACHERS REJECT NEW HAVEN PACT
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 21New Haven teachers tonight voted overwhelmingly to reject the latest contract proposal from the Board of Education, while teachers in Somers, in the northern part of the state on the Massachusetts border, returned to their classrooms today after a nineday strike.

title: Phillips Reports Finding Oil In North Sea, British Zone
