description: Senator Jacob K. Javits took potential voters by the arm up to Senator Charles E. Goodell yesterday, reemphasizing his endorsement of the candidate and warning against denigrat ing his chances.

title: U.S. PLANES ARRIVING IN JORDAN WITH AID
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 28 United States Air Force C130's began airlifting relief supplies to Jordan today while Jordan. ian armored cars ringed Amman airport to prevent them from being shelled by guerrilla mortars.

title: In Vietnam, Casualties and Fighting Ebb
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 28 (Reuters)The United States military command said today that no Americans were killed in South, Vietnam yester day. It was the second time this month that no deaths were re ported over a 24hour Period.

title: Stans Announces Broad U.S. Study of Mineral Resources, the First Since 1950
description: DENVER, Sept. 28The Unit ed States, increasingly more dependent on foreign raw ma terials and faced with energy shortages, will undertake its first comprehensive study of the nation's mineral resources since 1950. Commerce Secretary Mau rice H. Stans announced today.

title: Heart Patient Quits Smoking
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 28 (UPI)  Louis B. Russell Jr., who has lived longer with a transplanted heart than any other man, is giving up smok ing. Mr. Russell received a transplanted heart in August, 1968, and resumed smoking as soon as he had recovered. He took the pledge yesterday at luncheon of the Indiana Heart Association.

title: Theater Here and in London Separated by Money
description: The theater in London and New York is separated by more than water. It is sepa rated by money. It is sepa rated by thoughts of money, attitudes to money and dis tribution of money.

title: PRICES DOWN A BIT AS MARKET PAUSES
EDUCATION BILLS GAIN IN TRENTON
description: TRENTON, Sept. 28  Gov. William T. Cahill's controver sial $38million schoolaid pro gram received initial legislative approval tonight. The program consists of two bills, one of which calls for a $9.5million appropriation for private and narnchial schools.

title: 24 Penn Central Vice Presidents Lopped in Top Echelon Shuffle
description: The Penn Central Transporta tion Company yesterday an nounced a reorganization of its managerial structure, including the abolition, effective Thurs day, of the titles of execu tive vice president and senior vice president.

title: THE ARAB WORLD IS GRIEFSTRICKEN
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 28The Arab world went into mourning tonight over the loss of its major international figure. Arab distress was heightened by the fear that instability would increase in the area and diminish the already slender prospect of peace.

title: Israelis Get Assurances From Congress That They Can Buy Missiles and Tanks as Well as Planes
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28Israel received explicit assur ances from Congress today that the arms she might buy on favorable credit terms in the United States would include missiles and tanks as well as aircraft.

title: DIPLOMATS AT U.N. EXPRESS SORROW
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 28  Stunned diplomats from East and West, from Af rica and Asia as well as the Arab world, expressed sorrow today at the death of President Gamal Abdel Nasser and their apprehension over its conse quences.

title: A Witness Testifies That Manson Told of Doing All Those Killings
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept 28 John Leo Flynn, a movie bit player, testified today at the Tate ,Murder trial that Charles M. Manson told him a couple of days after the murders of the actress Sharon Tate and four Others in August, 1969: Don't you know I'm the one who's doing all these killings?

title: Exchange Answers Today In Robinson &
description: Attorneys for the New York Stock Exchange were expected to appear in United States Dis trict Court here this morning in response to a legal challenge from a customer of Robinson & Co., a brokerage house now in bankruptcy proceedings.

title: 1 GOVERNING BODY ASKED AT HUNTER
description: A reform plan for governing Hunter College that calls for an ombudsman to hear complaints and a 200member senate to re present the school's students, faculty members and administ rators was suggested yesterday by a special committee, set up after last spring's disruptions.

title: Priests Open Talks In the Netherlands; Politics in Forefront
description: AMSTERDAM, the Nether lands, Sept. 28World politics took the forefront of the agen da at the opening of a European priests assembly here today.

title: ATTACK ON CLERGY RENEWED BY VORSTER
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 28  Prime Minister John Vorster renewed today his attack on some South African clergymen and English language newspapers for at tempting to explain away the World Council of Churches decision to grant funds to some black African nationalist move ments.

title: Florida Banks Set Exchange
description: The Florida National Bank of Florida, Inc., a newly formed bankholding company, regis tered with the Securties and Ex change Commission yesterday 9,468,461 common shares that are to he exchanged for the out standing shares of 30 Florida banks.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Are Mixed at Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON. Spet. 28Treasury bill rates were mixed at today's auction compared to last week's levels, the Gov ernment reported late this aft ernoon.

title: McNamara's Aid Indictment
description: Robert S. McNamara's indictment of the industrial countriesand especially the United Statesfor spend ing twenty times more on military power than on foreign aid underscores a disturbing irony of the modern world. The former Defense Secretary, now President of the World Bank, believes stronglyas do wein the pre ventive medicine element in development assistance. By easing conflicts among the world's turbulent poor countries, aid from the rich nations could make possible a reduction in military dangers and defense burdens for all.

title: Mrs. Durand Is Killed In a Fall From Horse
description: CAHOKIA, Ill., Sept. 28 (AP)Mrs. Carol Durand, a former member of the United States equestrian team, was killed today at Cahokia Race Track when she was thrown by a horse.

title: CANADA WARNED ON FUND INFLOW
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28Andrew F. Brimmer, a member of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, warned Canadians today that he saw some disturbing devel opments in United States Canadian financial relations. He said the developments de serve attention before they be come a matter of urgency.

title: GOLF ACCORD NEAR ON UNIFORM BALL
description: A uniform golf ball for use throughout the world has been declared feasible by a com mittee representing the United States Golf Association and the Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St. Andrews, Scotland.

title: Chompion, Baitman Win Divisions of Brighton Beach Handicap at Belmont
TWO HELD IN BLAST FATAL TO POLICEMAN
description: OMAHA, Sept. 28Two lead ers of a Black Panther front or ganization were ordered to stand trial on murder charges after a teenage member changed his story today and implicated them in the fatal Aug. 17 booby trapping of an Omaha policeman.

title: RICHARD SEAMY, PLASTICS PIONEER
description: BOONTON, N. J., Sept. 28Richard W. Seabury, a pioneer in highdensity plastics and radio and a former Govern ment official, died on Satur day at the Riverside Hospital here after a short illness. He was 86 years old and lived at 219 Rockaway Street here.

title: Franchi's Pop Songs At Benefit Concert Captivate Audience
description: Sergio Franchi, who gave a concert Sunday night at Phil harmonic Hall for the benefit of Boys Town of Italy, must he unique among formally trained singers who turn from opera to popular music. As a rule, such singers become trapped in the vocal expectations of their background so that their treat ment of popular songs seems stiff and rigid.

title: Fourth Group of Hostages Here After Seeing President in Rome
description: Thirty three travel weary Americans, whose ordinary lives became the focus of inter national concern during three harrowing weeks while they were hostages in Jordan, ar rived at Kennedy International Airport last night and were met by loved ones, friends and a clamoring throng of newsmen.

title: Dance to Aid Boys'
description: The Fall Dance for the benefit of the Boys' Club of New York will be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Pierre on Oct. 22. Mrs. Robert B. Dickson is chairman for the invitational dinner dance. Serving as vice chairmen are Mrs. Merrill L. Magowan, Mrs. Michael P. McDonough and Mrs. David H. M. J. Steavenson.

title: U.S. Urges a U.N. Fund to Fight Drugs
description: GENEVA, Sept. 28The Unit ed States today formally pro posed the creation of a United Nations voluntary fund to fi nance an emergency program to fight the abuse of drugs and pledged an initial contribution of $2million.

title: COCACOLA ACCUSED BY F.T.C. ON CLAIMS
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 28 (UPI)The Federal Trade Com mission accused the CocaCola Company today of making false nutritional claims for its HiC fruitflavored drinks and said the HiC trademark itself should be banned as misleading.

title: Soviet Is Likely to Assure Cairo on Aid
description: MOSCOW Tuesday, Sept. 29Western diplomats expect Soviet leaders to assure the United Arab Republic promptly that President Gamal Abdel Nasser's death will not lead to a curtailment in Soviet support of the Arab cause.

title: Health Center to Gain
description: CRESSKILL, N. J., Sept. 28 A luncheon and a showing of fashions and furs by Os car de la Renta on Oct. 9 will benefit the West Bergen Mental Health Center. The event will be held at the Tammy Brook Country Club here.

title: AntiArab Jet Plot Laid to Seized Pair
description: An Israeli Army veteran and his wife, accused of trying to board a Londonbound plane here with a live hand grenade and four loaded guns hidden in their clothing, were reported yesterday to have planned to hijack an Arab airliner and take it to Israel.

title: Sadat Is Known as Leftist and an Enemy of Israel
description: The new interim President of the United Arab Republic is Anwar Sadat, the former Vice President, the Cairo radio an nounced today.

title: Bowdoin to Become Coed
description: BRUNSWICK, Me., Sept. 28 (AP)Bowdoin College, Maine's oldest institution of higher learning, said today that it planned to become a fullfledged coeducational school. Dr. Roger Howell Jr., the president, said that 60 undergraduate women would be enrolled for the 1971 1972 academic year.

title: Lists Slain Police
description: KINGSTON, N. Y., Sept. 28 (AP)James L. Buckley, Con servative party candidate for the Senate, said today that the United States could not survive in a state of siege, in a refer ence to attacks on policemen.

title: BROOKLYN ACADEMY TO GET FILM SERIES
description: The Museum of Modern Ari and the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the 112yearold per forming arts center at 30 La fayette Avenue, will present series of free weekly programs of the museum's film classics for members of both institu tions at the academy, starting Oct. 7 and running through May.

title: Colombian Pipeline Explodes
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 28 (AP)About five miles of the Texas Oil Co pipeline in south ern Colombia was damaged in an explosion today, the police said. They said they did not know the cause of the explosion.

title: Modern Touch in Ancient Setting
description: Although many honors await the creative ad man, wouldn't enshrinement of his work in the Holy Land just beat all? It may soon be possible.

title: Confused Birds Die at Empire State
description: Hundreds of migrating war blers, thrushes, vireos and tanagers, flying low under cloud cover and confused by bright lights, crashed into the Empire State Building early yesterday morning and fell onto the setbacks or down to the street.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Through the Motions

title: Great Songs of the 60's, A Times Book, Due Oct. 12
description: Great Songs of the Sixties, a collection of 82 of the most popular songs of the last decade, arranged for voice, piano and guitar, will be pub lished by Quadrangle Books on Oct. 12.

title: Architect of Cup Victory
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 28 Early in the summerlong trials to pick an America's Cup defender, a rare case of panic broke out aboard In trepid.

title: Miss Conway To Wed Oct. 10
description: ROCHESTER, Sept. 28 Miss Kathryn Mary Conway and Edward James Mulcahy Jr. plan to be married Oct. 10.

title: Fairlie, Ruffels and Carmichael Agree to Join Hunt Tennis Tour
description: Brian Fairlie, Ray Ruffels and Bob Carmichael, named among the world's top 32 ten nis players in an international poll, have agreed to join next year's 20City, $1million tour financed by World Champion ship Tennis.

title: New Research on Rubella Challenges Effectiveness of Vaccination Program
description: Recent studies have raised serious questions among some researchers about the sound ness and longrange effective ness of the nation's current rubella vaccination program.

title: 2 Prominent Queens Democrats Back Rockefeller in Campaign
description: Two prominent Queens Democrats announced yester day that they were supporting Governor Rockefeller for re election.

title: Keeler, Berkeley and Nanette on Comeback Trail...
description: They came back to the Broadway scene yesterday. Ruby Keeler after 41 years. Busby Berkeley after 35. And their sponsors, Harry Rigby and Cyma Rubin, are glad they came back and hope others will be too.

title: For Every Foot, for Every Taste, for Nearly All Occasions
description: The Chelsea Cobbler of London Ltd. Bespoke Shoe makers may seem a big title for the little shoe shop that's just opened its American doors Shop at 122 East 55th Talk Street. But it des cribes what the Chelsea Cobbler does. They make bespoke, or custommade, shoes. The fa shionaware Anglophile prob ably knows, however, that boots are the forte here, for Chelsea Cobbler boots have been warming some of the bestdressed legs in London ever since the midimaxi kick began. Now the Chelsea Cobbler has arrived in New York with a collec tion of offthepeg, or instock, boots  fortunately for American women, since bespoke ones require a six toeightweek wait. The ubi quitous, lacedup granny boot turns up here in canvas, in colors like purple or choc olate or offwhite for $60. Polished leather laced boots are $90.

title: Parcel Service Is Struck Throughout New England
description: Union employes of United Parcel Service struck through out New England yesterday after rejecting the latest com pany contract offer, The As sociated Press reported.

title: Negro Leader Guilty Of Carolina Rioting; Gets Year in Prison
description: ORANGEBURG, S. C., Sept. 28A jury of nine whites and three Negroes today found Cleveland L. Sellers Jr., a black activist, guilty of participating in a riot two nights before a fatal confrontation between state highway patrolmen and black students here in 1968.

title: SKIPPER DISPLAYS RUNNERUP POISE
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 28 (AP)Jim Hardy, skipper of Gretel II, stood alongside his defeated America Cup's chal lenger today, holding his wife with one hand and a cup of champagne in another.

title: Nasser Was Plagued By Ailments Since '67
description: President Nasser began in 1967 to suffer from a number of ailments. After a bout with influenza, he developed a severe leg inflammation and diabetes. He received treatment for both ailments in the Soviet Union on at least two occasions.

title: Coal Export Curb Asked
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) Representative Charles A. Vanik, Democrat of Ohio, urged the Nixon Administration today to limit the exportation of low sulphur coal to Japan. He said that increasing exports had created acute shortages in this country resulting in prices which have almost doubled and had forced domestic utili ties into the use of highpol luting, highsulphur fuels that will result in higher utility bills anddirtier air.

title: 3 Companies'
description: Stockholders of the American Enka Corporation and the In ternational Salt Company, at separate meetings yesterday, ap proved a threeway combina tion of the two companies with Organon, Inc. The new enter prise, known as Akzona, Inc., has assets of $360million and 13,000 employes.

title: Faulty Signal Ties Up Commuters on PATH
description: Several hundred commut ers on the Port Authority Trans Hudson lines were trapped under the Hudson River for almost two hours last night because of a faulty signal light.

title: City University to Expand Training for Unemployed
description: The Board of Higher Educa tion last night authorized the City University to sign a $6.5 million contract with the city's Manpower and Career Develop ment Agency to expand voca tional and educational programs for unpmnlnved adults.

title: Draft Cards Are Burned in Memorial at Kent State
description: KENT, Ohio, Sept. 28While candles sputtered in a cold, driving rain, several thousand Kent State University students gathered tonight on the gentle, grassy slope where four stu dents died last May 4 in a burst of National Guard rifle fire.

title: NORTHERN SCHOOL HELD SEGREGATED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) A Federal hearing examiner ruled today for the first time that a Northern school district was violating Federal civil rights laws and should lose most of its Federal aid.

title: Mrs. Grant Calls On the State to License Repairmen
description: Bess Myerson Grant, City Commissioner of Consumer Af fairs, yesterday urged the li censing of automobile, televis ion and radio repairmen to stop what she called the dishon esty, deceit and incompetence of some repairmen.

title: U..S. Officials See Period Of Instability in Mideast
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28United States officials, startled by the death of Gamal Abdel Nasser, tended to view it today as a blow to peacemaking efforts in the Middle East.

title: New York Aquarium Names New Curator
description: The appointment of John W. Clark as the curator of the New York Aquarium has been announced by Dr. James A. Oliver, director of the aquarium. Mr. Clark will as sume his new post next Monday.

title: East Germans Sentence U.S. Student to 7 Years
description: JERICHO, Vt., Sept. 28 (AP)  An American student held nearly 10 months in East Berlin has been sentenced to seven years in prison on charges of making propaganda statements against the East German gov rnment.

title: SUIT ON POLLUTION TO SEEK A.E.C. AID
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI)  Conservationists disclosed plans today for a court fight aimed at dragging the reluctant Atomic Energy Commission into the fight against thermal pol lution.

title: Eight States to Include Environmental Questions on the Ballot in November
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 28 Measures designed to improve the environment will be put be fore the voters on ballots of eight states in November.

title: REPORTS BY RAND SCORED IN COUNCIL
description: A City Councilman called upon the Corporation Counsel yesterday to take legal action against the Rand Corporation and the New York City Rand Institute for their alleged fail ure to deliver to the city a housing consultant study that will cnst more than S1million.

title: The New Eskimos'
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28During the heat wave last week our leaders told us, as usual during hot weather, to turn off our airconditioners.

title: Bishop, T elemart In Bankruptcy Step
description: Two more companies have joined a growing number of concerns seeking to overcome their insolvency through volun tary bankruptcy petitions un der the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: Board Allots $9Million For Containership Unit
description: The City Planning Commis sion yesterday approved a $9million allotment of capi tal budget funds to develop a new 25acre area for containerized shipping oper ations along the South Brooklyn waterfront.

title: OPEN VERDICT GIVEN IN HENDRIX'S DEATH
description: LONDON, Sept. 28 (AP)A London coroner returned an open verdict today on the death of Jimi Hendrix after a pathol ogist testified that the rock star had died of suffocation.

title: Mets Down Cubs on Garrett's 3Run Clout in 10th, 63, and Tie for Second
description: Having played themselves out of the possibility of finish ing first, the Mets and Chicago Cubs traded dramatic homerun punches at Shea Stadium last night and wound up tied for second with three games to Way.

title: City Planning Unit Votes To Extend Court Job Plan
description: The City Planning Commis sion voted yesterday to expand and extend for another year the court employment pro gram of providing jobs for se lected criminal defendants here.

title: Bank Guard Averts Holdup
description: MEDFORD, Mass., Sept. 28 (AP)A security guard averted a holdup today at the Tufts University campus branch of the Middlesex National Bank. The guard, who was not iden tified, exchanged shots with two persons, who fled:

title: Heller Terms Quick Upturn Unlikely
description: Walter W. Heller, chairman of the Council of Economic Ad visers under Presidents Ken nedy and Johnson, said yester day that there was little likeli hood of a quick snapback from this year's business slump.

title: News Summary and Index
description: President Gamal Abdel Nasser died after suffering a heart attack yesterday in Cairo only a day after his success in negotiat ing an end to the Jordanian hostilities. He was for 18 years the leader of Egypt and was the Arab world's strongest figure. [Page 1, Columns 58.]

title: Bank Debits in City Rose in August
description: Charges against checking accounts in New York City banks spurted in August by 10.3 per cent from the July level to $4.77trillion, the Federal Reserve reported yes terday.

title: Agnew to Go to Arkansas
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 28 (UPI)Gov. Winthrop Rocke feller announced today that Vice President Agnew would speak at a Republican cam paign rally Oct. 8 in Fort Smith.

title: Thais Arrest 35 and Seize Goods Stolen From PX's
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 28 Thai policemen seized several hundred thousand dollars in goods stolen from United States post exchanges Saturday aand today uncovered two additional truckloads of stolen PX mer chandise.

title: Carol A. Waugh Will Be a Bride
description: WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 28 Miss Carol Ann Waugh and Andrew Michael Gull plan to be married in January.

title: Riggs Wins ClayCourt Title
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 28 (AP)  Bobby Riggs of Plan dome, N. Y., beat Al Boyle of New York City, 16, 97, 62, yesterday to win the 50 singles title in the United States Lawn Tennis Association seniors clay court championships.

title: Advertising: Fisticuffs in Behalf of Peace
description: Should any of the heads of state who will be here for the United Nations 25th an niversary happen to be fans of American television they just might see a commercial of special interest. Its title is simply Third World War.

title: Independent Consumer Agency Is Approved by a Senate Pane
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 The Senate Government Oper ations Committee approved to day a bill to establish an in dependent Federal agency with broad authority to act as an ad vocate and protector of con sumer interests.

title: Financial Follies on Nov. 20
description: The New York Financial Writers' Association will pre sent Financial Follies of 1970 on Friday evening, Nov. 20, at the Americana Hotel in New York. In a departure from pre vious years, the dress rehearsal of the annual musical show parodying the year's activities in business and finance will be held on Monday, Nov. 16 Tickets for the Follies and the formal dinner preceding the performance are available at $50 a person from the associa tion at P. O. Box 4306, Grand Central Station, New York, N. Y. 10017.

title: Jewish Unit Here Gets Appeal From 7 in Soviet
description: Seven Soviet Jews, in a let ter received by the American Jewish Congress through the mail, have charged forcible detention in the Soviet Union in the quest to emigrate to Israel.

title: Rivers Cites Soviet Power In New Defense Fund Plea
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28Representative L. Mendel Rivers, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, to day fired the opening shot in the House battle over the de fense budget with a warning that the nation was in ter rible jeopardy because of ris ing Soviet military power.

title: A White Patrolman Killed in Cleveland; Partner Is Wounded
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 28 (AP) A white policeman was shot to death and his partner seri ously wounded early today in a predominantly black area of Cleveland that has been press ing the city for more police protection.

title: GUARD ON PLANES STILL IN DISPUTE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 Pentagon and Transportation Department officials con firmed today that they had reached no agreement yet to put a sky marshal force of military guards on commercial airliners.

title: Science Editor Honored
description: Daniel S. Greenberg, news editor of Science magazine, will receive Columbia University's 1970 Medal for Excellence, the university announced yester day. The medal is awarded an nually to a distinguished Colum bia alumnus under the age of 45. The 1970 award nomination cites Mr. Greenberg as a non scientist writing of science and ?? relation to society with lucidity, wit, knowledge and conviction.

title: City Moves Against 900 Buildings in Apartment Strike in Bronx
description: The city, administration said yesterday It had moved against more than 900 buildings of its list of 1,000 known to be in volved in the twoweekold Bronx apartment strike. The city listing is still being com piled.

title: A Vast Show of PreColumbian Art
description: The Metropolitan Muse um's new exhibition, Before Cortes: Sculpture of Middle America, which opens to the public tomorrow, must surely be the best exhibition of pre Columbian art of the sculp tor, lapidary and goldwork er ever assembled outside Mexico. It was made possi ble only by the goodwill and generosity of museums and private collectors in Europe, this country, Mexico, Guate mala, Costa Rica, Panama and the West Indies, with the National Museum in Mexico alone taking more than 60 fine pieces off exhibition for the occasion. Loans from the Musee de I'Homme in Paris, the British Museum in Lon don and museums in Ger many, Austria, Italy and Spain, include pieces that went to Europe at the time of the Conquest and are re turned to this continent for the first time.

title: Miss Moulton And Peter Pell Are Married
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 28Miss Alexandra Carter Moulton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Moulton, was mar ried here Saturday to Peter Jeffcott Pell, son of Mrs. Jeffcott Pell of Rome, and Clarence C. Pell of Old West bury, E. I. The Rev. Jack Schweizer performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Church of St. Michael and St. George.

title: Futures Traders Asked To Oppose Import Curbs
description: Traders in commodities were urged here yesterday to sup port opposition to the imposing of import quotas on a wide variety of products.

title: Financial Page Fan, RadioSet Tinkerer, Leaves $4Million
description: An unemployed 64yearold jackofalltrades who liked to repair radios and who read the financial pages as a child, has left stockholdings worth nearly $4million. But he did not leave a will.

title: New Books
description: A Literary History of France: The Eighteenth Century, 17151789, by Robert Niklaus (Barnes & Noble, $11.50):

title: Black Homeowners Fight Plan to Build School in Corona
description: A dozen Queens homeown ers from the Corona section, most of them black and many of them elderly, made quiet but emotional appeals at City Hall yesterday against a plan to demolish their homes to make room for a new inter mediate school.

title: Bridge:
description: The New YorkNew Jer sey Regional Championships played during the weekend at Grossinger's in the Cats kills proved to be a personal triumph for Paul Heitner of New York, the biggest man in the tournament.

title: CARL D. NESENSOHN, PHOTOGRAPHER, 72
description: TENANTS HARBOR, Me., Sept. 28 (AP)Carl D. Nesen sohn Sr., a retired news pho tographer, died at his home today. He was 72 years old.

title: Sol Linowitz Chosen Urban Coalition Chief
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (UPI)Sol M. Linowitz, for mer chairman of the Xerox Corporation, today was chosen chairman of the Na >tional Urban Coalition, suc ceeding John W. Gardner. tional Urban Coalition, suc ceeding John W. Gardner.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: AMEX PRICES RISE IN LOWER VOLUME
FUTURES IN CORN MAKE SHARP GAIN
description: Corn futures advanced sharp ly yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, but soybeans were off almost as much.

title: Girls in Slacks Hold SitIn
description: SUTTON, Mass., Sept. 28 (AP) About 35 girls who were not allowed into Sutton High School this morning because they wore slacks and pants suits con ducted a sitin in the school driveway.

title: STEEL PRODUCTION DOWN 2.8% IN WEEK
description: Steel production dropped by 2.8 per cent last week, com pared to output the week be fore, but industry sources said it was unlikely the change could be attributed to the strike against the General Mo tors Corporation, which began only two weeks ago.

title: Miss Towers to Play in Ari
description: Constance Towers has been signed to costar with David Cryer in the new musical, Ari, based on Leon Uris's Exodus. The show, which has book and lyrics by Mr. Uris and music by Walt Smith, will open at the Mark Hellinger The ater on Jan. 24 after preNew York engagements in Philadel phia and Washineton.

title: ALBATROSS SCORES IN YONKERS DEBUT
description: YONKERS, Sept. 28Local harness racing fans got their first look at the Canadian owned Albatross, generally re garded as the best of this sea son's 2yearold pacers, in the Star Pointer at Yonkers Race way tonight. The colt, a fleet son of Meadow Skipper and Voodoo Hanover, owned by Bert James of Windsor, On tario, and driven by Harry Harvey of Washington, Pa., proved an easy winner by eight lengths in 2:00 1/5.

title: Graham to Head Parade
description: PASADENA, Calif., Sept. 28 (AP)The Rev. Billy Graham. the evangelist, was named grand marshal today of the 1971 Tournament of Roses parade. A. Lewis Shingler. president of the event said the 5Iyearold Baptist minister would he the first clergyman in head the annual New Year's Day parade.

title: Oh! Calcutta! in 60 Cities
description: When the closedcircuit tape version of Oh! Calcut ta! was first announced, the producers hope was that it would saturate Americaand also play in Canada. Through a variety of local and na tional pressures, by last night's premiere the number of theatrical locations had eroded from 200 to around 75.

title: DOW WILL INCREASE HERBICIDES PRICES
description: The Dow Chemical Company announced yesterday that it would raise prices on two lines of herbicides, effective Oct. 1.

title: Meyer Liberman Dead at 88; ExChief of Arnold Constable
description: Meyer Liberman, retired board chairman of Arnold Con stable, Inc., the retail chain based on Fifth Avenue, died yesterday at the Harkness Pavilion of the ColumbiaPres byterian Medical Center after a long illness. He was 88 years old and lived at the Hotel Lom bardy. 111 East 56th Street.

title: Bronx Jury Convicts Detective Of Taking Bribe in Theft Case
description: A suspended New York detective was found guilty yes terday by a jury in State Supreme Court in the Bronx of accepting a $500 bribe in return for making sure a car thief he arrested was not brought to trial.

title: EDWARD J. SIMS
description: NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 28 Edward J. Sims, a musician, died today at Norwalk Hospital after a brief illness. His age was 94. He lived at 42 High Street.

title: Republican Candidate Kills Himself in Missouri
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 28John W. Peters, Republican candi date for the Second District Congressional seat held by Rep resentative James W. Syming ton, was found shot to death late yesterday at his campaign headquarters in suburban Brent wood.

title: Texaco and B.P. in Accord With Libya on Oil Prices
description: Texaco, Inc., and the British Petroleum Company, Ltd both announced yesterday that they had reached agreements with the Government of Libya on posted prices for oil.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: This is the time of year when those who have never hunted before, but plan to begin this fall, must register in the hunter safety courses required by more than 40 states before a license will be issued.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Prof. Gordon C. Zahn [letter Sept. 14] has presented an accurate analysis of the role of bombing and terrorism in the current phase of American his tory, with one significant exception. When he states that he finds some of our most dedicated oppo nents of the war joining people like General LeMay... who believe that the only way to get the peace we want is by more and more violence and bigger and better bombs, his analysis is unsound.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. The President was in Rome on the first leg of his European tour.

title: SPENDING TARGET SET BY OTTINGER
description: ALBANY, Sept. 28Repre sentative Richard L. Ottinger said today that he planned to spend "somewhere around $750,000 on a television and radio campaign beginning to night in his bid for election to the Senate. He explained that he was getting the money from his mother, sister, uncle and other relatives.

title: 3d Suspect in Police Slaying Is Seized
description: WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 28 (AP)The third of five per sons sought in the holdup slay ing of a Boston policeman was arrested today, the police said, leaving two coeds also charged in the case still at large.

title: Sabotaging The System
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28  Senator Sam J. Ervin of North Carolina, that remarkable bag of constitutionalism and contradiction, knows full well that the Electoral College is a deficient mechanism. We realize, he and five colleagues recently wrote in a minority report on direct popular election, that the present system has its defects. We believe, however, that remedies are available short of its wholesale de struction.

title: City Cabbies Are Enjoined From Work Stoppage Over Slaying
description: New York's cab drivers were enjoined last night by an im partial taxi industry arbitrator from carrying out a 24hour work stoppage in memory of a murdered cabdriver, one of seven slain this year.

title: Fix Is In for Mayor at Bet Demonstration
description: At 1:15 P.M. yesterday, Mayor Lindsay was informed that a $2 bet placed for him on horse No. 7 in the first race at Belmont race track had returned $32.

title: ARABWORLD HERO
description: CAIRO, Tuesday, Sept. 29President Gamal Abdel Nasser, leader of Egypt for 18 years and hero of much of the Arab world, died here yesterday.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: BANK IN BASEL WINS DEBT MORATORIUM
description: GENEVA, Sept. 28  A Swiss court today granted the trou bled United California Bank in Basel a sixmonth moratorium to wind up its affairs in an or derly liquidation after suffering a $40million loss in Switzer land's biggest bank scandal.

title: Last Call for Electoral Reform
description: Proponents of a constitutional amendment embodying fundamental reform of Presidential elections will try again today to cut off dilatory debate in the Senate and bring the amendment itself to a vote. Success at the present session is essential if reform is to be effected before the 1972 balloting. The amendment has already won overwhelming approval in the House.

title: Mary Quant's New Lengths
description: The Mother of Mini is ex pecting her first child. So she won't be at Bonwit Teller to day for the opening of the new Mary Quant Boutique on the store's fourth floor. A miscarriage last year and the uncertainty of air travel this year caused Miss Quant's doctor to suggest she say in England.

title: Who Speaks for Ethnic America?; He Came in Search Of Freedom and a Job But What Did He Find?
description: The Ethnic American is forgotten and forlorn. He is infuriated at being used and abused by the media, gov ernment and business. Pejorative epi thets such as pigs and racists or slick, patronizing labels like the silent majority or hard hats are graphic examples of the lack of respect; under standing and appreciation of him and his way of life.

title: The Arab Void
description: Gamal Abdel Nasser, son of a postal clerk who became idol of Egypt and sought to become leader all the Arab world, was a tragic and spectacular failure. Nevertheless, his sudden death yesterday leaves a void that can only add to the chaos already threatening overwhelm the Middle East.

title: Clinical Chemist Shortage Expected to Grow Worse
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 28The serious shortage of clinical chemists in the United States will be aggravated next sum mer when a new Medicare regulation becomes effective, according to a report published today.

title: Anthony Desiderio, President Of Whippany Paper Board, Dies
description: ROXBURY, Mass., Sept. 28Anthony Desiderio, president of the Whippany Paper Board Co., Inc., of Whippany, N. J., a major producer of paper board for the boxmaking and packaging industry, died Sat urday at the New England Bap tist Hospital after a short ill ness. He was 69 years old and lived in West Orange, N. J.

title: BROOKLYN'S ARABS GATHER IN GRIEF
description: For the Palestinians, Syrians and Yemenites of Brooklyn's Arab community in the Atlantic Avenue district, the talk last night was of our President Nasser and the feelings were of shock and grief.

title: PRICES ARE LIFTED BY OWENSILLINOIS
description: OwensIllinois, Inc., an nounced yesterday a price in crease of 4 per cent on all highdensity polyethylene plas tic bottles, effective Nov. 1.

title: Namath Quits as Chairman Of Broadway Joe's Chain
description: Joe Namath, the New York Jets quarterback, has resigned as chairman of the board of Broadway Joe's, Inc., an eleven unit restaurant chain based in Miami, the company announced yesterday. He and Michael H. Bite Jr., a director and secretary who also resigned, have trans ferred all their shares to Wil liam K. Cash, a director.

title: 4 N.H.L. Clubs to Use New Colored Skates
description: MONTREAL, Sept. 29 (Ca nadian Press)The National Hockey League announced today that an agreement had been signed with the Bauer division of Greb Shoe, Ltd., of Kitchener, Ontario, making the skate manufacturer's product the official colored skate for the league teams.

title: AVCO LISTS DROP IN QUARTER NET
description: Earnings of the Avco Cor poration in the three and nine months ended Aug. 31 plunged 66 and 62 per cent, respec tively, under the impact of high interest costs and the general softening of the econ omy that adversely affected most of its operations, particu larly government business.

title: Painting Showed Promise of Genius
description: The Artist's Father, the large portrait Paul Cezanne painted in 1866 at the age of 27, is one of the most power ful pictures this great painter produced in the difficult, early years of his career. It is a painting that looks to the past, however, far more than it looks to the future. It reflects Cezanne's extraordinary mastery of a cer tain established styleparticular ly the blunt real ism of Courbetwhile dis closing litle evidence of that luminous chromatic architec ture that we now identify as Cezanne's unique contribu tion to modern painting and that has such a widespread influence on the art of the 20th century. It is a master piece, but a masterpiece by an artist who is still groping his way to an esthetic terrain he can truly call his own.

title: Suit Striking Down 3 of RCA's Patents Reported by SCM
description: The SCM Corporation said yesterday that it had won a patent decision against the RCA Corporation.

title: Catholics Publish a Bible Reflecting Modern Trends
description: A Roman Catholic publish er issued yesterday a full translation of the Bible into English from the original languages. The translation, the first such ever produced under Catholic auspices, is known as the New American Bible.

title: Cabbies Here Mourn Slain Comrade
description: About 1,500 saddened and angry taxi drivers stopped work yesterday morning to attend a funeral mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral for a col league recently shot to death.

title: Chrysler Raises '71 Car Prices And Reduces Markup Figures
description: DETROIT, Sept. 29  The Chrysler Corporation raised prices close to $200 a car to day, following the example of other car manufacturers.

title: MayorProclaims Pulaski Day
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday proclaimed this Sunday Pulaski Day. The day honors Gen. Casimir Pulaski, who came here from Poland to fight in the Revolutionary War and was mortally wounded on Oct. 11, 1779, leading a cavalry unit at the Battle of. Savannah.

title: U.S. Eases Quotas On Importing of Oil As Shortage Looms
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29Confronted by what it ac knowledged to be a poten tially serious fuel shortage as winter approaches, the Nixon Administration an nounced today several ac tions to ease the situation.

title: Human Habits and Environmental Woes
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 29Hundreds of families are con fronted with the costly and anguishing task of replacing homes that were demolished by the great Los Angeles brush fires of the last few days.

title: Canada Approves Rise In Gas Exports to U.S.
description: TORONTO, Sept. 29The Ca nadian Government announced today that it had authorized a substantial increase in exports of natural gas to the United States but a smaller one than American distributors had sought.

title: Sherry Nager of N.Y.U. Fiancee
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., Sept. 29Mr. and Mrs. Melvin M. Nager of Great Neck have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sherry Nager, to Gary Richard Dia mond of Ardmore, Pa., son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Dia mond.

title: OPPOSITION FAILS IN SWEDISH VOTE
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 29  A long absentee ballot count in the general election of Sept. 20, during which doubts were cast at one point over the future of social Democratic rule, showed Sweden's centerright opposition parties today six seats short of a majority in Parliament.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Announcements of deaths, marriages, births and engagements may be tele phoned to OXford 53311 until 11 P.M. in suburban offices. 9:00 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Monday through Friday Newark (201) MArket 33900; White Plains (914) WHite Plains 95300; Hempstead (516) IVanhoc 36660; Commack (516) 5435400; Stamford (203) 3487767.

title: AMPHETAMINE USE IN SCHOOL DEFENDED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI) Government medical experts assured House investigators to day that they were aware of no evidence that ampheta mines were addicting in chil dren under age 12 who were treated with the stimulant drug to overcome learning dis abilities.

title: New Barney's Wing to Open Today
description: Barney's which has been calling all men to select, rather than settle for, its men's wear since 1924, will open its $3.5million Inter national House today next to the site at Seventh Avenue and 17th Street where Bar ney Pressman started the whole thing.

title: WOMAN SELECTED FOR PANTHER JURY
description: The first woman member of the jury to try 13 Black Pan thers accused of plotting to bomb public places was sworn in yesterday.

title: M'INTIRE CRITICIZES NIXON ON KY'S PLANS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29The Rev. Dr. Carl McIntire, chair man of the march for victory scheduled here on Saturday, accused the Nixon Administra tion today of violating freedom of speech by dissuading Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam from appearing at the rally.

title: 66 Members of House Say Campus Unrest Panel Blatantly Ignores Efforts Already Made by Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29A predominantly Republican group of 66 members of the House rallied today to defend Presi dent Nixon against what they regard as unfair blame placed on him by his Commission on Campus Unrest.

title: AGNEW CONDEMNS REPORT ON UNREST
description: SIOUX FALLS, S. D., Sept. 29 Vice President Agnew charged here today that the Presidential Commission On Campus Unrest had indulged in  scapegoating of the most irresponsible sort in saying that only the Presi dent could offer the moral leadership needed to reunite the country.

title: NARCOTICS RAIDS NET 80 IN JERSEY
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., Sept. 29 More than 400 law enforce ment agents fanned out through three New Jersey counties be fore dawn today and arrested SO persons on narcotics charges during raids the state police described as the largest they had ever participated in.

title: MARKET REBOUNDS FROM WEAK START
description: The stock market retreated yesterday morning in its initial reaction to the death of Pres ident Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt. But later the market rallied in rather impressive fashion to finish the day with modest gains.

title: Bridge:
OutofOrder Signs On Increase Again In Outdoor Phones
description: It has been getting difficult again to find an outdoor pay telephone in the metropolitan area that works, according to the state Public Service Com mission.

title: National Gallery Gets Early Cezanne
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29In one of the most difficult and expensive collecting coups in recent art history, the National Gallery of Art has acquired an early master piece by Paul Czanne.

title: Market Place:
description: Close your eyes and listen to Jules Freeman and you might think you were talk ing to, a truck driver from the Bronx. You'd be right on the accent but way off on the line of work.

title: Saigon Deputy Still Seeks New Regime
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 29A 34yearold mem ber of South Vietnam's Nation al Assembly defied President Nguyen Van Thieu today and renewed a call for the forma tion of a provisional Govern ment as a step toward peace.

title: Opposition Picks Candidate For Presidency in Seoul
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 29The opposition New Dem ocratic party nominated Kim Dae Jung, a 44yearold na tional legislator, today as its candidate to oppose President Chung Hee Park next spring in South Korea's presidential elec tion.

title: The Politics of Death
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29The death of President Nasser has revived the popular notion that history is merely the shadow of prominent leaders, but with a few spectacular exceptions, his tory has an irritating way of going on as before even when the stars depart.

title: Dance: Joffrey Troupe Opens Season
description: What promises to be New York's busiest dance season got off to a runaway start last night at the New York City Center, where the City Center Joffrey Ballet opened its sixweek fall season. Time was when the Joffrey dancers would drop in to New York for a mere two or three weeks, but now they have developed into a major com pany, and one of the most engaging in the world.

title: Cards Get Southpaw
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 29 (UPI)The St. Louis Cardinals acquired Fred Norman, a 28yearold lefthanded pitcher, on waivers from the Los Angeles Dodgers today.

title: City Plans to Double Methadone Project
description: The city's methadone pro gram for the treatment of nar cotics addicts is expected to double its capacity within the next 10 months, Mayor Lind say announced at City Hall yesterday. That would put the capacity at 5,000 persons.

title: U.S. Transfers Big Base In Vietnam Pullout Move
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 29 (AP)The United States announced three new moves today to disengage its troops and equipment from the war, including completion of the transfer of a big combat base to the South Vietnamese Army.

title: BLACK G.I. ACTIVISTS BOYCOTT A MEETING
description: HEIDELBERG, West Ger many, Sept. 29  Leaders of activist organizations of black American soldiers in West Ger many boycotted a special meet ing on racial conflict here today. They lounged beneath a chestnut tree at the Patton Barracks while a block away soldiers and Pentagon officials held a twohour session, in which some 60 persons, about 10 of them black, discussed racial issues. The Pentagon team was led by the recently appointed Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense, Frank Render 2d.

title: Mrs. Larkin, With 79, Wins Torgerson Memorial Golf
description: GLEN COVE, L. I., Sept. 29Mrs. Vincent Larkin of the Nas sau Country Club posted a 36, 4379 today to win the Women's Long Island Golf Association eighth annual Rein ert M. Torgerson Memorial championship for seniors over her home course. Par for the 5,530yard course is 36, 3672.

title: ISRAEL ASSESSES POLICY ON EGYPT
description: JERUSALEM, Sept. 29Thousands of Arabs in Israeli occupied territories displayed their emotions over the death of President Gamal Abdel Nas ser today in impromptu street marches, their grief turning briefly into hostility at Israeli policemen and security patrols.

title: Sports of The Times
description: There never has been anything manda tory about requiring the contesting teams in postseason play to have at least one 20game winner on their pitching staffs. It's been more or less taken for granted, like having the heaviest hit et bat in the fourth, or cleanup, position. There usually are raised eyebrows when the pattern isn't followed.

title: In Memoriam
description: FEIGINDaniel. In loving and cherished memory of rur son, Danny, who passed away two years ago. You are always in our hearts.

title: Money Imperils Romance
description: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 29Many a woman, content with her marriage, has been beard to say, One thing we never quar rel about is money. That can no longer be said about the liaison between Europe and the United States. And, as in so many unhappy marriages, it seems that every other worry or grievance feeds into the argument over money. At the moment, the European financial community, in cluding not only finance min isters and central bankers, but also private bankers and busi nessmen, have a long list of anxieties about the United States. It starts with stagfla tionthat perplexing mixture of economic stagnation and in flation.

title: Egyptians in the Streets and Chiefs of State Mourn Death of Nasser
description: CAIRO, Sept. 29As sounds of mourning for President Gamal Abdel Nasser filled the streets of Cairo, the interim President, Anwar Sadat, consulted today with Government and other po litical leaders on plans for the state funeral Thursday morning.

title: THIRD MET NORMA OF SEASON IS GIVEN
description: It's Norma time again at the Metropolitan Opera and the voice fans are grazing in gar dens of delight. Joan Suther land, Marilyn Horne and com pany staged another of their vocal feasts on Monday night and if that's all Norma were about, who would complain? In its oldfashioned way, the third performance of the season of fered bel canto of a sort that becomes legendary, so one did, his best to overlook some as tonishingly awkward staging and drama that rarely rose to lukewarm temperatures.

title: JUSTICE AIDES PLAN VISITS TO CAMPUS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI)  Attorney General John N. Mitchell, announced today that Justice. Department of ficials, including himself, would visit college campuses from Maine to California for face toface discussions with stu dents:

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Vote on Closure
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP)Following is the roll call vote by which the Sen ate refused today to invoke closure, or limit debate, on the constitutional amend ment for direct, popular election of the President, the vote falling 5 short of the required twothirds ma jority:

title: AUSTRALIAN LEADER WINS CENSURE VOTE
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 29 Prime Minister John G. Gor ton today survived a censure motion based on charges that he had ordered an official photograph doctored so that it made Gough Whitlam, the Opposition leader, appear to he making a speech under a Viet cong flag.

title: Dougherty Heads Group
description: ALBANY, Sept. 29 (AP)John L. Dougherty, managing editor of The Rochester Times Union, was elected president of the New York State Associated Press Association last night.

title: Governor Promises Goodell Aid; G.O.P. Audience Boos His Name
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., Sept. 29Governor Rockefeller promised financial help to the campaign of Senator Charles E. Goodell today, but was booed later in the day by a Republi can audience when he strongly urged the election of his run ning mate.

title: Saving an Awkward Day
description: NAPLES, Italy, Sept. 29Deflected by the death of Gamal Abdel Nasser, the high com mand of the United States Government wondered today, like everyone else, what hap pens next along the shores of the Mediterranean.

title: Writers Football Poll
description: The team standing, with points figured on a 20181614 1210987654321 basis for first through 20th places (first place votes in parentheses) and wonlosttied records:

title: RISE IN GROWTH RATE FORECAST FOR G.N.P.
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (Reuters)The Commerce De partment forecast today that the rate of real growth in the gross national product in the third quarter would be higher than the 0.6 per cent rate of the second auarter.

title: U.S. Releases Details of Its Housing Discrimination Charges Against Lefrak
description: The Justice Department, as part of an antidiscrimination suit it is prosecuting, yesterday cited six buildings in Brooklyn at which, it said, Samuel J. Lefrak and his agents had rent ed no more than 2.4 per cent of the space to Negroes. The buildings are in the Sheepshead Bay. Flatbush and Bensonhurst sections.

title: ARAB GOVERNMENTS PROCLAIM MOURNING
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 29Economic and political life in the Arab Middle East came to a virtual standstill today. All Arab governments went into official mourning and their chiefs prepared to fly to Cairo for the funeral Thursday of President Gamal Abdel Nasser.

title: Relief for Biafra
description: During Nigeria's civil war, Americans responded gen erously to the appeals for aid to the hungry and sick in secessionist Biafra. Many contributed indiscriminately and discovered belatedly, if at all, that their money was being used for dubious Biafran political purposes rather than for relief.

title: Executive Changes
description: Laurie W. Folmarproducing; Annon M. Cardsales; James W. Kinnearstrategic planning, and John W. GreenTexaco Canada, Ltd., and Caltex Petroleum Corporation, have been named senior vice presidents, newly created positions, and Alfred C. DeCrane has been appointed vice president of the producing departmentEastern hemisphere at Texaco, Inc.

title: Once It Was a Barn, Now It's a Chateau
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  Mr. and Mrs. Thomas George came here two years ago in search of a castle but with little hope of finding the chateau of their dreams.

title: PACIFIC TELEPHONE CITES PROFIT DROP
description: The Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company reported yesterday a decline in net in come for the three months end ed Aug. 31 despite increased revenues.

title: Egypt's Interim Leader
description: The man who announced to the world in July, 1952, that a group of army offi cers had seized power in Egypt and were demanding the abdication of King Fa rouk was a young army lieu tenant colonel named Anwar Sadat.

title: ADAMS CRITICIZES BIG GOVERNMENT
description: Dr. Paul L. Adams, the Con servative party candidate for Governor, asserted today be fore an audience of students that the voters In this country believed that they had little control over their own politi cal destiny because of the in creasing centralization of gov ernment.

title: Yugoslavia, Free Yet Bound, Thrives on Her Own Contradictions.
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 29The publicaddress system in the gleaming air terminal plays songs from Hair. The smell of popcorn perfumes the sidewalks of the Capital's shop ping district, a hodgepodge of modern highrise buildings and shabby storefronts. Downtown newsstands selling everything from Pravda to Playboy are festooned with nudes to catch the attention of hurrying crowds.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Memorial Seruices
description: WRIGHTMary Clabaugh. Yale University will hold a Memorial Service for the late Mary Clabaugh Wright, Professor of Chi nese History, on Friday, October 2, at 4 P.M. in Bartell Chapel, corner of Elm and College Sts., New Haven. Those wishing to celebrate her career as scholar, teacher and citizen are invited to attend. The Reverend William Sloane Coffin, Jr., Uni versity Chaplain, will conduct the service. Professors John K. Fairbank (Harvard), George W. Pierson and Jonathan Spence will speak. Charles R. Krigbaum, Univer sity Organist and Choirmaster, will be in charge of music for the occasion. Special Memorial Fund, Yale University Library. Contributions in care of Librarian.

title: OPEN MASS GRAVE FOUND IN AMMAN
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 29American and West German correspondents who entered the Palestinian quarter of Amman today for the first time since the civil war began on Sept. 17 found an open mass grave containing more than 40 bodies.

title: Protesting Groups Scuffle at City Hall
description: Encouraged by three state legislators, two groups of dem onstrators charged the steps of City Hall yesterday.

title: A Decorator Expands His Horizons
description: Valerian S. Rybar, Inc., the society decorating concern, was acquired yesterday by Richton International Cor poration in a move that may help establish the star system in designing massproduced furnishings as it has in fashions.

title: Memphis Road Plan Upheld
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 29 (AP) The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit upheld today a plan to con struct Interstate Highway 40 through Overton Park in Memphis.

title: Goldberg Chides Governor on Remark
description: ALBANY, Sept. 29Extrem ism is a fighting word, Arthur J. Goldberg said today, pro nouncing Governor Rockefeller guilty of the shabbiest kind of pandering to the voters worst instincts.

title: New Soviet TV Satellite
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 29 (Reuters) The Soviet Union today launched a new communica tions satellite in its Molnya I series, the official press agency Tass announced.

title: HOUSE APPROVES $10BILLION PLAN FOR MASS TRANSIT
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 The House approved today the first major Federal program in support of urban mass transit, a Nixon Administration pro posal to commit $10billion for new and improved bus and sub way systems over the next dozen years.

title: MRS. NIXON VISITS ITALIAN BOYS'
description: ROME, Sept. 29 (UPI)Mrs. Richard M. Nixon, surrounded by heavy police protection, motored 12 miles from Rome today to visit an Italian boys town patterned after the orig inal at Omaha.

title: Moscow Affirms It Seeks Mideast Political Accord
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 29The So viet Union today mourned the death of Gamal Abdel Nasser with a statement affirming its desire for a political settlement in the Middle East and calling on all Arabs to strengthen their unity in memory of the Egyptian President.

title: Perennial Rent Conflict
description: The old, citywide conflicts over rent control and decaying housing are being acted out once again in the strike by Bronx apartment house work ers, which entered its third week yesterday.

title: ACCORD REACHED IN OPERA DISPUTE
description: The New York City Opera Orchestra, which had been playing without a contract since the opening of the fall season on Sept. 9, came to terms with the company in a 12hour ses sion that ended early yesterday morning. The musicians had voted a strike after Sunday night's Manon, but no per formances were affected. Mon day was an offnight for the opera troupe.

title: VIOLENCE CLOSES SEVERAL SCHOOLS
description: Racial incidents at schools in Syracuse; Brentwood, L.I., and several New Jersey commu nities resulted in the closing of several schools and a number of injuries and arrests yester day.

title: BOSTON TRIUMPHS WITH 3RUN NINTH
description: BOSTON, Sept. 29Loyal be yond the call of duty, 14,254 fans showed up tonight with the thermometer at 62 degrees to watch the New York Yankees and the Red Sox go nowhere on the nexttolast day of the season.

title: GUILD UNIT AT POST SETS STRIKE DATE
description: The Newspaper Guild unit at The New York Post voted yes terday to strike the paper at 6 A.M. next Tuesday if it did not have a satisfactory contract by that time.

title: We understand.
description: The sorrow a family feels. The need to lessen the burden One's financial limits.

title: Major Expansion in Film And Chemicals Set by Olin
description: The Olin Corporation an nounced yesterday expansion programs costing $65million that will make the company a major producer of polyester film and will quadruple its produc tion of chemicals for urethane foams and coatines.

title: Rangers Down Wings, 43; APDS Tallies Two Goals
description: KITCHENER, Ontario, Sept. 29 (UPI)  Two goals by Syl Apps led the New York Rangers to a 43 victory over the Detroit Red Wings tonight in a National Hockey exhibition game.

title: Awtrey Gains TwoStroke Lead On Par 72 in Metropolitan Open
A Correction
description: Most editions of The New York Times yesterday carried a headline in which the name of Controller Arthur Levitt was substituted for that of Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz. The article dealt with a criti cism of Mr. Lefkowitz by his Democratic opponent, Adam Walinsky. The headline should have read: Walinsky Contends Lefkciwitz Fails In Actions on Factory Mishaps.

title: Yugoslavs Hail Nixon
description: BELGRADE, Sept. 29 (AP)The Socialist Alliance of the Working People of Yugoslavia, a Communistled mass organization, published a proclamation today about Presi dent Nixon's visit tomorrow. It read in part.

title: JAMES FISHER, 58, WILDLIFE WRITER
description: LONDON, Sept. 29James Fisher, one of Britain's best known authors and broadcast ers on nature and wild life, died today of injuries received in an automobile accident on Friday. He had just passed his 58th birthday.

title: GIANTS GUT DOWN ON PLAY CALLERS
description: It will be much easier to fol low the offensive dynamics of the New York Giants starting next Sunday. From here on, only Fran Tarkenton and Alex Webster will be responsible for calling plays.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: CREDIT MARKET DIPS NERVOUSLY
description: The bond market dipped nervously yesterday under the impact of this week's big supply of new financing and also perhaps from uncertainty over the death of President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic.

title: FOLK MUSIC STAGE GREETS A NEW ACT
description: Kate McGarrigle and Roma Baran, who appeared on Mon day night at the Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street, have the poten tial to be one of the wildest acts on the folk music circuit.

title: SUBSIDY PROPOSED FOR UNLEADED GAS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29Representative John W. Byrnes of Wisconsin, the ranking Re publican on the House Ways and Means Committee, pro posed today a different ap proach to the idea of using taxes as an incentive for the sale and use of unleaded gaso line.

title: Scenes Painted in Mink on Fur Coats
description: There is nothing so heart warming on a nippy fall day as a sable coat right down to the floor. Which is why close to 600 women were purring so contentedly at Bergdorf Goodman's showing of furs by Emeric Partos.

title: DELAY ON SCHOOLS LAID TO RED TAPE
description: The Board of Education, de spite its plans to ask for a $615 million school construction budget for 197172, came under attack from parents, teachers, and civic groups yesterday for laxity in its methods, contribut ing to overcrowding and being a party to endless red tape.

title: 1,000 in Family See Joan Kennedy's Piano Debut at Ball
description: Mrs. Edward M. Kennedy made her concert debut near midnight Monday in the Americana Hotel's Imperial Ballroom. She settled herself on the edge of a chair, raised her tanned hands over the piano keyboard and slowly with a certain dignity despite masses of photog raphers  delivered herself of a Mozart concerto. It was the high point of the Restore Ball, the season's first big gala.

title: Cambodians Describe Life Under the Foe
description: TANGKOK, Cambodia, Sept. 29The rubble is still smoking four days after the bombing, strafing and shelling of Tang kok ended in an enemy with drawal.

title: Threat Case Continued
description: BOSTON, Sept. 29 (AP)Judge Guy J. Rizzotto of the East Boston District Court has continued for six months, with out a finding, a charge of dis orderly conduct against Robert N. Bender, a Canadian who the police say made a remark about hijacking an airplane to Jordan. The case against Mr. Bender, 23 years old, of Ottawa, was con tinued today to March 30, 1971.

title: GEORGE M. JONES, 83; LED A COAL CONCERN
description: George Milton Jones, former president of the Logan County Coal Corporation, died Monday at his home in Phoenixville, Pa. He was 83 ears old and lived on Maysfield Farm in Phoenix ville.

title: Gilbert Seldes, Author, is Dead; Popular Arts Authority Was 77
description: Gilbert Seldes, author and critic and one of the earliest and most influential writers on the popular arts in America, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home at 125 East 57th Street, where he had lived for more than 25 years. He was 77 and had been ill for several years.

title: Stein's Right to Sell Forgeries Bearing His Name Is Affirmed
description: The state lost its suit yes terday to bar the sale here of paintings by master forger David Stein as long as he signs his imitative work with his own name.

title: Letdowns in N.F.L. Exceed Surprises After 2 Weekends
description: The disappointments have exceeded the surpr??ses in the National Football League af ter two of the 14 weekends of play. Notwithstanding the wonlost records, which have yet to come into focus be cause of inequities in the schedule, the clubs operating below expectations are the Cowboys, Red skins, Colts and Raiders. The sur prises, all mild, are the Cardinals, Lions, 49ers and maybe the Dolphins. Here is a quick look at the six divi sion races:

title: MORE LANDLORDS FACE CITY ACTION
description: The city's rent chief said yes terday the city expected to take over services in 300 to 400 more struck Bronx apartment build ings. Mayor Lindsay added the city was ready to do so in every building certified as a health hazard.

title: U. S., Taking Over Metroliners, To Try Hostess and Free Meals
description: The Penn Central's streaking Metroliners, the nation's fastest trains, may get some new touches of glamour in the air line stylehostesses and com plimentary meals.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: THE PRESIDENT

title: Captain to Marry Miss Schweppe
description: Mr. and Mrs. Denison W. Schweppe have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanore Darst Schweppe, to Capt. John Richard Day Baxendale of the Army Judge Advocate General Corps at Fort Mon mouth, N. J.

title: Hung Jury Causes Lombardozzi Case Mistrial
description: After deliberating for three days a jury declared itself un able to reach a verdict yes terday in an income tax case against Carmine Lombardozzi, reputed to be a member of the New York Mafia family of Carlo Gambino.

title: Listing of Books That Have Been Recently Published
description: GENERAL

title: Nancy Lakeman Of Northwestern Will Be a Bride
description: CINCINNATI, Sept. 29Miss Nancy Kay Lakeman and Jeffrey Von Kohorn, stu dents at Northwestern Uni versity, plan to be wed in June.

title: Hodgson Backs Economic Gradualism
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 29Secretary of Labor James D. Hodgson told steel union dele gates today that the Nixon Ad ministration had succeeded in curbing tailchasing inflation and assured them that the up ward trend of unemployment would be reversed by the end of the year.

title: Electoral Roulette
description: The late Senator Estes Kefauver once described the Electoral College method of selecting Presidents and Vice Presidents as a loaded pistol pointed at our system of government.

title: Books of The Times
description: Despite all inclinations to believe in mir acles (Hemingway Back From the Dead With Lyre Intact and Manuscript in Hand!), it is hard to approach Islands in the Stream with serious expectations. It was written during the time (around 1950) when Hemingway's fires as a fiction writer were dying (only The Old Man and the Sea

title: That Old Merit System
description: The suit by the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund to block eligibility tests given by the Board of Examiners to potential school principals could turn into a landmark case for the city's public education system.

title: No Delay on Family Aid Plan
description: WASHINGTONOver five months have slipped by since the House of Representatives passed the President's proposed welfare reform bill and sent it to the Senate. During this time the Finance Committee has given the bill careful examination to advance it. But now, less than a month remains be fore the Congress is scheduled to ad journ. It is the eleventh hour. It is time to take a stand on principle. It is time for the Senate to act.

title: U.S. Receives First Challenge for 1973 America's Cup
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 29 A departing sailbag marked Gretel II, Spinnaker Staysail and a telegram arriving from Australia today told a familiar story of America's Cup com pletion and renewal.

title: Dale Jones Fiancee of R. L. Burch 3d
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Win slow Jones of New York and Redding Ridge, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dale Carter Jones, to Robert Lee Burch 3d, a vice president of the New York investment banking firm of Kidder, Pea body & Co.

title: SENATE PUTS OFF DIRECT VOTE PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29Prospects for any electoral change by Congress this year dropped to a new low today when the Senate refused for a second time to cut off a three week filibuster against the plan for direct, popular election of the President.

title: Hits E.E.C. Links
description: GENEVA, Sept. 29The Unit ed States served notice today that it might lodge a formal complaint with the world's leading trade forum against the European Common Market for failing to abide by its interna tional trade commitments.

title: Woman Jockey Wins Three in Row Upstate
description: CANANDAIGUA, N. Y., Sept. 29 (AP)Edith Hinsley swept the first three races on the Finger Lakes program to day.

title: Perreault Finds Motif as a Jet Reserve
description: There comes a time in a football game, Pete Perreault was saying yesterday, when something happens, and then suddenly your mind becomes devoid of everything else ex cept what you have to do; it's good when that happens to you early.

title: California Brush Fires Partly Contained as Desert Winds Shift
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 29 (AP) Southern California's worst ordeal by fire seemed to be near an end today.

title: Jews Mark Start Of Rosh haShanah At Sundown Today
description: Rosh haShanah, the 10day period of spiritual selfanalysis and prayer and the most sacred in the Jewish faith, begins to day at sundown.

title: WORLD LEADERS TO ATTEND RITES
description: A fiveman delegation head ed by Elliot L. Richardson, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, was named by President Nixon yesterday to represent the United States at the funeral of Gamal Abdel Nasser, and other nations around the world were also making plans to send highlevel envoys to Cairo.

title: City Club Honors Mrs. Lasker
description: The City Club of New York has designated Mrs. Albert D. Lasker as the recipient this year of its Distinguished New Yorker Award, it was an nounced yesterday.

title: dvertising: Tabu Lifts Taboo on Romance
description: One of the few remaining things of permanence that a shaking socIety has been able to hold onto is about to be changed.

title: 3,500YearOld Fresco Found on Greek Island
description: ATHENS, Sept, 28  Greek archeologists exploring a city that lay buried under volcanic ash for 3,500 years have dis covered a multistory building with an exquisite wall painting in red, blue and golden ocher.

title: Drop Noted at Parley
description: The United States must seek an expanding world trade, but it cannot watch American in dustries wither, Stanley Neh mer, Deputy Assistant Secre tary of Commerce for Resources, told the second day's session of the first Inter national Commodities Confer ence at the New York Hilton Hotel here yesterday.

title: SUIT CHALLENGED ON BIG BOARD AID
description: The New York Stock Ex change issued a court chal lenge yesterday to the conten tion that its Special Trust Fund should be used to protect the 8,000 customers of Robinson & Co., a brokerage house in Bank ruptcy proceedings.

title: Reagan Is Far Ahead, Interviews Indicate
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 28The political behavior of the nation's largest state may be a riddle, but valuable clues are to he found in a pair of tracts called Marin County precinct 1116 and Southgate precinct 14.

title: MANSON FOLLOWER EXPLAINS SILENCE
description: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 29A witness in the Tate murder trial testified today that he did not report to the police Charles M. Manson's contention that he was a mass murderer because he thought Manson was just doing his thing.

title: Creations of 3 Top Architects Shown
description: Work in Progress: Archi tecture by Philip Johnson, Kevin Roche, Paul Rudolph, the exhibition opening at the Museum of Modern Art to day and continuing through Jan. 3, may turn out to be this season's most fashion ably hated show. That could make it a resounding anti success, the only kind of suc cess that has any real intel lectual currency these days.

title: SPORT DEPLORED BY NELSEN'S WIFE
description: CLEVELAND, Sept. 29 (AP)  Susan Nelsen would like her husband to retire from profes sional football. She says the game's hate and kill are un settling things.

title: Mrs. Crooner Wins on Links
description: OCEANSIDE, L. I., Sept. 29Mrs. Jess Gropper of the Tam O Shanter Golf Club won the President's Cup tourney at the Middle Bay Country Club today with a net 72. She had a gross score of 85.

title: MADDOX CAN'T STOP CLAYQUARRY FIGHT
description: ATLANTA, Sept. 29 (AP)Gov. Lester Maddox cannot block the heavyweight boxing match between Cassius Clay and Jerry Quarry scheduled Oct. 26, the Georgia Attorney General, Arthur K. Bolton, ruled today.

title: A 4th Man, Active at Brandeis, Seized in Boston Police Killing
description: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29 (UPI)  Michael Saul Fleisher, 21 years old, sought in the slay ing of a policeman during a bank robbery in Boston, Sept. 23, was arrested tonight at his home here.

title: William G. Blair Weds Ellen Lopin
description: Miss Ellen Lopin was mar ried here yesterday afternoon to William Granger Blair, public relations manager of The New York Times. State Supreme Court Justice Charles Margett performed the cere mony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Sam A. Lopin, parents of the bride.

title: Delaware Unanimous Pick In Lambert Cup Balloting
description: Delaware, which trounced New Hampshire, 5312, last Sat urday for its third straight vic tory, was the unanimous choice yesterday for first place in the weekly balloting for the Lam bert Cup, awarded after the season to the top middlesized college football team in the East.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON STAGE A RECOVERY
Smokewatchers Help Fight Pollution
description: My poor little children are dyingit's become a matter of survival, Mrs. Barbara Maltby said yesterday as she looked up at the choking black smoke coming out of a chimney.

title: Belmont Jockeys
PROFESSOR MAKES PIANO DEBUT HERE
description: Robert Hopkins, who heads the piano faculty at Youngs town (Ohio) State University, made his New York debut on Monday night at Town Hall. He played an allBeethoven pro gram, but it had been put to gether with more imagination than usual. In the center was the customary sonata, Op. 101 in A, but it was preceded by the Six Bagatelles of Op. 126 and followed by the Diabelli Varia tions.

title: PADEROSO SCORES AT ATLANTIC CITY
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 29 (UPI)  Walter Blum guided Paderoso to a threequarter length victory over Grate Fire today in the feature race at Atlantic City.

title: To Live in Peace
description: I only want to live in peace, a Palestinian business man told a reporter the other day as he showed visitors the bullet holes in his small home in devastated Amman.

title: Milk Price Plan Put Off
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI)The Agriculture Department said today that it had tenta tively decided to pigeonhole a proposed new formula for set ting minimum prices paid to farmers for bottling milk. A department statement said the agency was recommending that no action be taken on a plan to gear prices to a series of eco nomic indicators. Officials said they feared the plan in its present form might increase prices.

title: F. T.C. Says Chevron's Claims For a Gas Additive Are False
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29The Federal Trade Commission accused the Standard Oil Com pany of California today of falsely advertising that its gas oline additive called F310 sig nificantly reduced air pollution from auto exhausts.

title: WILSON CAUTIONS ON SOUTH AFRICA
description: BLACKPOOL, England, Sept. 29Former Prime Minister Harold Wilson warned today that any decision by the Con servative Government to sell arms to South Africa would be repudiated when the Labor party next wins an election.

title: NIXON BIDS CAIRO HONOR CEASEFIRE AND ACTFOR PEACE
description: NAPLES, Italy, Sept. 29President Nixon pledged today to seek good relations with whoever succeeds Gamal Abdel Nasser as Egypt's leader and urged Cairo to honor the Middle East ceasefire and move as rapidly as possible to construc tive peace talks aimed at a broad settlement.

title: 8 PLAYERS REFUSE TO BE REINSTATED
description: SYRACUSE, Sept. 29The eight black athletes who were reinstated last week after their suspension from the Syracuse University football team re jected their reinstatement to day.

title: TrillionDollar G.N.P.
description: Sam Nakagama, vice presi dent and chief economist of the Argus Research Corpora tion, forecast yesterday a 15 to20 per cent advance in pre tax corporate profits by the second quarter of next year and a 1971 gross national product of $1.05trillion.

title: Air Force, in Shift, To Permit Women To Adopt Children
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) The Air Force, recognizing what it called the recent em phasis on women's rights, rescinded today its rule for bidding women to adopt or have custody of minor children while in the service.

title: News Summary and Index
description: President Nixon pledged yesterday to seek good relations with the new leaders of the United Arab Republic and urged Cairo to honor the Middle East ceasefire and work toward a broad settlement. Mr. Nixon also announced that he would complete his Euro pean journey as planned. [Page 1, Col. 8.]

title: ALERT KNICKS TRIP BULLETS, 119 TO 98
