description: MEMPHIS, Sept. 29 The New York Knickerbockers ran their National Basketball Asso ciation preseason wonlost rec ord to 41 tonight with a 11998 victory over the Baltimore Bul lets at MidSouth Coliseum.

title: ExSoviet Dancer Takes Role With L.I. Ballet
description: MASSAPEQUA, L. I., Sept. 29  Aleksandr Filipov, the Soviet ballet dancer who de fected recently, has obtained his first job in this country with the Eglevsky Ballet Company here. He had been performing with the Moise yev classical ballet company, Young Ballet, on a Latin American tour.

title: WELFARE REFORM DELAYED IN PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29Supporters of the Nixon Admin istration's welfare reform leg islation have all but abandoned hope of getting it out of the Senate Finance Committee, where opposition seems to be rising rather than falling.

title: Orioles and Reds Installed As Favorites in Playoffs
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 29 (AP)The Baltimore Orioles and the Cincinnati Reds have been installed by Las Vegas bookmakers as favorites in the baseball playoff series begin nine Saturday.

title: 7 Movie Companies Sue A.B.C., C.B.S. Over Programing
description: Seven motionpicture com panies filed a complaint in Fed eral District Court here Monday to enjoin the Columbia Broad casting System arid the Ameri can Broadcasting Companies and their affiliates from pro ducing, distributing or having any interest in television enter tainment programs other than exhibiting them.

title: U.S. URGED TO AID AIR THEFT CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (UPI)  Governors Rockefeller of New York and William T. Cahill of New Jersey appealed to Congress today for speedy approval of a bistate agree ment aimed at curbing air cargo thefts.

title: An Arab Revolutionist
description: Nasser was the most successful leader of modern Arab history and his death leaves a vacuum not only in Egypt but throughout the area be tween Iran and the Atlantic.

title: Chief Executive Resigns At Georg Jensen Concern
description: Robert L. Meyers, president and chief executive officer of Georg Jensen, Inc., announced his resignation yesterday. Dan Rodgers will take over his du ties as chief executive officer.

title: Threat to the Waters
description: The National Environmental Policy Act, signed last year with great fanfare, will be of very little use unless President Nixon tells his subordinates that it means ex actly what it says. The Atomic Energy Commission, for one, has the notion that in licensing nuclear plants it has no authority even to consider a threat of thermal pollu tion, though the act clearly enjoins all government agen cies to weigh environmental factors in their decisions.

title: CHARLES M. HACKETT, PUBLISHER, WAS 61
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 29Charles Megginson Hack ett, president of the News Journal Company, and editor in chief of the NewsJournal papers, died of a heart ailment Sunday in St. Francis Hospital. He, was 61 years old.

title: Eban Says Destiny of Mideast Is Up to Egypt's Future Chiefs
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 29  Foreign Minister Abba Eban of Israel said today that the destiny of the Middle East was in the hands of Egypt's future leaders and that he was utterly incapable of predicting their course of ac tion.

title: MRS. VICTOR ECKSTEIN
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I., Sept. 29 Mrs. Anna Bumiller Eckstein, widow of Victor Eckstein, a former owner of Liichow's Res taurant on 14th Street in New York, died today after a brief illness. Her age was 78. Mrs. Eckstein was a, niece of August Luchow, the founder of the GermanAmerican restaurant.

title: UNIT OF TEXACO OIL POSTS LIBYAN PRICES
description: The Texaco Overseas Petro leum Company, a subsidiary of Texaco, Inc., said yesterday that it had reached an agree ment with the Government of Libya on posted prices for oil.

title: Kirk Victor in Florida Runoff
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Sept. 29Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr. won the Republican nomina tion for a second term today, and two littleknown Democrats upset established party leaders in other key Florida contests.

title: Charts of Races at Belmont
GoodwayArkwright Deal First of Kind
description: A plan to bring manufac turers and retailers closer together through the de velopment of combined mar keting programs was de scribed here yesterday as the basis for the first ac quisition of a residentbuying office by a company outside hr ref ail industry.

title: Plummer, Foster and Jackson: 3 Ivy Quarterbacks on Target
description: When college football ob servers termed the 1970 sea son The Year of the Quarter back, they had in mind such established stars as John Reaves of Florida, Jim Plun kett of Stanford, Dennis Dummit of the University of California, Los Angeles; Ar chie Manning of Mississippi and Joe Theis mann of Notre Dame. Almost no men tion was made of Eastern signal callers except for Frank (Red) Harris of Boston College, and nobody even thought about the Ivy. League.

title: White House Charge on Cuba Puzzles U.S. Officials
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 29American officials said today that the United States had only dubious and dated infor mation to indicate that the Soviet Union might be planning to build a strategic submarine base in Cuba.

title: LONGINES SOUGHT BY WESTINGHOUSE
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yester day it had agreed in principle to acquire the LonginesWitt nauer Watch Company, Inc., a leading importer of watches and other time pieces from Switz erland, through an exchange of stock. Based on Westing house's closing price of 63 on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, the transaction is valued at about $40.5million.

title: Philip Morris's New Leaf Set for National Debut
description: Philip Morris confirmed yesterday that it will go na tional in midOctober with its new brand. New Leaf.

title: GRAIN CONTRACTS SHOW DECLINES
description: All grain and soybeans fu tures declined yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. There appeared to be no out side influencing factor other than continuing good growing weather.

title: John Loeb Disputes Exchange Support Of Goodbody Link
description: John L. Loeb, a leading Wall Street figure, has chal lenged the New York Stock Exchange to justify the grounds for its preliminary approval of the proposed merger of Goodbody & Co. into a mutual fund manage ment concern.

title: RICHEY ADVANCES IN COAST TENNIS
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 29 (AP)Topseeded Cliff Richey, the United States Davis Cup star, defeated Mike Machette of Belvedere, Calif., 76, 63, yesterday in the first round of the Pacific Coast open tennis tournament.

title: Stocks on American Exchange Show Broad Advance in Prices
description: The American Stock Ex change made a broad advance yesterday in active trading.

title: Greetings
description: FIELDMr. and Mrs. Samuel Field extend to their relatives and friends very best wishes for a Healthy and Happy New Year.

title: Mets Beat Cubs, 31, and Take 2d Place by Game
description: The New York Mets passed the 1948 Cleveland Indians at the box office and the 1970 Chicago Cubs on the field last night as Jerry Koosman pitched them to a 31 victory over the Cubs at Shea Stadium.

title: Soviet Sub Base in Cuba?
description: It is curious that neither Moscow nor Havana has reacted publicly to the White House warning against construction of a Soviet strategic submarine base in Cuba. On occasion in the past the Soviet Government has been quick to deny much less serious accusations appearing even in obscure publications. But in this case, when a White House spokesman raised the possibility that the Kremlin had secretly begun work that would violate the spirit, if not the letter, of the 1962 Khru shchevKennedy agreement, there has not been a word of Soviet comment.

title: Madagascar Wins Brook Steeplechase at Belmont by 5 Lengths and Pays $11
description: I went one way at that last hedge and my horse went the other, but I managed to hang on, said Thomas Skiffington yesterday after scoring with Mrs. F. Ambrose Clark's Mada gascar in the 62d running of the $24,050 Brook Steeplechase Handicap at Belmont Park.

title: Hussein Expresses Confidence Chaos In Jordan Will End
description: EL HUMMAR, Jordan, Sept. 29  King Hussein, visibly af fected by the death of Gamal Abdel Nasser, voiced confi dence today that he would succeed in overcoming the chaos in this land.

title: FREED HOSTAGES IN BID TO ISRAELIS
description: A freed. American hostage, home after three weeks captiv ity in Jordan, said yesterday that he and 28 other hijacked Americans had appealed to Premier Golda Meir of Israel for areciprocal act of good will.

title: COUNCIL WILL STUDY CITY MASS TRANSIT
description: The City Council voted unani mously yesterday to set up a 10member special committee to look into operations of the city's mass transit systems and to make recommendations to insure a safe, adequate trans portation system.

title: U.S. Aides See Delay in Choice in Cairo
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29Speculation on the most likely succession to President Gamal Abdel Nasser centered here to day on three power concentra tions: the officer corps of the armed forces, the intelligence services and the Arab Socialist Union, President Nasser's all embracing politiacl front.

title: Last 6 Hostages Are Released; 19 Arabs Will Be Freed in Deal
description: GENEVA, Sept. 29  Six Americans, the last of the hun dreds of hostages seized by Arab hijackers three weeks ago, were freed today in Amman, Jordan. It developed that their release was part of an arrange ment involving the release of 19 Arabs held in Europe and Israel.

title: Nebraska Accuses Iowa
description: OMAHA, Sept. 29, (AP)Nebraska, presenting final ar guments today in a fiveyearold boundary dispute, accused Iowa of reneging on a 1943 agreement that the middle of the stabilized Missouri River channel would be the boundary between the two states.

title: T. G. Kline Fiance Of Ann E. Miller
description: DARIEN, Conn., Sept. 29Miss Ann Elizabeth Miller, a junior at American Univer sity, plans to be married here on Dec. 19 to Timothy Gordon Kline, a senior at American.

title: CHARGES FALSE, SEALE DECLARES
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 29The national chairman of the Black Panther party, Bobby G. Seale, pleaded not guilty today to murder, kidnapping and con spiracy charges in Superior Court.

title: State Hearing Told of Need for Medical Aides
description: Physicians assistants are needed to help solve the health manpower shortage, witnesses at a State Senate health com mittee hearing said here yes terday, but there was no con sensus on what legislative standards should be set for these paramedical workers.

title: 49 Players Are Used As Royals Win, 14.13
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 29 (AP)Ted Aber nathy singled home Bob Floyd with the winning run in the 12th inning to give the Kan sas City Royals a 1413 vic tory over the Minnesota Twins today. The game set a majorleague record for most players used49.

title: City Charges That a Firm Misled on Waterproofing
description: The city's Consumer Af fairs Department, as part of a new campaign against un licensed home improvement contractors, charged a base ment waterproofing company yesterday with misrepre sentation.

title: Connecticut Girl Is Found Slain, 7th Child Murder in State in '70
description: NEW HAVEN, Sept. 29The body of 5yearold Jennifer Noon, who had been missing since Sept, 21, was found this morning in a wooded area of Hamden, a suburban commu nity near here.

title: Flynn of WPIX Says His Inquiry Found Inaccuracies in the News
description: Francis M. Flynn, chairman of the board of WPIX and of The Daily News, said yesterday that WPIX had been guilty of in accuracies in its news pro graming during the latter part of 1968, but that they had been the subject of vigorous investi gation by station executives.

title: Entertainment
description: Events Opera

title: EDWARD QUIGLEY, EXPOSTMASTER, 70
description: Edward J. Quigley, who re tired as Postmaster of Brook lyn on July 1 after nearly a quarter of a century in the position, died yesterday in Methodist Hospital, Brooklyn, after a long illness. He was 70 years old and lived at 209 Lin coln Avenue.

title: Jewish Federation Seeking $30Million For Philanthropies
description: To a background of pictures that depicted its programs from the young to the aged, the Federation of Jewish Philan thorpies of New York last night began its $30million fund campaign at a dinner in the Plaza Hotel attended by 300 people.

title: Thieu Is Granted Authority To Revalue Piaster for G.I.'s
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 29 (UPI)The South Viet namese National Assembly to day completed and sent to President Nguyen Van Thieu a bill giving him the power to change the official exchange rate for United States military payment certificates being con verted to piasters.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Football Transactions
description: CLEVELADDSign??d wrl Randy M?? run, ?? bark, for taxi sq??ad.

title: Scientists Seek Secrets of Human Evolution in Study of Amazonian Tribes
description: ROME, Sept. 29A team of scientists who have won the confidence of Amazonian tribes virtually untouched by civiliza tion since the Spanish Con quest are using the tools of modern genetics to learn about human evolution in the primi tive state.

title: The Great Timahoe Mystery
description: DUBLINOnce upon a time when the first Irish peacekeeping troops were being sent to the Congo a pla toon of soldiers were lined up before their County Cork sergeant for a final briefing  a warning about the dangers of snakebite.

title: Army to Release Youth Inducted Erroneously
description: RICHLAND, Mich., Sept. 29 (AP)Steve Carrier, who was drafted into the Army 100 numbers too soon, has re ceived good news.

title: New Dramatists Planning a Party
description: A benefit party at the New Dramatists, 424 West 44th Street, will follow a first pre view performance Wednes day of The Rothschilds, the musical version of the book by Frederic Morton, at the LuntFontanne Theater.

title: GEN. STREETT, FLIER IN WORLD WAR I, DIES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) Maj. Gen. St. Clair Streett, a World War I pilot and then a general in World War II, died yesterday at nearby Andrews Air Force Base. He would have been 77 next Tuesday.

title: Firemen Honor a Comrade Killed on a False Alarm
description: More than 300 firemen paid tribute yesterday to a comrade who was killed last year when he fell from a fire engine re sponding to a false alarm.

title: Heavy Racing Card Gains Trenton 300, Reset for Saturday
description: Heavy rain on Sunday forced the Trenton 300 on to this coming weekend's auto racing program which was al ready so full it threatened to drown out the cheering at die football arenas with the roar of motors. The Trenton race, in which Al and Bobby Unser. Mario Andretti and the other stars of the United States Auto Club's cham pionship division will drive, has been rescheduled for Saturday afternoon at 3:15. Practice and qualifying will begin at 10 A.M.

title: HOUSE PANEL BACKS WIDER HOUSING BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) The House Banking Commit tee approved by a 24to4 vote today a S7billion omnibus housing bill extending existing programs and starting several new ones.

title: A STRONGER ROLE DUE FOR MAYORS ON MODEL CITIES
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 29The Nixon Administration plans to announce soon some new ap proaches in the Model Cities program that are designed to lead to sweeping revisions in the Federal grant system in urban areas.

title: Cards Rehire Schoendienst: Two Coaches Are Released
description: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 29 (AP) The St. Louis Cardinals rehired Manager Red Schoendicnst to day for a seventh year and re leased Billy Muffett and Dick Sisler as coaches.

title: Ottinger Links Goodell and Buckley to Nixon
description: ALBANY, Sept. 29  In the second facetoface confronta tion of the United States Sen ate campaign, Representative Richard L. Ottinger sharply criticized the Nixon Adminis tration today and linked his two opponents to the Ad ministration.

title: Japanese Payments Gain
description: TOKYO, Sept. 29 (Reuters)Japan had a S178million sur plus in her balance of interna tional payments for August, the Finance Ministry an nounced today. It was Japan's largest surplus this year.

title: Fischer, Colgate Back, Dropped From Squad
description: HAMILTON, N. Y., Sept. 29 (AP)Tom Fischer, the Colgate University football team's leading rusher, was dropped from the squad to day. He said he had decided to quit anyway because he objected to the tactics of Coach Neil Wheelwright.
